text: ORGANIZATION used PERSON exclusively as a reliever on teams that went to the ORGANIZATION World Series finals in 2014 and 2015 (winning it all in his freshman year), and he dominated out of the bullpen while earning co-playoff ORGANIZATION honors in the ORGANIZATION in the latter summer. The ORGANIZATION tried him as a starter at the beginning of his junior season before shifting him back to the bullpen as a closer. The ORGANIZATION eased him into pro ball in short stints after signing him for $1.6 million as a second-rounder.As a lefty with three pitches and a durable frame, PERSON has the ingredients to pitch in the middle of a big league rotation. His 90-95 mph fastball plays up because it has late life and steep downhill plane. He also shows feel for a sinking changeup and has a three-quarters breaking ball that fluctuates between a low-80s slider and a high-70s curveball.Colorado is still undecided about PERSON's long-term role. Though he could move quickly as a possible high-leverage reliever, he also has mid-rotation potential and a fresh arm that logged just 96 1/3 innings in three seasons at ORGANIZATION. His control and command improved steadily during his college career, but to make it as a starter he'll have to show that he can maintain a quality fastball into the late innings.

GPE was used very heavily at ORGANIZATION and would sometimes throw in excess of 120 pitches during his starts, even as an underclassman. The ORGANIZATION shelved him for the rest of the summer after they drafted him, and it paid off. GPE came out the following spring throwing harder than he had in college, his fastball sitting 94-97 for most of his starts. He held that velo throughout 2018 and reached Triple-A in his first pro season. He's a No. 4 starter on the cusp of debut.

PERSON entered the spring as a potential No. 1 pick as one of the top college arms in the class, especially after a sophomore season that saw him lead a Gators staff that included several early 2016 Draft selections and a strong performance for the ORGANIZATION Team last summer. Minor arthroscopic knee surgery kept him from fall ball and that clearly contributed to a sluggish start to his 2017 season, though his stuff came back a bit as the spring progressed.PERSON started the spring closer to the bottom end of his 90-94 mph fastball, but as he got his feet under him, he was sitting 93 mph and touching 95 more consistently with good sink. His slider has continued to look like an out pitch, though some feel he's been throwing it too much. PERSON threw his changeup more over the summer, showing a good feel for it, and it should give him a solid third offering in the future. He tends to be around the zone, though he's more control over command.A slightly uneven junior season has hurt his stock a little bit, but he did throw well in the ORGANIZATION, with his name reappearing in top 10 pick conversations.

In a Draft class short on good college bats, GPE stood out as one of the better ones, coming from a strong GPE program. That's why the ORGANIZATION took him No. 16 overall and signed him for more than $500,000 under pick value. The left-handed hitting GPE has long impressed with the bat. Hitting 10 homers both as a sophomore and a junior is quite an achievement, given how pitching-friendly GPE's home park is. He has an advanced approach at the plate and solid power, especially on the extra-base front, though he should have some over-the-fence pop at the next level. He walked more than he struck out during his college career and he continued to swing the bat well during his pro debut, quickly moving to full-season ball.A catcher in college, scouts questioned whether he could stay back there given how raw his defensive skills were. The ORGANIZATION had him playing first base only during his pro debut and that's likely to be his long-term defensive home, with the ORGANIZATION believing the bat will play at the corner position as well.

PERSON had shaken off a rough first month to the 2015 season and was on the brink of earning a promotion to Double-A when he and his ORGANIZATION were involved in a bus accident. The former first-round pick missed nearly two months, though he eventually did earn that bump up a level and finished the year off with a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION League.Despite missing so much time, PERSON was able to figure some mechanical issues out in 2015. Working with pitching coordinator PERSON, he worked to stop throwing across his body, squaring him up more like when he was in high school. When that happened, his stuff got sharper, especially his curveball. PERSON started missing more bats as he regained his plus breaking ball, which he throws with great tilt now that he's back in line. His fastball sits in the 94-95 mph range and he can crank it up to 97 mph. His changeup improved as well, showing flashes of a third at least PERSON average pitch.The ORGANIZATION love how PERSON reacted to competition within the system and his resiliency following a bus crash, feeling his delivery, along with his career, are now headed in the right direction.

There are ways to nitpick PERSON -- he's very likely to move out of center field entirely and he also strikes out a lot-- but, ultimately, he's a switch-hitter with plus power whose two swings are further along than is typical for most 19-year-old switch hitters. PERSON has big time thump from both sides of the plate and had 26 extra-base hits in just 52 AZL games. The strikeout issues make him a low-floor prospect, but there are very few switch-hitters in the minors with this kind of playable pop, and if PERSON can hit, find a way to stay viable in center field, or both, he could be an impact regular.

A shoulder injury during his junior season at FACILITY A&M hurt PERSON's ORGANIZATION stock, but the ORGANIZATION' willingness to take a shot in the third round might pay off. He didn't need surgery and reached Double-A in his first full season while staying healthy. His fastball touches plus, at 96 mph, and he goes after hitters with downhill sink and tail. He throws his changeup with a lot of deception and sink as well. The right-hander has two breaking balls, a big, downer curve or a wider, three-quarters slider. His delivery creates deception on all of his pitches, but it also comes with a lot of effort and hampers his ability to command the ball. Combine that with his injury history and some see a future coming out of the bullpen, something he did at the end of the 2012 season to limit his innings. A role switch like that could get him to the big leagues faster.

There are college catchers who can really hit, but might have to move out from behind the plate because of their defensive inefficiencies. Then there are those like PERSON, who undoubtedly have a future as a defensive backstop, with how much they hit truly determining what kind of professional career they have.A three-year starter at ORGANIZATION, PERSON's glove also earned him a spot on ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION. He has excellent hands and moves well behind the plate, allowing him to receive and block well. He has a strong and accurate arm, recording excellent pop times to second base on a consistent basis. Offensively, the right-handed hitter has been less productive. He does make consistent contact and rarely strikes out with decent on-base skills. And he's having his best offensive season now, albeit without any power.PERSON more than likely profiles as a backup at the next level. If his bat comes around with pro instruction, he could become a defensive-minded regular. In either case, his defensive skillset should have him off the board in the top six rounds.

One of several bat-first second basemen selected early in the 2015 Draft, PERSON was a first-team Big Ten selection after he hit .331 while pacing GPE's offense in numerous categories including hits (83), doubles (18) and runs scored (58). He suffered a broken fibula in the ORGANIZATION' season-ending loss to GPE that year, though that didn't deter the Rays from taking the redshirt sophomore in the third round. After a nondescript full-season debut with PERSON, PERSON has enjoyed a successful 2017 campaign as one of the top hitters in the ORGANIZATION State League.PERSON is a pure hitter, one with terrific strike-zone discipline and the ability to hit to all fields well as get on base at a high clip. He has consistent pop to the gaps from the left side of the plate, as well as sneaky raw power that he has started tapping into more consistently in 2017. PERSON has fully recovered from the torn ACL he suffered as a freshman, but he's not going to be a big threat on the basepaths. His arm will play at second base, where he makes all the necessary plays.PERSON's prospect stock is on the rise this season thanks to his breakthrough performance in the pitcher-friendly ORGANIZATION. He may not offer much defensively or on the basepaths, but the bat is good enough for PERSON to carve out a role as an offense-oriented second baseman in the big leagues.

A Cubs 20th-round pick in 2012 as a high school catcher, PERSON transitioned from a full-time hitter as an GPE freshman to a two-way player as a sophomore and a full-time pitcher as a junior. Based on his performance at the Big Ten Conference tournament and the ORGANIZATION in 2014, he entered 2015 as a possible first-round pick. He didn't live up those expectations and slid to the FACILITY in the seventh round, where he signed for $200,000.PERSON had PERSON surgery shortly after signing, which explained his velocity loss late in his junior season. When healthy, he's capable of pitching in the mid-90s, but he had dipped as low as 87 mph. His curveball wasn't as sharp as it had been in the past either.PERSON has a big league body at 6-foot-5 and 220 pounds and the makings of two power pitches in his fastball and curve. He also shows some feel for a sinking changeup. Still relatively inexperienced on the mound, he'll need to focus on improving his command once he regains his health.

PERSON excited scouts before the GPE with his premium stuff and athleticism and he established himself as the best high school pitcher available. PERSON was a two-sport star in high school and signed a letter of intent to play quarterback and pitch at FACILITY A&M. That, combined with his Type 1 diabetes, made him somewhat of a challenge to evaluate. The GPE, however, liked his complete package and made him the fourth overall pick of the GPE. PERSON throws his fastball in the low- to mid-90s, regularly touching 96 mph. He also throws a changeup and slider, which might be his best pitch. He is still learning how to pitch, but he could quickly improve his feel for the craft now that he is solely focused on pitching. PERSON joins PERSON's newfound wealth of premium pitching prospects and has as much potential as any of the group.

PERSON GPE has sent 11 pitchers to the big leagues since the turn of the century, and PERSON is talented enough to add to that total. An unheralded recruit out of GPE (Mo.) High, where he broke a 45-year-old career scoring record in basketball, he earned a spot in the GPE rotation at the outset of his freshman season. He led the ORGANIZATION with in strikeouts (106) as a sophomore and is on course to do so again in 2018.PERSON lacks consistency, with the quality of his pitches and even more with his command, but when he's on he can can display stuff worth of a late first-round selection. He can pitch at 92-94 mph with a fastball that has reached 98 mph and features some run and sink, and he can back it up with a sharp mid-80s slider. But there also are times when his heater and slider lose some power and flatten out.PERSON has yet to show much feel for a changeup and also possesses a curveball that isn't as reliable as his slider. He starts slow with his delivery before speeding up his tempo, which leads to him getting out of sync and struggling to locate his pitches. While he has been a durable in college and will get the chance to develop as a starter in pro ball, his ultimate role may be as a high-leverage reliever.

PERSON was a semi-sought-after high schooler but ended up at ORGANIZATION, where he broke out on the Cape after his freshman year. He looked like a mid-first rounder after his sophomore year and subsequent summer with collegiate PERSON, then took a giant leap forward this year, as a junior, when his command improved and because he added an 87-90 mph cutter that quickly became a plus pitch. 

While he threw a sinker most of 2017, PERSON now throws a flat four-seamer, up to 97 mph in most starts, but he doesn't throw it much compared to big league norms. In starts we've charted, PERSON threw 37% fastballs, 32% cutters, 16% splitters and 15% sliders. 

PERSON is unique, a nearly finished product who could probably pitch in the upper levels of the minors now, and maybe be in a rotation next year, pitching in a way that's becoming more common in the big leagues. On the down side, PERSON has some head violence at release and no physical projection and also relies heavily on a new pitch (the cutter) where there's lots of anecdotal evidence that says it dimishes velocity when used often.

Discussions of PERSON's presumptive selection at #1 overall are always qualified by assumptive health. PERSON had shoulder issues in high school that scared some teams off, he missed two starts as a sophomore with forearm tightness and experienced more forearm issues last summer with PERSON, then had non-surgical treatment on the arm in August of last year. He's still our top prospect, but by a smaller margin that some may expect, because he's a risky subset of pitcher. He's also very advanced and should move quickly, and this class lacks a standout, consensus bat to stick ahead of him. The ORGANIZATION have been zeroed in on PERSON most of the spring and he's the overwhelming favorite to go 1-1.

PERSON is universally appreciated by scouts for his broad skill base that would be coveted in any July 2nd class. Prospects with more subtle skills, or those with much of their value tied into contact, speed and defense are more appreciated now than in the past due to more games being played on the circuit than before. PERSON is a classic prospect that has good size (6'1 and projectable), even at 15/16 he has the projectable curremt above average to plus speed to profile in center field, a smooth cut from both sides of the plate that shows up in games and the chance for at least average raw power. He's the centerpiece of the ORGANIZATION international efforts this year and is expected to get around $3 million.

Teams looking for the best power college bat in the class may not have to look further than PERSON Diego.Bryant has been an excellent performer in a weak college conference, but he also led PERSON this summer in slugging percentage. He has easy plus power, maybe more, with the ability to hit the ball out to all fields. He also has a plus arm, and while some feel he'll have to move to first in the future, others feel he has the actions, arm and power bat to profile well at the hot corner. He's also shown the ability to play a corner outfield spot during his junior season.There is a good amount of swing and miss to his game, but the team that feels he'll hit enough will likely take his power bat off the board fairly early in the GPE.

PERSON went undrafted as a senior at an upstate GPE high school in 2011, but he drew six-figure free-agent offers from pro teams after starring that August at the ORGANIZATION World Series in GPE, N.M. He stamped himself as a potential 2014 first-rounder when he hit 95 mph during the 2012 Cape Cod League All-Star Game, and he reaffirmed that status with another strong performance in the Cape last summer.Though he lacked consistency this spring, PERSON also had some dominant outings, and he was in the mix to go No. 1 overall to the ORGANIZATION. That changed when he missed two starts in late April and early May, and PERSON announced he would require PERSON surgery. Because the track record with elbow reconstructions is encouraging, and he has so much upside, PERSON still should factor into the first round, perhaps even the upper half.PERSON hasn't fully grown into his lanky 6-foot-4 frame, yet at times he works in the mid 90s and hits 98 mph with his fastball. His big-breaking curveball can be equally devastating and his changeup can be a plus pitch at times. He throws a decent amount of strikes but will need to refine his command to become a frontline starter in the big leagues.

PERSON has a track record of hitting that dates back to starring with the GPE 16-and-under national team as a high schooler. He would have been an early-round pick in the 2013 PERSON had he been signable, but instead turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 27th-rounder to attend PERSON. He led the ORGANIZATION to consecutive PERSON Series appearances and ranked first in ORGANIZATION Division I in walks (78) and second in on-base percentage (.544) in 2016, then signed with the FACILITY for $3,380,600 as the 10th overall pick.One of the best all-around hitters available in the 2016 PERSON, PERSON stands out most with his left-handed power. He's strong, owns a quick bat and has good loft in his stroke. He's more than just a masher, however, as he's patient and controls the strike zone extremely well, which should help him hit for average and record high on-base percentages.Scouts are mixed on whether PERSON will stay behind the plate, though the FACILITY fully believe that he will. He looked better as a catcher during his junior season, though his arm and receiving still rate as fringy. His lack of speed will limit him to first base if he can't make it as a backstop, but his bat still would profile well at the less challenging defensive position.

PERSON barely registered on the scouting radar in the ORGANIZATION, waiting more than two years after he became eligible to sign before he landed a $7,500 bonus in October 2012. He started to draw attention with his high-octane fastball after making his GPE debut in 2014, though minor physical issues sidelined him that year and in the next two. Fully healthy in 2017, he worked a career-high 133 innings and advanced to Triple-A.PERSON's fastball has been clocked as high as 103 mph in the past, though he usually works from 93-97 mph as a starter, and it's especially difficult to hit because of the funkiness and angle his 6-foot-7 frame and low three-quarters arm slot create. That slot makes it tough for him to stay on top of his mid-80s slider, though it has gotten more consistent this year. He has a solid changeup that he locates well and is effective against both left-handers and right-handers.For an extra-large guy with a lot of velocity, PERSON throws a surprising amount of strikes. His delivery isn't smooth and features effort, yet he somehow makes it work and finally proved he could hold up over a full season in 2017. Some scouts aren't convinced he'll last as a starter -- he missed six weeks this year with blister problems -- though he'd still have plenty of value as a high-leverage option should he become a reliever.

Things have developed slowly for this GPE outfielder, spending two summers in the ORGANIZATION, then two more in the rookie-level PERSON. But after a 2012 campaign that saw him lead that league in home runs, finish tied for fifth in ORGANIZATION and end up seventh in slugging percentage, it looks like heâs starting to figure a few things out. PERSON has tremendous raw power and is just starting to learn how to tap into it. Heâs a solid runner, but isnât likely to be a major basestealing threat  as he matures. Heâs played all three outfield positions, but his plus arm and his power profile should fit very nicely in right field. Seeing what he can do in Ashevilleâs bandbox could be interesting in 2013.

PERSON was a plus-running center field prospect when he signed, but over four seasons, his body has matured in a way that is more PERSON than PERSON. He has already moved to a corner and might be limited to left field, but with that heft came power and a 2018 statistical breakout (65 extra-base hits) at Low-A Bowling Green. PERSON has below-average plate discipline, and that kind of flaw in a player near the bottom of the defensive spectrum is pretty scary, because it means both the hit and power tools need to develop into plusses for PERSON to clear the overall offensive bar at his position. There's enough thump here for that, though we'll have to wait and see on the bat.

GPE, who signed for $1 million as a sixth rounder in 2017, had a very strong spring and extended spring in GPE and looked like he might be pushed to short season ball as a 19-year-old. Then, just before short season leagues began, he was placed on the reserve list and didn't throw again all summer.  He is already much thicker and heavier than he was in high school. He was touching 96 before he was shut down and had one of the nastier changeups among teenage arms in GPE. He struck out a rehabbing PERSON with that changeup twice in extended, though his curveball remains pretty fringy. If his command improves and he finds a third pitch, the curveball or otherwise, he'll be a mid-rotaiton option. If not, he projects as a late-inning fastball/changeup reliever.

GPE is a well-built, semi-projectable infielder who fits best at second base, though he has played all over the infield. He's an above-average runner with good feel for contact and a good idea of the strike zone. The two-year ORGANIZATION stint is a bit of an indictment, and there will need to be more lift/power in GPE's profile for him to profile at second base, but his frame is such that it has a chance to come. He's more likely to be a multi-positional bench piece than a regular, but there are components present that give Polaco a shot to be the latter.

The ORGANIZATION landed PERSON at the outset of the 2014-15 international period, signing him one day after they had inked PERSON. The right-hander pitched well in his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION to earn a promotion to Rookie-level Gulf Coast League in late July, and he continued to climb the ladder in 2016 with PERSON Day assignment to the GPE League.Though he's an undersized right-hander, PERSON's athleticism and fast arm generate a fastball that can reach 95-97 mph, though he typically operates in the low 90s. While his heater doesn't have much movement at the moment, he he does a good job of throwing strikes understands the important of pitching down in the zone. PERSON's secondaries lag well behind his fastball, but he does have some feel for a breaking ball and at times will flash an impressive changeup.Like many of the young arms in GPE's system, PERSON is all projection right now. He impressed club officials last season with his combination of velocity and pitchability, and they believe he has the makeup to handle whatever challenge they throw his way.

A bit of a surprise as a first-round pick in 2014, PERSON was rewarding the ORGANIZATION' faith in him with a solid first full season as one of the youngest regulars in the LOCATION League when he tore the labrum in his throwing shoulder, ending his season early and leaving a long road of recovery ahead.The good news is all things are headed in a positive direction. PERSON returned to the field and quickly got pushed up to the Class A Advanced PERSON. It's unknown how his shoulder will respond, but if it does, PERSON has the tools to play shortstop for a long time, with solid actions, hands and range. Outside of the shoulder, the only thing that could push him off of shortstop is if he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame a lot as he matures. There's clearly strength to be added, which will help him at the plate. He already has very good at-bats, knows the strike zone and was flashing some extra-base authority as he continues to learn how to switch hit.PERSON's off-the-charts makeup will ensure he maximizes whatever he grows into and if his shoulder doesn't respond to stay at short, it won't be from a lack of effort.

GPE posted promising strikeout and walk rates in the early part of his career and then suddenly began hitting for power in 2015 and 2016 at ORGANIZATION before returning to career norms in 2017. On paper, GPE was very intriguing as a young pro because he played shortstop and had such terrific control of the strike zone, but eyeball evaluations were more generic, indicating a bench role at best, and were incongruous with GPE's performance, especially when he suddenly had power. He was sidelined for much of 2018 after he was struck by a pitch on the foot, but he put enough balls in play to note that his pull rate was up and his ground ball rate was down, and a hitter with this kind of innate talent would suddenly become very interesting if a swing change were to coax out some more power. At 25, GPE is probably just an up/down utility type, but that's also what we thought about PERSON at this time last year.

Widely considered the ORGANIZATION. 2 international prospect behind GPE dual phenom PERSON, PERSON profiles as a center fielder with plus power and speed. The five-tool player starred for GPE's 16-and-under league as a 14-year-old and began playing in the 18-and-under league at 15, hitting .325 and leading the league with 21 steals his first year. He sported a .383 batting average in the league at 16 and hit four home runs in the ORGANIZATION 18U Pan American Championship in 2014. He later was named to the all-tournament team in the 18-and-under World Cup in GPE in 2015.Playing for PERSON de Avila in GPE's PERSON, the island's top league, PERSON hit .393 with 12 home runs and 11 stolen bases last season. He was also part of the GPE team that played against the Canadian-American League last summer. The 19-game tour included stops in GPE, GPE, and GPE, PERSON left GPE last ORGANIZATIONvember and later established residency in GPE. He was declared a free agent by PERSON on April 20, making him eligible to sign May 20.

There is no one in the Philliesâ system with more tools than GPE. The young shortstop has plus speed, an 8 on the 2-8 scouting scale, and it works for him on both sides of the ball. He led the organization in stolen bases in 2012 and that was in a short-season league. But heâs far more than just a runner. GPE could develop into a plus hitter in time, one who hits .300 annually at the big league level. He has a good approach at the plate and understands his job will be to get on base. The switch-hitter has some pop as well and eventually could have average power. He made a lot of progress at shortstop, a new position for him after playing the outfield in high school and he has the arm and range to be above-average defensively there. The sky might be the limit for GPE; now itâs all about reaching that ceiling as he moves toward GSP.

PERSON was used as both a starter and reliever at ORGANIZATION last year, before eventually assuming a full-time bullpen role. The ORGANIZATION made him their fourth-round pick, signing him for $488,700, then deployed him as a starter in his pro debut, where he impressed scouts with his feel for four pitches.PERSON's fastball sits at 89-92 mph with good arm-side run, and he showed the ability to reach back for a few more ticks as a reliever. The right-hander's slider has the potential to be above average, thrown with power and depth in the mid-80s, and he keeps hitters off balance with an average curveball. PERSON's fringy changeup is his least-advanced offering, although it stands to improve with increased use as a starter.PERSON's deep arsenal and overall pitchability bode well for him becoming a big league starter. Should that not pan out, though, the fastball-slider combo is good enough to make him a setup man.

Hailing from the same ORGANIZATION team that produced PERSON and PERSON, PERSON received a $700,000 bonus as a 16-year-old in 2015, the largest bonus handed out by the ORGANIZATION in the 2015 international period. He's made enormous progress in his first two seasons en route to reaching full-season Class A Fort Wayne in late 2017 after a breakout performance with PERSON Tri-City. PERSON was even more impressive in the ORGANIZATION, where, as the circuit's youngest player, he pitched to a 1.04 ERA, allowing just four hits while striking out 11 in 8 2/3 innings across nine appearances. An elbow injury limited PERSON at the outset of the 2018 season, but he returned fully healthy in mid-June and made the jump straight to Double-A two weeks later.The epitome of a power-armed reliever, PERSON owns the best fastball in GPE's system and is one of the hardest throwers in the ORGANIZATION. He offered a glimpse at that impressive velocity in the ORGANIZATION, where he consistently pumped upper-90s heat and was up to 101 mph with a fastball that showed explosive late life. His hard slider in the upper 80s gives PERSON a second dynamic offering, one that should continue to improve along with his feel for pitching. PERSON did make gains as a strike-thrower in 2017, but his high-effort delivery and issues in repeating his arm slot still leads to well-below-average control, as evidenced by his 6.7 walks-per-nine in two professional seasons. With even modest improvement on that front, PERSON could soon jump on the fast track to becoming a closer in the ORGANIZATION.
GPE's velo was on the rise just before the draft, averaging just over 90 for the first time in his career, but in the postseason was back to 87-91 when he had to rely more on finesse.
GPE has pitched full seasons the last two years for PERSON and walked only single digits each year, thanks to his plus command, which makes the most of his solid average stuff.

PERSON originially joined the D-backs back in Dec. 14 as part of the three-team trade that sent him and PERSON from GPE to GPE and made PERSON a ORGANIZATION. His hopes on following up on a solid 2016 season that saw him reach Double-A for the first time were dashed by a shoulder injury that required surgery, keeping him off the field for all but 23 games in 2017. PERSON is once again healthy and ready to start working his way up to GPE. The switch-hitter has a really strong contact-first approach and has greatly improved his plate discipline and willingness to take walks. He may never be a huge power guy, though that tool is often the last to come, but with his new selectivity, he started tapping into his raw power for more extra-base authority and could be a double-digit home run guy in the big leagues. While he's played mostly shortstop, he's shown he can more than handle second base.PERSON eventually should settle in to being a solid utility player, though if more power comes, seeing him at second every day shouldn't be too surprising. For now, though, he'll focus on staying healthy and putting the shoulder issue in his rearview mirror.

The son of former ORGANIZATION player PERSON, PERSON caught scouts' attention with his strength and athleticism as a high school player in GPE. He began to turn that into performance at ORGANIZATION A Wisconsin in 2013, and he's built on that this season in ORGANIZATION A Advanced PERSON County.PERSON's contact-oriented approach and solid speed make him a natural fit at the top of the order. He hasn't shown much power yet, but some scouts believe it will eventually come. PERSON has played all three outfield positions, and he is a solid defender.PERSON probably isn't an everyday center fielder, but his strong arm and good routes make a good fit in right field. That puts more pressure on his bat to make him a big league regular.

PERSON's spot atop 2017 Draft boards was initially hurt by minor knee surgery the fall before his junior year and slightly lackluster stuff as a result at the start of his season. He did finish strongly and dominated in the ORGANIZATION World Series shortly after the ORGANIZATION feel he dropped in their lap at ORGANIZATION. 18 overall in the June Draft. He didn't pitch after signing as PERSON erred on the side of caution.By the end of his final season with GPE, PERSON was back to full strength, featuring his plus fastball and one of the best sliders in the class. He'll sit around 93 mph and touch 95 regularly with good sink. He threw his slider too much in college, but it is a true out pitch that gets a lot of swings and misses. He'll flash a very good changeup, something he'll have to throw more often as a pro. He generally throws strikes, though it's more control than command right now.Even though the ORGANIZATION went slightly over pick value to sign PERSON, he could prove to be a first-round bargain, a top-of-the-Draft talent found in the middle of the round. His Gators teammate A.J. PERSON made it to Double-A in his first full season of pro ball, and PERSON's stuff allowed him to follow a similar fast track.

In the ORGANIZATION' budget-busting 2016 international signing class, PERSON ($1.3 million) was the lesser-paid and, until close to signing day, lesser-regarded prospect when compared to PERSON ($3.9 million). PERSON looked like one of the top players in the class early, tailed off a bit, and then began improving in pro ball, whereas PERSON was a smaller kid with solid tools and advanced feel who slowly developed above average tools after GPE had locked him up at a lower price. PERSON has filled out some in the intervening time, and has sneaky raw power that may be above average at maturity. That, in combination with clearly above average bat control and enough patience that PERSON lays off pitcher's pitches, is a rare combination for an 18-year-old middle infielder. GPE and undrafted out of an ORGANIZATION high school three years ago, PERSON has blossomed at ORGANIZATION and not only is a lock to join PERSON (1988) and PERSON (1989) as ORGANIZATION selected in the top 10 picks, but he's also the prohibitive favorite to go No. 1 overall. PERSON has been in the spotlight since signing out of the ORGANIZATION in 2009. PERSON turns just 20 in 2013, so there's no reason to rush him, with the payoff being a very special run producer at the hot corner.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

In a year where college bats with a track record of performance were hard to come by, PERSON's offensive potential had many teams interested as the GPE approached.PERSON has shown an ability to have quality at-bats and make consistent hard contact with outstanding bat speed. PERSON can run, he can throw and he can hit for power.Many scouts believe he has the best overall package of tools in the class. PERSON has long had the stuff to be considered a top prospect, but had trouble staying healthy enough to show he can use those tools to be an effective pitcher. A college starter, Lingenfelter projects as a two-pitch reliever in pro ball. 91-95, above average slider.

GPE catching typically is in high demand and short supply. Well-regarded in high school in part because of his very loose, athletic, albeit somewhat unusual delivery, the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the 2015 second round. PERSON is a superb talent who can't help but take max-effort swings at just about everything. His approach and early-career maturity issues (which have improved but still exist) slowed his development a bit and he only has half a season at Double-A despite being 23 and having played pro ball for six seasons. But PERSON has great bat speed, power, and an innate feel for impacting the bottom of the baseball and lifting it into the air. If he weren't so aggressive (he appeared to be under a mandate to see more pitches in 2018) he'd be an easy plus future hit, plus future power center field prospect in the middle of our top 100. But the volatility created by the impatience, combined with PERSON's noticeably thicker 2018 frame, has created apprehension. His upside is huge, but so is the risk. Ultimately, he shares many traits with Phillies outfielder PERSON (though PERSON's a better defender by a wide margin), and, like PERSON, PERSON might just be such an amazing offensive talent that he'll be fine eventually despite his issues and several developmental bumps in the road.

GPE's talent could have made him a seventh- to 10th-round pick in the 2014 Draft, but questions about his signability dropped him all the way to the 26th round. Injuries have plagued PERSON since college. His back, his elbow, a Tommy PERSON, more back, the shoulder, more elbow. PERSON pitched out of GPE's bullpen for most of his college career, but scouts got excited when he took his full repertoire to the rotation as a junior. He'll sit in the 93-95 mph range with his fastball and can reach back for more at times. He does have a pair of breaking balls, with his slider ahead of the curve. He'll throw the harder slider with good late bite and it looked like a plus pitch for him at its best in 2018. PERSON is still working to develop his changeup, though he shows some feel for it. He's made progress in getting left-handed hitters out, using that third pitch more effectively at times.While PERSON's overall command and control have been inconsistent in his brief career, the ORGANIZATION feel they saw a better strike-thrower as he got settled in during his bounce-back 2018 campaign. He is athletic, which should help him repeat his delivery. Staying healthy helped PERSON take a nice step toward his ceiling as a mid-rotation big league starter.

Selected by the ORGANIZATION in the fourth round of the 2011 Draft out of PERSON (Fla.) CC, PERSON spent the first three seasons of his career in GPE ball before a breakout 2014 full-season debut at ORGANIZATION A Quad Cities. After the ORGANIZATION acquired him last May in exchange for two international bonus slots, PERSON enjoyed success at both ORGANIZATION A Advanced PERSON and Double-A Bowie. Following the season, PERSON added him to its 40-man roster. He returned to the LOCATION in 2016 and won five of his seven starts before landing on the disabled list in late May with soreness in the muscle area of his left shoulder. The left-hander attempted to throw a bullpen in early July, only to have his session shut down due to ongoing discomfort.PERSON works in the 91-94 range with his fastball and can reach back for a few extra ticks, throwing the pitch down in the zone with late life and running action. The slider has two variations: one with short, tight action in the mid- to upper-80s; the other in the 82-85 mph range with more traditional sweeping action. PERSON's changeup lags behind the two offerings, which has caused problems against right-handed hitters throughout his career.That the ORGANIZATION adjusted PERSON's mechanics following the trade contributed to his success as starter in 2015, as it allowed the left-hander to make better use of his athleticism and repeat his delivery with more consistency. PERSON will need to continue to make strides with both his changeup and control to break through as a starter, but his strong track record against lefties could help him carve out a bullpen role in the coming year.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 14, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, a GPE commit, was selected as a 2015 Perfect Game Underclass High Honorable Mention and as a member of the 2016 Perfect Game Underclass Second Team.PERSON has an aggressive approach at the plate, and while he spins off contact occasionally as a result, he also boasts power potential thanks to his quick bat and strength. PERSON had some of the most intriguing tools among high school players in the 2014 Draft, and he would have gone in the top three rounds had he not been set on attending ORGANIZATION. He also knows how to use his speed on the bases. PERSON's overall game draws comparisons to that of PERSON, though his arm is significantly stronger.

The ORGANIZATION Diego-area high school standout jumped up ORGANIZATION boards after a tremendous summer showcasing his present stuff and his projectability. He complements that with both a breaking ball and changeup that could be plus in time. That still could happen, even with his sluggish start to the spring, if teams feel his summer was the real deal.

Sometimes hitters put up power numbers in college and it doesn't translate to the pro game. He is willing to take walks, however, with the potential of being a three true outcomes kind of run producer. He's a fringe-average runner who is a better athlete than what he might appear to be. He's an adequate defensive first baseman and has also seen considerable time in right field.GPE will have to prove he can hit enough to tap into his raw power in order to profile well as a big league regular at first. It will be fun to see how his home run potential develops as he moves up the ladder.

After saving a school-record 28 games in his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION, PERSON had some success as a starter in the ORGANIZATION and moved into the ORGANIZATION rotation as a junior in 2016. But he went 2-10 with a 4.86 ERA, his stuff regressed and he slid to the FACILITY in the 11th round. He immediately found success once returning to the bullpen in pro ball and advanced to the big leagues in a little more than two years, though he had a disastrous 2019 during which he injured his shoulder in a car accident in March and saw his season end when a line drive broke his jaw in June and necessitated multiple surgeries.PERSON's fastball dipped into the low-90s with less life when he was a starter, but in shorter stints it's back to sitting in the mid-90s, reaching triple digits and featuring heavy sink. His power slider ranges from 87-90 mph and has become a consistent plus offering. He'll mix in a changeup to combat left-handers and flash some average ones at times, though it got hammered in his brief introduction to the Majors.PERSON's control got shaky at times in college and early in his pro career, but he has done a much better job of challenging hitters the past two seasons. He keeps the ball down in the strike zone, a necessity for someone who will work high-leverage innings at ORGANIZATION. He could emerge as GPE's closer once he returns to full health.

ORGANIZATION was a high-profile prep pitcher in south GPE before the 2015 draft, and the main question about him focused on his rail-thin 6-foot-5, 160 pound frame. If you thought he would put on a good bit of weight, then you could see him adding velocity to his 88-92 mph heater. But the question was whether he would have enough stuff and durability to start if he stayed about the same size. He's filled out some since the ORGANIZATION took him in the comp round in 2015, but it looks like he's always going to be very thin. 
His velocity has crept up a bit to 90-93, hitting 95 mph, but the life, plane, deception, extension, and command combine to make the fastball an above average pitch now. The additional arm speed has helped his breaker improve; it flashes plus at times. And he's kept the positive attributes scouts originally noticed in his delivery and the athleticism, so the command may also end up being plus. The changeup is a 45, so his curve, pitchability, and deception are the carrying tools we think will turn him into a league average starter. ORGANIZATION also had his first pro injury in 2018, and his strikeout rate was down in his first taste of Double-A, before he had upper back issues that have him on the shelf to start 2019. So long as his stuff in intact upon return, we think he's a No. 4 starter with a chance to be a No. 3.

A thoroughly modern hitter, PERSON has above-average ball/strike recognition for his age, and everything about his swing is geared for power. While he takes the occasional, gorgeous uppercut rip, it's clear his feel for contact is undercooked from both sides of the plate, something that won't be helped by a recent thumb fracture and ligament tear that may cost him most of this season. He's increasingly likely to max out as a 40 hitter, or thereabouts, which makes it imperative that PERSON learn to attack pitches he can drive and take his share of walks. 
An amateur shortstop -- he signed for $1.9 million with the ORGANIZATION in their deep 2016 July 2nd class but was declared a free agent due to the ORGANIZATIONâ violations in the international realm, then signed for an additional $2.5 million bonus with PERSON -- PERSON made all of seven 2019 starts at second base before hurting his thumb, and should settle in there. He could be a three true outcomes middle infielder a la PERSON, or peak PERSON and PERSON.

ORGANIZATION had a pair of pitchers from its staff get drafted in the top five rounds in 2015, with PERSON going No. 4 overall and PERSON landing in the fifth. PERSON, a three-year starter, continued that trend in 2016 when he signed with GPE as its fourth-round pick. PERSON is the epitome of the advanced, yet not exciting, college arm. A Sunday starter a year ago, the right-hander served as ORGANIZATION's Friday night starter in 2016, after his strong showing in the ORGANIZATION last summer. The right-hander lacks a true out pitch but effectively employs three average offerings. He generally pitches around 90-91 mph with his heater, but there could be some more velocity to unlock at the next level. He mixes in a solid slider and changeup and demonstrates exemplary control of all three pitches.A lack of a true out pitch limits PERSON's ceiling, but his polish, durability and track record suggests that he could move quickly.

A native of GPE, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION as a 16-year-old in 2009. After a productive 2014 season with PERSON, he was acquired by the ORGANIZATION as a part of the January trade that sent PERSON to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON turned around and traded him the following offseason along with PERSON to the Angels.While PERSON improved as a hitter in 2014, as he began using the whole field more and ironed out some flaws in his setup at the plate, he regressed in 2015. He does have some loft in his swing, which could allow him to tap into his raw power. Behind the plate, PERSON is still developing as a receiver. He has above-average arm strength and has thrown out 40 percent of would-be basestealers in his career. He still has work to do, but PERSON's tools give him the chance to develop into a big league backstop in time.

It wasn't until his fourth summer after signing that PERSON made it to full-season ball, but he made it count, winning the organizational batting title while also topping the system in hits and stolen bases in 2014. He's followed it up with a strong performance in 2015.A terrific athlete, PERSON plays a high energy brand of game that in many ways makes him the most exciting player in the organization to watch. At the plate, he's all about making contact. He has a very handsy approach and has shown an ability to hit well with two strikes, getting low in his stance and continuing to put the ball in play with authority. As a result, he doesn't strike out a ton. PERSON has flashed some power, and there might be more to come, though he's more of a line-drive hitter now. A tick-above-average runner, his instincts and aggressiveness help him on the basepaths. He's also shown he can play all three outfield positions well. PERSON's energy can get in the way at times, but he should learn how to keep it in check when necessary as he matures.

At age 18, PERSON established himself as the favorite to win 2014-15 Rookie of the Year honors in GPE's top league before defecting that April. The ORGANIZATION spent $31 million to sign him seven months later, $15.5 million for his bonus and an equal amount in penalty tax. He spent most of his first two pro years holding his own as one of the youngest regulars in the high Class A GPE, then batted .333/.390/.491 in Double-A during the final month of the 2017 season. Returning to Double-A in 2018, PERSON made across-the-board improvements at the plate during the first half and then showcased his abilities to a national audience by hitting a pair of impressive home runs in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON. His progress caught the attention of the GPE, who acquired PERSON along with four other prospects in a 5-for-1 deal for PERSON at the All-Star break. PERSON shows the potential for solid tools across the board with the exception of his power, although he has begun to show more pop after toning down his setup and incorporating his lower half more in his right-handed swing. He makes consistent barreled contact, driving the ball with authority to all fields, with enough bat speed and strength to provide 12-15 per season. PERSON could very well surpass those power projections, especially after he tightened his approach and drastically reduced his chase rate during his return to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON has above-average speed but has yet to show much prowess as a basestealer. He spent most of his pro debut in center field, where he projected as an average defender. He's likely a better long-term fit in right field, where he played the majority of last year, and has the arm for the position.

The last high schooler from GPE to do anything of note in the pro game was PERSON, now a starter in the ORGANIZATION rotation. He was drafted back in 2006. ORGANIZATION provides the FACILITY's first real hope from the prep ranks since then.ORGANIZATION definitely has some tools to help him make an impact. He can really hit, with a line-drive approach and more power to come as he matures. He has very good speed from the right side of the plate and is a threat on the basepaths. That speed gives him the chance to stay in center field and he has more than enough arm for the position. He's strong, stocky and athletic.ORGANIZATION was making some noise as the weather warmed in GPE and his tools could have him off the board in the top five rounds.

The ORGANIZATION of the 2014 Connie Mack World Series, PERSON hit a key two-run double and pitched 3 1/3 scoreless innings to win the championship game. He has the most electric arm in GPE this spring but showed little feel for harnessing it until late in the season.The PERSON recruit has a strong 6-foot-3, 240-pound frame and a very quick arm, and when he keeps his mechanics under control he looks like a future ace. PERSON can work at 93-95 mph fastball and hit 98, with some late life when he keeps it down in the zone. His curveball can be a true 12-to-6 hammer and reach the mid-80s.The problem is that PERSON can't hold his delivery together, often flying open and overthrowing. That causes his fastball to straighten out and his curve to lose its shape, and prevents him from keeping either pitch near the strike zone. He has yet to show much aptitude for throwing a changeup.

PERSON GPE has sent nine pitchers to the big leagues since 2001, and PERSON could join the club despite being unimposing on the mound. He led ORGANIZATION Division I with a 1.01 ERA in 2012. PERSON had streaks of 38 1/3 straight scoreless innings and 73 consecutive without an earned run. After a strong encore in 2013, he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $40,000 as a ninth-round pick.PERSON has continued to work his magic in pro ball, as he would have led the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League ERA with a 1.62 ERA in his pro debut if he hadn't fallen just short of qualifying. He got off to a hot start in 2014, swiftly reaching high Class A while continuing to get outs with his outstanding pitchability.PERSON usually pitches at 87-88 mph with his fastball, which plays up because of his ability to locate it wherever he wants. His lone plus offering is his changeup, and he can keep hitters off balance by throwing a curveball and a cutter for strikes. Based on pure stuff, it's hard to project PERSON as a big league starter, but based on his track record of blowing away expecations, it would be silly to bet against him.

PERSON was sitting in the mid-80s as a rising junior but got himself into excellent physical shape and was touching 97 at showcase events last summer. He has an average curveball, below average changeup and lacks the mechanical grace and fluidity of most of his peers.

PERSON intrigued scouts with his athleticism before arriving at the ORGANIZATION in GPE, and his breakout performance there will earn him a seven-figure bonus -- if he's willing to sign. Also a four-star wide receiver recruit, he's committed to play football and baseball at FACILITY, where his father PERSON is a defensive line coach. PERSON believe he may prefer to play football, though some will consider him in the first round if they believe he can be lured away from the ORGANIZATION Heels.After looking overmatched at times on the showcase circuit last summer, PERSON had no problem handling quality pitching at the ORGANIZATION. He made repeated hard contact with his quick right-handed swing and displayed at least average raw power. He employs a big leg kick and doesn't have much track record offensively, but he has the upside of a solid hitter with 15-20 homers per year.PERSON' most explosive tool is his speed, which earns top-of-the-scale 80 grades from some evaluators. Just with his sheer quickness, PERSON can steal bases and cover a lot of ground in center field, and he potentially could be elite in both areas if he devoted his full attention to baseball. He has fringy arm strength, which is more than playable in center, and it could improve if he got on a throwing program.

The top catcher in the 2013 GPE class, ORGANIZATION was ranked ORGANIZATION. 10 on MLB.com's PERSON 100 at the time of the GPE. Many thought the ORGANIZATION were eyeing him for their first pick, at ORGANIZATION. 9, so they were no doubt thrilled when he was available at ORGANIZATION. 14. The left-handed hitting catcher is the complete package. ORGANIZATION is strong-bodied with some projection to his frame, which could lead to more power to go along with a very solid hit tool. Behind the plate, ORGANIZATION has a plus arm and a very quick exchange, leaving no doubt about his ability to stay behind the plate. He gets high marks for his all-out effort and should be a leader behind the plate for the ORGANIZATION.

In some ways, PERSON is a college arm stuck in a high schooler's body. He has a really advanced feel for a prepster. He has a three-pitch mix that won't wow you in terms of pure stuff, but it's solid average across the board. Both his changeup and perhaps even his curve have the chance to be better than average in the future. His fastball has a lot of sink and will sit in the 90-93 mph range. He has very good command, showing the ability to locate and move the ball around the zone. While he will be just 19 for all of the 2013 season, his pitchability may allow him to move a little faster than many high school draftees.

PERSON made a name for himself on the national stage last summer, winning the junior portion of the All-Star Game Home Run Derby by bashing 13 homers with a metal bat at ORGANIZATION. A month later, he won the Derby at the Under PERSON All-America Game at FACILITY Field.PERSON has tremendous power and bat speed, not to mention quality athleticism and arm strength. Whether he realizes that upside depends on how much he develops at the plate and how much weight he'll eventually pack on his lean 6-foot-5 frame. PERSON weren't sold on PERSON's pure hitting ability, and his busy setup at the plate can affect his timing.PERSON definitely has the arm for shortstop, but his speed and defense may not be more than average, which could eventually lead to a move to third base.

PERSON had as much helium as any position player in the last couple of weeks before the 2014 Draft. The ORGANIZATION felt fortunate to get him with the 23rd overall pick in June and signed him for $2 million. Now he'll try to go one step further than his father PERSON, who topped out in Triple-A as an outfielder and now scouts for the Dodgers.Derek stands out most with his plus-plus speed. He can run the 60-yard dash in less than 6.4 second, and his quickness gives him tremendous range in center field and allows him to be a disruptive force on the bases.PERSON has some offensive potential to go with his speed. He has the bat speed and strike-zone discipline to hit for average, and he should have solid gap power once he fills out. As a bonus, he throws better than most center fielders.

PERSON noticed PERSON at ORGANIZATION Thomas More High (PERSON, GPE.) while scouting eventual Royals supplemental first-rounder Chase Vallot in 2014, and he developed into the state's best prep prospect for 2015. He went undrafted, however, because he wanted to attend his local college. Three years later, he should become the first Louisiana-PERSON pitcher selected in the first five rounds since the turn of the century.PERSON created a stir by hitting 98 mph in mid-March after missing a month with an oblique injury, though he usually pitches at 91-94 with some run and angle on his fastball. He has aptitude for spin, throwing a curveball with power and depth and morphing it into a slider at times. He also has an effective changeup to combat right-handers.While he possesses four pitches, PERSON also has a lot of work to do to remain a starter at the next level. He lacks reliable command, and he loses velocity and location on his fastball at times when he falls in love with his breaking pitches. He also has a history of nagging injuries, leading to questions about his durability.

Signed at age 18 by the Mariners in July 2014, PERSON made an impressive GPE debut in 2015, reaching the short-season ORGANIZATION at age 19. PERSON sent PERSON to the ORGANIZATION in November in the deal for PERSON Benoit.PERSON has already shown rapid improvement since he began his pro career, and there might be plenty more left in the tank. His fastball will sit in the low 90s, but he can reach back for more velocity at times. He throws it with plenty of life down in the zone, generating a good amount of groundball outs. He has the chance to have at least an average curveball, which he can throw for strikes, and his changeup shows glimpses of being an above-average offspeed pitch. PERSON is around the plate and missed plenty of bats during his pro debut and should improve with further refinement of his command.The right-hander has room to add strength to his 6-foot-3 frame, which could lead to more velocity in the future. He might be far off from being big league ready, but the ORGANIZATION might have found a steal.

PERSON was deemed untouchable by ORGANIZATION managing general partner PERSON in 2015, including him in a group with more hyped prospects PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON. A 13th-round pick in 2012 who signed for $100,000 out of GPE, PERSON didn't allow a run in 11 appearances following a September callup that year and earned a spot on GPE's PERSON roster. But his struggles across three stints in the Majors, as well his two-plus months spent on the Triple-A disabled list with an undisclosed injury, caused the ORGANIZATION to change their tone following the 2016 season, when they dealt PERSON to Seattle for right-hander Zack Littell.PERSON has an unorthodox delivery that adds life and deception to his pitches, making him almost unhittable when he throws strikes. He sits at 93-95 mph and can reach 98 with his fastball, backing it up with a true slider in the low 80s. He also has a changeup he can use to cross up hitters.PERSON hit few speed bumps in the Minors, recording a 2.30 ERA with 243 strikeouts and just five homers allowed in 215 1/3 innings in five seasons. He missed time at the beginning of 2013 and 2015 seasons with shoulder issues, but if he can stay healthy and avoid his occasional control lapses, he stands to help bolster the ORGANIZATION' bullpen. Meanwhile, his track record against lefties and righties gives PERSON more upside than a mere situational reliever.

PERSON might be the most confounding pitching prospect in baseball. He didn't focus full-time on the mound until 2011, when he was a supplemental first-round pick out of a GPE high school, and his upside and lack of polish remain evident in his fifth year in pro ball. PERSON's strong build allows him to maintain a 93-97 mph on his fastball, which can reach as high as 99 and also features heavy sink. His second-best pitch is a slider/cutter that's more notable for its upper-80s velocity than its bite. His curveball has good depth at times and his changeup has some sink and deception.When each of his pitches are at their best, PERSON has a plus-plus fastball and three solid-or-better secondary offerings. His delivery tends to get out of whack, so he has trouble throwing strikes and putting his pitches where he wants when he does find the zone. The ORGANIZATION are known for their ability to develop pitchers, so they still might turn him into a frontline starter, but an increasing numbers of scouts are pegging him as a reliever.

PERSON took a step back in 2012 before rebounding in a big way in 2013. The big right-hander went 5-0 with a 1.81 ERA in 31 games between Double-A Birmingham and Triple-A Charlotte to earn a spot in GPE's bullpen, where he posted a 3.26 ERA in 19 1/3 innings. PERSON's fastball has been clocked as fast as 100 mph, but he more often sits in the low-90s. His arsenal of secondary pitches (changeup, slider, curveball) is average, and he has average command, so he may stay in the bullpen, where he can let his fastball loose.

The ORGANIZATION surprised most of the industry when they chose PERSON eighth overall in the 2013 Draft, a move designed to save enough money to land PERSON with their next selection. But they also viewed PERSON as a quality prospect in his own right and signed him for $2.2 million. The only player ever drafted in the top five rounds out of PERSON, he has the tools to contribute offensively and defensively.The problem is that PERSON's right-handed stroke got out of whack when he started swinging for the fences when he reached Double-A in 2014. Making matters worse, he tinkered with his stance and stride and struggled to find a comfortable approach. If he can fix his swing, he still has the natural strength and leverage to hit 20 homers per season while hitting for a decent average.While PERSON won't be a stolen-base threat, he moves well for his size and has nearly average speed. A shortstop in college, he needs to cut down on his errors at third base but has the agility and arm strength to be an asset there.

The D-backs have had their fair share of pitching prospects coming from the first round of the GPE, with PERSON and PERSON leading the way. They may have found another potential starter a bit later, nabbing PERSON in the 15th round of the 2015 GPE after he had a solid year as ORGANIZATION's Friday night starter.A PERSON All-Star during his first full season in 2016, PERSON earned a promotion to the GPE League in early July. With a three-pitch mix and an ability to throw strikes, he should be able to stay in a rotation long-term. The right-hander will touch 94 mph with his fastball, and he throws it with heavy sink, using his 6-foot-6 frame well. He mixes in a solid slider in the mid 80s and has a usable changeup as well. While he doesn't miss a ton of bats, he gets groundball outs and doesn't hurt himself with walks.PERSON's ceiling may be that of a back-end starter, one who is durable and can log innings. Finding that in the 15th round will certainly be a feather in the scouting department's cap if it all comes together.

PERSON has a large, athletic frame and is already bigger than his cousin, PERSON. Listed at 6-foot-5, 215 pounds, PERSON is an imposing presence in the batter's box, but he moves well, having played basketball early in his high school career before focusing on baseball.  PERSON generates good bat speed and has solid power as a result. He shows some feel for hitting, though he remains raw at the plate.  PERSON plays shortstop in high school, but he spent a lot of time at third base on the showcase circuit. He will likely move there whether he signs with an ORGANIZATION organization or upholds his commitment to GPE. He earns praise for his makeup and effort on the diamond.

PERSON GPE has an enviable track record of baseball success, producing a Hall of GPE (PERSON), 12 GPE 4-A state championships and 15 picks in the last 20 Drafts. The school's latest prospect is PERSON, the fastest runner in the 2015 Draft. Though his senior season came to an early end with a hamate bone fracture in early April, the injury shouldn't affect his Draft status.PERSON' top-of-the-line speed helps him beat out grounders for base hits, wreak havoc on the bases and cover plenty of ground in the field. More than just a slap hitter, the ORGANIZATION recruit shows bat speed from both sides of the plate and has gap power. He had one of the better batting practices at the workout before the Under PERSON All-America Game, hitting balls out of Illinois-Chicago's PERSON as a lefty and righty.While PERSON' quickness allows him to cover ground, scouts aren't sold that he has the arm for shortstop or the hands for the middle infield. He draws a lot of comparisons to PERSON, albeit with more strength, and could follow the ORGANIZATION' speedster's path from shortstop to center field.

It hasn't been the easiest path for the big right-hander, but PERSON's spring as PERSON's Friday starter has put him squarely on the map as redshirt sophomore.PERSON pitched in relief at ORGANIZATION as a freshman, then left the school and attended PERSON, but didn't pitch. He's had problems with both knees and spent the year rehabbing. The work has paid off as he's thrown well for the ORGANIZATION, with a fastball up to 95 mph, a wipeout slider and a splitter he uses as his offspeed pitch. He goes right after hitters and is very aggressive on the mound.That bulldog mentality, when combined with his power stuff and his injury history, may have some looking at him in a short-relief role.

PERSON was acquired from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal and has loud tools, with all but the hit tool grading above average. The power may not play in games due to an indiscriminate approach, rather than poor bat control. That will be more palatable if PERSON can stay in center field, but the general consensus is that he's a right fielder. He's more of a low-end regular type in a corner.

The ORGANIZATION teen is the top catcher in this year's class and appears to have all of the tools to make him an everyday Major Leaguer one day.PERSON is not a physically imposing figure, but the switch-hitting catcher has shown a strong arm and the ability to be a good receiver behind the plate. Scouts are certain he will improve in every area as he matures because of his good makeup and positive attitude.PERSON was the cleanup hitter for the ORGANIZATION 15-and-under team that won the gold medal last year in GPE and was eventually named to the all-tournament team. His raw power in batting practice and his ability to hit for power in games also separate him from his peers behind the plate. He makes solid contact from the right side of the plate and has a longer swing as a left-handed hitter. Scouts don't seem to mind that PERSON is not built to run.

The ORGANIZATION regime purportedly considered PERSON for the 2015 draft's first pick, which seemed ill-advised given how risky both PERSON and his draft demographic were and are (raw, cold-weather prep outfielders can be PERSON or PERSON). He fell to pick 13. As a pro, PERSON has become a power and patience center field prospect. He owns a 12% career walk rate and in 2017 started tapping into power thanks to a swing change. He was a candidate for a 2018 national breakout, but got hurt during spring training and missed the entire season while recovering from labrum surgery. The injury ate an important year of PERSON's development, and also created risk that he has to move to left field if his arm strength doesn't return (he began throwing a baseball again in late-August). Just as he was starting to answer a lot of the pre-draft questions, a bunch of new ones were introduced, but we're still enamored with PERSON's physical gifts and upside. He'll likely begin 2019 at Hi-A.

A 2013 international signee out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON opened eyes the next year during his impressive professional debut in the ORGANIZATION. That success carried over into his first stateside action in 2015, when he slashed .344/.380/.469 in 45 games between the ORGANIZATION and GPE York-Penn Leagues. PERSON advanced to full-season ball for the first time in 2016, only to miss a portion of the first half with an ankle injury and appear in just 73 games.PERSON's quick hands from the left side of the plate fuel his game as a slap hitter who predominantly hits the ball on the ground and sprays it from line to line. He's also an adept bunter and gets out of the batter's box quickly, utilizing his above-average speed. PERSON will never offer much in the way of power, but he makes enough hard contact to accrue his share of doubles and triples.A raw defender when he signed, PERSON was one of GPE's more improved outfielders in 2016 after making strides with his routes and angles to the ball. He's capable of playing center field but profiles better in left, where his speed and average arm strength are cleaner fits.

PERSON shot up ORGANIZATION boards in 2011 behind a dominant spring as PERSON's closer. He ultimately went to the GPE in the fourth round, signed for $400,000 and reached Double-A the following year in his first full season as a pro. But mechanical problems prevented PERSON from taking the next step, and he stalled out in the LOCATION over the next two seasons. In April 2015, the GPE traded PERSON to GPE for cash considerations in the amount of $1. After making endless tweaks and changes and failing to turn the corner during his years GPE, PERSON went back to throwing how he felt most comfortable. He saw immediate results and, as a result, quickly regained his confidence. The right-hander went on to have a breakout PERSON campaign between Double- and Triple-A, and the ORGANIZATION rewarded him with a callup in September.With the ORGANIZATION, PERSON used his 96-97 mph heater and a sharp, late-breaking slider in the low 80s to strike out 24 batters in 18 1/3 innings. He continued to pile up strikeouts to begin the 2016 season before landing on the disabled list in early May with rotator cuff tendinitis in his right shoulder.

GPE of the same GPE recruiting class that featured future No. 3 overall pick PERSON (Rockies) and second-rounder PERSON (ORGANIZATION), PERSON redshirted in 2011 and pitched just 13 innings for the ORGANIZATION in 2012. He transferred to PERSON, an ORGANIZATION II program, and signed for $100,000 as a 13th-rounder in 2013. His pro career didn't begin to take off until 2015, when he earned swift promotions from low Class A to high Class A and from reliever to starter.Coming out of the bullpen, PERSON worked with a 95-97 mph fastball that reached triple digits and flashed a wipeout slider. His stuff hasn't been quite as overpowering since he moved to the rotation, but he has been effective nonetheless. He has shown the makings of a decent changeup and continued to fill the strike zone in his new role.PERSON still may be better suited to be a reliever because he's more dominating in shorter stints and there are questions about whether his big body is conditioned well enough to handle a starter's workload over a full season. Even if he does move back to the bullpen, the extra innings this year will help make up for the fact that he worked just 56 frames in 2014, when he missed a month with shoulder issues.

PERSON's stock has risen all spring as scouts have been impressed with his natural hitting ability. He has an easy, loose swing and uses his quick hands and natural strength to drive the ball. He squares the ball up well and hits plenty of line drives. PERSON is an average runner, which may eventually force him to move off of center field, but his athleticism and improving feel for the game help make him a solid defender. PERSON missed his sophomore year with a torn labrum in his non-throwing shoulder, but the injury has not impacted him since. He turned 19 in March and will be a Draft-eligible sophomore if he upholds his commitment to PERSON.

In a system filled with raw, toolsy position players, PERSON stands out for his polish at the plate. After signing for a well-over-slot $800,000 as a third-rounder in 2014, he batted .300/.404/.356 with nearly as many walks (74) as strikeouts (76) in his first two pro seasons.PERSON is an advanced hitter for his age, recognizing pitches and controlling the strike zone better than most and producing line drives to all fields. He barrels balls easily and has a quick right-handed bat, so he might reach double digits in home runs once he gets stronger. He has average speed that plays well on the bases but won't result in many steals.Though PERSON saw more action at second base in his pro debut and third base the last two years because PERSON has so much shortstop depth, the ORGANIZATION believe he can play short. While his range is average, he has good instincts, reliable hands and a solid, accurate arm. PERSON tried him as a catcher during instructional league and may give him more exposure behind the plate.

In last year's GPE, a toolsy high school hitter from GPE with professional bloodlines was taken in the second round. That was PERSON, whose father PERSON played in the ORGANIZATION and who worked with cousin PERSON to hone his craft. This year there's another son of a pro in the region in PERSON, who has the potential to go in the same neck of the woods in the GPE, and whose father currently manages the Triple-A PERSON in the ORGANIZATION' system.PERSON has all the tools and athleticism one would want to see from a high school performer. There's raw power from both sides of the plate and while it's more of a line drive swing from the left side in games, he shows the pop in batting practice regularly with plus raw power overall. He's also a plus runner with basestealing ability, though he was slowed a bit with a hamstring injury earlier this spring. The only question about him on the offensive side is the swing and miss to his game, with some wondering about him making enough contact to tap into that raw pop.The PERSON commit has played infield in high school, but there is consensus that he'll move to the outfield at the next level, and he did play out there over the summer. He has the tools to play a strong center field and the bloodlines, not to mention a familial coach, to maximize his potential.

There isn't a lot of college hitting in this year's PERSON class, and the college catching crop is particularly thin. But GPE's ability with the bat, coming from a strong GPE program, has him poised for early-round consideration.GPE has long impressed with the bat. His 10 home runs as a sophomore, while playing in a pitching-friendly home park, led the ORGANIZATION as they won the ORGANIZATION World Series. He has an advanced approach at the plate and solid power, especially on the extra-base front, though he should have some over-the-fence pop at the next level. He's continued to be very consistent at the plate as a junior, though there are many questions about his ability to stay behind it as a pro. His catching skills are quite raw, with a fringy arm and rough receiving skills.Teams might want to send GPE out as a catcher; those that do might consider him in the opening round. But his bat alone -- and he has played first base at times -- should make him a day one selection.

An effective three-year college starting pitcher at GPE taken in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft, PERSON found his home in the ORGANIZATION system as a reliever and racked up 64 saves in his first three years. But in 2018 at ORGANIZATION, he was employed mainly in a set-up role, pitching well enough to earn a spot on the 40-man roster.PERSON has an often deceptive three-quarters delivery that enables him to hide the ball well. Able to throw up to 97 mph, he can also keep hitters guessing by changing arm angles and tempo or shortening his stride. Unless he develops his below-average and seldom-used changeup, he could have time managing left-handed hitters in the big leagues. He could temper that with by burying a backdoor slider in on lefties.While he certainly has the mentality to be a big-league closer with a delivery not unlike PERSON or PERSON, his stuff projects as a likely better fit as a middle reliever or right-handed matchup specialist. PERSON doesn't walk a lot of batters nor he is victimized much by the long ball, and he is capable of racking up strikeouts.

PERSON raised his profile with a strong summer turn with ORGANIZATION. He's continued to show enough with the bat to make him the kind of college performer who typically does well once the ORGANIZATION rolls around.The Tennessee outfielder has always shown a good amount of bat speed, but in the past it's typically generated more line drives than loft, more extra-base gap power than over-the-fence pop. While PERSON does swing and miss a bit, he was walking at a higher rate in 2015 and more than doubled his career home run total over his first two years with the ORGANIZATION. A fringy runner with an average at best arm, PERSON likely would profile best in left field defensively.A team that thinks PERSON can tap into his bat speed and strength and provide more consistent power will take him early as a potential every day corner outfielder.

PERSON bounced around to three different colleges as an amateur and after a solid junior season pitching in relief at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, the ORGANIZATION made him their seventh-round pick in 2015. Given a chance to start, the big right-hander had reached Triple-A and was just about knocking on the big league door when he needed PERSON surgery. He did return at the very end of the summer in 2018 and participated in instructional league play, then shook off the rust to pitch his way back to Triple-A in 2019 and got called up to GPE for the first time in GPE, though he didn't appear in a game during his first stint in the big leagues.PERSON pitches at 93-94 mph as a starter but showed the ability to get 97-98 mph on occasion, and could pitch there consistently in shorter stints should the ORGANIZATION ever put him back in the bullpen. He does have two distinct breaking balls, and he'll go back and forth depending on which one he has a better feel for. It might behoove him to focus on one, with the slider the leading candidate, if he returns to relieving. His changeup does give him an option against left-handed hitters.Now healthy, PERSON is once again ready to impact the big league staff. He could serve as a back end starter, but it might be exciting to see how his already-good stuff plays up as a short reliever.

PERSON was one of the top two-way players in the college ranks leading up to the 2014 First-Year Player Draft. In addition to playing right field and hitting in the middle of the order for PERSON, he also pitched out of the Titans bullpen. PERSON' fastball got up to the mid 90s, and he saved seven games for PERSON in 2014. But thanks to his powerufl bat, professional scouts liked him more as a hitter. He controls the strike zone well and could hit for a solid average to go with his pop. After playing several positions during his college career, PERSON has settled at third base as a professional. He's made progress at his new position and has already shown that he could move quickly in the ORGANIZATION.

A late-round pick of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON was released after two uneventful summers in GPE's system.
