Tigers scout PERSON convinced him to go to an open tryout in GPE, which led to a spot as a backup outfielder in the ORGANIZATION. An injury opened a starting spot for him and he ended up winning league ORGANIZATION honors. PERSON was far from done, jumping all the way to Double-A while continuing to perform. While he's 25 years old, he's still a little green in terms of experience as he continues to figure things out. His well above-average speed is his carrying tool and he thinks he's capable of stealing 70 bases a year once he learns the nuances of the craft. He can really go get the ball in center field and while his arm is fringy, it's accurate. He doesn't always look pretty at the plate, but he makes contact and knows his job is to get on base.With a brother who played in the ORGANIZATION and another who played pro basketball in GPE, PERSON clearly comes by his athleticism honestly. That, and his unwillingness to give up on his dream, could get him to the big leagues.

One of several bargains signed by PERSON assistant GM for international operations PERSON and his staff, PERSON turned pro for a $25,000 bonus out of the ORGANIZATION in 2010. He pitched in the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON at age 20 and made his big league debut in a relief role last September at age 22.PERSON has one of the best changeups in the Minors, and its combination of deception and sink earns plus-plus grades from some evaluators. He sets it up with a running fastball that usually operates at 92-95 mph and climbs as high as 98 in short stints. His curveball used to be a weakness but he has added depth to it and it's usually an average pitch.Similar to PERSON at the same stage of their careers, PERSON has a ceiling of a mid-rotation starter and a good chance to become at least a late-inning reliever. To stay in the rotation, he'll need to resist the temptation to overthrow his fastball (which causes it to straighten out) and to fall in love with his changeup (which leads him to drop his arm slot and turn his curve into a slurve). He also needs to refine his ability to control and command his pitches, which has diminished as he has risen through the Minors.

A very strong spring had this GPE prep right-hander climbing up ORGANIZATION boards. The LOCATION commit has one of the most electric arms coming from the mid-Atlantic region in recent memory. Though he factored in the top two rounds, he asked teams in mid-May to not draft him because he wants to attend college.Just 17, PERSON can flat-out bring it, cranking the fastball up to 100 mph and hitting the mid 90s with regularity. He can maintain velocity into starts as well, combining the fastball with a low- to mid-80s slider that flashes plus. He shows a little feel for a changeup but doesn't use it in games. There's some effort in his delivery, which leads to some inconsistent command, and the question will be whether he can tone down the delivery to improve his control.The other question is about his size, as PERSON fits the mold of the "undersized right-hander." But with a strong and thick body, there shouldn't be concerns about durability.

Entering the 2011 season, the ORGANIZATION had the game's consensus top two catching prospects in GPE PERSON and PERSON. PERSON never put a lot of effort into catching, and his career has fizzled since he got traded to the ORGANIZATION, and some evaluators wonder if PERSON might be headed down the same path. He continues to post solid but not spectacular offensive numbers, but his work ethic and maturity are concerns.PERSON still shows the impressive tools that earned him a $3 million bonus in 2009. He generates huge raw power with bat speed, strength and loft in his right-handed swing, and his throwing arm is well above average. He can lapse into an all-or-nothing approach at the plate at times, but he has enough offensive upside to profile as an everyday player if he has to move to first base.If he can stay behind the plate, PERSON could be an All-Star. He has no problems throwing out basestealers, but his blocking and receiving need a lot of work. He topped Double-A PERSON catchers with 17 errors and 10 passed balls in 2014, often looking indifferent about his defense.

One look at PERSON, a 6-foot-6 right-hander, and you think "durable starting pitcher." His inconsistencies on the mound, however, make some wonder if that's ultimately his best role, though he did make his big league debut as a starter in 2015.PERSON did shake off a slow start in his first taste of Triple-A in 2014 to finish the season well, but it left some question marks. PERSON's fastball has enough velocity, sitting in the low 90s and touching more than that at times. He throws it with good downward angle and sink when he's on, though he's up in the zone more than he should be. His changeup is his best secondary offering, with his slider coming in a close third. Both have the chance to be PERSON average, but again, he struggles to throw them consistently well. PERSON doesn't hurt himself with walks, but his command within the strike zone has hurt him. He'll continue to get work as a starter, but his fastball might play better in short relief, long-term.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011, PERSON hit .231 in his pro debut before batting .315 or better in each of the next four seasons. He's one of the best hitters in the ORGANIZATION' system and is continuing to hit for a high average in Double-A this year, though he's still searching for a position. He broke into pro ball as a catcher, moved to third base in 2015, shifted to second base this year and also has seen action at first base and left field.PERSON's bat earned him a spot on PERSON's 40-man roster last November and was his ticket to the big leagues this July. He's a switch-hitter with a knack for squaring up fastballs from both sides of the plate. Beyond producing lofty batting averages, he has the pure hitting ability, solid bat speed and strength to create average power.PERSON doesn't contribute a whole lot outside the batter's box, however. He has enough arm strength to play a variety of positions, but his lack of speed and quickness makes him best suited for the infield corners or catcher. He has been erratic at the hot corner and offers the most intrigue as a catcher, where he threw out 45 percent of basestealers in the lower Minors.

A draft eligible sophomore whose frame remains projectable, PERSON will run his fastball up to 97 but he lacks a clear bat-missing secondary. Some scouts project heavily on his cutter/slider and curveball because we are talking about a sophomore and one who spent much of his freshman year in the ORGANIZATION bullpen where his reps were limited.

PERSON was one of the youngest players in the 2013 Draft class, and he also had some of the best power. His relative youth hasn't been apparent in the ORGANIZATION, as he has held his own at every level. Now it will be up to the ORGANIZATION to further develop him after acquiring him in the trade that sent PERSON to the D-backs.PERSON packs a lot of power in his big, physical frame. His approach at the plate is still a work in progress, however, limiting how much of that pop he can use in games. At his best, PERSON uses the whole field to hit, and with more experience, he should be able to drive the ball out of any part of the park. PERSON was a shortstop in high school, but he was quickly moved to the outfield by the D-backs. He has the tools to become an adequate outfielder once he gets used to the new position.

After the PERSON signed PERSON away from a scholarship to the ORGANIZATION of GPE, they sent the GPE high schooler out as a shortstop. His fringe average arm meant a move to second made sense and that's almost exclusively where he's played for the past two years. He's still learning that side of the infield, but should be an average defender when all is said and done. He's a slightly above-average runner who is better underway and he's shown the skills to be a solid contact hitter from the left side of the plate. He could be a decent offensive-minded second baseman or, at the very least, a valuable utilityman best suited for second, but who could help out at shortstop and third if needed.

PERSON dominated as a full-time reliever in GPE Cod last summer, sharing the league lead with eight saves while not surrendering an earned run in 13 appearances. Though he's one of college baseball hardest-throwing starters, he hasn't had nearly the same success during three years at ORGANIZATION. His fastball velocity and performance in college baseball's top summer league could still get him drafted in the first five rounds, however.PERSON has been clocked as high as 98 mph and can carry a 93-95 mph fastball deep into games, with good downhill plane and some armside run. His changeup can be a plus pitch at times, featuring deceptive arm speed as well as fade. He flashed an improved slider on the GPE last summer but lacks feel to spin and has pitched with a below-average breaking ball for much of 2018.While PERSON generates premium starter velocity without much effort, hitters see the ball well against him and don't miss his fastball as much as would be expected. His control and command lack consistency, which also makes him vulnerable. The consensus is that he's best suited for a relief role as a pro, and he could have a plus-plus heater in shorter stints.

PERSON sat out all of 2016 after transferring to PERSON & Mary from GPE, where he had appeared in just 12 games out of the bullpen as a freshman. The redshirt sophomore pitched to mixed results in his first season with The Griffin but showed enough arm strength and stuff to warrant a third-round selection by the ORGANIZATION. A physically strong and durable left-hander, PERSON operates in the low-to-mid 90s with his fastball and can reach back for 96 mph, all while maintaining his velocity deep into games. His changeup is his best secondary offering, one that receives above-average grades from scouts, and he also features a pair of average breaking balls in a curveball and a slider. After missing plenty of bats but struggling to throw strikes as an amateur, PERSON pitched to opposite results during his pro debut. Learning to repeat his delivery as well as harnessing his stuff and throwing more strikes would bode well for his chances of remaining a starter, although there's little doubt among scouts that PERSON could move quickly in a bullpen role.

Looking at his stuff without all the context that encompasses 'mound presence,' PERSON is a three-pitch middle-relief prospect. His fastball typically sits in the low 90s and his slider is solid average, perhaps a tick above. But PERSON is a gargantuan 6-foot-7, takes a large stride toward the plate, and releases the ball much closer to home than the average pitcher, creating a ORGANIZATION Fister-like effect that allows his stuff to play up. He has a 1.16 career ERA in pro ball and has K'd more than a batter per inning. Like most XXL pitchers in their early 20s, PERSON struggles with control, but hittersâ inability to adjust to his delivery in short stints has limited their overall ability to reach base. As a result, he has a 1.05 career ORGANIZATION despite an 12% career walk rate. Itâs hard to say how this rare type of deception will play in the big leagues, assuming upper-level hitters are still flummoxed by it as PERSON moves on. PERSON was dominant for a half decade with a similar type of deception but he had much better stuff.

Though PERSON hit 94 mph with his fastball and backed it up with an interesting slider in high school, he wanted to play every day and the ORGANIZATION granted his wish after signing him for $914,600 as a second-rounder in 2014. He has moved quickly, beginning 2017 by batting .357 in the World Baseball Classic for GPE and ending it in GPE, where he hit his first big league homer off PERSON. In between, he batted .314 as the youngest regular (age 21) in the Triple-A PERSON, where he was just one of two regulars with more walks (52) than strikeouts (50).One of the best pure hitting prospects in baseball, PERSON recognizes pitches and controls the strike zone better than most players his age. He uses the whole field, repeatedly barreling balls with a quick left-handed stroke geared for line drives. Though he homered just seven times in 132 games last season, his hitting ability, bat speed and strength should translate into average power if he adds some loft to his swing.As good as he is in the batter's box, PERSON's best tool actually is his plus-plus arm. Despite average speed, he has spent much of his pro career in center field, where his instincts help him get the job done. Scouts are split on whether he can handle center on a daily basis in the Majors, but no one doubts that his arm would play in right.

A strong showing as a Pittsburgh junior in 2016 pushed PERSON into the first round of the GPE, where the ORGANIZATION selected the big right-hander with the ORGANIZATION. 21 overall pick. A back injury limited PERSON somewhat during his first full season, but he still jumped on the big league radar by pitching well at ORGANIZATION A Advanced ORGANIZATION and then boosted his stock even more against better competition in the ORGANIZATION. Returning to the ORGANIZATION State League in 2018, PERSON made just six starts at ORGANIZATION before moving up to Double-A New Hampshire. He was an LOCATION All-Star at midseason, and continued to pitch well down the stretch while leading the ORGANIZATION to an LOCATION title. An imposing presence on the mound at 6-foot-7, PERSON uses his height to his advantage by creating a steep angle to the plate. The downhill plane only enhances the right-hander's sinker, a plus pitch he throws with heavy late life in the low- to mid-90s. This enables him to generate ground balls at a near-elite rate (57 percent in '18). PERSON's curveball has become his best secondary offering and plays nicely off his sinker, keeping hitters off-balance with its shape and late bite. His slider wasn't as sharp in 2018 but is still viewed as an average pitch, and he also throws a changeup that's a distant fourth pitch. Despite his size, PERSON's long levers are consistently in-sync, and he repeats his delivery well. It allows him to pound the zone with his entire arsenal. PERSON assuaged concerns about his durability last season by accruing more than 156 innings, or more than double the workload from his first full season. The only drawback to PERSON's profile is that he doesn't miss many bats and therefore doesn't rack up strikeouts. Instead, he mostly pitches to contact, consistently attacking the bottom of the zone early in the count to force weak contact. Altogether, PERSON has the look of a future backend starter at the highest level, perhaps more if he can improve his breaking balls and start to generate more whiffs.

Drafted as the most advanced college bat in the 2010 Draft class, PERSON quickly got to Triple-A with the Cardinals in his second full season, though most felt he took a step back from a productive first year. He has continued to scuffle in the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION since the PERSON got him at the 2012 PERSON for PERSON. He still has some of the hitting tools that made him a first-round pick apparent, with a short, quick stroke and the ability to spray line drives to all fields. PERSON shows some pull power, but perhaps tried too hard to muscle up in 2012 and got away from his game plan. There is some question what his defensive home will be, with a strong enough arm for third but fringy defensive tools otherwise.http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article/mia/bernie-pleskoff-miami-marlins-third-base-prospect-zack-cox-remains-a-mystery?ymd=20131006&content_id=62601086&vkey=news_mia

PERSON spent his first three years at FACILITY as a reliever, but is starting for the first time as a senior after not signing with the ORGANIZATION, who took him in the 2012 Draft.As a starter, he's shown the ability to mix four pitches well, all of which could be PERSON average as he develops them. Big, strong and durable, he throws his fastball, curve, slider and changeup around the plate consistently and varies his arm slot to give hitters different looks.A team that takes PERSON can give him the chance to remain as a starter, knowing that he had success as a lower-angle lefty reliever in the past.

Originally a member of the 2014 graduating class, PERSON chose to speed up the process and graduated a year early before becoming the ORGANIZATION' second Draft pick in June. PERSON played shortstop in high school but will almost certainly move to a corner, where his below-average speed and 6-foot-4, 200-pound frame profile better, and left-handed hitting third basemen are always valued highly. PERSON has shown some ability to hit, and his strength allows him to hit for power as well. If he can't handle the hot corner -- though that's where he played during his pro debut -- he could give a corner outfield spot a try.
GPE has hit 101 mph this spring after dramatically reducing the length in his arm stroke, but offers little else currently.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON ORGANIZATION is a right-handed pitcher who has earned a 2016 ORGANIZATION and is currently labeled as a top 500 recruit in the college class of 2017. The ORGANIZATION commit plays high school baseball at FACILITY and his fastball touches 90 mph.

Both PERSON's father and brother played college baseball, but it looks like PERSON is going to be the first in the family to extend his playing career to the professional ranks.After a strong summer in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON has kept hitting for PERSON. His plate discipline and pitch recognition are as good as any college hitter in this Draft class. He's more of a line-drive hitter right now, but there is some slugging potential in his left-handed swing, plus excellent bat speed and good balance at the plate. PERSON is very versatile as a defender. He's more of a corner outfielder, but he can even play center field in a pinch, and he can even play first. PERSON's home park is not hitting-friendly, and many Cavaliers hitters have gone on to hit better at the next level. The team that thinks that will happen for PERSON, and that more power will come, will take a long look in the top few rounds.

Two-sport athletes are supposed to be slow to develop, since they don't focus on one sport as amateurs. The ORGANIZATION have been pleasantly surprised by how quickly PERSON's game has advanced, as he backed up a solid first full season with a strong 2014 in the ORGANIZATION State League at age 20.A former running back in high school, PERSON is as athletic as they come, with tools aplenty. He has excellent bat speed and makes consistent hard contact to all fields. He doesn't have a ton of over-the-fence power, but he hits the gaps consistently. He doesn't strike out much, but he needs to walk more if he wants to be a more complete top-of-the-order catalyst. PERSON has above-average speed. That, and his aggressive style of play, makes him a dangerous baserunner. His speed plays well in center field, as does his solid throwing arm.PERSON has come a long way in a short time. The ORGANIZATION are excited that he might just be scratching the surface of his enormous potential.

GPE throws hard for his age, sitting in the low-90s and bumping up against 95. He's short but not small and sturdily built, quelling concerns about his durability but propagating ones about his fastball's projection. He garners swings and misses with the curveball and GPE's changeup has significant projection because his arm action is so efficient. Like many GPE prospects, GPE's cultural influence is apparent in GPE's efficient and consistent delivery.

At 6-foot-1, 180, PERSON would look out of place in a team photo of big league first basemen, full of big-bodied mashers and explosive rotational athletes. He lacks prototypical first base pop but there's a non-zero chance he makes enough contact to balance the offensive scales sufficiently to profile as a platoon 1B/LF or low-end regular. His 2018 post-draft showing in the ORGANIZATION was impressive from a bat-to-ball standpoint and he took great at-bats and made hard contact during instructional league, though that was all against pitching comparable to what he saw in college. He's a sleeper bat we like but it's a tough profile, one he'll have to hit his way to.

When the ORGANIZATION scouted PERSON at FACILITY A&M, they thought his stuff as a reliever could have placed him in the top two rounds of the 2016 Draft. But he struggled in his junior year, so he was still on the board when the ORGANIZATION picked in the fifth round that June. His power stuff has played well in the lower levels of the Minors, and he was a ORGANIZATION State PERSON All-Star in 2018.With big stuff that projects well for the ORGANIZATION as a reliever, PERSON has two effective pitches with a plus-plus 94-98 mph fastball and an above-average power curveball that ranges from 87-90 mph. There is no question he has swing-and-miss stuff, with a 12.3 K/9 ratio entering 2019. He also gets a lot of weak contact on the ground, as evidenced by his 1.60 GO/AO ratio through the 2018 season.PERSON still has work to do to sharpen his command and control after he had 4.9 walks-per-nine innings last season at ORGANIZATION while he posted a 1.76 ERA in 44 games. He doesn't need to have pinpoint control in short relief, but more consistent strikes could lead to him getting high-leverage innings late in games.

The term "projectable right-hander" gets tossed around quite a bit around GPE time, and Canning fits the description quite well.The ORGANIZATION product and ORGANIZATION commit already has an interesting three-pitch mix that he's not afraid to use. His fastball will touch the low 90s with some good sink when he keeps it down in the zone. He has a good feel for his changeup, and his slider has a good late break when his mechanics are right. With a frame that seems ideal for adding strength and good weight, there could be a lot more in the tank, velocity-wise, all coming from a clean and easy delivery.Canning might not profile as one of the top prep arms in the GPE class, but the team that dreams on what he might become is the one that will take him in the top five rounds.

PERSON starred for three seasons at ORGANIZATION, going 30-9 with 403 strikeouts (second-most in school history) and appearing in two College World Series. His velocity decreased during his junior year in 2017 and caused him to drop toward the end of the first round, and he signed for a slightly below-slot $1,925,000 after a post-Draft physical raised concerns about his back. His stuff stayed down in his first full pro season but has rebounded somewhat in 2019 and had advanced to Double-A when the ORGANIZATION sent him, along with PERSON, to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.PERSON had one of the best curveballs in the 2017 Draft, and while it's still often his best pitch, it's not quite the low-80s hammer he had at ORGANIZATION. His fastball is back up to 91-95 mph after ranging from 88-92 mph in 2018, though he never has commanded his heater particularly well. He improved his fading changeup when he had to use it more often out of necessity, and he also has picked up a cutter.Even when PERSON was thriving in college, scouts questioned the effort in his delivery and some projected him as a reliever. He may never have more than average control or command, a problem for a pitcher without much margin for error. His competitiveness allows him to get the most out of his ability, though he has looked like a back-of-the-rotation starter early in his pro career.

One of the best all-around athletes to come out of GPE in years, PERSON could become the first first-round pick out of GPE since PERSON in 2000 -- if he has a strong spring. Born in GPE, he moved to GPE when he was 10 months old.PERSON is built like a linebacker at 6-foot-4 and 225 pounds, and all of his physical tools (raw power, speed, arm strength) grade out as plus. With his strength, bat speed and leverage, he can hit the ball farther than most high school players.Relatively new to baseball, PERSON lacks polish at times at the plate, on the bases and in the field. But he has shown significant improvement in the last year and has prototypical right-field tools. He'll attend GPE if he doesn't turn pro.

Though PERSON only threw in the low 80s in high school, PERSON still valued him as a recruit because he was a projectable left-hander with a competitive streak. After pitching in middle relief as a freshman, he emerged as the ORGANIZATION' best starter the last two seasons. His 119 strikeouts as a junior matched PERSON's single-season record (PERSON, 1970) and also ranked 17th among all ORGANIZATION Division I hurlers. That knack for missing bats earned PERSON a selection in the fourth round by GPE, and he signed for pick value at $245,600.PERSON's standout pitch is a changeup that arrives in the low 80s and drops off the table as it approaches at the plate. While he has gotten stronger, he won't overpower hitters with a fastball that tops out at 93 mph but usually settles in at 88-90. It plays above its velocity, however, because he commands it well and his funky delivery leads to some awkward swings.Though his mechanics are unorthodox, PERSON repeats them well and doesn't have any problem finding the strike zone. His biggest need is to improve his fringy slider, and he's committed to using it so he'll have a true three-pitch mix. His durable frame lends itself well to an innings-eating role at the back of a rotation.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON is an ORGANIZATION State commit who has been outstanding in travel leagues, landing on five All-Tournament squads -- including one with the ORGANIZATION scout team -- and a Most Valuable Player award at the 2016 18U ORGANIZATION Day Classic. He has also won three ORGANIZATION championships.Hauver makes quality contact at the plate. He is developing power thanks to his solid build. As he prepares to make contact, the infielder has an even stance and uses a leg lift as a trigger, following the motion with a loose, compact swing.Hauver reads defensive hops properly in the field. His feet work in sync, and he has average arm strength for his position.

When PERSON fractured his wrist during PERSON's second series of the year, he was hitting .560 (14-for-25) with two doubles, two homers, and three steals in three attempts. For two long weekends in GPE he did everything. He crushed balls in all parts of the strike zone, ran plus-plus times to first base, and made several highlight reel defensive plays at second base. The wrist fracture kept him out for the rest of February, all of March, and most of April. When he returned, PERSON kept hitting, but not for power, which is consistent with what plagues hitters for several months after they've had a break in the hand/wrist area. 
That trend continued through his first pro summer, which was interrupted by a hamstring issue, as PERSON struggled to pull and/or lift the ball at all. He had a downward, slashing swing instead of the dynamic and athletic cut he'd had early in the year, when he could scoop and lift stuff at the bottom of the zone. But he kept making contact. It was a month before a pro pitcher was able to strike PERSON, who only K'd in 3% of his pro plate appearances last year, out. 
It's fair to make a distinction between prospects who are small, and ones who are just short. PERSON is short, but is built like a little tank. PERSON is small, a diminutive 5-foot-7, 165 pounds, and this, combined with his total lack of post-draft power, has the pro side of scouting very concerned. He looked tired and sluggish during instructional league, though it wasn't as if he'd played a whole year and was an obvious candidate to be run down, furthering concerns that his size will be an issue. We're inclined to believe there's a substantial bounce-back on the horizon. He was the best draft-eligible hitter we saw last year, a complete player with few, if any, flaws.

GPE isn't the sexiest prep arm, as he doesn't throw particularly hard or have lots of physical projection, but he has a bit of both and, more importantly, advanced feel for a three pitch mix to go with a clean arm action.

Signed for $115,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, PERSON spent his first three seasons in pro ball in the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION. He hasn't had much statistical success since coming to the GPE in 2016 and led the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION with 12 losses in his full-season debut last year. Nevertheless, he has one of the better ceilings among Royals pitching prospects.PERSON has a quick arm that generates 93-97 mph fastballs and uses his 6-foot-3 frame to throw downhill, getting more than his share of swings and misses as well as groundballs. His curveball gives him a second plus pitch at times, though it's not as consistent as his heater. He needs to improve his changeup and employ it more because left-handers have pounded him on a regular basis.Though PERSON has impressive stuff, he's still figuring out how to use it. He gets hit harder than he should because he doesn't command his pitches well, and his control regressed at the start of the 2018 season. If he can't realize his potential as a starter, he has the tools to make an impact as a reliever.

PERSON has done nothing but rake since his selection in the second round of the 2013 Draft. He hit .371 during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION, posted a .340 clip as a 19-year-old old to win the LOCATION batting in his full-season debut, and hit over .300 again in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 before a late-season promotion to Double-A Bowie. It was more of the same last season in PERSON's return to the LOCATION, as he paced the circuit in on-base percentage (.406) and finished fourth in batting (.320) en route to a late Triple-A promotion and the ORGANIZATION' PERSON of the Year award. Back in the ORGANIZATION in 2017, PERSON continued to showcase his plus hitting ability and earned a trip to the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON for a second straight year.PERSON's feel for hitting has long belied his age. He makes a lot of quality contact with a level left-handed stroke and never tries to do too much, letting the ball travel deep so as to utilize the whole field, while also showing a very impressive approach and plate discipline. PERSON profiles as a gap hitter but showed more over-the-fence pop in 2016, and he's produced similar power numbers in his first full Triple-A campaign. Improvements in PERSON's blocking, receiving and game-calling last season have helped to assuage some concerns about his defensive profile. PERSON now project him to be average behind the plate, though his fringy arm and catch-and-throw skills limit his impact on the running game. The ORGANIZATION signed free-agent catcher PERSON to a one-year deal during the offseason, in part to allow PERSON additional time to develop, as he represents the club's next long-term option behind the plate.

Long known to area scouts in LOCATION for his multiple tools, PERSON jumped onto bigger radar screens with a strong performance in this year's PERSON. He's not a slam-dunk early-round choice, as some don't necessarily see him translating those tools into consistent production, but he's shown enough to warrant some top six round consideration.PERSON's best now tool is his speed and he's been recorded with 4.1-second times out of the left-handed batter's box to first base this spring. That speed should allow him to be a threat on the bases as well as cover a ground in the outfield. He has some skills at the plate and makes hard contact when he stays behind the ball. There is a ton of raw power which shows up in GPE, but not yet consistently in games. With enough arm and instincts, he has the chance to stay in center long-term, unless he fills out his 6-foot-5 frame too much, in which case he could fit a corner outfield profile from a power perspective just fine.While opinions of PERSON varied, there are some who feel he's the type of player who could exceed projections. A LOCATION commit, some see an PERSON body type, with production to potentially follow.Prospect ORGANIZATION - PERSON, GPE.

PERSON has progressed steadily through the system after signing out of GPE for $775,000 in 2008. Even with his development slowed by a high ankle sprain this year, he's on the verge of reaching the ORGANIZATION. Yet it remains to be seen whether PERSON will be an everyday player or a fourth outfielder.An extremely patient hitter, PERSON diligently works counts and uses the entire field. Scouts believe he can be too passive at times, however, and would like to see him try to drive balls more often. PERSON needs to get stronger, as well, or else he might be pegged as more of a tweener than a regular.PERSON' speed, arm and defensive ability are all fine, but he presently lacks the power to fit on an outfield corner or the quickness to start in center. While his skills are best suited for left field, he's capable of playing all three spots.

The ORGANIZATION thought they were getting a bat-first backstop when they took GPE as a Draft-eligible sophomore out of GPE in the ORGANIZATION B in 2016. A solid first full season that saw him play across two levels of A ball has further cemented that evaluation. After reaching Double-A for the first time, the ORGANIZATION dealt him with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.GPE showed, at least during his time with GPE in the LOCATION, that his power will play. That's particularly true from the left side of the plate, where his pop is at least average, but he has 45 power from the right side as well. There is some swing and miss, but he's also willing to be selective in waiting for a pitch to drive. The ORGANIZATION hadn't worked much with launch angle previously, but they are shifting some focus in that direction and that should help GPE, who has always been about lifting the ball. His defense remains behind the bat and while he has a long way to go, he's made progress and worked hard behind the plate. He'll never wow anyone back there, but there is confidence he'll be capable enough to stay there. That gives him the chance to be a switch-hitting, offensive-minded big league regular catcher with power. What team wouldn't want that kind of player?

There might be other young pitchers with more pure stuff, even those who were taken along with PERSON out of high school by the ORGANIZATION. But this lefty -- sent to the ORGANIZATION in the blockbuster deal that gave ORGANIZATION, PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON -- has more polish than many pitchers of his age. Thatâs not to say he doesnât have good stuff. PERSONâs fastball will sit in the 89-91 mph range, and he throws it with good deception and movement. His curve has good three-quarters break to it when he throws it correctly, and his changeup can be a plus pitch. PERSON can throw them all for strikes even if thereâs a little cross-fire to his delivery. His feel for pitching could allow him to start moving faster.

Though PERSON was the hardest thrower in their system, he was so raw that the ORGANIZATION declined to protect him on their 40-man roster after the 2014 season. The ORGANIZATION picked him in the Rule 5 Draft and immediately sold him to the GPE, who couldn't keep him and lost him on waivers to the ORGANIZATION. Returned to GPE right before the start of last season, he skipped a level to Double-A and had his most consistent year as a pro to earn a spot on the 40-man this time around.PERSON has a lightning-fast arm that has regularly produced upper-90s fastballs since he became a full-time reliever toward the end of 2014. He can reach 102 mph with his heater, though it gets straight toward the upper limits of its velocity. He pairs his fastball with a slider than can creep into the low 90s and runs the gamut between a wipeout pitch and a below-average slurve.PERSON has the pure stuff to become a closer but still has a lot of work to do to reach his ceiling. He has spotty control and command, in part because he falls in love with radar-gun readings, overthrows and has trouble repeating his mechanics. He also allowed more hits than he had strikeouts in his first two years in full-season ball, which may be a sign that he lacks deception.

PERSON helped lead ORGANIZATION to the GPE state 7-A championship and a No. 2 national ranking in 2013, but he worried clubs, didn't put up big numbers and was committed to PERSON. He dropped to the 30th round but wound up signing for $440,000, the equivalent of fourth-round money. Since then, he has established himself as one of the better young hitters in the system.PERSON has an advanced approach at the plate, displaying patience and a penchant for using the opposite field. His hand-eye coordination allows him to make consistent hard contact, and he has the bat speed and strength for average power if he lets his swing loose and turns on more pitches. Compared to other Red Sox first-base prospects, he can't match the pure hitting ability of PERSON or the raw power of PERSON Ockimey.After playing mostly on the outfield corners in 2014, PERSON saw the majority of his action at first base last season. He shows good hands and footwork at first, though he moves well enough despite below-average speed that the outfield is still a possibility. He has the arm strength for right field, having shown a low-90s fastball when he was a two-way player at ORGANIZATION.

Though it seems like PERSON was more inclined to nibble with his fringy fastball in the hitter's paradise of the ORGANIZATION, he was still pretty successful and of interest to teams ahead of the trade deadline. His fastball plays because he hides the ball well, it has some life at the top of the zone, and he works it up around the hands of righties, causing significant discomfort. His command enables his milquetoast breaking ball to play, but his dastardly changeup, which PERSON uses against hitters of both handedness, is clearly his best pitch. The deception may not play multiple times through a batting order if PERSON ends up in a traditional starting role. Instead we think he fits best in a role like PERSON, who has similar stuff.

Three-pitch lefties with mid-90s heat always have a shot, so while PERSON's walk rate remains a disconcerting 13%, the fact that he showed 96 with an occasionally good changeup and breaking ball means he's still pretty interesting. His arm action is so long that it needs to be split into two movies and while that is probably part of why he so badly struggles to throw strikes, it also makes him really tough on left-handed hitters. The existence of three pitches (the fastball, an upper-80s change, low-80s slurve) better positions PERSON for the three-batter minimum rule, but he still needs to throw more strikes or he's just upper-level depth.

PERSON was regarded by most scouts as the toolsiest player in the 2014 Draft, but concerns about his hitting ability caused him fall into the second round, where the ORGANIZATION signed him for $1.3 million as the 51st overall pick. Though he hit .310 and led the Rookie-level PERSON with 66 hits in his pro debut, the LOCATION native struggled with the move to full-season ball in 2015, hitting just .231 with a ORGANIZATION-leading 162 strikeouts at ORGANIZATION A ORGANIZATION. PERSON fared much better in his return to ORGANIZATION in 2016, however, earning mid-season All-Star honors in the ORGANIZATION before moving up to ORGANIZATION A Advanced Lake Elsinore in late June. PERSON' bat speed, foot speed, arm strength and defensive ability all grade as well above average. He's an outstanding defender in center field, where he gets great jumps, uses his double-plus speed to cover a ton of ground and shows a ridiculously strong arm. PERSON' swing is just as explosive and gives him plus raw power, but he's been unable to make consistent contact as a pro, let alone apply it consistently in games. Meanwhile, strikeouts will continue to be a problem for the young outfielder until he improves his pitch recognition and strike-zone management.PERSON' frustration showed at times last season, but the ORGANIZATION felt he did a good job separating his defense from his struggles at the plate. His tools and athleticism give him the ceiling of a star-caliber player, and he could develop into an everyday player with a modicum of improvement at the plate.

GPE is built like a human sports car, chiseled and squared-shouldered. He runs like one, too, and may be a plus defender in center field at peak. He has crude feel for slasher-style contact right now and the way his style of and quality of contact develop will dictate what kind of role he's capable of playing. Right now he swings and hits like a tweener, but he's so young that his physical abilities, which are loud, matter much more at this stage. He's a talented, long-term developmental piece.

The ORGANIZATION liked PERSON enough to give him a $250,000 bonus as a 17th-rounder in 2012, but after he posted a 6.44 ERA in his first three pro seasons, they gave him to the FACILITY for two months of PERSON. He started to make progress during his year in GPE's system, then really blossomed in 2016 following a trade to the Rockies in exchange for PERSON. PERSON led GPE farmhands with 156 strikeouts in 168 1/3 innings and pitched well in five late-season starts in Double-A.Drafted as a projectable right-hander who topped out at 92 mph in high school, PERSON has gained 25 pounds since turning pro and now sits at 93-96 mph and reaches 98 with some sink on his fastball. His mid-80s slider is harder than it is sharp but can be a plus pitch at times. He'll also flash an average changeup, though it lacks consistency.PERSON has a durable build, throws strikes and keeps the ball down in the zone. He has all the ingredients to fit in the middle of the rotation and shouldn't require much more development time. If for some reason he doesn't make it as a starter, he could be a high-leverage reliever whose stuff shows even more power in shorter stints.

PERSON was deployed all over the diamond to begin his professional career, seeing time at every position save for pitcher and catcher. He took over at shortstop full time at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Carolina in 2013, after he was passed by PERSON on the organizational ladder. He reached Triple-A for the first time in 2015 and continued to build on that success in his return to GPE this season before making his big league debut in July. PERSON has into his own offensively in the past two years, demonstrating a better feel to hit as well as improved bat-to-ball skills. He generates sneaky power through physical strength and bat speed, though his barrel path is more conducive to hitting ground balls and line drives than home runs. Once a free swinger, PERSON has cut down on the whiffs in 2016, though he's also drawing few walks. An above-average runner, PERSON is still learning how to utilize his slightly above-average speed on the basepaths. His wheels also stand out at shortstop, where he shows impressive range and athletic actions as well as a rocket arm. PERSON's overall game needs more consistency, but he has the necessary tools to become a quality big league middle infielder.

The GPE high school product has the kind of size and raw skill set scouts like, even if it might take a little while for him to develop. Big and strong, PERSON will show flashes with his bat and should grow into more power as he matures and gains a better knowledge of the strike zone. He was a shortstop in high school, and thatâs where he played in the Rookie-level PERSON during his summer debut. Many feel, however, that with his size, a move to third will be necessary in the future. He should have the defensive tools necessary to be a good third baseman, and if it comes together as the D-backs think it will, his bat would profile well there, too.

PERSON was the second-youngest player in the LOCATION League in 2013, playing much of the season as a 17-year-old. He more than held his own against the older competition, and he continued playing well ahead of the curve in the ORGANIZATION in '14.The son of former All-Star PERSON, PERSON has a good feel for hitting from both sides of the plate. He is an above-average runner, and while PERSON doesn't hit for much power now, scouts expect that to change as he matures. Defensively, PERSON has a strong arm and good infield actions. He is a good bet to stay at shortstop, and he has the potential to be an above-average defender.PERSON's youth and inexperience are understandably exposed at times, but he is already very advanced for his age.

Undrafted and unheralded out of high school, PERSON blossomed into one of the top hitters in college baseball and the highest pick ever from GPE. Ranked as the top position prospect in the ORGANIZATION in each of his two summers in college, he went ninth overall in the 2015 Draft and signed for $3 million.A switch-hitter who's better as a lefty, PERSON exhibits good balance and controls the strike zone well. With plus bat speed from both sides of the plate and some deceptive strength, he should hit for both average and power. He's a solid runner with some basestealing aptitude.PERSON possesses athleticism and has a strong arm, and his value will be even higher if he can play up the middle. He broke into pro ball as a center fielder, though many scouts believe he fits best on an outfield corner. He played mostly second base in 2013 but lacks smooth infield actions.

An unheralded 24th-round pick out of LOCATION in 2013, PERSON signed for $35,000 and recorded a 6.96 ERA in his pro debut before making a name for himself in his second pro season. He was named pitcher of the year in the Rookie-level PERSON, which he topped in strikeouts (77) and strikeouts per nine innings (12.8). He upped his whiff rate to 16.7 in four starts at low Class A Great Lakes, where he fanned 14 in one game to break PERSON's single-game franchise record.PERSON threw in the low 90s at LOCATION and boosted his fastball into the mid-90s once he improved his delivery and conditioning in pro ball. He also improved his slider, which now operates in the low 80s with depth and gives him a legitimate swing-and-miss pitch.PERSON is willing to throw his changeup and does a reasonable job of throwing strikes. He projects as a starter but it remains to be seen how his stuff will hold up over an entire year in full-season ball. At worst, his fastball and slider should make him a useful reliever.

GPE dominated as a ORGANIZATION high school senior in 2013, going 11-0 and pitching an 11-strikeout one-hitter in the state 4-A championship game, but he went undrafted because he was a finesse left-hander with a strong commitment to PERSON. He stepped right into a weekend-rotation role with the ORGANIZATION as a freshman and has served as a reliable starter for three seasons, winning the clinching games of ORGANIZATION regionals and super-regionals to send ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION World Series in 2015.GPE hasn't added much velocity in three years of college and operated with a fringy 89-91 mph fastball that will hit 93 on occasion and features some run and sink. He does have a pair of weapons in his curveball and changeup, both of which are solid and show flashes of becoming plus offerings. He can run his curve into the upper 70s with 11-to-5 break and keep right-handers at bay with his sinking changeup.Though there's some effort in GPE's delivery and his control has slipped a notch this spring, he usually locates his pitches where he wants. That's important to his future success because he has no projection left in his stocky 6-foot-1 frame and little margin for error. That said, he's a higher-floor prospect with the moxie to be a back-of-the-rotation option and the curveball to be a situational lefty if starting doesn't work out.

A highly regarded recruit who got just four innings as a GPE freshman in 2016, GPE opened eyes by starring in the ORGANIZATION that summer. His success prompted him to transfer to the ORGANIZATION JC of GPE, Manatee-Sarasota, which made him Draft-eligible as a 2017 sophomore. He ranked second among national juco pitchers with 133 strikeouts before the ORGANIZATION selected him 27th overall and signed him for $2.2 million.GPE's best pitch is his 12-to-6 curveball, a low-80s hammer when he stays on top of it. His fastball is close behind, ranging from 91-96 mph with impressive movement and downhill plane. He rarely used his changeup as an amateur, so GPE had him focus on it during his introduction to pro ball, which partially explains his 9.21 ERA in his debut.The ORGANIZATION see considerable promise in GPE's changeup and see him developing into a starter with three quality pitches. He does feature effort in his delivery and has trouble keeping his mechanics in sync, a problem that cropped up again in his first summer as a pro. If he winds up in the bullpen, he has closer upside.

PERSON burst onto the prospect scene in 2015, hitting 10 homers in 48 games in the ORGANIZATION at age 17. He signed as a shortstop but has moved down the defensive spectrum to right field, retaining his loose, lefty swing and physical projection. In the interim, PERSON has had maturity and consistency issues, which he appears to be moving past now. Longer-limbed power hitters typically take the longest to develop offensively, making his pro debut that much more surprising. He'll be 21 years old next year, with a chance to get to Double-A and regain the everyday player projection some saw in 2015.

The ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the fourth round of the 2015 GPE, making him the highest-drafted player to come out of GPE. The top ORGANIZATION II prospect in his GPE class, he signed for $484,000, made his pro debut at ORGANIZATION A Short-Season Tri-City and then earned All-Star honors while finishing sixth in the batting race (.320) at ORGANIZATION A Fort Wayne in first full season. He made even greater strides at the plate with PERSON in 2017, especially in the power department.A left-handed hitter with bat speed and strength, PERSON is an offensive-minded backstop who knows how to drive the ball and projects to hit for power and some average. He has a knack for making contact and does a good job controlling the strike zone, in turn limiting his swing-and-miss at the plate.PERSON's large frame raises questions among evaluators about whether he can stay behind the plate long term. He has decent hands and some raw arm strength, but his receiving skills are below average and he needs to improve his catch-and-throw skills after throwing out just 20 percent of attempted basestealers in 2016.

PERSON's high price tag as a Draft-eligible sophomore in 2017 scared away many teams, and he ultimately turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 29th-round pick to return to PERSON. As a junior, PERSON once again ranked among the LOCATION's premier starters and helped lead the ORGANIZATION to a runner-up finish in the 2018 College World Series. The GPE, after selecting PERSON in the third round in June, went $436,800 above slot to sign the right-hander for $1.1 million.PERSON may be extremely skinny, listed at 6-foot-3 and 165 pounds, but he has some power to his fastball, which sits at 90-94 mph and peaks at 97. He also has a mid-80s slider that has a high spin rate and qualifies as a plus pitch at its best. He also will mix in an effective changeup and a curveball he can throw for strikes. PERSON has a quick arm and generates velocity without much effort in a repeatable delivery that allows him to fill the strike zone.PERSON's stuff stands to improve in the professional ranks if he can add weight to his wiry frame. It also would help answer questions about his durability, especially after PERSON held him out of summer ball for two straight years and limited him in fall practice as a junior. It's a mid-rotation profile if all comes together for PERSON, though he's likely to be brought along slowly given the relevant concerns about his durability.

There's nothing subtle about PERSON. As a freshman, he earned the nickname "PERSON" because of his constant energy and his full-out sprints from the bullpen to the mound. He takes the same approach on the mound, aggressively attacking hitters, and it resulted in school record for saves this spring at ORGANIZATION' stuff has kicked up a notch in his junior season. After pitching with an 88-92 mph fastball last year, he's now operating at 90-95. He also throws a tough upper-80s cutter that he can turn into a mid-80s slider with more break when he wants.PERSON also has a curveball that shows signs of turning into an average offering, though he uses it infrequently and mostly just to give batters a different look. He's not big, but he has a solid build and sound mechanics. He repeats his delivery well, enabling him to throw strikes and keep the ball down in the zone.

One of 20 players in baseball history taken in the first round of two GPE, PERSON went 21st overall to the ORGANIZATION in 2011 and 14th overall three years later, when he helped ORGANIZATION win the 2014 College World Series. Signed for $2,613,200, he led the Double-A PERSON with a 2.81 ERA in 2016, then got knocked around in Triple-A last year before a groin injury truncated his season in mid-July. He made his big league debut with a pair of starts this April, but pitched so poorly after returning to Triple-A that the ORGANIZATION shifted him to the bullpen in June to simplify things.PERSON's fastball velocity has fluctuated, in part depending on his usage of sinking two-seamers and harder four-seamers. He spent much of 2017 working at 90-93 mph after spending the previous year at 92-94 mph with a high of 97. The quality of his curveball and cutter vary as well, leaving his fading changeup as his best and most consistent secondary offering.PERSON's control has slipped this year and his command is even less reliable, leaving him more hittable than he should be. Some club officials believe he'd be best served by simplifying his pitch mix and attacking hitters with his four-seamer, a true slider and his changeup. Reducing his arsenal could make it easier to refine his pitches and realize his upside as a mid-rotation starter.

After PERSON came out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE and dominated both in his pro debut and in the ORGANIZATION in 2014, he looked poised to get to GPE in a hurry. His trip was delayed when he scuffled with a move to Double-A in 2015, though he righted the ship with a bounce-back 2016 season that saw him reach Triple-A for the first time. However, his progress was slowed by a shoulder strain that forced him out for the first two months of the 2017 season.With renewed confidence and a more streamlined delivery that was consistently online, PERSON had better results. His velocity ticked upward, sitting consistently in the 94-96 mph range and thrown with good movement to get ground-ball outs. His slider also improved and he continues to refine it. He actually has shown glimpses of a decent changeup, but he doesn't use it enough. His command got better, thanks to his online delivery. He can still get under the ball at times with too much of a low-3/4 slot, which impacts both his command and the quality of his pitches.Hard-throwing right-handed relievers are becoming a depth position for the ORGANIZATION farm system and PERSON once again looks like he belongs in the group that will help out in GPE soon.

PERSON has the quintessential rags-to-riches story. He was released by the Phillies in 2009, picked up by the ORGANIZATION after a long layoff from affiliated baseball in 2013, then pitched his way from A ball to the big leagues in 2014. PERSON was a starting pitcher when he first joined the ORGANIZATION organization, making 12 starts in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. The ORGANIZATION moved the left-hander to the bullpen and sent him, at age 25, to the LOCATION. He went from GPE to GPE and up to GPE before becoming a surprising September callup. Along the way, he struck out 14 batters per nine innings in the Minors while not walking a ton of batters, using a fastball in the 90-93 mph range and a plus slider that's absolutely killer on left-handed hitters. PERSON is likely never going to be more than a lefty specialist, but those who can establish themselves in that job can pitch for a very long time.

In an age when radar gun readings often rule the day, GPE stood out on the summer showcase circuit more with his feel for pitching than plus velocity. He threw 12 shutout innings for the 18U GPE National Team, and there was a reason he got the ball for their gold medal game against GPE, won by GPE thanks to his six scoreless frames.There are better fastballs among the deep high school pitching crop in this GPE class, but GPE's pitchability is what separates him. That's not to say he doesn't have good stuff, because he has the potential to eventually develop three pitches that could garner a 60 on the 20-to-80 scouting scale. He'll throw his fastball in the 89-94 mph range, maintaining the velocity throughout his starts, and he opened some eyes by touching 96-97 mph frequently in the early stages of the spring. He's also made mechanical changes to vastly improve his command of the pitch. He throws a slower curveball with three-quarters tilt and good spin rate and introduced a new, and very effective, slider this spring. And his changeup gives him a third secondary pitch that could be plus when all is said and done.The top left-hander in the GPE class, GPE has thrown well enough this spring to cement himself as a potential top 10 pick in June.

Born in GPE, PERSON attended high school in GPE. His elbow blew out when he was a senior, just as he was experiencing an uptick in velocity. WHen he returned, so did his mid-90s fastball. PERSON was traded as part of a package for several good A's relievers. He's advanced from a stuff and pitchability standpoint, enabling him to succeed at Double-A already at age 20. He's a potential mid-rotatino starter.

PERSON may not be quite as advanced as the other top high school pitching prospects in the 2015 Draft, but he may deliver quality velocity as easily as any of them. He works at 90-92 mph and tops out at 96 while looking like he's just playing catch. He could sit in the mid-90s once he fills out his 6-foot-4 frame and gets more consistent. While his curveball and changeup have a ways to go, PERSON has some power and depth to his breaking ball and some fade and deception to his changeup. His athleticism and lack of effort in his delivery bode well for his ability to throw strikes.He's part of the same ORGANIZATION Community program that spawned PERSON, who went on to GPE PERSON and became the 13th overall pick in the 2014 Draft. PERSON has committed to PERSON.

GPE was the ORGANIZATION' top prize in the 2012 international signing class. They've given him challenging assignments, and he was among the youngest everyday players in his league in each of his first two professional seasons. GPE has a short, compact body that is well suited to a career behind the plate. He has a quick release and strong arm, and he will shut down the running game as he gains more experience. He's making strides with the finer points of catching, including game calling. While defense is the strongest part of GPE's game, he has the tools to develop offensively, as well. The potential to be a top-notch all-around catcher is there, but he will be just 19 for all of the 2015 season and remains a long way from a finished product.

Some international prospects come to the GPE and are, at least initially, overwhelmed. Not so for PERSON, who made his GPE debut in 2012 and was among the ORGANIZATION leaders in a host of offensive categories. He continued his strong play in Class A LOCATION in 2013 until being traded to the ORGANIZATION in August as a part of the deal that sent PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION. While PERSON isn't the biggest guy in the world, he's shown he can really hit and projects to be an above-average hitter in the future, with more power than you'd expect from a guy his size. A well-above-average runner, the GPE infielder should be able steal bases consistently, and that speed should also help him with his range as he continues to improve at second base.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

UC PERSON had a pair of pitchers from its staff get drafted in the top five rounds in 2015, with PERSON going No. 4 overall and PERSON landing in the fifth. GPE with power projection and pretty swing that likely ends up in right field. Some see him as a more physically projectable version of PERSON.
