PERSON's above-average speed makes him a threat on the basepaths, and he's improved his basestealing efficiency to maximize that tool. Defensively, PERSON has already played a number of positions, mostly in the middle infield, though he has seen time at third and even in the outfield. He has the range, quickness and arm for the left side of the infield and the ORGANIZATION had him playing shortstop during his first season in the organization, though his versatility could come in handy in the future.

An exceptionally athletic, twitchy and lean high school catching prospect, PERSON is a potential plus defender with a plus arm and visible leadership qualities. He also has a chance to grow into above average raw power, but scouts aren't sure if he's going to hit.

Â PERSON was lightly scouted as a lankly and soft-tossing left-hander, but the ORGANIZATION took a flier on the local high school product in the 19th round. Since then, PERSON has made significant strides, and he was one of the key pieces PERSON acquired in exchange for PERSON at the 2013 PERSON Deadline.PERSON's velocity has improved significantly since he signed. His fastball now sits around 90 mph, and it has reached as high as 96 mph. While PERSON's already gotten stronger since signing, there's even more projection left in his frame. His body type and his low three-quarters arm slot lead to comparisons to PERSON Sale.Even with all of his advances so far, PERSON still has plenty of room for growth. His secondary pitches have good potential, but they are inconsistent. PERSON needs to refine his command. He started making those adjustments in 2014 at ORGANIZATION A Lancaster, where he has thrived despite pitching in one of the most hitter friendly parks in the ORGANIZATION.

GPE is rare because he's a righty hitter and lefty thrower and also because he's a standout defender already despite only being an average runner. He has some pop and feel to hit, but there's still some uncertainty about his offensive impact.

Left-handed-hitting middle infielders are always a hot commodity, and PERSON seemed to be cementing his place in the top three rounds as the GPE approached.Oregon State always does a good job of recruiting in its own backyard, finding solid, hard-nosed players to commit. PERSON definitely fits that description, getting very high marks for his intensity and hustle. He has some outstanding tools to go along with his plus makeup, especially his above-average bat that sprays line drives all over the field. PERSON has excellent speed, which helps him as a basestealing threat and in covering ground on the infield. He has the instincts, range and hands to play shortstop with an average arm, though some think he might be best suited for second base.There is little question, however, that PERSON can stay up the middle and develop into an exciting top-of-the-order table-setter in the future.
A 2018 7th round senior sign, PERSON's combination of power and chance to play several positions (including catcher) makes him an interesting potential bench piece.

One of the biggest pop-up guys this spring, GPE sent scouts scurrying to PERSON amid reports that he was hitting 96 mph with his fastball and 86 mph with his slider. While he only flashes that type of stuff rather than maintains it, it's possible that he could sneak into the top three rounds.Though GPE's fastball can climb into the mid-90s, he doesn't tend to hold that velocity and often works at 88-92 mph. His slider has its moments too but he throws it too much and it often devolves into a less powerful pitch with slurvy break.Also a star quarterback for PERSON, GPE has the athleticism and frame to remain a starter. To do so, the ORGANIZATION recruit will have to become more consistent with his fastball and slider, develop a changeup and improve his control and command.

A heady high school infielder from the ORGANIZATION, PERSON really jumped on the map when he made ORGANIZATION's 18 and under national team as an underclassman in 2017. PERSON during the 2018 Tournament of PERSON carried over to the rest of his summer, but he used those difficulties to motivate him to return to a level of consistency during his senior year in Washington.When PERSON is going well, he can do a little bit of everything well, even if he doesn't have a carrying tool that jumps off the page. The switch-hitter can drive balls in the gaps and can stay inside the ball and go the other way when needed while showing good command of the strike zone. There's bat speed and he could eventually approach average power when he physically matures. PERSON runs well and has excellent instincts, both on the basepaths and defensively, where he is a natural leader. He has the hands, actions and arm to play shortstop, though some think second base might be his long-term home. He's also athletic enough to handle the outfield if need be.PERSON gets as high marks for his feel for the game and intelligence as he does for his tools. Whether he gets drafted early enough to forego his commitment to ORGANIZATION remains to be seen.

Sometimes in baseball, a player has to take a step back before he can take a step forward. Perhaps putting too much pressure on himself to get to the big leagues in 2015, PERSON struggled with his move to Triple-A. The ORGANIZATION are hopeful the lessons learned will help the powerful outfielder reach the highest level soon.PERSON still has as much raw pop as just about any prospect in baseball. Few doubt his ability to hit 30 homers annually if he's an everyday player, even with his difficulty in making contact. PERSON will always rack up strikeouts and he spent too much time in 2015 trying not to do so. He does need to improve his pitch recognition and plate discipline, with the hopes that a healthy walk rate will help offset the swinging and missing. PERSON runs well for a big man and his strong arm plays well in right field, where his power also could profile well.Once thought to be the top prospect in the system, PERSON needs to stop pressuring himself to perform as such. A little selectivity can go a long way as his power will play at any level and in any park if he can improve that aspect of his game.

An Ontario native, GPE pitched one season at ORGANIZATION State JC (Okla.) before transferring to ORGANIZATION and serving as the team's closer in 2014. He signed with the ORGANIZATION for $25,000 as a 10th-round pick that June, but missed the entire 2015 season while recovering from PERSON surgery. He returned to the mound fully healthy last June and impressed as part of Class A Lansing's starting rotation, his first work as a starter since 2013, and he's made even greater strides this season as a member of Class A Advanced PERSON's starting rotation. GPE has shown plenty of arm strength post-surgery. His fastball sits comfortably at 92-94 mph, with good life and some run, and reaches 96, and it's easy to see GPE, with his physically strong frame, adding even more velocity. His power slider gives GPE a second above-average pitch, and he's capable of missing bats with both. His changeup is well below average, however, and he'll need to at least make it a viable offering to remain a starter.Most scouts think that GPE will eventually return to the bullpen, where his fastball-slider combination could make him a late-inning option. But with his success over the last two seasons, GPE is looking more and more like someone who can stick as a starter.

PERSON was ORGANIZATION's No. 19 international prospect in July 2016 when the ORGANIZATION inked the GPE for $1.25 million. After he unofficially got his feet wet in the ORGANIZATION Winter League, he turned in a very solid first full season of pro ball, earning a promotion from the Class A Advanced PERSON up to the Double-A PERSON in 2017.PERSON hit well during his time in GPE, a notorious pitcher's park and league, and held his own upon reaching Double-A. He showed an ability to make consistent contact with excellent bat speed and more extra-base thump than anticipated, especially before his promotion, though he is hit over power. His overall approach improved after his bump up, as he walked more and struck out less. PERSON runs well and can steal a base, and he's still learning to use that speed effectively in the outfield. He's capable of playing all three spots and the ORGANIZATION feel he's better in center than expected, showing good range going back and to the gaps. His solid average arm works well from the corners.It was a very positive first step for PERSON, one that puts him close to the doorstep of the big leagues. The outfield is obviously crowded in GPE, but he should be ready to fill a need should one arise in 2018 at the ripe old age of 23.

PERSON has been on radars since the ORGANIZATION gave him $3 million to sign out of the ORGANIZATION. Hitting .353 in his GPE debut didnât hurt and heâs tantalized with his skills since. PERSON appears to have put some of the attitude issues he had during his full-season debut in 2011 behind him and it should be noted heâll still be just 20 years old for all of the 2013 season. PERSON earned a promotion in 2012 and his bat should help him continue to move up the ladder. He has above-average raw power and his approach at the plate has improved, giving him the chance to be an outstanding all-around hitter. Heâs always had a plus arm behind the plate, but there had been questions about his ability to handle the defensive rigors of the position in the past. He did seem to make some strides with the glove, though he needs to continue to work on his receiving skills, and the ORGANIZATION hope that can continue.

A 16th-round pick out of ORGANIZATION II LOCATION in 2012, PERSON made strides at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Jupiter in '14, and he then built on that progress with a strong showing in GPE Fall League. That led to a breakout campaign in 2015 at ORGANIZATION and a promotion to the ORGANIZATION in early August. After underdoing PERSON surgery in 2007, PERSON typically sits in the mid 90s and can get up to 98 mph with his heater. His feel for his curveball has improved in the past year to the point where it's at least an average offering. PERSON also can mix in a slider and a changeup, though neither pitch is particularly advanced.PERSON has worked to refine his delivery, and he threw more strikes than ever last year during his time in the LOCATION. His control regressed upon reaching the Majors, but the right-hander's stuff was plenty good. With his size and arm strength, PERSON has the raw tools to be an impact reliever. He's expected to compete for a spot in the ORGANIZATION' Opening Day bullpen.

A native of GPE, PERSON began his collegiate career at ORGANIZATION Community College before transferring to GPE State. After two solid seasons there, he signed as a senior with the ORGANIZATION for $3,000 in the 37th round of the 2016 Draft. He went from organizational filler to interesting prospect by hitting 17 homers across two levels of A ball in his first full season, then reaching Double-A in his second and hitting 21 more home runs. After impressing in the ORGANIZATION, he was sent to the D-backs as part of the package received for PERSON Goldschmidt.The stocky infielder is mostly all bat, but it's a good one. He's shown the ability to make consistent hard contact from the right side of the plate with at least solid average power. PERSON hits a ton of fly balls and showed his power by smashing a dozen home runs in GPE Beach in 2018, an extreme pitcher's park. While he doesn't walk a ton, he did cut his strikeout rate down considerably in 2018 and showed a much better overall approach in the AFL.PERSON has seen time defensively at three infield positions and a little time in the outfield corners. With below-average speed and a fringy arm, his best bet to be a regular will be at second, with a career as an offensive-minded utility type a possibility.

A two-time national champion at GPE, PERSON parlayed a breakout performance in the ORGANIZATION into a big league callup in late 2014, just two years after being taken in the fourth round of the 2012 Draft. He started slowly last season back at ORGANIZATION but got back on track during the second half and earned his second September callup in as many years.During his time at GPE, PERSON developed a reputation as an excellent hitter, one with a good approach and more gap power than anything else. He finally unlocked his power in 2014, more than doubling his home run total from the year prior, though doing so did cause him to deviate from his approach and swing for the fences too often in '15. Despite being a capable defender at first base, the presence of both PERSON and PERSON ahead of PERSON on the organizational depth chart inspired the GPE to give him a look in the outfield during spring training. He passed every test Baltimore threw his way, and has played left field almost exclusively in 2016. PERSON's outstanding work ethic and overall feel for the game allow him to get the most of his raw tools, and with improved consistency at the plate, he could fit the profile of a regular big league corner player.

GPE of a group of college middle infielders who, while not jumping out as impact type bats, could go in the top few rounds, PERSON has been a three-year starter at ORGANIZATION State some like better than the others from that crop.PERSON is the quintessential scrappy college gamer type, but one with some tools he can count on. PERSON has plus speed, his carrying tool on both sides of the ball. It allows him to have enough range to stay at shortstop defensively and to be a base-stealing threat offensively. He has enough arm to play the premium position, though his best chance at being a regular might come at second baseman in the future. What kind of profile PERSON has will depend on his bat. There's no power to speak of, but if he hits he could be a speedy every day guy on the right side of the infield. At worst, there's a high probability of him becoming a valuable utilityman at the big league level.

Though GPE wasn't a highly touted recruit when he arrived at FACILITY, he claimed a spot in the weekend rotation at the start of his freshman season and never relinquished it. He has performed consistently for the ORGANIZATION and could become their highest-drafted pitcher since the ORGANIZATION took PERSON seventh overall in 2010. He's missing more bats than ever this spring and could go in the second round.Scouts quibble about which of GPE's pitches is his best because there are three legitimate candidates. He doesn't blow hitters away with a fastball that sits at 90-92 mph and tops out at 94, but it plays up because he commands it so well and generates good downhill plane and running action. His cutter/slider can be a weapon, though he can fall in love with it, and his tumbling changeup could become a plus offering if he used it more.GPE's athleticism enables him to repeat his high three-quarters delivery and throws strikes with all of his pitches. He even can mix in a curveball for show when desired. He's unlikely to become a frontline starter, but he's one of the better bets in this year's college crop to settle in the middle of a big league rotation.

PERSON had a rocky career at ORGANIZATION, always tantalizing scouts with stuff but struggling with health and control. The PERSON made PERSON their 2015 second rounder, but he didn't sign and fell to the sixth round as a 2016 senior. PERSON simplified his delivery in 2017, which probably contributed to a breakout year. He seemed likely to spend most of 2018 at ORGANIZATION and perhaps reach the majors in 2019, but he had elbow issues during the spring and didn't break camp with an affiliate. His GPE rehab was successful enough for PERSON to get on a mound in games for a bit, but he felt continued discomfort and needed PERSON. The mid-summer timing of the surgery means he'll likely miss all of 2019, which means he'll be back when he's a few months shy of 26. The time crunch alone makes it likely that he ends up in relief, though PERSON could move quickly and be a strong, late-inning piece when he returns.

After landing a modest $45,000 bonus at the relatively advanced age of 18 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON emerged as one of the best arms in the ORGANIZATION' system. He came straight to the GPE for his 2015 pro debut and earned rapid promotions in each of his first three pro seasons. His control lapsed last year, but he still recorded a 3.44 ERA at two Class A stops because he was able to overpower hitters. He reached Double-A for the first time in GPE, only to then be dealt to the ORGANIZATION later in the month with PERSON and PERSON in exchange for PERSON. PERSON can blow his fastball by hitters, ranging from 93-99 mph with two-seamers with nice sink and four-seamers with explosive riding life. He also can produce wipeout breaking stuff when he's on, though there are times when he can't find the strike zone with his slider or curveball. He uses a splitter as a changeup, and it likewise can elicit swings and misses or avoid the plate.Opponents struggle to make solid contact against PERSON, who has four pitches that can grade as plus or better but lose effectiveness when he can't tame them. He's athletic enough to figure out control and command, but his delivery has timing issues that have prevented him from throwing consistent strikes. His walk rate jumped from 4.5 per nine innings in his first two seasons to 6.5 in his third, a sign that he's more likely to become a late-inning reliever than a frontline starter.

A second-round pick in 2014, when he won ORGANIZATION USA player of the year honors while at ORGANIZATION, PERSON didn't have much offensive success above low Class A until last season. Despite missing two weeks with a concussion, he set career highs in most categories, including batting (.274), slugging (.485) and homers (17). But after hitting well in Double-A last August, he hasn't been able to replicate that success in 2018.PERSON is at his best when he shortens his right-handed swing, enabling him to pull pitches more consistently. His strength and the loft in his stroke could produce 15 or more homers per year with regular playing time at the big league level. He has gotten more aggressive as he has progressed through the ORGANIZATION and will need to tighten his strike zone to succeed against more advanced pitching.PERSON has worked hard to get better defensively. He has made himself into an average receiver and also has enhanced his footwork and accuracy with his throws. Because PERSON already has the game's best catcher in Buster Posey and spent the ORGANIZATION. 2 overall pick in the 2018 Draft on another backstop in GPE, he may never be more than a backup and has begun playing first base to add to his versatility.

GPE has the class' most electric arm and he somehow finds a way to throw strikes even though his arm action is all over the place. His arm slot's variability alters the shape and plane of all of his pitches and really isn't sustainable, long term. He'll need to find mechanical consistency to start. If he does, because he pretty clearly has the best raw stuff in the class, he has its highest ceiling.

Thought to be one of the best college pitching prospects at the start of the 2015 season, PERSON slumped late in the year, causing him to slide to the ORGANIZATION at ORGANIZATION. 35 overall. He opted to return to GPE for his senior year rather than sign and struggled for much of the 2016 season. This time around, though, he bounced back late and landed in the fourth round, getting a $750,000 bonus, more than $200,000 above pick value.PERSON worked at 92-94 mph, touching as high as 97 mph for much of his junior season, but was down to 88-92 mph with a slider that wasn't as sharp and a changeup that wasn't as effective as it had been in the past, and he struggled with command, something that was an issue at times in his college career. Some chalked up the regression of his stuff to slower arm speed, but that rebounded down the stretch, and some scouts felt he was throwing better than he ever had at the end of his senior campaign.If the Tigers can harness the PERSON that showed up for most of 2015 and at the very end of 2016, they might have a mid-rotation starter, and a fourth-round bargain, on their hands.

It's becoming fairly clear that PERSON simply hits. He hit in the ORGANIZATION, then finished second in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION in batting average during his 2011 GPE debut. The move up to the LOCATION in 2012 didn't faze him as he continued to show the ability to make consistent contact. The young ORGANIZATION has shown a pretty good approach at the plate and while he's not the biggest guy in the world, he might have a litte extra-base power. He has excellent speed that should help him on the basepaths. PERSON played multiple positions in the past, but settled in at second base in 2012 and it looks like he should be a solid defender there.

GPE has parlayed a strong Cape showing into attention this spring where he flashes #3/4 starter upside with a low-to-mid-90's fastball and a plus changeup. Went lower than talent suggested in the draft due to needing TJ after signing.

PERSON PERSON's presence in PERSON made the fast-approaching PERSON expendable in trade, and PERSON sent him to GPE for PERSON at the 2018 deadline. A 2017 breakout that saw PERSON slug .424 at ORGANIZATION seemed to be a mirage when he hit just .245/.303/.350  for three months at ORGANIZATION (that power output is closer to career norms), but after the trade PERSON slugged .562 and his ground ball rate dropped from 44% to 33% in about a 100 balls-in-play sample, which should be fairly stable. If there's suddenly more lift here then PERSON could be a top 100 prospect by mid year. He's going to stay at short (plus range, average hands, above-average arm) but the average big league shortstop had a 95 wRC+ last year and PERSON is a very aggressive hitter likely to run below-average ORGANIZATION. If there's been a swing change (his swing with PERSON was not conducive of power) then extra pop might propel PERSON toward toward regular playing time. If not, he's a low-end everyday player or utility man.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, an ORGANIZATION commit, was named to the ORGANIZATION team at the 2016 Perfect Game National Championship and was also a preseason All GPE in both 2015 and 2016.Schroer has a large frame and a well-proportioned body. The right-hander has fair command of both his fastball, which sits at 87-88 mph, and his curveball, which lacks consistent bite.Schroer is still developing his power but makes solid contact and has a medium-length swing with an uppercut finish.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION back in 2011, PERSON has always intrigued with his size and arm strength. Pegged for the bullpen very early in his pro career, the big right-hander has the chance to make an impact as a late-inning reliever in the future.PERSON has always thrown hard, with a fastball that typically sits in the mid-90s. He can reach back for something extra and touches 98-99 mph with regularity. He scrapped a curveball for a developing, and more effective, slider and he'll mix in a changeup on occasion to keep hitters honest. Especially for a power arm, PERSON does an excellent job of throwing strikes, though he was more hittable than one would expect when he made his full-season debut in 2014. Some of that could be attributed to the bandbox in GPE, and he made a big step forward as he moved up the ladder in 2015, finishing the year in Double-A, opening some eyes in the ORGANIZATION and earning a spot on the 40-man roster.Giving someone a "future closer" label is always dangerous, but if PERSON can continue sharpening his breaking ball to go along with his plus fastball, he has the potential to make that kind of contribution.

GPE is a commodity that's hard to come by in prospects. When one combines it with an outstanding college season swinging the bat, he's likely to rise up ORGANIZATION boards. That's what happened with ORGANIZATION, who hit .384 as a GPE junior to land him at pick No. 33 in 2017. Though he was banged up, he had a strong pro debut in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League and was holding his own during his full-season debut in the GPE League until a sprained elbow shelved him in June. A move to Double-A in 2019 produced mixed results and he was sent to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON in mid-July.ORGANIZATION should be able to use his legs to wreak havoc on the basepaths. He's still learning his left-handed swing and he had a tendency to hook balls on the ground early on. He's now working on getting some separation so he can impact the ball, and he's learning to slash the ball to the left side so he can use his legs to help him more. The combination of approach and speed could make him an above-average hitter, albeit one with little power, in time. It's unclear what ORGANIZATION's long-term defensive home will be. He's unorthodox defensively at short, with a fringy arm, but he does have impressive range. He impressed in big league camp during 2018 Spring Training, playing on both sides of second base. He also played some outfield in college, though he's played shortstop almost exclusively as a pro.It could be that ORGANIZATION ends up fitting a super-utility role at the big league level, with his speed playing at a number of positions, though it's too early to rule out an every day gig at second base. Most importantly, he's making up for lost at-bats in 2019.

PERSON was a part of GPE's back-to-back national championships and has established a long track record as a successful hitter. He adjusted well to the professional ranks, reaching Double-A PERSON in his first full professional season.PERSON has a good approach at the plate and has an excellent feel for the barrel. He has unlocked more of his power as a professional, and he blasted 20 home runs in the first half with PERSON in 2014. Defensively, PERSON is strictly a first baseman, but he has the tools to be a solid defender.PERSON earns praise for his understanding of the game, and as he taps into more of his raw power, fits the traditional first-base profile better now than scouts thought he would when he was at GPE.

Stop if you've heard this one already. Here's another high school catcher with a chance to be impressive on both sides of the ball.Left-handed-hitting catchers are always a hot commodity, and PERSON has the chance to really hit at the next level, both for average and power. PERSON love his strength both at the plate and behind it.His best tool defensively is his arm, which is plenty strong enough. He needs to continue to work on the other parts of his glove game, but he shouldn't be one of those prep catchers who will have to move from behind the plate, with the potential to be an everyday catcher at the highest level.

PERSON was listed at 235 pounds on the 2015 Area Code Games roster but was tipping the scales at 260 not long before that. At that event, he was sitting in the 90-92 range with feel for locating a solid-average curveball. He looked like a mature-bodied pitchability prospect whose stuff might be done improving. During that fall and winter, though, PERSON began to reshape his physique. He dropped about 50 pounds and came out the following spring with much better stuff, his fastball creeping into the 93-95 range and touching 97. 
PERSON and his stuff have continued to improve, though he had a somewhat chaotic 2018. He missed the season's first 50 games due to a suspension for the use of an unknown stimulant, then had his season debut pushed back due to a lat strain. He finally toed the rubber at ORGANIZATION in June and made five four-inning starts before he was removed in the first inning of his sixth outing and placed on the ORGANIZATION with an oblique strain. He missed a little over a month, then made two more starts in August before feeling lat discomfort warming up for what would have been a third. He was shut down as a precaution and sent to the ORGANIZATION to pick up innings. 
His stuff was wholly intact in GPE, as PERSON sat 93-97 and touched 99. His apparitional changeup haunts both left and right-handed hitters, disappearing beneath barrels as it approaches the plate. PERSON's array of breaking stuff is well-designed. His power 12-6 curveball honors his GPE heritage but has been de-emphasized as an out pitch in deference to his tilting, mid-80s slider. He has the best collection of stuff in the minor leagues, and might have been in the big leagues last year if not for various setbacks. He may be on somewhat of an innings limit this year because he didn't pitch all that much in 2018, but barring that, we expect he'll help the ORGANIZATION cause at some point in 2019.

One of the better prep hitters in the 2015 Draft class, PERSON, who went by PERSON at that time, signed for $2.7 million as the ORGANIZATION. 15 overall pick. While he hit well that summer in his pro debut, finishing with a .309 average, PERSON has struggled at the plate in each of the next three years, showing little in the way of average or power, albeit as a younger player at each level, as his prospect stock declined. That changed in 2019, though, as PERSON rebounded remarkably to hit for average and produce legitimate power numbers while climbing from Double- to Triple-A. For years PERSON was unable to find his comfort zone as a hitter, and he looked particularly lost at the plate in 2018, setting up so far off the plate with an open stance that his front foot was borderline out of the batter's box. PERSON's stance, along with his naturally passive approach, opened the door for pitchers to attack him, and he struggled to drive the baseball even when he got a hittable pitch. The ORGANIZATION determined that PERSON's point of contact was consistently too deep, and they worked with him ahead of the 2019 season on hitting the ball more out in front. The results from that adjustment have been staggering, as PERSON is now clearing fences with ease while consistently driving to ball from pole-to-pole. What's more, he's tapped into that power without it detracting from the plate discipline and on-base skills that have been a staple in his pro career.An average runner who earns high praise for his ability to read pitchers and steal bases, PERSON swiped a career-best 38 bases in 2017, but just 11 last year in Double-A. Defensively, PERSON primarily plays left field but has seen time at all three outfield positions throughout his career.

Performing well in the ORGANIZATION is always a plus for college hitters, and PERSON set himself up extremely well this summer, winning the ORGANIZATION MVP award while reaching double-digits in home runs and steals.PERSON's a good pure hitter with some pop, and he has plus speed to go along with it. That speed allows him to play a good center field.The only knocks against him might be that he's not the biggest guy in the world and he doesn't play for a huge college power in GPE. He continued to perform like he did in the ORGANIZATION during his junior season, keeping many teams very interested.After a very strong sophomore season on both sides of the ball, PERSON kept it going for ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION over the summer. He carried it over to his junior season, pitching and hitting well for the 'Zags. Clearly a very good athlete who can handle the bat, it's his left arm that could have him drafted in the first round in June.

PERSON was a high profile amateur, closing for ORGANIZATION and PERSON before PERSON took him in the third round in 2015. They didn't add him to the 40-man this winter and the ORGANIZATION took him in the Rule 5 as an MLB-ready middle reliever who flashes two plus pitches at times. The bump in the road that led to not adding PERSON to the 40-man roster was a shoulder aneurysm that derailed his 2016 season. He needed a surgery that transplanted a vein from his groin into his shoulder in order to repair it, and the industry worried at the time that the injury threatened his career. His above-to-plus stuff is back and PERSON is at least a big league-ready middle reliever with a chance to be a set-up man. There was some suggestion by scouts that PERSON wasn't the type of pitcher who excels with all of the data and information that PERSON offered; PERSON's approach with him will reflect that. UPDATE: PERSON was returned to the ORGANIZATION on 6/24/19.

GPE has as much raw power at age 19 as many mid-20s 4A sluggers do. He's going to have elite raw power at peak and leads the minors in home runs, but beware of all the whiffs. He could be baseball's top prospect in a year if he solves his contact issues.

GPE's best prep pitching prospect since PERSON went 12th overall to the ORGANIZATION in 2006, PERSON helped PERSON win the 18U World Cup in GPE in September. Coached by his father PERSON at GPE (Ala.) High, he's part of a typically strong ORGANIZATION recruiting class. He has been better than ever this spring, impressing a throng of scouts with a shutout at the ORGANIZATION in March and pitching his way into the upper half of the first round.PERSON spins one of the best curveballs among high schoolers in the 2016 Draft class, a 76-80 mph bender with good depth, though he can fall in love with his breaking ball at times. He also throws an 88-94 mph fastball with deceptive angle and some late life. Both pitches figure to add more velocity once PERSON strengthens his athletic frame.PERSON has feel for a changeup that has shown signs of developing into a plus pitch as he has used it more as a senior. With his loose, whippy arm and clean delivery, he shouldn't have trouble remaining a starter in pro ball. PERSON has a ceiling of a No. 2 starter and a relatively high floor for a high school pitcher.

A 2014 Freshman All-American as a third baseman at FACILITY, PERSON has spent the last two years behind the plate. His offense has suffered and his defense is inconsistent, yet he still flashes enough ability to project as a big league catcher if he can make some refinements. PERSON has good feel for hitting and makes consistent contact from the right side of the plate, though he walks infrequently. His strength stands out more than his bat speed and most of his current pop comes in the form of doubles, but some scouts think he could develop average power. Whichever team drafts him also could return him to the hot corner and hope his bat shows the promise it did two years ago.It's more likely that PERSON will enter pro ball as a catcher. He can demonstrate solid arm strength and reliable receiving skills, though at times his release gets too long and he'll clank balls off his mitt. He's a well below-average runner but has enough agility behind the plate.

The ORGANIZATION stayed in their own backyard for this first-round pick. The former GPE prep star features two above-average pitches, with a fastball that runs up to 94 mph with above-average life and a curve with a three-quarter, tight rotation to it. His changeup, like with many young pitchers, is behind his other offerings, and he needs to improve his overall command. A two-way player in high school, he's a good athlete, which should help him in repeating his delivery in the future. He has outstanding mound presence and aggressiveness on the mound. PERSON was one of the younger players in his GPE class, and though he has passed every test so far, the ORGANIZATION have been careful to bring him along slowly.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of the ORGANIZATION in October 2011, they knew he was all about projection. After making his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2014 and finally getting the chance to play "under the lights" in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2015, that's still very much the case, though PERSON shows exciting glimpses of where he could be headed.Pure stuff-wise, the right-hander who will be 22 for all of the 2016 season has the chance to be a solid starting pitching-prospect. His fastball is plus, touching the mid-90s and occasionally a bit more. More than anything, he needs to work on repeating his delivery consistently so he can execute and command his pitches.Worst-case, PERSON could be shortened up and be very effective as a hard-throwing reliever, but it's way too early to give up on his potential as a starter.

GPE boosted his profile by topping out at 93 mph at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship last October, and he has continued to perform well against top competition this spring. He has plenty of room to add strength and could start reaching the mid-90s regularly once he fills out. He has advanced feel for a changeup, selling it with deceptive arm speed and achieving some fade.After flashing a solid slider on the showcase circuit, GPE has seen it become more fringy this spring and has lost some trust in his breaking ball. He has an easy delivery and repeats it well, allowing him to work both sides of the plate. He's reminiscent of PERSON in the way he works faster than most pitchers while pounding the strike zone.

As the ORGANIZATION approached, the scouting industry was divided about GPE's upside, but there were enough teams who found his offensive profile intriguing to make him a candidate to be taken in the top three rounds.GPE does bring a combination of strength and bat speed to the right side of the plate. He uses a leg kick for timing, whipping his bat through the zone to make loud contact. His power shows up particularly to the pull side and there's hope there will be enough to profile at an outfield corner. A fringy runner, GPE has solid baserunning instincts and while not a burner, he can cover enough ground to be a capable outfielder. Those not in the GPE camp may not think he profiles well enough for an outfield corner, but the team who likes the offensive potential will try to take him early enough to woo him away from his ORGANIZATION commitment.

ORGANIZATION registered on the national scene in 2014 when he threw a complete-game shutout in the ORGANIZATION World Series, capping off two years of effective starting for a top-notch GPE program. His junior season was not as effective, but the ORGANIZATION thought enough of him to take him in the fifth round and watched him turn in another gem in GPE before signing in mid-July. Developing high school catching is a tough exercise. When that catcher comes from a cold-weather area like western GPE, even more patience is needed. The ORGANIZATION initially drafted PERSON from PERSON in the fourth round of the 2013 Draft. He made it to full-season ball in 2015, but missed a large chunk of that year with a foot injury. He receives well and has a strong arm that's allowed him to throw out just over 34 percent of potential basestealers heading into 2019. PERSON started to swing the bat with a bit more authority over the past two seasons and hit well in the GPE League before stumbling post-promotion. A slow heartbeat for a catcher isn't a bad thing, but some added energy could help him reach the big leagues as a backup backstop.

He outhit PERSON (the ORGANIZATION. 2 overall pick in the 2015 Draft) in each of the last two seasons at ORGANIZATION, but it wasn't PERSON's bat that got him drafted in the second round in June. Some scouts grades his fly-catching ability as a 70 on the 20-80 scale. He has a weak arm but that doesn't detract from his overall brilliance in center.Though there's too much going on in PERSON' approach at the plate, he does a good job of making contact and uses his quickness to get on base. He has the speed and instincts to steal bases, though he offers little in the way of power.

The state of GPE features two of the best college shortstops in this year's Draft. PERSON's PERSON looks like a lock to go in the first 10 picks, while PERSON is a projected second-rounder who should supplant PERSON as the highest-drafted position player ever from GPE-Lafayette.Thought he played third and second base in deference to PERSON on the GPE collegiate national team last summer, PERSON is capable of sticking at shortstop in pro ball. He'll need to improve his pitch recognition and learn to tone down his approach to take better advantage of his quickness.

Is PERSON the top shortstop from the ORGANIZATION in this year's class?Let the debate begin.Here's what we know: PERSON has the potential to be a five-tool player and has very polished actions on offense and defense for his age.On defense, he has soft hands and good body control. He has strong arm that continues to improve. He might not wow scouts with explosive actions on defense but he has good range and many project him as an everyday shortstop in the big leagues one day.PERSON has slight upstroke on his swing from both sides of the plate and hits the ball hard from each side of the batter's box. It's clear PERSON has idea of what he wants to do when he steps to the plate. The shortstop has shown gap-to-gap power and that part of his game is expected to improve as he matures. Scouts rave about his overall hitting potential.He trains in the ORGANIZATION with PERSON.

PERSON's development has been a rollercoaster after going in the first round in 2013 out of an Atlanta-area high school. He's always has plus raw power, but his motor, defensive home and in-game contact/power balance have varied year-to-year.

A product of a Mount St. PERSON (GPE) program that has yielded eight big leaguers, most notably PERSON, PERSON was GPE's top prep pitching prospect in 2014, but he slid to the ORGANIZATION in the 21st round because he was committed to PERSON. He's the ORGANIZATION's best pitching prospect since PERSON in 2006, but an inability to throw strikes again this spring got him banished to the bullpen.Splitting his time as a starter and reliever on the GPE, PERSON displayed an interesting four-pitch mix while recording a 0.55 ORGANIZATION and an .086 opponents' average -- both of which would have led the league if he hadn't fallen a few innings shy of qualifying. His best pitch is a 92-94 mph fastball that tops out at 96, though both his hard curveball and slider can be plus offerings at times. He also shows the makings of an effective changeup with some sink.PERSON still has projection remaining in his skinny 6-foot-4 frame, which boosts his ceiling even higher. But he won't reach it if he doesn't throw more strikes, and he still ran into trouble with walks while dominating the GPE. He has a loose arm and a fairly simple delivery, so there's nothing glaring that should hamper his control, but it's becoming increasingly likely that he'll be a reliever in pro ball.

PERSON was a solid 2nd round pick most of the spring, then his velocity ticked up to 90-94, touching 96 mph down the stretch and top scouts were scrambling to get looks at a later-blooming, cold weather arm.

PERSON's broad, square, muscular shoulders look like they belong to a D1 high school football prospect. He has one of the better frames of all the 17-year-old hitters in pro ball, and plenty of room to add power to a body that already produces a lot of it. PERSON has explosive hands and a natural uppercut swing. He hits many more balls out during BP than is typical for a hitter this age, and has taken his peers deep in games, too. 
PERSON's feet and actions are workable on the infield but he struggles with throwing velocity and accuracy when he's forced to throw from a lower arm slot, as shortstops often are. If he can't correct that, he'll need to move to the outfield. If he can, this is a shortstop with 80 bat speed. PERSON is a potential superstar. Much of his profile (the plate discipline, ultimate defensive home) is still not in focus, but this young man has rare physical talent.

PERSON toiled for five summers in the ORGANIZATION system but couldn't get out of rookie ball because of an inability to throw strikes. The D-backs signed him out of indy ball, and while the strike zone still wasn't his friend, the ORGANIZATION rolled very low-risk dice by taking him in the ORGANIZATION phase of the 2015 Rule 5 Draft. He pitched across two levels of full-season Class A ball, got added to the 40-man roster at the end of the 2016 season and made his big league debut in 2017.Earlier in his career, PERSON had some serious difficulty with direction to the plate, contributing to his wildness. That has been addressed with some success, and while he still walks too many, he is able to more frequently attack the zone with his two plus pitches. Even if he's more control over command and getting too much of the plate, he's still successful because of how good his raw stuff is. He'll throw his fastball in the 95-100 mph range, and according to the data the ORGANIZATION collect, he has one of the best curveballs in the system.PERSON came back from his 2016 success with a breakout year in 2017 that saw him get big league innings. PERSON and his teammates from PERSON in GPE spent more than a month in the GPE playing against top high school teams from GPE earlier this year. That said, there's the belief that PERSON could still hit at least 10 home runs when he gains strength. He can also spray the ball to all fields.Scouts view PERSON as a good defender with solid fundamentals, and they compare him to PERSON infield prospect Hak-Ju Lee. PERSON has been scouted heavily by the ORGANIZATION.

For much of his high school career, ORGANIZATION was splitting his focus between baseball and quarterbacking for a football program often known as "Quarterback High."The athletic third baseman gave his full attention to the diamond in his senior year and scouts are intrigued by the left-handed-hitting third baseman's potential. He makes consistent hard contact using a quick stroke. There's power to come, especially given ORGANIZATION's projectable frame that has a lot of room to add strength.ORGANIZATIONlooks like has the tools to stick at third as well, giving him the chance to be a very intriguing high-upside high school hitter in this year's PERSON class.

He doesn't have sleeves (which is the nature of the garment) but PERSON still does a good job hiding the ball from hitters. His deceptive, overhand delivery looks like a trebuchet and creates late carry on his fastball, which sits 94 and touches 97. His secondary stuff is more average, but PERSON's delivery gives him some margin for error when he misses in the zone. He'll still need to improve how he locates his secondaries to miss big league bats and be a roster lock reliever.

PERSON drew a $1.5 million bonus as a 16-year-old in 2015 and he's a perfect example of the reward in signing a top July 2nd prospect as his tools have taken a huge step forward since signing: his run grade jumped from 60 to 80, his arm from 60 to 70, his raw power from 45 to 55 while he's also become arguably the best defender at any position in all of minor league baseball. The only issue for PERSON are tweaking the mechanics of his swing. He needs to lift the ball more and have a stronger base to tap into some of his power and allow his athleticism to play. These are fixable things, he's just turned 19, he has plenty of hitting tools to surive until this point on them alone, the ORGANIZATION rave about his makeup and coachability and his athleticism would be world class in any sport. With little improvement, he's a Kevin Pillar 2-3 win type defensive specialist and his upside is a 6+ win type perennial All-Star.

Because PERSON stood 5-foot-5 and weighed 150 pounds midway through his junior year at GPE (N.C.) High, he wasn't a high priority for the 2017 GPE. But that has changed as he grown six inches, added 20 pounds and emerged as one of the fastest runners available. High-level decision-makers poured into GPE to see him throughout the spring and while he generates some mixed opinions, he might not last past the second round.PERSON famously clocked a 3.85 home-to-first time from the left side of the plate in front of several scouts in mid-April and gets running grades from 70 to 80 on the 20-80 scouting scale. Speed is far from his only intriguing tool, as he's a switch-hitter with surprising bat speed and deceptive wiry strength and also possesses a strong arm.There are some questions with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION commit doesn't always play with a lot of energy and some scouts wonder if he has the hands to stick in the infield, though the worst-case scenario is that he'd still be a valuable defender in center field. He'll be 19 years and three months old on GPE day, making him one of the older players in the 2017 crop.

PERSON was outstanding as ORGANIZATION's ace and finished his college career with a 23-9 record and 2.80 ERA, racking up 285 strikeouts over three seasons. The A's selected the right-hander in the second round of the 2014 Draft, and he offered a taste of his potential in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League after signing for $750,000. Although he struggled during his introduction to full-season ball in 2015, PERSON was able to make some adjustments over the course of the season and finished the year on a high note before truly breaking out in '16.PERSON's fastball sits in the low 90s, topping out at 95-96 mph, and has arm-side run and late sinking action. His curveball projects to be above average and is his best secondary offering at the moment, though he also has good feel for a changeup that could be at least PERSON average once developed. His slider was his go-to out pitch at ORGANIZATION, but it's been below average as a pro and requires further refinement.Though pounding the zone has never been an issue for PERSON, his first full season indicated that the quality of his strikes must improve. Some scouts wonder if he'll have the durability to remain in the rotation, although that hasn't been an issue so far. ORGANIZATION officials believe he has what it takes to be a big league starter, and the club's track record of developing undersized right-handers bodes well for his future in the role.

PERSON has two legitimate pitches and a history of success against top competition, so the ORGANIZATION felt comfortable drafting him in the seventh round in 2015, then giving him second-round money to sign him away from ORGANIZATION. The right-hander showcased his potential during his pro debut in the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League, posting a 1.66 ERA over nine outings including eight starts, but his 2016 campaign came to and end before it even began when he was diagnosed with a torn ORGANIZATION and then underwent PERSON surgery in April.The Arkansas prep's frame doesn't require much projection, but he has a fastball that reached 97 mph last summer in the ORGANIZATION, and generates a lot of sink and groundouts when he works in the low 90s. PERSON has good feel for spinning a curveball, giving him a second above-average pitch, and he also mixes in a fringy slider. His fading changeup should continue to get better as he uses it more often at the next level.PERSON repeats his delivery well, but not without some effort. The ORGANIZATION will develop him as a starter, but some scouts believe the right-hander is destined for the bullpen, which, in the wake of his elbow surgery, could be his long-term home.

PERSON University has had just three players taken in the top 10 rounds of the June Draft since it was instituted in 1965. A fellow Patriots backstop, PERSON hopes to follow in GPE's footsteps, though it's unlikely he'll hear his name as early in the Draft.PERSON has a solid track record with the bat at PERSON, hitting well over .300 in each of his three seasons as a starter, though he did appear over-matched against quality pitching in the ORGANIZATION last summer. For most of his college career, he's shown outstanding contact and on-base skills, drawing as many walks as strikeouts. Early on this spring, he was selling out on his swing trying to get to his power, but went back to his contact-first approach from the left side of the plate and got back to staying through the ball more effectively. PERSON also runs very well for a catcher, even stealing some bases along the way. His best defensive tool is his above-average arm and while he is an acceptable receiver, he does need to work on his setup behind the plate.There's a dearth of catching, especially in the college ranks, in this year's class, which will certainly help PERSON's status. He has a floor as a left-handed-hitting backup with solid contact skills but could develop into a solid regular if everything clicks.

The ORGANIZATION were undeterred by PERSON's torn ORGANIZATION suffered shortly before the 2013 Draft and feel they perhaps got a steal by taking the ORGANIZATION State product in the seventh round.PERSON repaid their faith in him by swinging the bat during his pro debut, which didn't come until the 2014 season because of the knee injury. He has the purest swing in the ORGANIZATION' system, keeping his bat in the zone for a long time. PERSON uses his hands to hit very well and uses the whole field. He's definitely more a hit for average than power guy and might top out at around 12 homers annually, albeit with good on-base skills. PERSON made a lot of strides defensively during instructs last fall, giving more confidence he can stay at the hot corner long-term, something that had been previously questioned.PERSON may never fit the profile of a run-producing corner infielder, but with that smooth swing from the left side, could eventually be a ORGANIZATION Boggs-lite type player.

PERSON was an early 2016 draft 1-1 candidate (mid-90s, plus changeup) before he tore his ORGANIZATION as a sophomore and missed his entire junior year to rehab. His velocity and feel for locating his fastball both regressed in 2018, but they seem to have rebounded this spring. PERSON has been up to 96, sitting 93-94 early in starts before settling into the low-90s later. It's a two-seamer, one that probably pairs best with his changeup, PERSON's best chance of missing bats. He now has two fringe breaking balls, which is a player dev miracle considering there was a stretch when it was unclear if PERSON would ever have just one. He profiles as a sinker/changeup backend starter.

There wasn't a better story at the 2015 ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON than PERSON. He originally signed with the ORGANIZATION for $725,000 in 2006 and stagnated for four years in low Class A before getting released in 2013. He served stints in three independent leagues before signing with the ORGANIZATION last October, and he has put up huge numbers in the upper levels of the Minors this season.If PERSON gets to the big leagues, it will be his huge power that takes him there. He probably won't post high batting averages and on-base percentages, but he has found more success since toning down what had been an all-or-nothing approach. While PERSON has a strong arm and broke into pro ball as a third baseman, he's strictly a first baseman. He's a well below-average athlete and runner who's a shaky defender.

PERSON has a history of hitting wherever he has gone. He batted .404 playing part-time as a GPE freshman in 2010, then won national junior college player of the year honors after hitting .488 at ORGANIZATION (GPE) JC in 2011. He batted .296 in his first two pro seasons -- then noticeably changed his approach in 2013.PERSON' batting average tumbled to .240 in Double-A, but he also bashed 21 homers. He got too power-conscious and tried to pull too many pitches, but there's a happy medium where he can use his formerly shorter stroke and the whole field, and be a solid hitter with average power.Though he's a below-average runner, PERSON shows good instincts on the bases and the outfield. He has a decent arm and has played on both corners, seeing the majority of his time in left field.

PERSON led the ORGANIZATION with a 1.17 ERA in 2012, and PERSON made him the highest player drafted from GPE in the '13 PERSON. PERSON teamed with PERSON, the team's first-round pick, during their professional debut, and the two will be closely linked for the foreseeable future.PERSON throws his fastball in the low 90s, with good sinking action. His changeup is his best offspeed pitch, and his curveball gives him a third quality offering. PERSON throws all of his pitches for strikes, and he aggressively attacks hitters.PERSON doesn't have PERSON's upside, but his stuff and his advanced pitchability could have him moving quickly toward the ORGANIZATION. He profiles as a durable middle-of-the-rotation starter.

PERSON underwent PERSON surgery as a sophomore at ORGANIZATION State but came back strong the next year, and the ORGANIZATION selected him in the first round in 2013. He ably handled a challenging assignment to Double-A Mississippi in his first full professional season, though he headed back there in 2015.When he's on, PERSON pitches down in the zone and gets heavy sinking action on his low- to mid-90s fastball. As a result, he creates a lot of groundball outs and surrenders very few home runs. His curveball and changeup give him two more solid offerings, and he aggressively attacks hitters and throws strikes with all three of his pitches.PERSON earns praise for his makeup and understanding of his craft. He has the makings of a solid big league starter, especially if he can continue to refine his offspeed pitches and command as he gets more innings under his belt.

Every Draft, scouts bemoan the lack of college bats worth considering in the early rounds. That's why when one comes out and outperforms expectations, they tend to move up boards. PERSON's performance at GPE this spring fit that description to a T, as the junior shortstop made across-the-board improvements at the plate while showcasing his usual top-of-the-scale speed. Impressed by PERSON's tools and overall development, the A's selected him with the ORGANIZATION. 33 overall pick in June, and then saved money by signing him for less than slot value.There is no question about PERSON's speed. On his high school track team, he ran a 10.6-second 100-yard dash, and that speed translates well on the diamond. He's a definite basestealing threat, one who knows his job is to get on base and wreak havoc. The only player in ORGANIZATION history to lead the club in hitting in three consecutive seasons, the left-handed-hitting PERSON raked a career-best .384 this spring, all while showing some surprising extra-base pop.After manning second base as a sophomore, PERSON was moved to shortstop this year, where his speed helps him range-wise, but his other skills likely fall short. The A's will deploy him there to begin his career, though most scouts see a move to center field in his future, where that speed would really be an asset.

When two high school shortstops are taken one spot after another, it's bound to create comparison and competition. Perhaps people will take sides in the ORGANIZATION vs. PERSON debate for years, but there's no question both are extremely talented young middle infielders. PERSON didn't head to full-season ball right away, but when he did, he quickly hit his way up a level, then showed off some pop in the ORGANIZATION before getting hurt. PERSON has plus bat speed that should allow him to hit for a ton of power and average, especially if he can refine his approach and gain better plate discipline. Many were ready to move PERSON to third right away, but he showed some ability at shortstop, with a very good arm and good hands. His instincts allow his average speed to play up on both sides of the ball. Even if he has to move to third, his bat should profile just fine there.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

There's not much physical projection here but PERSON has explosive present tools. He's an above average runner with average present raw power and a pull-heavy uppercut approach to contact that lets him get to it in games.

Likely in need of a swing change to profile at first, ORGANIZATION' cut too often slices down at the baseball, and he can only get to his considerable raw power in certain parts of the strike zone. He has good bat control and makes mid-flight adjustments to breaking balls, which he has the raw strength to punish even if the timing of his lower half has been compromised. He's a good hitter, just one we're skeptical will clear the offensive bar at first base without trading some contact for power. ORGANIZATION is also another example of why we should be skeptical of hitters' power numbers at FACILITY.

PERSON is as raw a prospect as is available in this draft and, compounding the risk associated with his profile, he's old for the class. But he's a 70 runner with plus bat speed and has a chance to play a premium position while hitting for power (if he ever learns to hit). So there's huge ceiling here, you just need a telescope to see it.

GPE comes from a baseball family, with a father who made it to Triple-A with the ORGANIZATION, an uncle who played in the ORGANIZATION organization and a brother who currently plays in the ORGANIZATION organization. PERSON has made a name for himself as a three-year starter at PERSON and one of the better performers in the ORGANIZATION Association.A left-handed hitter who plays shortstop for PERSON, GPE could be a favorite of the analytics set because of his outstanding on-base skills and his fairly consistent performance with the bat. He has walked far more often than he has struck out and that, along with his excellent speed, makes him a potential table-setter in the future. There is some raw power to tap into, though it's not a huge part of his game. Stealing bases is and he has been very efficient on that front. Defensively, some see a move off of shortstop, mostly because his fringy arm won't play there. Second base or perhaps even center field might be a better fit.A team taking GPE in the first five rounds will be banking on his bat and on-base skills translating to the pro level. His brother PERSON was taken in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft, 132nd overall, so there could be some family bragging rights on the line.

When PERSON signed for $800,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011, he had a reputation as one of the best athletes on the international market that year. He has lived up to that billing and more than held his own as the youngest regular in the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League last year.PERSON has very quick hands and a patient approach at the plate, which, along with his well-above-average speed, should allow him to hit for high averages. A legitimate basestealing threat, PERSON has the skills desired in a leadoff man. He makes consistent hard contact, and he could develop some pop if he can add strength to his lean frame.PERSON's speed plays well in center field, too, and he throws better than most players at that position. He already has skipped a level, and he could continue to advance rapidly, putting him on track to reach the Majors at age 22.

One of the youngest players in the 2013 Draft class, PERSON began his pro career at age 17, after the D-backs took him in the second round. He spent two years in GPE's system before going to PERSON as part of the ORGANIZATION trade in November 2014. He continued his quick rise through the Minors the following year and then finished his 2016 campaign with his first taste of Double-A. Returning to the LOCATION in 2017, PERSON turned in his best offensive season as he hit for more average and power and tightened his approach. After the season, the ORGANIZATION added him to their 40-man roster. He was finishing up his first season in Triple-A when he was traded once again, this time as part of the package the ORGANIZATION received for PERSON Pham.PERSON began to tap into his raw power in his first Double-A exposure, and that trend continued in '17 in the form of a career-high 14 home runs, though he didn't keep that up in 2018. It's easy for scouts to forecast even more pop in his future because PERSON still produces the majority of his contact on the ground, albeit while effectively using the entire field. With more lift to his swing and improved ability to turn on the ball, PERSON could emerge as an annual 20-homer threat.A shortstop in high school, PERSON was quickly moved to the outfield by the D-backs. He's an underrated athlete who moves well and has the tools, including a solid-average arm, to become an adequate corner outfielder. Still scraping the surface of his offensive potential, PERSON is seemingly a few adjustments away from putting it all together en route to the ORGANIZATION.

GPE isn't especially exciting, as he has a swing that emphasizes contact and allows almost no power, but he's hit everywhere (he won two Cape batting titles), he's a plus runner and he can play shortstop.

A two-sport star at ORGANIZATION, PERSON averaged 11 points and 4.6 rebounds as the ORGANIZATION' starting shooting guard before sliding over to the mound in March. He quickly impressed scouts with his raw stuff, size and athleticism. PERSON generates easy velocity with his loose, easy delivery. He throws his fastball in the low-90s and touched 95 mph this spring. He also throws a slider, curveball and changeup, though his secondary stuff is still developing. PERSON has never solely focused on pitching before and is understandably raw as a result. He has the skills necessary to quickly make improvements once he gets acclimated to playing professional baseball.

Undrafted out of the ORGANIZATION prep ranks, PERSON spent a year at ORGANIZATION (GPE) JC before going to the ORGANIZATION in the 29th round of the 2013 Draft. While he was initially developed as a reliever, PERSON's success in the role as well as his deep arsenal prompted PERSON to give him a shot at starting. After his strong showing in the 2015 ORGANIZATION, PERSON continued to make strides as a starter this season in his return to the Class A Advanced PERSON before moving up to Double-A Montgomery in late May. However, PERSON's campaign was put on hold in early July when, during his fifth start for the ORGANIZATION, the right-hander suffered a broken thumb on a comebacker. Though he's somewhat undersized at 6-foot-1, 175 pounds, PERSON's lightning-quick right arm generates a fastball that can reach 96 mph, and he does a good job of locating it to both sides of the plate. He supports his heater with a sharp curveball that has late, 12-to-6 action that helps him miss bats. He'll also mix in a decent slider as well a changeup that could serve as a third average-or-better offering for him with improved feel.PERSON's four-pitch mix, track record of being difficult to barrel and solid control profile offer something to dream on as a starter, although concerns about his durability and a lack of a true third pitch may ultimately force him back into a bullpen role. Should that happen, PERSON has the stuff to emerge as an effective setup man for the ORGANIZATION in the coming years.

PERSON has missed all of 2017 with a stress fracture in his back. When healthy last year he was 90-94 with a potential plus changeup and future average curveball. He's a draft eligible sophomore and we know even less about PERSON than other eligible sophs because he missed much of his senior year with various ailments, too.

GPE, athletic, albeit undersized catcher who's athletic enough to project behind the plate. Has keen eye for the strike zone, some bat control, but some risk that his offensive tools won't withstand full-season grind due to lack of physicality.

PERSON made adjustments and hit his way to Hi-A as a 19-year-old after a bad first month of 2017. He still chases breaking balls away from him too often but otherwise has great feel to hit and sprays hard contact all over the field. He's a plus runner with the speed to play center field and he should continue to develop there as he accrues more reps (PERSON was a high school infielder and two-sport prospect). He profiles as a table-setting doubles machine.

PERSON played for the GPE Junior National team while in high school and headed to GPE PERSON after going undrafted in 2011. There, he impressed scouts with his big arm and ideal pitcher's frame. PERSON's fastball touched 97 mph when he worked out of the bullpen in college, though it typically sits in the low 90s when he starts. There is some projectability left in his 6-foot-5, 220-pound frame, and he could end up pitching with a tick more velocity. He also has the makings of solid curveball and is working to improve his changeup. PERSON remains somewhat raw, but the Nationals like the upside and feel he can become a Major League starter in time.

We suppose PERSON could catch on occasion, but he probably shouldn't be back there every day due to issues with receiving and mobility. Despite only fitting at 1B/ORGANIZATION, PERSON' combination of power and on base ability make it likely that he finds his way into regular big league at-bats somewhere, especially if the ORGANIZATION is instituted in the ORGANIZATION. His 19% walk rate was among the best in the minors last year, and just 33% of PERSON' balls in play are on the ground. He's a pretty good three true outcomes prospect, a bat-only 1-2 WAR player Ã  la Josh Bell or PERSON, who we'll likely see in the big leagues by 2020.

GPE love the big left-handed hitter's stroke at the plate, and his body reminds many scouts of PERSON. But it is PERSON's lack of foot speed and a below-average arm that have most wondering when -- not if -- he will move from the outfield to first base. He's a solid fielder and has an accurate arm.Overall, PERSON has notable raw power and one of the best rhythm and timing approaches among all hitters in the international market this year. An average athlete, PERSON has always had the ability to hit for average. But now teenager also understands that he has the ability to hit the ball out of the ballpark, and it sometimes affects his approach. One scout said he would not be surprised if PERSON ended up hitting 40 home runs in the big leagues one day.In the end, PERSON offers an intriguing offensive package, which means clubs interested him must decide how comfortable they are with what has been sometimes described as a "high-reward-yet-limited skill set" at this age.

Since signing out of the ORGANIZATION in March of 2013, PERSON has moved slowly up the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION' system. He spent two seasons in the ORGANIZATION before making his GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and earning a promotion up to PERSON and the GPE. The 2016 season saw him go to short-season GPE, where he looked poised to make a big leap developmentally.PERSON was throwing very well in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League, showing a solid three-pitch mix and the ability to command them all. His fastball has been in the 93-96 mph range. He backs it up with a curve that has sharp bite, a breaking ball he's shown the ability to throw for strikes and generate swings and misses. He also has a good feel for his changeup.A teenager for all of the 2016 season, PERSON is still ahead of the developmental curve. He'll have to prove he can start, as all 6-foot-1 right-handers do, but his stuff plus his command should give him every chance to do so.

When the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the third round of the 2017 Draft, the hope was the ORGANIZATION State PERSON product would be the kind of advanced college starter who could move rapidly through the system. While he did struggle a bit when he first got there, he did live up to his advanced billing by reaching Double-A in his first full season.PERSON is all about mixing his pitches, his overall feel for pitching and his command, rather than pure stuff, with three offerings that typically grade out as average. He will show an above-average fastball on occasion, with a tweak to his delivery helping him add a tick, though he usually sits in the 90-93 range. He mixes in his average changeup effectively and he'll show an average breaking ball. His ability to keep hitters guessing and fill up the strike zone will continue to be key for him moving forward.After initially struggling in GPE, PERSON made solid adjustments and pitched very well over the season's final month. If he can continue to show that kind of command and crispness of his pitches, he'll be ready to impact the back end of the ORGANIZATION rotation soon now that he's put the injury in his rearview mirror.

Projected as a possible third-round pick in 2014, PERSON blew out his elbow three starts into his junior season at ORGANIZATION and had PERSON surgery instead. He rejoined the ORGANIZATION rotation midway through the following spring and pitched his way into the fifth round in 2015, signing for a below-slot $300,000. His first full pro season went well, as he made 27 healthy starts and led the Class A Advanced PERSON in strikeouts (155) and strikeout rate (9.9 per nine innings).PERSON relies heavily on his lone plus pitch, an upper-70s curveball with good depth. His fastball operates in the low 90s and is effective because he hides it and commands it well. He has trouble against left-handers because his changeup is fringy, and he'll also mix in a decent cutter.Though he had a successful 2016 as a starter, PERSON may be better suited for the bullpen in the long run. Although he held up and maintained his stuff last year, his smaller stature and his medical history are concerns, and he did miss the first two months of 2017 with forearm tendinitis. His fastball has sat at 93-96 mph in shorter stints and his competitiveness would work well in a late-inning role.

O'Conner became the first-ever catcher taken by the ORGANIZATION in the first round of the Draft when they picked him 31st overall in 2010. He struggled offensively at the outset of his professional career and didn't make his full-season debut until 2013, but O'Conner found his footing in the ORGANIZATION State League the next year and parlayed his breakout into a selection to the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON. His bat regressed considerably with the move to Double-A in 2015, while a back injury has kept him off the field entirely so far in '16.O'Conner's plus raw power is still his best offensive tool, and he utilizes it enough to believe he'll produce double-digit homers as well as plenty of doubles. He's aggressive to a fault, though, as his pop comes with a concerning number of swing-and-misses and few walks. O'Conner's swing, meanwhile, is geared toward driving the fastball, which is why he struggled to adjust to a steady diet of secondary pitches last season.Despite not beginning to catch until his senior year of high school, the athletic O'Conner has transformed into an excellent defender behind the plate. He can shut down a running game with his elite arm strength, showing the ability to unleash rocket throws from a variety of arm angles. While his defense lessens the pressure on his bat, O'Conner must consistently hit advanced pitching to carve out a role in the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was an under-the-radar juco athlete in the 2018 draft class who the PERSON popped in the 11th round. His pro debut went well, with the 20-year-old excelling at both short season clubs for PERSON. PERSON is a plus-plus runner who tinkered with the infield in the spring but fits best in center field long-term. He has a good swing and a chance to be a 50 or 55 bat, which would come with little game power. But that, along with his speed and defense, would help make him a high level reserve or low-end regular. The track record is short and BABIP-fueled, but some blazing runners can do that even in the upper levels, so PERSON is one to monitor.

Some international prospects generate a ton of buzz and get huge seven-figure bonuses. Others sign for a lot less and end up being huge bargains. If his debut in the ORGANIZATION was any indication, PERSON will be one of the latter. The undersized lefty impressed scouts as a 17-year-old in the ORGANIZATION in 2012, but injuries held him back in 2013. When healthy, PERSON shows an advanced feel for pitching for a teenager. He should have an above-average fastball that he commands well, a solid curve and even a feel for his changeup. His secondary stuff is still inconsistent, though time is still very much on his side, even after missing most of the 2013 season.

Ultra-twichy infielder with a good frame (ORGANIZATION body comp) for age. Has quick, short stroke, plus bat speed, and an abbreviated finish thorugh contact. Can lift balls down and in but otherwise the wing is geared for all-fields liners and grounder. Has natural feel for contact, stiff-legged runner with good straight line speed. SS/2B/CF defensive possibilities due to speed/range.

After PERSON finished his career at ORGANIZATION in GPE and wasn't drafted in 2013, he returned home to the ORGANIZATION, thinking his career was over. He went to a tournament after he was home, was seen by a ORGANIZATION scout and was subsequently signed in August as a non-drafted free agent.That non-prospect reached Double-A in late June of 2015, a year after he set a record for the ORGANIZATION in the short-season LOCATION with 48 stolen bases. Speed is his best tool and PERSON is a true burner on the basepaths. It also helps him cover ground in center field, where he's played exclusively during his pro career. At the plate, he has no power to speak of, but understands it's his job to get on base and score runs as a top-of-the-order catalyst. With that in mind, he could improve his plate discipline and up his walk rate.What kind of future PERSON has remains to be seen, but even making it to Double-A far surpasses any expectations.

PERSON had three remarkably consistent years at ORGANIZATION and ended his college career with a .340 average. He has excellent hitter's timing and bat control, and his swing is athletic but compact, enabling not only high rates of contact, but also promising contact quality. That's not to say PERSON will have in-game power. He's a line drive hitter, an old school, two-hole type of hitter, the kind who's sort of an endangered species in the current big league hitting environment. Some teams considered PERSON's lack of power to be a bit of an issue in their pre-draft evals and thought he was more of a tweener fourth outfield type, a projection echoed by pro scouts who saw PERSON in the summer and fall. 
He has plus speed, speed that PERSON exhibited during instructional league even after he had been shut down for the summer with a foot injury. His frame is maxed out and he can't afford to slow down much and still be viable in center field every day, but while this creates some long term risk for his profile, he's fine out there right now. His most likely path to a sizable everyday role involves PERSON out-hitting what we currently have projected for his bat.

GPE has produced a fair share of GPE talent over the years, with PERSON and PERSON the most recent examples to get taken in the first round, both in 2015. But there hasn't been much in the way of middle infielders to come from GPE of the ORGANIZATION and while PERSON may not go as high as that pair in 2015, he does have a shot to be a rare GPE shortstop at the next level.The PERSON A&M commit might be a bit unpolished, but he has considerable tools and upside. He has a decent approach at the plate for his age and experience level, with a natural feel to hit. There should be some power in the future as well. PERSON is a plus runner and uses that speed well on the basepaths. He is capable of making the spectacular play defensively and while his arm might grade out as average, he can reach back for more when needed and he's usually very accurate.
