He worked more at 92-94 mph when he slumped, topping out at 97 on some days and just 92 on others. He had one of the best curveballs in the GPE, a power downer that can climb into the mid 80s, though it too was less sharp in the latter part of the season.PERSON also has a changeup with some sink and deception, but he's likely a reliever long-term because of command and delivery concerns. The ORGANIZATION kept him in the bullpen, and he advanced to full-season ball during his summer debut.

PERSON was the most improved Cape Cod League player from 2016 to 2017, improving his batting line from .229/.301/.321 to .310/.391/.401. He also won the prestigious summer circuit's ORGANIZATION award and established himself as having one of the best combinations of physicality and athleticism among college position players in the 2018 Draft. He and PERSON had a chance to double the number of PERSON hitters ever selected in the first round, following PERSON (1981) and PERSON (2014), though PERSON's up-and-down junior season likely will knock him down to the second.PERSON has exceptional hand-eye coordination, allowing him to repeatedly barrel balls even though he still can get fooled by breaking balls. His left-handed swing presently is geared more to line drives, but his size and strength create plenty of raw power that's more obvious during batting practice than in games. He's a patient hitter who's not afraid to work deep counts and will take walks when he's pitched around.For a 6-foot-4, 220-pounder, PERSON has a surprisingly broad base of tools. He focused on getting in better shape in 2017, improving his speed to above average and looking surprisingly efficient while playing center field on the Cape. He has played mostly first base and right field for the ORGANIZATION, has a solid arm and profiles best at the latter position.

PERSON is a third-generation shortstop from GPE and his familiarity with the game is apparent in his strong natural instincts. PERSON' impressive bat speed and strike zone recognition cause him to stand out as the most advanced hitter in his class. The shortstop is a line-drive hitter now, but his power is expected to increase as he matures and his above-average speed could eventually turn him into a 30-30 player.PERSON' lean frame and natural athleticism project well defensively, too. PERSON is a solid defender now with an arm that flashes plus at times. As he continues to develop, some scouts feel PERSON will turn into a plus defender in the Majors. If he doesn't stick at short, others have suggested that his tools could play in center field if necessary.The Marlins are the favorites to sign PERSON, who trains with his father, PERSON, in GPE.

Slowed by biceps tendinitis in the spring, PERSON's stuff was fine when he returned. He was touching 99 while throwing live BP, and sitting 92-96 during his starts in extended spring training. His 13-start Northwest/Sally League tour, during which he walked just 19 in 54 innings, was the first step toward quelling concerns about his viability as a starter, though we're still somewhat apprehensive here at ORGANIZATION. 
PERSON's repertoire depth is not the issue. Based on his pitch usage during instructional league, his changeup seemed to be a developmental priority, and he has indeed made progress with it. It now comfortably projects to average, while PERSON's fastball/breaking ball combination has been excellent since he was a high school underclassman.  He incorporates all kinds of crafty veteran wrinkles into his delivery's cadence on occassion. An extra shoulder wiggle, a GPE gyration of the hips, the occasional quick-pitch -- all sorts of things designed to take hitters by surprise. PERSON often sentence quirky, visibly fiery and emotional hurlers to late-inning duty, and we do think PERSON would thrive in such a role, but view these traits as positives. PERSON has a unique build and delivery, and is a very short strider whose 5-foot-4 extension sucks some of the perceived velo out of his fastball. This, plus the lower slot, might make him unusually vulnerable to lefties despite his velocity. This, his brief injury history, and still fringy command all contribute to a bundle of relief risk in our opinion.

A teammate of PERSON at the GPE Baseball Academy, PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $984,700 as a supplemental first-round pick in 2012, the same year that the ORGANIZATION made Correa the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall choice. After a slow start to his pro career, PERSON settled in nicely this year in low Class A after moving to second base. The ORGANIZATION acquired him in August as the first of two players to be named in exchange for PERSON Hernandez.The son of 16-year big league shortstop PERSON, PERSON developed tremendous instincts while growing up around the game. A natural right-handed hitter, he began switch-hitting late in his high school career. PERSON won't be much of a power threat, but he controls the strike zone well, and he could develop into a ORGANIZATION. 2 hitter.PERSON has solid arm strength, but his fringy speed and quickness make him a better fit at second base than as a shortstop. If he doesn't hit enough to become a regular, he's capable of playing on the left side of the infield and serving as a utility man.

PERSON is one of the many high-ceiling prep pitchers the ORGANIZATION grabbed in recent Drafts. His early results weren't indicative of his talents, but his tools started to line up with his performance in 2014, as he reached Double-A PERSON as a 21-year-old. After that successful season, he was dealt to the ORGANIZATION as a part of the three-team trade that sent PERSON Myers from the ORGANIZATION to the ORGANIZATION.PERSON throws his fastball, which regularly hits the mid 90s, from a good downhill angle, creating lots of ground balls. His power slider gives him a second above-average pitch, but the development of his changeup will be critical to his future. PERSON' older brother PERSON has pitched in the ORGANIZATION for the past five years. Though it might still be a couple years before PERSON is ready to join him in the big leagues, he has the potential to be a solid starter in time.

On July 12, 2015, PERSON represented the ORGANIZATION, the team that signed him out of the GPE in 2011, in the ORGANIZATION, pitching a perfect inning and striking out two. Less than three weeks later, he was on his way to the ORGANIZATION organization as part of the PERSON trade.PERSON didn't have to go far, traveling from GPE to GPE in the ORGANIZATION State League and bringing his big stuff with him. The 6-foot-4 lefty is all about power with a fastball that sits in the low-90s and has good sink to it when he's throwing downhill. His slider shows glimpses of being above-average and while his changeup needs work, he has enough feel for it to become a Major League average pitch in the future. ORGANIZATION remains the southpaw's biggest problem as he's walked more than 4.5 per nine in his ORGANIZATION career.PERSON has shown glimpses of putting it all together and commanding his three-pitch mix and since he'll be just 22 for all of 2016, so the inclination was to let him keep starting. With his command not improving, the ORGANIZATION moved him to the bullpen in June, where he has the chance to be a power lefty reliever.

A seventh-round pick by the ORGANIZATION out of a GPE high school in 2010, PERSON opted to attend PERSON instead. He ranked seventh in ORGANIZATION Division I with 11.0 strikeouts per nine innings in 2013 -- one spot ahead of GPE. 1 overall pick PERSON -- but PERSON lasted until the fourth round because scouts were concerned that his over-reliance on his slider had sapped his velocity.PERSON's slider still is his best pitch, a mid-80s breaker with a lot of bite. The ORGANIZATION are calling for his slider a lot less than PERSON did, and his fastball has perked up. He's working in the low 90s with good sink that induces a lot of groundouts.The brother of ORGANIZATION third-base prospect PERSON, PERSON has a rudimentary changeup. He shows the control and command to remain in the rotation, though some scouts worry that his crossfire delivery puts too much stress on his shoulder and believe he'd last longer as a sinker/slider reliever.

GPE saw his ORGANIZATION stock begin to take off during his sophomore season at ORGANIZATION, when he took over as the team's everyday catcher at midseason. He improved it even more as a junior this past spring when he was one of three finalists for the PERSON, presented annually to the nation's top amateur catcher, and paced PERSON in on-base percentage while also finishing second on the team in hitting. That improvement at the plate, along with his well-known defensive prowess behind it, earned GPE a $300,000 bonus as the ORGANIZATION' third-round pick. PERSON sent GPE to GPE in return for $1 million in international bonus pool money in December.Regarded by scouts as one of the better defensive catchers in his class, GPE is a true leader behind the dish, one who already knows how to slow down the game and handle a pitching staff. His plus arm is a weapon and helped him nab 60 percent of attempted basestealers as the starter for the ORGANIZATION, and he also receives high marks or his receiving and blocking. That combination could make GPE at least an above-average defensive catcher at maturity.At the plate, GPE has exhibited strong on-base skills and a mature, patient approach, as well as good feel for the barrel and some power potential from the right side of the plate, though that wasn't as evident during his pro debut. While there's plenty to like about his bat, it's his defense that will enable him to carve out a career as a big league catcher.

The ORGANIZATION took PERSON out of GPE State with the hopes he'd be one of those advanced college lefties who could fly through their system. He hasn't disappointed on that front, reaching Triple-A in his first full season. He's not going to wow you with pure stuff and there isn't a ton of projection there, but he has an advanced feel and four pitches to work with. He pitches to contact, and can work his average fastball to both sides of the plate. His slider is the better of his two breaking balls, with late downward tilt and bite. His above-average changeup is plus at times, with good fade. His ceiling is somewhat limited, but he's not far from being ready to step in as a middle-of-the-rotation type in the big leagues.

PERSON was one of the youngest players in the 2012 Draft class and perhaps its best athlete. He was certainly its fastest member and some scouts even believe his speed is comparable to fellow ORGANIZATION native PERSON Hamilton.PERSON' speed is truly elite, but he is more than a track star. If he can refine his aggressive approach at the plate, he has the tools to be a solid all-around hitter. He even has the raw strength to eventually hit for some power. Thanks to his speed, he covers a lot of ground in center field and should be an above-average defender in time.While PERSON remains raw and needs to refine nearly every aspect of his game, he is one of the system's most exciting players.

PERSON is one of the hardest throwing high school pitchers in the 2014 Draft class, but he was dealt a significant setback this spring. He suffered an elbow injury that has kept him off the mound since PERSON, leaving his future uncertain.When healthy, PERSON throws his fastball from 91-95 mph, topping out at 97 mph. He doesn't have a physical frame, instead generating his velocity with athleticism and arm speed. There is some effort to his delivery, and the rest of his game may remain inconsistent until he refines it.His mid-70s curveball will range from a below-average to an above-average pitch, and his changeup shows flashes of becoming an effective offering, but he'll need to throw it more often. PERSON, who plays with his twin brother at PERSON, is committed to GPE.

PERSON was a well-known name to scouts years before he was drafted because as an underclassman, he was great at ORGANIZATION's Tournament of PERSON. That put PERSON (as well as PERSON and PERSON) much further ahead of the notoriety/perceived polish curve than is typical for cold weather hitters. PERSON isn't physically projectable and doesn't have big raw power, so he isn't the sexy upside high school player to whom clubs are drawn, but he does have a long track record of hitting and showing plus defensive ability in center field. He's a plus runner with a plus arm (90-92 on the mound) and gets great jumps on fly balls. There's a real chance PERSON could have four tools that grade out as a 60, along with power that's a 45 or 50, and he's much closer to hitting that upside than most 19-year-olds.

PERSON PERSON was a ORGANIZATION fourth-round pick out of a Mississippi high school in 1983 before playing 14 seasons in the big leagues. His son Ke'Bryan resembles his father as a player and figures to go a couple of rounds earlier in the Draft.PERSON is an advanced high school hitter who doesn't try to do too much at the plate. He utilizes an effortless right-handed stroke and focuses on hitting line drives from gap to gap. He can turn on pitches when opponents challenge him inside and should develop average power.He lacks speed on the bases and first-step quickness, but PERSON has worked hard to get into better shape and improve as a defender. He has good instincts, soft hands and a strong arm that should allow him to remain at third base. Though he has committed to GPE, he's one of the more signable top prospects in the GPE high school crop.

Ever since PERSON was drafted by the ORGANIZATION in the second round out of ORGANIZATION State Fullerton in 2016, there's been a waiting game to see how his fringy stuff/plus command combination would falter as he moved up the ladder. A funny thing happened on the way to his predicted failure: He stumbled in his first year with the Phillies after coming over in the ORGANIZATION deal, but then he adjusted and dominated two levels in 2017, leaving him knocking on the big league door.Despite that fringe-average stuff, PERSON still managed to finish fourth in the system in ORGANIZATION in 2017 while amassing 150 innings along the way. His fastball typically scrapes 90 mph, though he can reach back for a 92-93 mph on occasion. He's tightened up his slider some so it approaches average and he throws his fringy curveball and solid average changeup at will at any point in the count. No one throws more strikes than PERSON, with a career 1.6 walks-per-nine rate that was lowered thanks to his 1.1 BB/9 in 2017.There might not be another pitcher in baseball who does it quite the way PERSON does. He puts all of his stuff in a bowl, mixes it up and it somehow comes out above-average. It's just about time to get him to the big leagues and see if it's for real.

PERSON was a high profile athlete when he arrived on campus at GPE, and some scouts pegged him as the type who would go from a sub-$500,000 player in high school (basically, a talented lottery ticket) to a top two rounds guy in college, and that's exactly what happened. PERSON took PERSON in the first round when he was a plus runner with average raw power, had a good chance to stick at shortstop, and demonstrated surging contact skills. The more pessimistic projections about PERSON's bat ended up being more accurate -- the speed, defense, and raw tools have held steady while he has struggled against pro pitching. In 2018, he repeated Double-A at age 23 and finally hit well, but now will jump two levels to the big leagues as the top pick in the Rule 5 Draft. Offensive expectations are low, in part because PERSON has never been able to tap into his raw power in games, but also because he has needed to repeat levels to find success. That said, some clubs see these raw tools as rare even at the big league level and think there's some low-end regular upside still here with the right coaching.
PERSON was eligible last year but some scouts worried about his durability. This year he's improved his command and the stuff is flashing above average with no durability issues.

Few players in the ORGANIZATION' system had their stock improve in 2016 as much as PERSON, whom the club signed as a catcher out of the ORGANIZATION in January 2012. PERSON, in his age-21 season, hit for both average and power in the Class A ORGANIZATION, and he did so while playing more games at third base than ever before. That success followed PERSON up to the Class A Advanced PERSON in 2017, when he finished third in the circuit in hits (131), total bases (198) and doubles (29).The ORGANIZATION view the switch-hitting PERSON as one of the better pure hitters in the system. He has a discerning eye and a knack for making hard contact from both sides of the plate, though much of his power comes as a left-handed hitter. Prior to his impressive 2017 campaign in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON finished third in the ORGANIZATION in total bases (213), and 53 of his 130 hits went for extra bases (35 doubles, six triples, 12 home runs). And while he may be short and stocky, PERSON is a good athlete who moves well for his size.Defensively, PERSON continues to see some work at third base, though the bulk of his playing time continues to be a first base, where he's an average defender. The ORGANIZATION increased PERSON's versatility even more in 2017, offering him reps behind the plate and in the outfield in addition to his usual work at both infield corners. That versatility will be key for the ORGANIZATION in getting PERSON's bat to the ORGANIZATION.

How much do the ORGANIZATION believe in PERSON? In GPE, managing general partner PERSON labeled him untouchable in trade talks, lumping him in with much more famous prospects PERSON, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON. Two months later, after PERSON recorded 11 straight scoreless outings in the big leagues, GPE added him to its PERSON Game roster.Not bad for a 13th-round pick in 2012 who signed for $100,000 out of GPE. PERSON has an unorthodox delivery that adds life and deception to his pitches, making him tough to hit when he throws strikes. His main weapons are a 92-97 mph fastball and a low-80s slider, and he'll also mix in a changeup to keep hitters off balance.PERSON has breezed through his first four years of pro ball, posting a 2.23 ERA and allowing just four homers in 184 1/3 innings. If he can reduce his occasional control lapses and stay healthy -- he missed time at the start of the 2013 and 2015 seasons with shoulder issues -- he shows the potential to be more than just a situational lefty.

The son of former All-Star pitcher PERSON and younger brother of GPE infielder PERSON, PERSON was the first high school position player to be taken in the 2014 Draft, and he signed quickly for pick value, $3,851,000.A former two-way player with a low-90s fastball on the mound, PERSON focused on his middle-infield play as a senior, and the work paid off. He has always had the actions and arm to stick at shortstop, and his plus speed plays well on the bases. He has a solid left-handed swing and uses the whole field to hit. He showed the ability to add some strength this spring and will continue to need to add more muscle as he moves up the professional ranks.A rare high school shortstop who will no doubt stay there, PERSON has the chance to one day become an elite-level talent at the premium position.

A supplemental first-round pick in 2011, PERSON dominated lower-level hitters in his first two full pro seasons and looked like he'd become the ORGANIZATION' next homegrown frontline starter. His inability to harness his stuff began to catch up to him in Double-A in 2014, however, and repeated difficulties last year prompted his move to the bullpen last July. PERSON returned to the rotation this year in his third stint in Double-A but pitched worse than ever.PERSON still has his trademark fastball that runs from 92-99 mph, and he can get swings and misses at the low end of that range with heavy sink and at the high end with sheer velocity. He hasn't shown much feel for his secondary pitches, the best of which is a slider/cutter that stands out more for its upper-80s velocity than its bite.San PERSON hasn't made a final decision as to whether PERSON will be a starter or reliever in the long turn. The bullpen seems to be the more likely destination because high pitch counts won't matter in shorter stints and he won't need to use his fringy curveball and changeup as much. But if he can't develop some semblance of control or command, he won't have a role in the big leagues.

PERSON was the top prep prospect in PERSON in 2016, but a disappointing spring and a college commitment to the in-state ORGANIZATION left him undrafted. He has performed steadily since moving into PERSON's rotation as a sophomore and allowed two earned runs or less in his six of his eight Big Ten Conference starts this spring. He should join teammate PERSON to give the ORGANIZATION two pitchers taken in the top five rounds of the same Draft for the first time since 1994 (PERSON to the ORGANIZATION in the third round, PERSON to the ORGANIZATION in the fifth).PERSON owns one of the livelier fastballs in the college ranks, usually operating at 91-94 mph, topping out at 96 and holding his velocity deep into games. Its running and sinking action mirrors that of his solid changeup, which he sells well and has good separation from his heater. His slider ranges from 81-86 mph and can be an above-average pitch at times, though it lacks the consistency of his other two offerings.While PERSON has some effort in his delivery, he repeats it well and doesn't have any difficulty throwing strikes. He has a relatively high floor as a three-pitch starter with a track record of performance. His ability to generate ground balls will make him useful as a reliever if he can't cut it in a pro rotation.

PERSON tied a GPE high school record with 25 homers in 2011 before attending ORGANIZATION, where he played three positions in three years. After moving from third base to catcher to shortstop, he signed for $200,000 as a sixth-rounder in 2014 and played all three positions (as well as second base) in his pro debut. The ORGANIZATION made PERSON a full-time catcher and will keep him there going forward. There's no doubt that PERSON has the tools and the makeup to stick behind the plate. He has a strong arm and has worked to streamline his release, which helped him throw out 34 percent of basestealers in 2015. PERSON has sure hands and also has made progress improving his receiving and blocking skills.PERSON wore down physically and his offense suffered as a result during his lone season as a college catcher, but he managed the workload better last year. He makes consistent contact and has power in his compact right-handed stroke, but he won't be productive at the plate until he implements a more disciplined approach.

Acquired as part of the return from PERSON for PERSON, PERSON has a near-ready relief profile that might yield multi-inning value because of the depth of his repertoire. He brings 95-98 mph heat from the left side and complements it with a bevy of inconsistent secondary offerings. Opinions vary scout to scout as to which of PERSON's other pitches is best. The changeup has the best movement but PERSON struggles to set it up because he can't locate his fastball consistently. His slider is short and cuttery, the curveball has depth but lacks bite. Taken together, they could be enough to flummox hitters one time through the order, but probably not several times.

PERSON didn't reach a full-season league until 2013, his fifth year as a professional, and hasn't had much success. Yet the ORGANIZATION believe his slow progress and so-so stats belie the life in his right arm and the projection remaining in his skinny 6-foot-5 frame. Unfortunately for him, he blew out his elbow three starts into the 2014 season, had PERSON surgery and won't return to the mound until mid-2015.PERSON's best pitch is a 92-94 mph fastball, and while it doesn't have a lot of life, he does a good job of using his height to leverage it down in the strike zone and get groundouts. He could throw harder as his body physically matures, though his fastball already qualifies as a plus pitch.To make it as a starter, PERSON will have to improve the rest of his repertoire, as well as his control and command. He'll flash some solid curveballs but his changeup is little more than a batting-practice fastball. He falls behind in counts to often, allowing hitters to sit on his heater.

A talented enigma at GPE, PERSON's prodigious stuff was finally deployed with some consistency in 2017 as he struck out a whopping 191 hitters in 141.1 innings. His fastball and curveball are both plus while his changeup, slider and command remain fringey, but fringe command is still more than a grade better than what PERSON showed in college. He's progressing but remains a volatile prospect with #2/3 starter potential

PERSON is the best prospect to come out of ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Ga.), which has produced big leaguers PERSON and PERSON, and 2010 first-rounder PERSON. PERSON' speed and athleticism compare favorably to any of the top prep talents in the 2019 Draft, and he's also one of the better high school hitters available. He draws comparisons to PERSON, though he has considerably more pop than the former batting and stolen-base champ.PERSON has game-changing speed, uses his quickness to beat out bunts and grounders and has the instincts to develop into a premium basestealer. PERSON's 2019 GPE high school player of the year, he has a quick left-handed stroke and controls the bat very well, making consistent contact and using the entire field. While he won't be a slugger, he has looked a little more physical this spring and has the bat speed and deceptive strength to hit 10-15 homers on an annual basis.The biggest question with PERSON is where he'll eventually make his defensive home. The ORGANIZATION recruit has solid arm strength and a chance to stick at shortstop, but he doesn't have the most fluid actions. He might fit better at second base or center field, and he played the latter position in deference to PERSON Jr. on PERSON at the 18-and-under PERSON in GPE last fall.

The ORGANIZATION went over-slot to sign GPE, a GPE high school standout, away from the ORGANIZATION of GPE and they hoped they were getting an athletic switch-hitter who could develop the skills to stay behind the plate. Though he started slowly during his full-season debut in 2012, there was definite progress made. He can swing the bat well from both sides and his overall approach is solid, though he needs to tone down his aggressiveness and find a consistent rhythm at the plate. He should have some power â itâs mostly to the pull side right now â and he does make hard contact. His overall defensive game needs work, as expected, but he does have a solid arm and the athleticism that allows him to be an average runner should help him move behind the plate as he continues to learn the nuances of catching.

PERSON began 2016 as the ORGANIZATION' top-rated prospect, but he wasn't even the best shortstop prospect in the system by the end of the year. After arriving from the ORGANIZATION via the ORGANIZATION Chapman trade, PERSON not only supplanted him but also pushed him to second base at ORGANIZATION A Advanced GPE. PERSON started to get back on track in 2017 with a return to GPE and then looked like his old self after a promotion to Double-A PERSON, where he was hitting .300/.381/.525 when the ORGANIZATION dealt him to GPE as part of the ORGANIZATION blockbuster for PERSON Gray.One of the fastest runners in baseball, PERSON has top-of-the-scale speed and led the Minors with 82 steals in 2015 before dipping to 36 last season. He can get from the right side of the plate to first base in less than 4.0 seconds and wreak havoc once he gets on base. His quickness also should boost his on-base ability, though he'll need to tighten his plate discipline to become a quality leadoff man.While his speed gets the most attention, PERSON has a nice array of tools. His deceptive strength gives him solid raw power and he has an offensive ceiling of a .275 hitter with 15 homers per season. Few players can match his combination of quickness and arm strength, though he has been erratic at shortstop. Some scouts believe he'll wind up at second base or in center field, where he saw increased playing time in 2017.

There's raw power and there's in-game power. Many a prospect over time has the former, but never can find a way to tap into it to have the latter consistently. While there is a lot of swing and miss to GPE's game, he's shown that he can hit the ball out, with 51 homers over his first two full years of pro ball. It's that power the ORGANIZATION wanted when they acquired him last fall from the D-backs in return for catcher PERSON Herrmann.GPE's power comes more from strength than bat speed and he's always going to strike out a lot. While he'll draw some walks, he'll never hit for a high average. He played both the outfield and first base in the D-backs system and the ORGANIZATION plan to let him play mostly in the outfield moving forward, though they won't abandon first base entirely. He'll mostly play the corners, but might see some time in center as well. GPE runs well for someone his size, stealing 24 bases in 2015.The upper levels should be a good challenge for GPE to see if the power will keep showing up against better pitching. If it keeps coming, his left-handed power bat could be of value, at least off of a big league bench.

Looking for a high-risk, high-reward proposition? Then PERSON, the tall lefty from southern GPE, just might fit the bill. The 6-foot-6 southpaw is all projection at this point, though he's shown glimpses of what might be in there. At an early event run by ORGANIZATION scouts, PERSON was 92-93 mph with his fastball, commanding it to both sides of the plate while throwing downhill effectively. He hasn't repeated that, sitting more in the 88-90 mph range with his fastball, with a good feel for the strike zone. His breaking ball has improved, though it comes and goes, sometimes looking like a potential out pitch and sometimes looking like a below-average slow rolling curve.Some feel three years at ORGANIZATION would do PERSON some good for him to hone his craft and add strength, while others feel he could mature in a pro environment slowly just as well. A team that has seen him throw well and is willing to be patient in unlocking the potential might roll the dice early in the GPE.

Another exciting arm talent who cannot stay healthy, PERSON has thrown just 20 innings in parts of three pro seasons. His injury issues date back to his college days at ORGANIZATION when he had shoulder trouble that the coaching staff initially said was hamstring tightness. An excellent on-mound athlete with advanced command, PERSON was 91-93 the summer after he signed, then 92-95 with a reshaped array of secondary offerings the following spring. He looked likely to be a quick-mover, someone who might reach Double-A in his first full season. PERSON, his ORGANIZATION did not cooperate and PERSON had PERSON a week after PERSON did. PERSON returned during 2018 extended spring training and his velocity had totally returned. He was 92-93 early in rehab outings, then 91-95 in his first official ORGANIZATION game back from surgery, but it would be his last in-game outing of the summer as he was shelved for the remainder of the regular season by a setback. 
ORGANIZATION has surgical command of a low-90s heater and plus power changeup. So firm is PERSON' cambio that ORGANIZATION units often mistakenly classify it as a sinker as it resides in the mid-to-upper 80s. It bottoms out late and hard, and is PERSON' best secondary pitch. His breaking stuff has evolved since college and at last look, he was throwing a fringy curveball that is effective because of his ability to locate it, and an average upper-80s cutter. He's a potential fourth starter with a value-altering injury history.

It took a while for him to break through, but 2012 might be the year the ORGANIZATION look back and say was when PERSON became legit. PERSON moved slowly through the system, including parts of two seasons with GPE in the ORGANIZATION, before advancing up to ORGANIZATION in 2012. He's played all over the field and looked a bit like an organizational filler type, but really took off, settled in as a regular shortstop and finished second in the organization in hits. PERSON has the chance to be a solid Major League hitter, one who has a line-drive swing from both sides of the plate. There's some extra-base pop to come as well, though power isn't likely to be a huge part of his game. His speed and his defense will be, however. A plus runner, he's still learning how to use that to his advantage on the basepaths and it helps give him outstanding range. He has great hands and a plus arm, giving him every opportunity to be an everyday shortstop at the big league level.

PERSON won 13 games and struck out 138 batters as a sophomore in 2015, setting GPE school records and leading all ORGANIZATION Division I pitchers returning to college in 2016. He had first-round aspirations entering the year but had an up-and-down junior season before finishing with a 16-strikeout complete game in the Big Ten Conference tournament. He fell to the ORGANIZATION in the fifth round but landed an above-slot $637,500 bonus.The PERSON' career leader in wins (30) and strikeouts (307), PERSON works from a low three-quarters slot that adds life to his pitches, all of which have the potential to be at least solid. His fastball usually runs from 90-94 mph with sink, though his velocity was down to 86-88 at times early in the college season. His sweeping slider can get swings and misses from both lefties and righties, and he shows some feel for a fading changeup.PERSON has a strong, durable build that lets him maintain his stuff over the course of a game and a season. He fills the strike zone, too, though some scouts wonder if he might be better suited as a reliever because of his arm angle. In shorter stints, he might have two plus offerings with his fastball and slider.

Most teams didn't evaluate PERSON as a first-round talent in the 2013 Draft, but the ORGANIZATION loved his bat, so they drafted him 25th overall and paid him a $1,866,500 bonus. He has justified their faith, winning the Rookie-level PERSON MVP award in his pro debut and finishing second in the short-season LOCATION in hitting (.333) in 2014. Last year he skipped a level to high Class A and batted .304 at age 20.PERSON is an extremely advanced hitter for his age, with outstanding hand-eye coordination that allows him to barrel balls repeatedly. He almost does so too easily, making so much hard contact that it cuts into his walk totals. Being more selective also would help his power totals, as he has the bat speed to produce 15 homers per season if he waits for pitches he can drive.PERSON has sure hands and solid arm strength at shortstop, but his fringy speed and range likely will lead to a position change down the line. PERSON thinks he's an underrated defender but also has PERSON at shortstop and PERSON at second base in the big leagues. PERSON might profile best at third base and also could wind up on an outfield corner.

PERSON was a rotation mate of PERSON at the ORGANIZATION of GPE. And while he lacks his former teammate's upside, PERSON pitched well in 2012, his first full professional season. He is an intelligent pitcher and mixes his four pitches well. PERSON's stuff is average. His fastball sits in the upper-80s with sinking action. His best secondary pitch is his changeup. PERSON's success is based on his control, which is among the best in the ORGANIZATION system. He will need to continue to paint corners as he moves to higher levels of the ORGANIZATION.

Coming off a strong sophomore year at ORGANIZATION and with PERSON, PERSON looked like a mid-first-round pick entering 2014. His stuff wasn't as sharp last spring, but his pitchability and track record of success still led the ORGANIZATION to make him their top choice (27th overall) and sign him for $1,843,000.Though he has hit 97 mph in the past, PERSON usually works at 91-93 with his fastball. He commands it well and imparts good sink on it, but his best pitch is clearly his changeup, which is deceptive and features even more life. He has yet to show much aptitude for spinning a breaking ball, and there's some thought that he might be better off trading in his slider for a cutter.PERSON's feel for pitching, his competitiveness and his makeup all earn high praise. If he regains his previous velocity and makes progress with his breaking ball, he could be a No. 3 starter. If not, he still could crack the back of a big league rotation.

Coming off of a strong showing in the 2015 Cape Cod League, PERSON excelled as GPE's Friday night starter last spring and was lauded as one of the more consistent college pitchers on the LOCATION. He signed for slot value in June as the ORGANIZATION' fourth-round pick, impressed club officials while reaching PERSON in his pro debut and then emerged as one of the ORGANIZATION's top breakout hurlers in 2017 with another dominant performance across multiple levels.PERSON' lightning-quick arm produces a 92-95 mph fastball that he uses to attack hitters on both sides of the plate. His secondary stuff isn't quite as good, but his hard slider can be an out pitch at times, and he'll mix in an average curve and a changeup for which he has decent feel.There's some concern after the GPE that PERSON' arm was too quick and that effort in his delivery could mean a move to a bullpen, but he's shown the ability to maintain velocity deep into starts with above-average control, all while missing plenty of bats and generating more than enough ground-ball outs. Now a year removed from the GPE, there's little doubt that PERSON has what it takes to be a quality big league starter.

The 2012 Draft class wasn't a great one in terms of catching depth, especially from the college ranks, so ORGANIZATION was able to ride a strong junior season at ORGANIZATION into the supplemental first round. At ORGANIZATION, he was a contact-first, offensive-minded catcher, but he has some obvious strength and should hit for more power in the future (he did hit seven homers, including four at home in GPE -- a tough park for hitters). He may not wow anyone with his skills behind the plate, but he's a solid receiver who works well with pitchers and with an arm that was strong and accurate enough to throw out 32 percent of would-be basestealers during his pro debut. There isn't much catching depth in the ORGANIZATION' system and ORGANIZATION rises right to the top of that class.

The ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the fifth round last June and were to set to sign him to a well-above-slot bonus until their agreement with ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick PERSON fell apart. PERSON filed a grievance and ultimately settled with the ORGANIZATION before the matter went to a hearing. He had been committed to ORGANIZATION, but instead of playing for any college this season, he joined ORGANIZATION's post-graduate team.PERSON got off to a strong start, showing the same kind of stuff that initially piqued scouts' interest. His fastball gets up to 95 mph and consistently sits in the low 90s. He's improved his breaking ball, making it more of a curveball, but it and his changeup remain inconsistent. He's also made strides with his delivery, but still struggles at times to find his release point.PERSON has some rough edges that will have to be refined in the ORGANIZATION, but he has the upside to become a big league starter. He earns praise for his makeup.

PERSON had a strong start to his 2018 season before he was shut down in July with a shoulder issue. He didn't pitch for the rest of the summer. PERSON touches 95 and will show you an above-average slider and average changeup. He sat 86-90 as a rising high school senior but has since altered the timing of his arm swing for the better, and the resulting velo is fairly new. Because his delivery is somewhat grotesque and PERSON has now had a shoulder problem, there's apprehension about his health. He was breaking out, then just broke, so now we're in wait-and-see mode regarding his stuff.

PERSON was a 45 FV on last year's ranking, evaluated as an MLB-ready utility infielder or low-end regular at shortstop. During the offseason he was shot in the hip during a robbery in GPE and required surgery. The initial surgery was botched and PERSON needed a second operation during the summer, which ended his regular season. When he returned to action in the ORGANIZATION, he had clearly lost a step overall, but it was most obvious when watching PERSON play defense. There's a chance this was just rust and that PERSON will go back to doing the things that placed him in the ORGANIZATION' offseason infield conversation before he was shot; average range and plus actions at short, a plus arm, some speed, and feel for contact. He'll bounce back into the 45 FV tier if those things return in the spring, but he looked like a fringe bench piece last fall.

A minor mechanical tweak unlocked some of PERSON's previously undiscovered raw power last year and he hit 26 home runs between PERSON and Triple-A. Some of that was due to the hitting environment in GPE, but scouts think the power uptick is real. PERSON already had a chance to be an everyday player because of his superlative bat-to-ball ability, speed and plus-plus defense at second base. With the power folded in, he's a potential star. Whether or not he debuts in GPE this year could depend on a PERSON trade, but he's probably ready.

PERSON comes from the same ORGANIZATION program that spawned PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the 2011 Draft, and fellow big league pitcher PERSON. He spent his freshman year at catcher and his sophomore season at third base before returning to shortstop, his natural position, as a junior last spring.Though he struggled early on the showcase circuit, PERSON quieted his setup and performed better at the plate later in the summer and fall. He shows signs of becoming a solid hitter and offers surprising pop for a 5-foot-11 middle infielder.The ORGANIZATION recruit isn't a burner but moves well on the bases and in the field. His strong arm grades out at his best tool. PERSON will get every chance to stay at shortstop in pro ball, but if he can't, he may have enough bat for third base.

ORGANIZATION's late surge as a GPE high schooler got him taken 10th overall by the ORGANIZATION in 2013, but he declined to sign for reasons that never have been explained fully. After showing pedestrian stuff at ORGANIZATION State ORGANIZATION as a freshman, he looked electric as a reliever in GPE Cod League, where scouts voted him the summer circuit's top prospect. That prompted him to abruptly transfer to a junior college (ORGANIZATION of LOCATION) so he'd be eligible for the 2015 Draft, in which he went 18th overall.Signed for $2,333,800, ORGANIZATION generates differences of opinion as to whether he'll be a starter or reliever because his stuff fluctuates. His fastball often hit 96 mph in 2013, parked at 88-92 at ORGANIZATION, touched 98 in the ORGANIZATION and sat in the low 90s with sink in junior college. His slider showed signs of becoming a plus pitch on the GPE but lacks consistency.ORGANIZATION still is honing his changeup and learning to trust it. He has an athletic delivery and fills the strike zone, which will help his cause to remain in the rotation.

PERSON had just joined the D-backs organization in a deadline deal with the ORGANIZATION last summer, when a foul ball off his leg ended his system debut after four games. After a productive ORGANIZATION, PERSON got back to doing what he's done throughout his Minor Leauge career: hit with power.PERSON finished fifth in the Minors in home runs in 2014 despite missing the final month of the season and he continued to hit the long ball in Triple-A in 2015. He has the ability to hit the ball out of any park to all fields, when he makes contact. PERSON can't always tap into his power because of a lack of plate discipline and some serious swing-and-miss in his game, meaning he's never going to hit for a high average. It also remains unclear where PERSON fits defensively. He does have arm strength, but it appears his catching days are over as the D-backs have moved him to an outfield corner.Whether he can stick in right or left, or gives first base another try, it's his power bat that will eventually get him to the big leagues.

PERSON was known as a glove-first shortstop when the ORGANIZATION drafted him in 2010, and he remains an elite defender now. He has the arm, range and hands to be an above-average defender at shortstop. Playing on the same team as PERSON in 2014 forced PERSON to split his time between shortstop and second base.  PERSON's bat isn't as advanced as his glove. He is still learning how to hit, and his swing has a tendency to get long. Without much power, he'll need to continue to improve his on-base skills.  Thanks to his defense, PERSON won't have to hit a ton to carve out a role in the ORGANIZATION. He still has time on his side, but will need to prove he can handle the more advanced pitching he'll face in the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION.

A very young righty who signed for $600,000 last July, PERSON has a fastball in the 88-91 range and spins a good breaking ball on occasion. He's mechanically inconsistent, which impacts his fastball command and causes the shape of his curveball to vary, but PERSON is the age of a high school junior and it's unreasonable to expect more polish at this time. There's debate about whether or not his frame is actually projectable as, while his measurables indicate that it is, he's slight of build.
PERSON has a rock solid utility profile. He has foul line to foul line doubles power and just enough physical ability to stick at shortstop.

PERSON became the first GPE citizen drafted when the ORGANIZATION took him out of GPE Joaquin Delta (Calif.) JC in the 38th round of the 2015 Draft, and the first to sign with an ORGANIZATION organization when the ORGANIZATION paid him $147,500 as a 14th-rounder out of Nevada-Las Vegas a year later. He has extensive experience pitching with GPE national teams and worked an inning in the 2017 World Baseball Classic. PERSON struggled as a swingman in high Class A last year but returned to level in 2018 and dominated as a starter. The performance netted PERSON his first Double-A promotion in early July, though he would make only one PERSON start (a seven-inning, 11-strikeout gem) before heading to the ORGANIZATION as one of five prospects dealt by the ORGANIZATION to get PERSON Machado.PERSON's best pitch is a fastball that sits at 91-95 mph, touches 97 and plays better than its velocity thanks to some armside run. He backs up his heater with a big-breaking curveball that he can land for strikes or get hitters to chase out of the zone. He has made improvements with his slider and changeup, which has helped fuel his success in 2018.He's also locating his pitches better this year, enhancing PERSON's chances of remaining a starter. He has demonstrated a consistent ability to miss bats that also could make him useful as a late-inning reliever. He didn't start pitching full-time until he got to junior college and was young for his draft class, so he has more room to develop than the typical pitcher in his third year in pro ball.

After transferring from PERSON (Fla.) JC to GPE, PERSON erupted to hit an ORGANIZATION Conference-best 16 home runs as a junior, leading to his selection in the third round of the 2016 Draft. He became the first player from his class to reach the Majors the next year, earning a September promotion straight from Double-A after he'd produced a .329 average with 32 homers and 32 doubles across two levels. In 2018, PERSON was limited by a sore shoulder during the spring and then lost nearly two months of the season to a stress fracture in his ankle that ultimately required offseason surgery. The injury bug continued to plague PERSON in 2019, as suffered a thumb injury during Spring Training that delayed the start of his season and also missed time with a hamstring strain in June. PERSON showed during his first full season that he has the physical strength, bat speed and barrel control needed to hit for average and power at the highest level. While injuries robbed him of some of that explosiveness in 2018, PERSON also deviated from the hit-to-all-fields mentality that had made him successful in the previous year, as he all too often sold out for pull-side power in an attempt to replicate his 2017 results. He generally has an aggressive approach that leads to a lot of contact but nets him few walks, thus underscoring how PERSON' on-base skills are linked to his production.PERSON has played all three outfield positions as a pro, but profiles best in right field because he has average speed and range as well as plus arm strength. He will need to hit for average and power to hold down the position in the big leagues, and the ORGANIZATION are confident that a fully healthy PERSON will be able to get back on track toward reaching his potential in 2019.

The 2014-15 PERSON of the Year in GPE, PERSON is a glove-first prospect with good speed (6.6 seconds in the 60-yard dash) and excellent range. The 6-foot, 185-pound shortstop has been described as a high-energy player who is making progress at the plate. PERSON is expected to be an everyday player when he gets called up to the big leagues, likely after some time in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON won a gold glove in GPE and made a name for himself with stellar defense. He's also a plus runner and should improve as a base stealer with professional instruction on a daily basis. Scouts like his makeup and his level of confidence. His arm is considered average. On offense, PERSON lacks power, but his light bat should improve as he develops. PERSON was declared a free agent by PERSON on Jan. 11, and he agreed to a $6 million deal with the ORGANIZATION to sign during the 2015-2016 period, though the club did not confirm the agreement. The ORGANIZATION ultimately signed PERSON for $7,000,000 when the 2016-2017 international signing period began on July 2..

Strong-armed Texas high schoolers don't usually attend college in the LOCATION. PERSON took that path, however, in part because his brother attended graduate school at ORGANIZATION, and his family was moving to GPE. Now he's a good bet to become the first pitcher from the ORGANIZATION State to go in the first three rounds since PERSON and PERSON were first-rounders in 1998.A ORGANIZATION 26th-round pick in 2011, PERSON struggled as a freshman before becoming the ORGANIZATION' No. 1 starter and starring in the ORGANIZATION last year. He built on that momentum this spring, maintaining his 90-96 mph fastball deep into games. His slider generates swing and misses but still lacks consistency.PERSON's changeup features some deception and sink, but his nascent splitter could be an even more effective third pitch. His strong build should give him the durability required of a starter, though his high arm slot allows hitters to pick up his pitches more easily than scouts would like. He throws strikes but still is refining his command.

Some believe PERSON might be the best prospect to ever come out of GPE. The switch-hitting shortstop is extremely athletic with above-average bat speed and solid arm strength. He has shown gap-to-gap power from both sides of the plate, and has good speed that plays in games. Scouts like his makeup and maturity.PERSON has experience in international tournaments, but he has not had a lot of exposure against quality pitching and it sometimes shows at the plate. The teenager has a smooth swing, and although it could use some work, most believe his bat will improve with age and instruction. On defense, PERSON has shown good hands, nice range and solid footwork, but is far from a finished product. PERSON should blossom as he comes into his own as a player, and his success will rely heavily on a club's player development program.

Whenever a projectable high school pitcher shows a jump in stuff, he's bound to move up GPE boards. That's exactly what was happening with PERSON in GPE, though some concern about mechanics was giving some scouts pause.PERSON, a 6-foot-5 right-hander committed to the ORGANIZATION of GPE, had always intrigued because of his frame and fairly solid idea of how to pitch. When he went from throwing his fastball in the 88-92 range to sitting closer to 92-94 mph and touching 96, his stock definitely jumped. He'll complement the fastball with a slider that flashes average and he shows some feel for a changeup. PERSON uses a three-quarter arm slot with a high elbow, a kind of unorthodox delivery that will make some scouts pause. Given the leap he's made stuff-wise, a team is bound to look past that and nab him in the first few rounds of the GPE.

The GPE has been known over the years to chew up pitchers and spit them out. GPE, who many thought would have a big 2016 season after a solid first full year of pro ball, definitely struggled in the hitter-friendly circuit, going 2-15 with a 6.31 ERA. Despite that, the ORGANIZATION feel the junior college product has a good chance to bounce back.GPE didn't pitch a ton at FACILITY A&M, totaling just 72 2/3 innings over two years, and pitching entirely in relief in his 2014 Draft year. The ORGANIZATION have worked to stretch him out as a starter and will continue to do so because he has the repertoire necessary to pitch out of a rotation. The 2016 season was his first as a full-time starter and his ability to find the strike zone consistently really backed up. He also lost the feel of his changeup, which graded as the best in the system a year ago internally. His heavy sinking fastball still got ground-ball outs when he kept it down, though that happened less frequently last year. His slider flashes as an above-average breaking ball, but not with any consistency.It's clear the mental wear of the GPE got to GPE. He'll get the chance to wipe the slate clean and the organization is still very much committed to him as a starting pitcher.

One of the more projectable pitchers in the ORGANIZATION system, PERSON signed for $1.1 million as a second-round pick in 2014. Because he's young and needs time to physically develop, PERSON didn't allow him to exceed five innings before the 32nd start of his pro career last August.PERSON already pitches at 91-93 mph and reaches 96 with hard sink on his fastball, which could sit in the mid-90s once he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame. His secondary pitches lack consistency but show flashes of becoming solid offerings. He throws his slider in the low 80s and his changeup has some fade and sink.PERSON has a quick arm and a clean delivery, so he's able to repeat his delivery and throw strikes with ease. Once he adds strength and refines his secondary pitches and command, he could blossom into a mid-rotation starter.

PERSON has hit everywhere he's gone since the ORGANIZATION drafted him 37th overall in 2010. PERSON hopes that will continue in its system after the club acquired him as part of the trade that sent PERSON to GPE in July.PERSON doesn't have any real standout tools; instead, he is a steady all-around performer. He has a knack for putting the bat on the ball, despite an unconventional timing mechanism in his swing. PERSON is an aggressive hitter, and he has developed solid power as he has matured.PERSON is a below-average runner, limiting his range defensively. Still, he has the hands and footwork necessary to be an average defender at second base. PERSON earns praise for his makeup, and he knows how to get the most out of his tools. He profiles as an offensive-minded second baseman.

When PERSON became the first ORGANIZATION Division I team in 21 years to win a regional tournament in its playoff debut last June, PERSON was named Most Outstanding Player after picking up two victories in the four days. He followed up with a strong summer in the ORGANIZATION and has performed well again this spring.PERSON can hit 94 mph with his fastball, but he usually pitches at 88-92 mph. He lacks downhill plane because he's 6 feet tall and leaves his heater up in the strike zone more than he should, but it's effective because his extreme crossfire delivery produces run and sink and allows him to get inside against righties.PERSON's breaking ball varies between a fringy slider in the lower 80s and a promising cutter in the upper 80s, and he may want to focus on the cutter in pro ball. His changeup has some sink and is an effective third pitch. He throws enough strikes to remain a starter, though his lack of a true plus pitch gives him little margin for error.

Wherever PERSON has been, he's hit. He parlayed a career .348 average and .469 on-base percentage into an eight-round selection in the 2015 Draft by the ORGANIZATION. PERSON taken that late have to prove themselves level-by-level, and PERSON did just that, hitting over .300 in his pro debut and full-season debut in 2016. He kept on hitting and getting on-base enough to earn a late promotion to Double-A at the end of the Double-A season.PERSON has used a contact-first approach to hit .311 in his pro career heading into the 2018 season, while his strike zone discipline is also advanced, leading to a .413 on-base percentage as well. Right now he is all about line drives to the gaps from the left side of the plate, but he does have close to average raw power that his approach doesn't let him get to. The ORGANIZATION will continue to work with PERSON on small mechanical changes to try to tap into that pop a little, though he'll always be hit over power. He doesn't look pretty behind the plate and needs to continue to work on his receiving and game-calling, but he manages to get the job done, throwing out just over 30 percent of would-be basestealers in his career.The ORGANIZATION are confident he can stick behind the plate, and left-handed hitting backstops are always a hot commodity, at least as backups. If he can continue to hit and find a way to add a little power, he might outperform those projections.

Born in GPE, PERSON moved to the GPE for his sophomore year of high school in 2016. Since arriving with a mid-80s fastball, he has developed into the hardest thrower in the '19 prep class. He repeatedly reached the upper 90s on the showcase circuit last summer and broke PERSON's Under PERSON All-America Game record with a fastball clocked at 99 mph. PERSON usually works at 94-97 mph and has reached triple digits with his fastball. He can overpower hitters with sheer velocity, gets good riding action on his four-seamer and can show heavy sink on a two-seamer. Opponents can't afford to sit on his heater because he has a pair of power breaking pitches, with his sharp low-80s slider currently grading better than his upper-70s curveball with good depth.PERSON dabbles with a changeup that gets too firm but flashes good sink at times. The ORGANIZATION State recruit's control and command are inconsistent, in part because he has a long arm action, so some scouts project him more as a reliever than as a starter. There's not a lot of projection remaining in his frame, which is smaller than his listed height and weight, but his present stuff already is plenty good.

After winning ORGANIZATION accolades at the World Junior Championships in 2010, PERSON was set to sign with the ORGANIZATION for $350,000 as a 16-year-old until the ORGANIZATION threatened to ban him from ever playing or coaching in GPE if he signed before graduating from high school. He waited to do so, then broke the bonus record for GPE position players by signing with the ORGANIZATION for $2.05 million in 2012. He seemed headed for obscurity after posting a .614 OPS in his first five pro seasons before breaking out in Double-A this year and helping GPE as a stopgap solution at third base in the Majors.Even when he wasn't producing offensively, PERSON controlled the strike zone well. He still does, and he also has become more selectively aggressive and tries to drive the ball on occasion. His plus speed remains his best tool, though it never has translated into much in the way of stolen bases.A versatile defender, PERSON has seen action at shortstop, second base, third base and center field. With his quickness, average arm and offensive profile, he's best suited for the middle infield. He has given the ORGANIZATION a lift at the hot corner and could have a future as a utilityman if he continues to hold his own at the plate.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $10,000 as a nondrafted free agent out of ORGANIZATION in 2014, it might have been perceived as a favor to his cousin, PERSON. But he has proven himself to be a legitimate prospect, breaking out in Double-A in 2017 and winning Triple-A PERSON MVP honors this season. He followed up with a solid performance in the ORGANIZATION, forcing GPE to protect him on its 40-man roster rather than risk losing him in the Rule 5 Draft.PERSON' strength is his ability to make repeated hard contact, which helped him make a run at league batting titles in each of the last two years and top the ORGANIZATION in runs (93), hits (180), doubles (39), extra-base hits (65) and total bases (285). Most of his power currently comes in the form of doubles but he might develop into a 20-homer threat if he added some loft to his right-handed stroke. He doesn't strike out much, yet he puts the bat on the ball so easily that he rarely draws walks.PERSON lacks quickness but has a strong arm and covers enough ground to serve as an average defender at third base. He has soft hands that also work well at first base, where he has seen action throughout his pro career. Though it remains to be seen if and where he'll break into the ORGANIZATION' crowded infield, he doesn't have much left to accomplish in the Minors.

GSP is the quintessential scrappy college shortstop. None of his tools grade as better than average, but scouts love the way he plays the game and think his work ethic and versatility could translate into a big league role as a utilityman.Though GSP didn't perform well with wood bats in the ORGANIZATION last summer, he rebounded with a strong spring. He has a short, quick right-handed stroke and does a fine job of controlling the strike zone. He has more pop than most middle infielders and can hit mistakes out of the park.With average quickness and fringy range, GSP won't be an everyday shortstop at the next level. But he has enough athleticism, instincts and arm to play almost anywhere on the diamond. If he's going to become a regular, it would be at second base.

The younger brother of former GPE first-rounder PERSON, PERSON stood out mostly for his defense during his first two years at ORGANIZATION before breaking out at the plate as a junior, leading to his selection by the ORGANIZATION in the fifth round of the 2015 ORGANIZATION. After he signed for $335,400, PERSON took the Class A Short PERSON by storm, winning ORGANIZATION honors and leading the league in average (.358), stolen bases (47), on-base percentage (.432) and runs scored (64). As a result of his success, the ORGANIZATION sent PERSON to Class A Advanced Bakersfield to begin his first full season. PERSON hit a collective .184 between his freshman and sophomore seasons with the ORGANIZATION, and his offensive struggles carried over to the 2014 Cape Cod League, where he hit just .196 with his ORGANIZATION stock on the line. But things came together for him as a junior, and he continued to make strides at the plate in his pro debut after he shortened his swing. He's a disciplined hitter and makes a lot of contact, which in turn allows him to utilize his plus wheels. While he'll never offer much in the way of power, PERSON did show more consistent pop to the gaps in the LOCATION League.Defensively, PERSON shouldn't have trouble sticking at shortstop, where he profiles as an above-average defender with soft hands, good range and an absolute cannon for an arm. Though still has quite a bit to prove at the plate in spite of his impressive pro debut, PERSON could turn out to be one of the biggest steals of the 2015 ORGANIZATION with another strong showing in his first full season.

The ORGANIZATION had been linked for months to PERSON, a GPE defector, before signing him in late July for $1.5 million and a matching penalty for exceeding their international bonus allotment. He was one of GPE's biggest expenditures as it exceeded its international pool for the first time. Though he had limited success in sporadic playing time in 2012-14 in GPE's PERSON, he was one of the league's youngest players and fared better in the island's 18-and-under and 23-and-under leagues.PERSON stands out most for his offensive potential. He has a quick right-handed bat and has added strength since defecting, giving him intriguing raw power for a middle infielder. He's aggressive at the plate but makes consistent contact and uses the entire field.While PERSON has just average speed, the ORGANIZATION believe he'll be able to stay at shortstop. He has good actions and a quick first step, giving him range to both sides. He also has soft hands and solid arm strength that should fit well at second or third base should he need to change positions.

PERSON popped on the scouting radar when he outpitched the late PERSON in a GPE playoff matchup in 2014, though his commitment to PERSON made him slide to the ORGANIZATION in the 36th round. After winning LOCATION pitcher of the year honors as a sophomore and performing well in the ORGANIZATION and fall practice, he entered 2017 as a potential second-round pick. While his stuff hasn't been as sharp during his junior season, he still has one of the higher floors as a starter among college pitchers and is a lock to become the first Paladin ever drafted in the first five rounds.PERSON reached 96 mph with nasty sink on his fastball during fall ball, but he has pitched more at 88-92 and topped out at 94 with a less heavy heater this spring. He has full trust in his changeup, which shows signs of becoming a plus pitch but has graded more as an average offering in 2017. The same is true of his curveball and cutter, which flashed solid more often in the past.While he isn't especially big, PERSON has gotten stronger during three years of college. He has no issues repeating his delivery and pounding the strike zone. PERSON also love his competitive demeanor and he has all the ingredients to become an effective No. 4 starter.

The ORGANIZATION used both of their first-round picks on up-the-middle preps in 2013, selecting PERSON with the ninth-overall pick and then nabbing ORGANIZATION at ORGANIZATION. 14, targeting the GPE state product for his revered defensive prowess. He reached Double-A for the first time in 2016, the same year that he was dealt with PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION at the ORGANIZATION. Sidelined with a left oblique injury for much of the first half in 2017, ORGANIZATION performed well back in Double-A after making a healthy return in July and then made up for lost time in the ORGANIZATION Winter League during the offseason.ORGANIZATION's defense has long been his calling card, and there's little doubt that it will get him to the big leagues. An excellent blocker and receiver who garners high praise for his game-calling and his ability to handle a staff, ORGANIZATION also is adept at controlling the running game with his plus arm and efficient pop technique. At the plate, ORGANIZATION continues to show natural hitting ability with a level, line-drive producing swing and advanced feel for the zone, and he even showed an uptick in power in 2017, connecting on a career-high six home runs with Double-A New Hampshire despite playing in just 34 games. ORGANIZATION's stock as a hitter seemingly is on the rise now that he's healthy. His glove, meanwhile, is good enough for him to carve out a role as defensive-minded backup, if not a regular in the big leagues.

GPE has not developed as expected to this point. We anticipated he'd move quickly to third base in pro ball, but hit for enough power to overcome it. Instead, he has held serve a shortstop and only just begun to see time at third, but has struggled to get to his considerable raw power in games. His lower half usage has improved, but GPE's bat still has downward entry into the hitting zone and he doesn't extend well through contact. He has a nearly 50% groundball rate as a pro and ends up pushing a lot of contact the other way. There's ceiling here because of GPE's shot to stay at short and adjust his way into game power, but there's a low floor if he moves to third and can't make tweaks.

If you showed up to see PERSON play on the right day, you might see the best player on the field. On other days, you might leave scratching your head.There's no question PERSON has some tools in his big, strong and athletic frame. A Gulf Coast League teammate with PERSON and PERSON, PERSON has been a bit slower to develop than his counterparts, though he'll still be just 21 years old for the 2014 season. While still working to find a level of consistency, PERSON has some serious right-handed raw power. He will be able to tap into that power more if he can refine his approach and learn to not try to do too much at the plate. With a strong arm and his offensive upside, PERSON profiles well as a future right fielder.PERSON and PERSON may have moved more quickly, but time is still on PERSON's side.

The home run ball returned with a vengeance in GPE League Baseball in 2017, but that doesn't mean teams aren't still in need of the table-setters to get on base and run in front of the slugging run producers. When a hitter like PERSON also plays up the middle defensively, teams are definitely going to sit up and pay attention.While he is a bit undersized at 5-foot-10, PERSON' performance over the summer and into his senior season had many evaluators looking past that. His speed is his best tool, an easy plus that allows him to get down the line in a hurry from both sides of the plate and be a basestealing threat. He has a contact-oriented approach and uses all fields well, and while he's not likely to be a home run threat, he could grow into his frame for more extra-base pop with an PERSON type of build. He has excellent actions and footwork at shortstop and has shown he has enough arm to stay on the left side of the infield.Assuming teams can look past his size, the one other hurdle might be his commitment to GPE. PERSON is a good student whose parents are educators, so he'll have to go early enough to bypass college, a distinct possibility.

Since signing him with an over-slot deal in 2010, the ORGANIZATION didn't hesitate to challenge PERSON a bit, sending him to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League for his debut, largely against much older competition. Then he spent the 2012 season in full-season ball at age 20 and while his overall numbers were mixed, he finished very strongly, with a 1.68 ERA over his final nine starts. The big right-hander could have three above-average-or-better pitches and above-average command when all is said and done. PERSON will touch 95 mph with his fastball, with plenty of movement. The ORGANIZATION went well above slot to secure PERSON, signing him for $325,000 as an 18th-round pick in 2011. GPE, positionless athlete with plus bat speed and plus-plus wheels, flat swing. A developmental project.
