He's seen as very signable and the team that takes him will be banking on him returning to form; we've assumed there's a little more slider feel that will be teased out but not the 60 pitch of the summer.

Undrafted out of high school because he had PERSON surgery, PERSON pitched largely in relief as a freshman at GPE, then moved into the weekend rotation behind 2017 first-rounder PERSON. A strong ORGANIZATION Cod League showing last summer catapulted him into the Friday night role for the ORGANIZATION, where he's had a bit of an up-and-down season.At his best, PERSON stands out with his arm strength and power arsenal. His fastball will typically sit around 92-93 mph, but he can reach back for more, flashing a plus 97-mph heater at times, both on the ORGANIZATION and occasionally this spring, and he does maintain his velocity throughout starts. His secondary stuff, however, has backed up some. In the past, he'd show a short, quick, deep breaking ball with late break at the plate. It's been more of a slurvy pitch this spring with more of a loopy break to it, leading to hitters laying off of it and sitting on what is a largely true fastball. He has a changeup, but doesn't throw it much.While he does largely throw strikes, PERSON does need to refine his command within the zone. That, plus some effort in his delivery, has some scouts predicting a future in the bullpen, though with his ability to maintain his fastball, he could get the opportunity to start at the outset of his pro career.

Signed for $2.475 million as the 12th overall pick in the 2012 Draft, PERSON played well in high Class A at the end of that summer -- which might have been the worst thing for him. The FACILITY sent him back to that level for his first full pro season, and he responded by recording the lowest batting average (.178) and most strikeouts (160 in 383 at-bats) in the ORGANIZATION. When he returned there again in 2014, he was able to slow the game down and topped the ORGANIZATION with 84 RBIs.After tasting failure for the first time, PERSON responded with a more balanced and disciplined approach and did a better job of recognizing pitches. His right-handed swing looked smoother and handsier than ever, and he didn't get consumed by trying to hit homers. He may chase too many pitches to ever hit for a high average but he now has a better chance of translating his bat speed and strength into plus power. A solid runner who played center field in his first two pro seasons, PERSON moved to left field last year. He needs to improve his defensive focus after leading ORGANIZATION outfielders with 14 errors. He has a plus arm in high school but it plays closer to average now.

Twenty-one years after the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON from PERSON, the club picked PERSON out of the same GPE school. In 2014, he hit 22 home runs with PERSON, tied for the most in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON produces plenty of raw power and does a good job of getting to it in games. While his pop comes with its share of strikeouts, his approach has improved in the ORGANIZATION. He's willing to take a walk, and looks to hit the ball the other way more often. Big, right-handed hitting first basemen face some challenges, but the ORGANIZATION have had success with PERSON, who also fits that profile. PERSON is an adequate defender, but, as with PERSON, it'll be up to his bat to carry him to the big leagues.

The 2014 Conference USA player of the year after hitting .368/.442/.626, PERSON went in the second round and signed for $1.1 million that June as a catcher with offensive potential. He didn't do much at the plate in his first three pro seasons -- fracturing bones in his face when he got hit by a knee while trying to break up a double play in 2016 didn't help -- but has started to drive the ball more consistently this year.PERSON's strength and the loft in his right-handed swing could translate into 15 homers per year at the big league level. He makes consistent contact but hasn't shown the same plate discipline he did at ORGANIZATION, so he may not hit for a high average. His offensive package profiles well enough to be a big league regular as a catcher, though he's hopelessly blocked in GPE Francisco by PERSON GPE.PERSON's arm has gotten stronger and his release has gotten quicker since he has turned pro, and he recorded the best pop times (1.85 seconds) in the ORGANIZATION during the offseason. His receiving and blocking have improved as well. He has gotten some time at first base this year, enhancing his versatility if he winds up a backup to GPE.

For the second time in six GPE, scouts are flocking to see a left-hander at GPE (Ill.) High. PERSON landed late third-round money ($426,000) after dropping to the 15th round because he needed PERSON surgery. PERSON hasn't had any health issues and could go in the top five rounds this June as clearly the top prospect in the state of Illinois.PERSON usually operates at 88-91 mph and tops out at 93 with his fastball. He commands it well, generates some armside run and should have a plus heater once his 6-foot-4 frame adds muscle. He does a good job of selling his fading changeup, which shows signs of becoming a plus pitch.PERSON exhibits much more feel for his changeup than his slurvy breaking ball. It's more of a soft curveball at this point, and he may be better off working with a harder slider in the future. More strong than athletic, the ORGANIZATION State recruit repeats his delivery and lives in the strike zone.

PERSON's power potential was evident when he was an GPE high schooler, but he lasted until the ORGANIZATION took him in the 34th round of the 2015 Draft because he was coming off PERSON surgery and had a firm commitment to GPE. He played in just 41 games during his first two college seasons while dealing with the effects of multiple concussions. Finally healthy, he has broken out in a big way in 2018, leading ORGANIZATION Division I in slugging (.944) and ORGANIZATION (1.456) and all D-I Draft-eligible players in homers (22) through the end of the regular season.PERSON's 6-foot-5, 210-pound build gives him strength and leverage, which combined with his solid bat speed produces prodigious raw power. A right-handed hitter, he excels at crushing the balls to the opposite field, though some scouts wonder how he'll have the same success against quality inside fastballs in pro ball. His size adds length to his swing and his aggressiveness leads to strikeouts, so he'll hit more for power than average at the next level.Though he plays first base for the GPE, PERSON is a good athlete for his size and should be capable of playing the outfield corners. He has average speed and will flash solid run times on occasion, and his arm earns similar grades. The best-case scenario is that he profiles as a right fielder.

PERSON has shown some of the best stuff in the system ever since the ORGANIZATION made him the first pitcher they selected in the 2015 Draft and signed him for an over-slot $320,000 in the sixth round. But he saw his first two pro seasons end prematurely because of a recurring stress fracture in his elbow and also missed the first three weeks of the 2018 season. PERSON shifted him to the bullpen in order to keep him healthy, and he not only stayed on the mound but also posted the best numbers of his career.PERSON had four legitimate pitches as a starter but focuses on two as a reliever. His upper-80s cutter is his bread and butter, and he plays it off a 92-95 mph fastball that can hit 97 with some modest life. His downer curveball showed flashes of becoming a plus offering when he used it more in the past season, and his fading changeup had its moments as well.Working in shorter stints, PERSON demonstrates better control and command than he did as a starter. He has a strong, athletic frame and a sound delivery, so he should be durable, but the ORGANIZATION didn't have him pitch on consecutive days in 2018. He proved he could handle a heavier bullpen workload this year and made his big league debut in April.

The ORGANIZATION doubled up on GPE prep hurlers in the 2014 Draft, taking left-hander PERSON in the first round followed by PERSON in the 12th. While PERSON was the more highly touted prospect at that time, it's been PERSON who has enjoyed the most success as a pro. He impressed during his full-season debut in the Class A ORGANIZATION and built on that performance in 2017 Class A Advanced GPE, posting a 2.51 ERA that paced all GPE League hurlers with at least 100 innings pitched. With PERSON's arrow pointing in the right direction, the ORGANIZATION acquired him, PERSON, PERSON and PERSON from PERSON for outfielder PERSON. PERSON has seen his stuff and overall pitchability improve in each of his four seasons. He compensates for being undersized with a high-spin-rate fastball that sits 89-93 mph and induces whiffs in and above the zone. PERSON's breaking ball is his best secondary pitch, flashing plus at times with late downer action, and he exhibits feel for a promising changeup. His entire arsenal plays up because he's a good strike-thrower, though he's likely to be challenged in that regarded against upper-level hitters.PERSON's swing-and-miss fastball, combined with his two average-or-better secondary offerings, gives him a chance to be successful against hitters on both sides of the plate, which he was in 2017. That he's an undersized righty who lacks a plus pitch leads some to peg PERSON as a future reliever, but he's passed every test in his career thus far.

Despite playing with a right hand injury eventually diagnosed as a broken hamate bone, PERSON led PERSON to its first-ever ORGANIZATION USA regular-season title in 2016, earning league player-of-the-year and defensive-player-of-the-year recognition along the way. The first college shortstop drafted in 2016 and the highest pick in school history, he went 51st overall and signed for $1.1 million. His hamate injury hampered him early in his debut but he hit .320 with four homers in his final two weeks, and then he missed most of the first three months of the 2017 season with repeated hamstring issues.Taller than most shortstops at 6-foot-4 and possessing just average speed, PERSON nevertheless should be able to stick at the position. His quick first step and his instincts enhance his range, and he has the strong, accurate arm to make any throw necessary. If he does have to move, he has enough bat to still profile as a regular at second base.PERSON has a track record of making consistent contact and could produce solid batting averages if he improves his patience at the plate. He has more raw power than the typical shortstop, thanks to the leverage in his right-handed swing, and should be good for double-digit home runs and plenty of doubles on an annual basis. He's not a threat to steal but runs the bases well.

GPE PERSON had a string of first rounders -- PERSON and PERSON in 2009, PERSON in 2010 and PERSON in 2011 -- broken in 2012, but PERSON looks like a good bet to get the ORGANIZATION back in the top 30 picks.A big, strong left-handed-hitting third baseman, PERSON has good projection to his frame, meaning heâs likely to grow into more power as he matures. Heâs a polished hitter, one who stood out on the GPE this past summer, and he should be able to stay at the hot corner defensively.In his second straight summer in the GPE, PERSON led the summer circuit in ORGANIZATION with 42 and played in his second consecutive GPE Cod League All-Star Game, where he went 1-for-5.He may not go as high as his uncle, former No. 1 overall pick B.J. PERSON, but he should be one of the earlier college bats to come off the board.

PERSON GPE has had five outfielders selected in the top three rounds of the past six GPE, and PERSON should go in the same territory in June. A semi-regular as a freshman and a left fielder in deference to gifted defender PERSON on the ORGANIZATION' 2015 College World Series team, he's the center fielder and offensive catalyst on their '16 squad.PERSON is well suited to bat atop a lineup, as he has a patient contact-oriented approach and the plus speed and know-how to steal bases. His flat left-handed swing doesn't yield much power, but his on-base skills rank among the best in college baseball. PERSON has performed well during two summers in the ORGANIZATION League.Though he hadn't played much center field for ORGANIZATION before this spring, PERSON's speed and instincts make him at least a solid defender there. His arm strength is below average, but it isn't considered a liability.

As GPE struck out more and more during his final few seasons as a shortstop, he frequently appeared despondent, sullen, and visibly affected by his struggles in ways that were often obvious and concerning. He struck out in at least 30% of his at-bats every year since the ORGANIZATION acquired him from GPE as part of the ORGANIZATION deal. While his defensive actions remained enticing (they were, especially around the bag, some of the smoothest and quickest some scouts had ever seen), GPE also became error-prone. He seemed a mess, a potential ORGANIZATION candidate. 
This spring, GPE has moved to the mound. His first bullpen session, which took place in front of a very small contingent of ORGANIZATION front office folks, was electric. The first fastball was clocked by PERSON at 97 mph, and a few fastballs later, GPE touched 100.4 mph. He has been working, an inning at a time, twice a week in GPE Spring Training. PERSON saw him shortly before publication, and he was 95-98 with natural cut at times (in the linked video you can see how his fastball's spin axis is somewhat slidery) and had pretty impressive slider feel for someone who has only been pitching for a few weeks. He'll likely head out to an affiliate in the next week or so (probably PERSON). GPE seems comfortable and confident on the mound, and he's going right at hitters with that fastball. He'll move as quickly as his strike-throwing and slider allow him to, and PERSON has incentive to move him along because GPE is on the 40-man. We may see him on the mound at ORGANIZATION this season.

A strong finish to his junior season at ORGANIZATION helped PERSON move into the sandwich round. He has a live arm that can deliver fastballs up to 97 mph, and he has a slider that should be a very good secondary pitch in the future. PERSON has a changeup, but itâs behind the fastball-breaking ball combination. Heâs not the biggest guy in the world and has had some command issues in the past, though not during his summer debut in the ORGANIZATION. With his power stuff and size, some see a future in the bullpen, but the ORGANIZATION sent him out as a starter and may give him the chance to stick in a rotation for the time being.

PERSON is very polished for a prep pitcher, and it showed when he spun three consecutive no-hitters in March and April, three shy of the national high school record. He may not get drafted high enough to lure him away from a commitment to GPE, where he could make an immediate impact as a freshman.PERSON's pitchability stands out more than his pure stuff, though he does have a pair of solid pitches in his fastball and slider. He works from 87-91 mph with his heater, which features some riding life, and he can throw his slider for strikes or use it as a chase pitch. His changeup will need more work.He's a good athlete who does a nice job of repeating his easy, balanced delivery, though scouts wonder how much more velocity PERSON has in the tank. He's not extremely physical and lacks standout arm speed. Should he attend college, he'll be Draft-eligible as a sophomore in 2018.

An offensive lineman in high school, ORGANIZATION lost a ton of weight to get in baseball shape. That helped him reach the fourth round of the 2014 Draft. The down side of that transformation was that he tired during his first full season of pro ball, though there is a good amount of offensive upside to be had here.ORGANIZATION had primarily played third as a pro heading into 2016, though he mixed in some first. That's where he played nearly exclusively during the 2016 season. He's a below-average fielder at both corner infield spots.In the end, though, it will be ORGANIZATION's bat that carries him up the ladder. Finding that happy medium between too slimmed down and offensive lineman should help him reach his offensive ceiling.

It's growing more difficult to reconcile PERSON' obvious physical tool with his complete lack of performance, even though he has been young for his level since his pro debut. He put on a show during PERSON (though, somewhat suspiciously, everyone did), he has visually evident feel for contact supported by his lower strikeout rates, he runs well-enough to stay in center field. But in three pro seasons now he's hitting a collective .253/.315/.351 and it's starting to make teams antsy. When we passed around initial drafts of our Top 100, all but one source providing feedback on PERSON' ranking told us to move him down, some indicating he should be off, entirely. We still think he'd go somewhere in the first round were he draft eligible and that he has everyday tools, but so far as his stock throughout the industry is concerned, the clock is certainly ticking.

PERSON electrified ORGANIZATION fans in 2012, when he did a backflip on ORGANIZATION right after getting drafted 13th overall and played well at two Class A stops at the end of his debut. He still shows glimpses of the high ceiling that earned him a $2,475,000 bonus but has struggled for much of his four full pro seasons. In the last two years in Double-A, he has had trouble making consistent contact and missed time with finger, foot and oblique injuries.PERSON' bat speed and strength give him jaw-dropping raw power, but it remains to be seen whether he'll be polished enough as a hitter to make the most of it. His right-handed swing can get out of control at times and his plate discipline regressed in 2015 after improving the year before. He may never hit for a high average but could produce 25 or more homers per year at GPE Cellular Field if he can refine his approach.Coming out of high school, PERSON had solid speed and arm strength. He since has lost a step as he has matured physically and his throwing motion is a bit stiff, so he now fits best in left field after playing primarily in center field in his first two pro seasons.

A one-time Miami area high school standout who tripled off of current ORGANIZATION power-hitting prospect PERSON at ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION, PERSON is one of those players whose whole exceeds the sum of his parts.None of PERSON's tools jump off the page, yet the ORGANIZATION thought enough of his makeup and instincts to send him to the ORGANIZATION in 2014 at age 20. While it might look like he lacks the arm strength to stay at shortstop, he tends to make up for any deficiencies with outstanding fundamentals, with excellent footwork, a quick release and an accuracy. His solid-average defense is ahead of his offense as of now. He has a line drive approach and uses the whole field, is a solid bunter and runs well. He needs to improve his approach at the plate and work counts more, but given his baseball smarts, that should come with time and experience.PERSON is still way ahead of the curve in terms of age and the level he's playing at. His feel for the game and natural confidence should continue to allow him to play above his tools.

PERSON is still a under-the-radar as a prospect: he wasn't a top pedigree amateur prospect, signing for $300,000 when the ORGANIZATION were in the international penalty box, and has only played in the ORGANIZATION as a very limited participant in instructional league. He made quite an impression on the scouts who have been able to see him for his loud tools: plus batspeed, running speed, and arm strength, along with a chance to stick at shortstop. PERSON has put on about 20 pounds since signing, with one scout comparing his frame and toolset to PERSON's, though the skills and feel for the game are obviously not even close to that. He also has a good plate approach but can play out of control at times, especially at shortstop. PERSON likely will head to ORGANIZATION in 2019 at age 19.

GPE has a great swing and thunderous raw power. He also went from having one of the worst approaches in baseball last year to having an average one. We don't think he fits at third base, but his stock is up as we're more confident he'll have the offensive skills to profile in left field.

GPE homered 10 times in his final 16 games at ORGANIZATION, winning LOCATION tournament ORGANIZATION honors after going deep five times in five days, including a three-homer game against GPE. He finished with 20 homers after totaling six in his first two years with the ORGANIZATION, bashing his way into the sixth round of the 2017 Draft. After signing for $260,200, GPE homered in three of his first four games as a pro.As a first baseman with big left-handed power along with swing-and-miss concerns, GPE earns comparisons to a poor man's PERSON. With his bat speed and the size and leverage his 6-foot-3, 235-pound frame provides, he can crush the ball out of any part of the park. While GPE may never hit for a high average, he has shown a greater willingness to use the entire field and has made more contact in 2017.All of GPE's value comes from his bat. A high school catcher who played some right field as an ORGANIZATION sophomore, he'll be limited to first base as a pro because of his well-below-average speed. GPE can become an adequate defender but will need to improve his consistency.

GPE high schools haven't produced a big leaguer since PERSON, who the ORGANIZATION drafted in the second round in 2002, but PERSON should end that drought if he can build on the success he had at the end of last season. Signed for $225,000 as an 18th-rounder in 2012, he saw his stuff tick up last year and allowed just two runs over his last four starts in high Class A.PERSON's fastball has improved from 85-88 mph in high school to 88-94 these days, and he can ride a four-seamer up in the strike zone or sink a two-seamer in the lower half. He also can spin a curveball that creeps into the low 80s, keep hitters off balance with a solid changeup and mix in a cutter.PERSON's arsenal plays up because he throws all his pitches for strikes and generally keeps them down in the strike zone. He has a ceiling of a No. 3 starter but projects more as an efficient No. 4.

It's become somewhat standard of late for the ORGANIZATION not to have a first-round Draft pick, and 2012 was no different, with PERSON being their first selection, in the second round. The GPE high school product is big and strong, with a low-90s fastball that has good movement. He could have a plus heater when all is said and done. His slider could end up being his best pitch, with excellent bite to it. He has a feel for a changeup, though it needs some work, not uncommon for prep pitchers. PERSON's solid pro debut in the ORGANIZATION, albeit brief, should leave ORGANIZATION fans wanting to see more.

An elite athlete, PERSON is a three-sport star in high school. The same athleticism that allows him to throw down dunks on the basketball court has helped him develop into a coveted right-hander. PERSON' fastball sits in the low 90s and tops out at 95 mph with excellent life. His sharp slider is his best secondary offering and has the potential to be a swing-and-miss offering. His changeup and curveball give him two more pitches that have the chance to be average or better. PERSON, a GPE recruit, has a loose, easy delivery and repeats it well. His long, lean build leads scouts to believe he could add more velocity as he gets stronger and focuses solely on baseball.

PERSON jumped on scouts' radars during 2014 Cape Cod League and then followed it with an even better junior season at ORGANIZATION, leading to his selection in the fourth round of the 2015 Draft by the FACILITY. Despite pitching well in his professional debut -- half of which he spent in the full-season LOCATION League -- the FACILITY traded PERSON and right-hander J.B. Wendelken to GPE in December for PERSON Lawrie.PERSON has the makings of three average-or-better pitches, each of which plays up due to his advanced command. His 6-foot-5 frame and long arms help him create an angle to the plate and also lend to his deception, allowing him to sneak up on opposing hitters with his 88-90 mph fastball. The left-hander's ability to command his heater throughout the zone helps set up his curveball and split-changeup, with both offerings showing above-average potential. While some scouts view PERSON as a future No. 5 starter, others believe he could jump on the fast track to the ORGANIZATION with a move to the bullpen given his command, ground-ball tendencies and solid track record against both right- and left-handed hitters.
GPE is twitchy, has a plus arm and flashes shortstop-worthy actions. He lacks much physical projection but, if he can stay at short he might make enough contact to profile as a utility man.

PERSON continues to be the youngest regular wherever he plays and, as a result, heâs taken some lumps along the way. He struggled for much of the 2012 season in the ORGANIZATION, though he rallied to finish off the year well. He does have the ability to hit for average and power when heâs locked in, but he needs to pick up breaking stuff better for him to find consistency at the plate. He has an outstanding arm and the skills to stay at third long-term. The ORGANIZATION will need to be patient in letting PERSON develop. Theyâve pushed him fairly aggressively so far, but even if things have to slow down for him, he has plenty of time to get the reps he needs in the Minors.
Low-slot, three-pitch righty. Up to 95, slider is out pitch.

The ORGANIZATION were cautious at first with PERSON -- their 2011 first-rounder -- but they let him loose in 2013. He responded by pitching his way from PERSON to Double-A Pensacola by the end of the year, moving him into the upper levels of PERSON's system.PERSON throws his fastball in the mid-to-upper 90s, and he can touch 100 mph. He also throws a big breaking ball and a solid changeup, giving him three pitches with the potential to be above-average offerings. PERSON has smoothed out his delivery as a professional, leading to an improvement in his command. He throws all of his pitches for strikes, and he has an advanced understanding of his craft.PERSON combines the size, stuff and makeup to be a front-line starter in the ORGANIZATION.

If your team of attractive thieves needs a grease man for The Big Heist, then consider PERSON, who is an acrobatic, top-of-the-scale athlete who has on-job robbery experience. A plus runner, PERSON's speed and athleticism help hide some of the circuitous routes he takes to fly balls, and he has the physical talent to be a plus defender in center field as he refines those. He tracks pitches well, walks a lot, and has terrific bat control, which leads to low-lying, all-fields contact. He's a potential leadoff hitter with a plus glove in center, a potential first-division regular. Some clubs think he'll eventually hit for power, but that would require a drastically different approach/style of hitting than PERSON currently employs, and there are a host of other things to refine before the ORGANIZATION tweak a thing PERSON currently does pretty well. He'll be a 19-year-old at Hi-A all season, and could be a top 100 prospect by mid-summer.

PERSON GPE (PERSON, Ga.) is a baseball powerhouse, winning three state titles, sending seven players to the big leagues and getting six players drafted in the top three rounds. PERSON entered 2018 as a good bet to increase that last number to seven, but he hasn't thrown as well as he did on the showcase circuit last summer. While he still offers more upside than the typical prep left-hander, clubs don't think they can take him high enough to sign him away from his PERSON commitment.After sitting at 92-93 mph and touching 95 at times with angle and run on his fastball last summer, PERSON has seen his velocity drop 2-3 mph for much of this spring. His slider has similarly regressed, losing some power and bite and rarely looking like the potential plus pitch he flashed in the past. His changeup wasn't quite as deceptive as it had been previously, though he has the makings of an average third offering.PERSON has a strong frame and the athleticism to throw strikes, though his control also has wavered this year. His delivery is clean but also somewhat slow and gives batters a good look at his pitches. He has a ceiling as a mid-rotation starter but will need plenty of patience and development to get there.

PERSON signed for $500,000 (late third, early fourth round money) as a fifth round high schooler in 2017. He has a four-pitch mix headlined by a slider/cutter and his 88-92mph fastball plays up because it approaches hitters at a tough angle. He'll likely make his full-season debut in 2019 and projects as a No. 5 starter.

For the third year in a row, the ORGANIZATION took a high school position player with their first pick in the ORGANIZATION and this time it was PERSON, whom many thought to be the best pure prep hitter in the 2013 ORGANIZATION class. The ORGANIZATION first baseman has the chance to be an above-average hitter and should add more power as he develops. While he's a quality defender at first, he is limited to that position, so how much pop he does add will determine just how well he profiles at the corner infield spot. Most are confident, however, that his bat should carry him to the big leagues.

One of two lefties the ORGANIZATION received from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal prior to the 2015 season, PERSON certainly made a good first impression on his new organization, pitching across two levels and finishing in the top five in the system in ORGANIZATION, wins, strikeouts, ORGANIZATION and batting average against. He continued to pitch well in Triple-A in 2016 and was called upon to make his big league debut in a spot start in early July.PERSON uses a combination of athleticism, deception and a feel for pitching more than pure stuff to get hitters out. His fastball grades out as average, but plays up because it sinks and he commands it well. He's simplified his breaking ball, going to a slider that is effective. PERSON worked on his changeup a lot in 2015 against right-handed hitters and that's allowed that offspeed pitch to improve. While both secondary pitches are Major League-average offerings, the ORGANIZATION are pleased with how they progressed in 2015. He's all the more effective because he pounds the strike zone.PERSON's ceiling might be somewhat limited, with a No. 4 or 5 starter career ahead of him. But he's also a pretty good bet to reach that ceiling, and in the near future.

PERSON signed for a lot of money ($4.5 million) and amid a lot of controversy in February 2012. He presented a different birthdate than he had previously, a move that some clubs believed was designed to free him from the international bonus restrictions arising from the new Collective Bargaining Agreement. MLB eventually decided that it couldn't determine his birthdate, allowing the ORGANIZATION to keep him but also suspending him until July 2013.PERSON has barely played as a pro, breaking the hamate bone in his left hand 17 games into his debut last summer. He'll need plenty of polish and time to develop, but he also possesses the two tools every team looks for in a right fielder. He has above-average power, thanks to his bat speed and the leverage in his swing, and a cannon for an arm.PERSON will need to make some adjustments at the plate, where his long swing and pull-happy approach hamper his abilty to make consistent contact. He runs well for a big man and should be at least an average defender.

PERSON looked like the prototypical pitchability college lefty after two strong seasons at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, including a starring role in the ORGANIZATION World Series. He backed that up by pitching most of his first full season of pro ball in Double-A after the ORGANIZATION took him in the fifth round of the 2015 Draft. A combination of so-so performance and injuries have caused him to stall a bit.PERSON does have a good feel to pitch and knows how to move the ball around the zone. But he tends to nibble too much and work off the plate, leading to a much higher walk rate than is desirable from a finesse lefty. He has average stuff across the board, with a fastball that sits around 90-91 mph and works best when he keeps it down in the zone to get groundball outs, an average slider and a changeup that usually has good fade to it. The ORGANIZATION have preached to him about being more efficient and force contact earlier in counts because he is not overly physical and long innings will make it harder for him to hold up as a starter. He did have two disabled list stints with a forearm strain in 2017.PERSON made up for some lost innings and pitched largely in relief in the ORGANIZATION, throwing better during that limited stretch. He doesn't really have the stuff to be pitch out of the pen, so he'll have to make strides in attacking hitters to reach his potential as a back-end starter.

Since he was drafted in 2010, people thought PERSON looked like a future reliever. Maybe it was the bloodlines -- he is the son of former closer PERSON, after all -- and maybe it was the stuff.After missing a year following PERSON surgery and another one trying to get innings under his belt as a starter, PERSON moved to the bullpen in 2013, and he took off. Though he was a swingman on a loaded GPE pitching staff in 2016, most clubs had no trouble projecting Dunning as a mid-rotation starter. After producing a supplemental first-round pick in both 2012 (PERSON, GPE) and 2013 (ORGANIZATION, GPE), ORGANIZATION has a similar talent coming through its pipeline. While any discussion of GPE is mostly about projection, the GPE thought enough of him after his 2011 GPE debut in the ORGANIZATION that they sent him to the full-season ORGANIZATION in 2012 at age 19. Relatively projectable, ORGANIZATION sits in the 89-92 range with curveball feel and could develop enough of a changeup and control to pitch at the back of a rotation.

The ORGANIZATION have a reputation of late for producing professional-level pitching talent, and for good reason given the five arms that were taken in the top four rounds a year ago as well as PERSON, who could be a top pick this coming June. Joining the A's organization by way of ORGANIZATION III Birmingham-Southern, ORGANIZATION is now the de facto top catching prospect in the system since PERSON was shipped off to GPE. The best junior college prospect in the 2016 Draft, PERSON likely will fall just short of becoming the highest selection in GPE A. Logan (Ill.) CC history, a distinction that belongs to FACILITY Sox 1994 second-rounder PERSON. The ORGANIZATION recruit has no problem filling the strike zone, though he'll need to improve the command of his fastball and the consistency of his secondary pitches to make it as a big league starter. Finding college bats with power seems tough to do these days, so when a hitter at a good college program not only has it, but shows he can use it in games, teams will take notice. PERSON was among the nation's leaders in home runs in 2015, a breakout season at just the right time.PERSON's power from the right side of the plate is not in question, with home run pop to all fields, and not just in batting practice displays. PERSON had one of the strongest arms among catchers in the 2016 Draft, but worries about his bat and signability pushed him to the Reds in the 28th round and eventually to GPE. He has a more selective approach, is putting together more competitive at-bats and is making better contact. He's stronger and his right-handed swing looks quicker, giving him a chance to produce close to average power.

A toolsy outfielder as well as an outstanding closer at ORGANIZATION State PERSON, PERSON might be one of the more intriguing prospects from the 2013 Draft class because the Reds are going to continue, in some capacity, to allow him to be a two-way player. Both that curve and his command should improve if he were to focus solely on pitching. PERSON has been inconsistent at times with the bat, though he does have some raw tools to hit and run well.

PERSON has arguably the best hitter's traits in the entire draft. His bat is quick, he can move the barrel around and square pitches in various parts of the strike zone, he generates good extension through contact and has already started to grow into the power necessary to profile at firts base. PERSON also has mature ball/strike recognition and often displays visible contempt for umpires who lack it. He's a good athlete and potential defensive asset at first with good hands, footwork and an above average infield arm.

PERSON is a perfect example of a high risk/high reward type prospect. The raw tools are undeniable; whether he can put them to consistent use remains to be seen. He has a lot of work to do at the plate -- he didn't exactly light the world on fire in his performance in the ORGANIZATION in 2013 -- but there are the skills to perhaps be an average hitter with average power. He has a strong arm that works fine at shortstop, but it's unclear what his long-term defensive home is. The future fielding grade is based on him at third base, though the Twins have PERSON at the same level and PERSON above, and many feel PERSON will end up in the outfield. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON landed two All-Tournament team awards in 2014 and '15, and he earned the GPE 24-5A Newcomer of the Year award in '15. PERSON parlayed a stellar junior season into an offer and a commitment to the ORGANIZATION of GPE at FACILITY. PERSON hit everywhere he'd ever played before a surprising summer slump with the GPE collegiate national team. There are those who believe PERSON has one of the best bats in the 2015 college class. He was named the 2014 ORGANIZATION of the Year as a sophomore, after leading the league in all three slash stats at .351/.472/.557. PERSON has a quick left-handed stroke, strength and patience. He has plus raw power but he doesn't fully tap into it because he bats from an extreme crouch and has a flat swing. He might hit 20 homers per season if he stands more upright and adds some loft. Though he's listed at 6 feet and 230 pounds, he's a better athlete than his build might indicate. An all-state running back at FACILITY (PERSON, Fla.), an athletic powerhouse that produced PERSON and several other pro and Olympic athletes, PERSON has close to average speed. He has good instincts as a runner and defender, though a below-average arm limits him to left field.

Since moving to the bullpen in July of 2018, PERSON has struck out more than a batter per inning in what are almost always multi-inning appearances. After a dominant month at Hi-A to start 2019, the ORGANIZATION moved PERSON to Double-A and atrted to vary his workload, and first asked hiim to throw on back-to-back nights at the end of July. He's being groomed for a relief role, one that will likely be fastball-heavy. His fastball has life at the top of the zone and PERSON really hides the ball well, so he's able to slip it past hitters at the letters. His secondary stuff is average on pure stuff but plays well off his heater. He profiles as a middle reliever.

The ORGANIZATION made PERSON a sixth-rounder in 2012, one year after his brother, GPE, went in the seventh round to the ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION quickly made the younger PERSON a second baseman, where his range and arm will likely make him a solid defender. Some scouts believe PERSON has a higher ceiling than his older brother. He began his first full-professional season in the ORGANIZATION.

The first position player selected by the ORGANIZATION in the 2015 Draft, PERSON gave up a Stanford commitment to sign for $1 million as a second-rounder. His debut didn't go well, as he hit just .201/.281/.282 in the Rookie-level PERSON and left several scouts wondering whether his left-handed swing would play in pro ball. He made quality adjustments before his second season, however, and is looking more like the player the ORGANIZATION hoped they were getting.After producing a lot of weak contact last summer, PERSON now has a more consistent approach, is getting in better position to hit and has more leverage in his stroke. He's exuding much more confidence at the plate, tinkering a lot less and not rolling over on weak grounders as much as he did a year ago. He still needs to tighten up his plate discipline, but he could hit for a decent average with 15-20 homers per season.Though PERSON isn't especially quick out of the batter's box, he has close to plus speed once he gets going. He has played all three outfield positions in pro ball and has seen most of his time in left field, where his fringy arm fits best. His overall game has drawn him comparisons to PERSON and PERSON.

Depending on when you saw PERSON, GPE's left-handed closer, you saw a potential late-inning reliever with a power arm or a southpaw with poor command and less than explosive stuff who looked more like a specialist. The ORGANIZATION clearly saw enough of the former to make him their third-round selection in the 2015 Draft.At his best, PERSON has a plus fastball from the left side, one that will touch 96 mph on occasion. He'll more typically sit in the 89-92 mph range, leaving some wondering if he has the capacity to hit the mid-90s with more consistency in the pro game. His curve is fringy at times, better when he stays on top of it. He has a quick arm and his delivery does add some deception. The effort in that delivery does make it a bit more difficult for him to find the strike zone more consistently. If PERSON can unlock that plus velocity more consistently, he could evolve into lefty setup man. At worst, PERSON does have the deception to be a specialist down the line.

After spending his first two college seasons at first base, PERSON made the move behind the plate during the summer in the ORGANIZATION and was named an All-Star in the elite summer college circuit.During his junior year, PERSON saw some time behind the plate for the GPE, while also playing first base and right field. He has the skills to stick as a backstop, with a solid average arm and quick release. He's very athletic and runs well for a catcher or first baseman. He doesn't get cheated at the plate, and his combination of bat speed and strength should mean he hits for average and some power at the next level.PERSON's value obviously is higher if he's behind the plate, and the team that believes he can develop there will take him in the first few rounds.

PERSON's ORGANIZATION stock steadily improved during his senior year at ORGANIZATION, where he posted a 1.07 ERA with a 0.85 ORGANIZATION and 11.8 strikeouts per nine while leading the program to a third-place finish in the 2014 ORGANIZATION World Series. If not, the right-hander's power arm could make him an effective late-inning reliever.

Acquired from GPE as part of the ORGANIZATION Pressly trade, PERSON has reached Double-A as a starter despite having been projected as a reliever for almost his entire pro career. He throws really hard -- typically in the mid-90s, peaking above that -- and has a great build. It makes sense to give him starter reps until he's needed in the majors, since it means more chances for him to refine his secondary stuff and control. He's a high-probability middle reliever, but he has a set-up man's arm strength.

PERSON joined the D-backs along with PERSON last Trading Deadline, the return for PERSON. The D-backs had drafted the lefty out of high school in 2011, but didn't sign him, so they were happy to land him three years later and watch him pitch very well in six post-deadline starts in his new organization.PERSON worked in a piggyback system with the Brewers during his first taste of full-season ball, with mixed results. But he really took off after the trade, showing much better command and a better understanding of how to use his three-pitch mix. His fastball is a tick above average now, touching 93 mph with good life, and there might some more in the tank. His curveball is an average breaking ball and his changeup shows glimpses of being an above-average secondary pitch. The left-hander misses bats, but before his six-start revelation with the D-backs, throwing strikes consistently had been elusive.PERSON's success in those areas carried over to his first full season with the D-backs and it's looking like he might have the ceiling of a No. 3 or 4 starter.

On a ORGANIZATION staff loaded with hard-throwing right-handers, no one throws harder than PERSON. He usually deals at 92-95 mph, tickles the upper 90s and has peaked at 99.PERSON's fastball lacks life and command, however, so it gets hit more than its velocity suggests it should. As a result, the ORGANIZATION have used him mostly as a set-up man, which is also his likely ceiling as a pro.PERSON's second pitch is a hard curveball with 11-to-5 break. He's not especially tall, so he needs to stay on top of his pitches with his overhand delivery to achieve some downhill plane. Otherwise, his stuff becomes vulnerable when he leaves it up in the strike zone.

When the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the seventh round of the 2012 Draft and went over pick value to sign him away from attending PERSON, they knew the right-hander was a bit of a long-term project as a position player who emerged as a pitching prospect during his senior year of high school. He throws his fastball in the 90-95 mph range and he's shown an ability to use his 6-foot-5 frame to throw it downhill and get groundball outs. He throws both a curve and a slider, with the former a bit ahead of the latter. His changeup continues to improve the more he throws it. He's generally around the strike zone with all of his pitches.While PERSON has been in pro ball for six years, he might still have some upside while getting close to being ready to knock on the door as a back-half of a rotation type starter.

PERSON began to ascend the fall after his freshman year, when he looked like one of the two most talented PERSON players during fall practices in GSP. He then broke out as a sophomore, and further separated himself from the rest of the top talents with an electrifying 2018 postseason. He held the top spot, wire-to-wire, during the subsequent 12 months, which included him hitting .427/.584/.772 as a junior. It's because GSP is good at everything. Remarkably mobile for someone his size, he comfortably has the skills to not only stay at catcher, but excel there. He's an agile ball-blocker, he can throw, and he's a con artist pitch-framer who gets umpires booed because fans are convinced they're all strikes. On top of that, this is a switch-hitter with both power and feel for contact from both sides of the plate and an intense, earnest, vocal leader. He is arguably the best draft prospect of the last half decade, a polished, complete player with star-level physical tools.

PERSON was a projection prep arm from GPE whose price was just high enough to get him to GPE. He had a big freshman year there and then had a national coming-out party as the ace of ORGANIZATION USA that summer. PERSON continued at about that level for the next two seasons, slinging in a heavy, 91-96 mph sinker from a low slot with a deceptive, crossfire delivery. He threw strikes and had a plus slider. Scouts who weren't as enthusiastic about PERSON's changeup, or arm slot, or the length of his arm action saw a reliever. His stuff would flatten out and his command would back up as he fatigued into the late stages of some starts. The ORGANIZATION had PERSON change his delivery and arm action for the first half-dozen or so starts in 2018, focusing on a more traditional four-seam fastball approach. It didn't work, and GPE let PERSON go back to what he had been doing later in the year, and his dominant final two months of 2018 reflect his comfort with this approach. We think the likely outcome here is a multi-inning power reliever who dominates righties with strikeouts and groundballs, though some see a starter in the mold of PERSON. Either way, PERSON should move quickly, especially if he's only asked to face a lineup once or twice per outing.

PERSON is PERSON's all-time saves leader. He was 93-96 with an above-average slider almost every time out as a ORGANIZATION, but began experiencing wild fluctuations in velocity during his early time in pro ball. But in 2017, his stuff returned to its collegiate form; the ORGANIZATION traded him for ORGANIZATION bonus space, and PERSON sped to the majors. He profiles as a standard, two-pitch reliever, but the velo fluctuation and 2016 injury dilute his FV a tad.

PERSON was raw and lanky when PERSON signed him as an 18-year-old out of GPE in 2009. He combines it with a sharp hard slider that is an above-average offering at its best.Like many tall pitchers, it has taken PERSON some time to smooth out his delivery. He still likely will never pitch with great control, but his stuff is good enough to make him effective at the back of a bullpen.

PERSON doesn't have prototypical size for a starting pitcher, but he makes up for it with arm strength. He was PERSON' ace as a junior and excelled in the role. PERSON's fastball typically sits in the low-90s and routinely reaches the mid-90s. His curve is a potential out pitch, with a hard, sharp break to it, and his changeup has the chance to be an average offering as well, though he has to become more consistent with his arm speed. PERSON goes right after hitters, and his bulldog mentality would serve him well if he ever moves to the bullpen. The ORGANIZATION will develop him as a starter for now, and he has the tools to give him a chance to stay in the rotation.

PERSON declined to sign with the ORGANIZATION as the 21st overall pick in the 2011 Draft, then became the 18th player ever taken in the first round twice when the ORGANIZATION popped him at ORGANIZATION. 14 last June. After helping ORGANIZATION win the ORGANIZATION World Series, he signed for $2,613,200. When he's on, PERSON has three plus pitches and the look of a frontline starter. He can throw his 92-97 mph fastball past hitters or throw them off balance with his lively changeup. He also has a power curveball, though he lost his feel for it at the end of the college season.With his strong, athletic build, PERSON maintains his stuff into the late innings. He had a history of struggling to repeat his delivery and losing his control and command at times, but he has been much more consistent in his first full pro season.

LOCATION has never had a pitcher taken in the top five rounds of the GPE, with only outfielders PERSON and PERSON going that early. PERSON, who began the year as the ORGANIZATION' Tuesday starter but worked his way to being their Friday night ace en route to being a ORGANIZATION semifinalist, has the chance to become the first.PERSON has a solid three-pitch mix that points to a future as a starting pitcher at the next level. He'll throw his fastball in the 90-94 mph range and maintains his velocity, able to reach back for that 94 late in starts when he needs it. His breaking ball is close to a 12-to-6 curve with late and sharp break to it and he throws an effective mid-80s circle change that has the bottom fall out of it. He commands all three pitches well and has thrown a lot more strikes, while missing more bats, this year compared to his sophomore season.PERSON has a limited ceiling, that of a No. 4 or 5 starter. But his performance in his GPE season has had more than ORGANIZATION voters take notice, giving him a good chance to become the first LOCATION pitcher to go in the top six rounds since the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in 2008.

GPE parlayed his impressive turn in the 2014 Cape Cod League with a strong junior year at ORGANIZATION into a second-round selection in the '15 PERSON. The ORGANIZATION gave the right-hander a $1,108,000 bonus as the ORGANIZATION. 55 overall pick, and GPE quickly rewarded the organization by pitching well at ORGANIZATION A Wisconsin in his pro debut. A right forearm strain suffered early in 2016 led to a two-month disabled-list stint, and GPE was ineffective when he finally took the mound. PERSON healthy in 2017, GPE finally furthered his development, pitching well over 22 starts (3.38 ERA) with PERSON and then finishing his season on a high note in Double-A.Listed at 6-foot-6, 265 pounds, GPE has an imposing presence on the mound. He's sacrificed some of his velocity for better command, though he still sits comfortably in the low 90s and at times higher, with an upper-80s cutter enables him to effectively attack left-handed hitters under the hands. His changeup is below average because he throws it too firmly, albeit it with fastball-like arm speed. His curveball, though still slurvy at times, has improved as a professional and receives average grades from evaluators. He throws all four pitches for strikes, and knows how to utilize his height to drive the ball down in the zone.GPE's strikeout rate backed up in 2017 as he focused on throwing more quality strikes and working deeper into games. While he still needs to refine his secondaries and fastball command, as well as answer some lingering questions about his durability, GPE has all the ingredients needed to become a big league starter.

PERSON projected to go in the middle of the first round of the 2014 Draft, yet the FACILITY Sox were able to get him with the 44th overall choice in the second round. If his pro debut (which included a 59/4 K/BB ratio) is any indication, he could be a bigger steal than PERSON was with the ORGANIZATION. 3 overall pick.PERSON has a promising four-pitch repertoire that starts with a low-90s fastball that tops out at 96 mph with good sink. His hard slider gives him a potential second plus pitch, while his curveball and changeup show the makings of becoming solid offerings. Add in his control and makeup, and PERSON has a high floor to go with his lofty ceiling. One of the most athletic and projectable pitchers available in the 2014 Draft, he's a former three-sport star who easily repeats a loose, effortless delivery.

Ever since the ORGANIZATION took him and gave him a way above-slot bonus in 2010, PERSON has hit his way quickly up the organizational ladder, reaching Double-A in 2012 and winning PERSON MVP honors along the way. He can flat-out hit, adjusting extremely well to any and all pitching. He drives the ball to all fields and while he hasn't shown too much in the way of home run power to date, there is definitely pop in his bat that will come. PERSON started his pro career as a third baseman and could have been an average defender there, but he moved to the outfield in 2012, largely to find the quickest path to the big leagues for his bat. There isn't a spot waiting for him just yet, but don't be surprised if he hits his way into PERSON's plans in the near future.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

A good get for $150,000 in the ninth round of his draft, PERSON is a slightly atypical teenage projection arm with feel for spin. PERSON to the way PERSON was viewed by a minority of teams, some clubs thought PERSON's measurables were misleading as to his projectability and that his frame was so slight that there was nowhere to put extra mass. So far PERSON's fastball is up a little bit from high school but still south of the average big league heater, and we now have quantifiable verification that he can spin his breaking ball well (about 2500 rpm on average). If the velocity suddenly pops, he'll shoot up past the relief-only types on this list as PERSON will have a better chance of starting.

There are gothic cathedrals in GPE that have smaller gaps between their ceilings and floors than PERSON, who had some of the most explosive but unkempt talent in the 2018 draft class. PERSON's special bat speed and ability to rotate are both evident to the naked eye, and he also has remarkable bat control for a player who takes such high-effort swings. But everything about his game is very raw and he'll likely require years of polish before he's ready for the majors. This is especially evident in his footwork in the box, where PERSON's stride length and direction are both highly variable. At times, this enables PERSON to turn on pitches on the inner half; at others it wrecks his swing's balance and composition entirely. There's also a wide range of potential defensive outcomes for PERSON. He may end up on the middle infield or in center, depending on how his body and infield actions develop, or possibly in an outfield corner. The good news is that PERSON was one of the youngest players available in the 2018 draft and he didn't turn 18 the middle of October. There's a lot of time for both him and the ORGANIZATION to figure this stuff out, and he has some unteachable talents (the bat speed and bat control) that could drive an offensive profile befitting any position if he transforms into a hitter instead of a swinger.

The best teenaged prospect to come out of GPE since PERSON in 2011, PERSON sparked a bidding war among teams that landed him a $31.5 million bonus from the ORGANIZATION. That's the largest bonus ever given to an amateur player, eclipsing the $16.25 million (deferred over 11 years) Aroldis PERSON got from the Reds in 2010. Factor in the matching $31.5 million penalty that PERSON had to pay for exceeding its international bonus pool, and the total outlay for his services was $63 million.PERSON offers more offensive potential than most middle infielders. He's a switch-hitter with electric bat speed who makes consistent hard contact from both sides of the plate. He could deliver a .280 average and 20-25 homers on an annual basis, and he also has the well above-average speed to be a significant basestealing threat.PERSON primarily played second and third base in GPE while also seeing time at shortstop and in center field. His strong arm can play anywhere on the diamond, and the consensus among scouts is that he fits best at second base. He's young and may need a couple of years in the Minors, but he looks like a star who will be worth the wait.

Undrafted out of ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, GPE), PERSON spent two years pitching for the ORGANIZATION in the independent Frontier League before inking a deal with the Marlins in July 2016. He's since climbed quickly through the Minors, opening his first full professional campaign with PERSON, where he was a ORGANIZATION State PERSON, and reaching Double-A roughly a year after signing.PERSON may pitch with a tick below average velocity, but his fastball plays up because he creates a good downhill angle to the plate with a deceptive delivery. And while his stuff may not be overpowering, it hasn't stopped the right-hander from piling up his share of whiffs early in his pro career. He profiles as a back-of-the-rotation starter or a long reliever.

GPE school players from western PERSON often need some time to adjust to the pro game, with the level of competition at the amateur level there not particularly high. He also struck out nearly 47 percent of the time and, simply put, he'll need to put balls in play more to tap into that power. PERSON runs well and plays a better center field than anticipated, with good jumps and routes to go along with a solid arm, giving him a chance to stay up the middle long-term.PERSON is still a project, one far away from the big leagues. If he can learn to control the strize zone more, he could unleash a lot more power and run production in the future.

An athletic, toolsy outfielder when the ORGANIZATION drafted him in 2012, PERSON turned that promise into production in a breakout 2014 season. He was named the ORGANIZATION of the Year after posting a .905 ORGANIZATION, collecting 153 hits and scoring 87 runs in 130 games between Class A Quad Cities and Class A Advanced Lancaster. In his first two years in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON looked more like a top-of-the-order hitter thanks to his patience, contact-oriented approach and speed. He's an above-average runner, giving him an intriguing power-speed combination. PERSON' speed gives him a chance to stick in center field, though some scouts think he's better suited defensively for right field. His strong arm will play well at either position.

PERSON became a full-time catcher in the summer before his senior season at GPE (GPE) High and showed enough promise to earn top-five-rounds consideration in the 2013 Draft, though he went unpicked because he was strongly committed to GPE. He was the regular catcher on the ORGANIZATION' 2014 College World Series team as a freshman and has split time behind the plate the past two years while also seeing action at first and third base.PERSON's most impressive tool is his plus raw right-handed power, which he generates with a combination of bat speed and strength. The question is how much he'll be able to tap into that pop in pro ball because he often tries to do too much at the plate and pull every pitch out of the park. His receiving and blocking skills are fine, and he has a solid, accurate arm. Though he's a bottom-of-the-scale runner, he moves well enough behind the plate.

Players taken in the 28th round of the GPE, even athletic two-sport standouts like ORGANIZATION, don't enter pro ball with a ton of expectations. ORGANIZATION signed for $100,000 back in 2013 and has consistently outperformed his GPE status, including hitting his way across three levels up to Triple-A in 2017 and earning a spot on the 40-man roster. That led to his first big league callup in 2018.After a slow start to his pro career, things really started to click for ORGANIZATION in 2016 when he hit over .300 and got on base more than 40 percent of the time. He continued to draw walks, and while his strikeout rate went up, he doesn't chase very often and showed some more extra-base pop, especially late in the season. His future is likely to be that of a very valuable fourth outfielder, but if his defense and baserunning continue to improve, the ORGANIZATION are not ruling out the 23-year-old developing into more of an impact type of big leaguer.

PERSON had a huge sophomore year at ORGANIZATION's, then followed up with a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION, making him one of the better college catching options heading into his Draft year in 2017. But a rough junior year hurt his stock, making him available in the fifth round for the ORGANIZATION, who signed him for just below pick value. The ORGANIZATION like his leadership behind the plate.There's work to be done on PERSON's defensive game, but the ORGANIZATION are committed to allowing him to develop behind the plate. If he can progress there, he has the makings of an offensive-minded backstop who can at least be a serviceable backup at the highest level.

Once a walk-on at ORGANIZATION, PERSON has become one of the more well-rounded catching prospects in the minors. He has always had near elite arm strength but because he didn't catch much pro-quality stuff in college, his receiving and ball-blocking were undercooked for a college prospect when he first entered pro ball. Those aspects of his defense have vastly improved, and he's now an average defender with a chance to be above, and his arm douses opposing baserunners. 
PERSON also has plus raw power, though he hasn't typically hit for it in games for various reasons. In college, a broken hamate likely masked his power and was part of the reason he fell to the 2016 draft's third round. In pro ball, his swing has been very compact, relying on PERSON's raw strength rather than efficient biomechanical movement to deliver extra-bases. He broke his other hamate last year. PERSON's nearly .500 SLG at ORGANIZATION is above what we expect moving forward, and instead think PERSON will be a high-contact bat with doubles power, which would be an above-average regular behind the plate.

PERSON didn't make an immediate impression after signing for $75,000 out of the ORGANIZATION (P.R.) JC in 2015, batting a combined .223/.317/.319 in his first two pro seasons. Then he opened eyes in the GPE PERSON in 2016-17, leading the circuit in on-base percentage (.393) while ranking second in hitting (.330) and ORGANIZATION (.806). PERSON's hand-eye coordination and penchant for making hard contact suggest that his hitting ability is very real, even if a right thumb injury has affected his numbers this year. He began to tap into his solid raw power more often in 2017, and he could do so even more if he adds some loft to his right-handed stroke because he hits a lot of ground balls. He also walks infrequently because he puts the ball in play so easily.One of the best all-around players in the ORGANIZATION system, PERSON also offers quality defense at third base. He's agile, has sure hands and a strong arm, though he needs to cut down on his errors after leading ORGANIZATION third basemen with 21. He has fringy speed but runs the bases aggressively.

GPE hit for average but not much power in his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION and in the ORGANIZATION, and his prospect stock didn't take off until he hit 13 homers last spring. He earned Mid-American player of the year honors and went in the third round to the FACILITY, signing for $719,100. He doesn't have the smoothest right-handed swing, but he manages the strike zone extremely well and makes consistent hard contact. He might top out around 15 homers per season, though that might be enough to make him a regular considering his hitting and on-base ability.GPE has solid speed out of the batter's box and is a plus runner once he gets going. He's quick enough to steal a few bases and GPE has made him a full-time center fielder after he manned right field for ORGANIZATION. He has the plus arm to play there in pro ball and his ability to handle all three outfield spots will help him if he winds up as a reserve.

The ORGANIZATION took PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 35 overall pick after his junior year at ORGANIZATION. Rather than sign, the right-hander bet on himself and headed back to school for his senior season. That decision didn't go as well as planned and after an uneven season, he ended up landing in the fourth round of the 2016 Draft. While injuries have slowed PERSON's progress, it still looks like the ORGANIZATION got a serious bargain. The elbow wasn't a problem for PERSON in 2018, but he did suffer a broken foot (while walking on an uneven sidewalk) that ended his season in late July after he had made two starts in Triple-A. When he's healthy, PERSON will sit in the low 90s and can reach back for 95 mph. He has a trio of secondary pitches that receive average grades from evaluators. PERSON's slider continues to be ahead of his fringy curveball, though he does land the latter for strikes and uses it in any count. He's made progress developing a changeup to the point where it's regarded as an average big league offering, with room to improve. Facing Double- and Triple-A hitters for the first time last year led to a regression in PERSON's control, but he's generally around the zone with all four pitches, with feel for sequencing that leads to weak contact and a solid number of whiffs. Despite his season-ending injuries in back-to-back years, PERSON still has been able to move through the ORGANIZATION relatively fast and will open 2019 on the cusp of the Majors. A strong performance back in Triple-A should help him get there, while further improvements to his secondary arsenal and command could help him reach his potential as a mid-rotation starter.

A 33rd-round pick out of a GPE high school by the ORGANIZATION in 2016, PERSON made an instant impact at ORGANIZATION. He led the LOCATION and all ORGANIZATION Division I freshmen with 10 wins and helped the ORGANIZATION advance to the first super regional in program history in 2017. He has improved throughout his college career and could factor in the first five rounds of the Draft.PERSON employs a low arm slot and opens early in his delivery, which doesn't thrill scouts but creates tremendous sink. He has averageish velocity on his fastball, ranging from 88-95 mph, but well above-average life that generates a lot of swings and misses as well as groundballs. He also commands his heater well, and the net result is that it plays as a plus pitch.PERSON has a sweepy slider that's effective because it moves in the opposite direction from his sinker. His fading changeup is a reliable third option and can be a solid pitch at its best. A dogged competitor, he has a ceiling of a No. 4 or 5 starter and could have value as a multi-inning reliever.

PERSON has two legitimate pitches and a history of success against top competition, so the PERSON felt comfortable drafting him in the seventh round, then giving him second-round money to sign him away from ORGANIZATION State.The Arkansas high school right-hander doesn't have much projection remaining in his 6-foot-1 frame, but he can hit 96 mph with his fastball and he generates a lot of sink and groundouts when he works at 88-93. He also has good feel for spinning a curveball, giving him a second solid pitch. His fading changeup should continue to get better as he uses it more often at the next level.Though he's not projectable, PERSON has a strong frame and repeats his sound delivery well, which bodes well for throwing strikes and staying healthy.

GPE to a strong showing with PERSON in 2013 and the following spring at ORGANIZATION, PERSON appeared to be on his way to becoming a top 10 pick in the 2014 GPE until he underwent PERSON surgery that May. Despite the injury, he didn't fall far on GPE day, as the ORGANIZATION grabbed him 18th overall.When healthy, PERSON usually deals fastballs at 91-93 mph, topping out at 97, and the pitch plays up because it has nice life, and he can locate it where he wants.
