He also shows flashes of having a useful changeup.The ORGANIZATION have had success helping young pitchers through PERSON rehab, including PERSON, their top prospect and 2012 first-rounder. Once PERSON returns to full health, he has the potential to give the ORGANIZATION system another premium arm.

After two years as a little-used two-way player at FACILITY, PERSON transferred to LOCATION. He went undrafted as a junior first baseman/closer, and was one of the first seniors taken in 2015 when the ORGANIZATION signed him for more than $400,000 below pick value at the start of ORGANIZATION B.PERSON ranked among the ORGANIZATION II leaders in home runs and slugging percentage, but his future is on the mound. He was working at 93-95 mph and reaching 97 with his fastball. His 82-86 slider gives him a second plus pitch at times, though it can get slurvy. PERSON has a physical, durable frame that allows him to maintain his velocity even when he pitches on consecutive days. He has a decent delivery that he repeats well, allowing him to throw strikes. He'll probably be a late-inning reliever in pro ball, though he flashes an average changeup in bullpen sessions and could get a look as a starter, especially given the ORGANIZATION' penchant for developing college relievers into rotation members.

GPE burst onto the national scene last summer hitting 100 mph at multiple events and flashing two plus breaking balls. That alone is enough to go on the first day if the health checks out, which GPE's does. The neutral aspect is that he's a maxed-out 6-foot-2, 200 pounds. The negative aspect is a very long arm stroke and as you might guess, a power approach rather than fine command. No prep prospect can be everything as an 18-year-old but GPE's velocity was 95-98, touching 100 this spring in early starts with lots of rest and was more 92-96 touching 97 when on normal rest. Pitchers lose velocity as they age, so many teams prefer a more conventional delivery and arm stroke, and a pitcher with average stuff and good feel who can grow into power stuff, rather than a power pitcher who has to learn feel only when his stuff declines. The recent track record of prep pitchers who hit 98-100 before the draft is riddled with injuries and command regression. With prep pitching being so subject to specific team tastes to try to avoid busts and attrition, many teams are out on GPE on Day 1 and others, particularly the more progressive clubs that value velo, spin rate, high octane stuff in shorter stints, and area control with that stuff, are interested in the 20s and 30s.

Some scouts look at PERSON and see ORGANIZATION third baseman PERSON at the same age.Like the young GPE, PERSON is a hard-hitting infielder with a good projectable body and a strong arm. The infielder runs a 6.8-7.1-second 60-yard timed run and will likely end up as an average runner. It is his bat, arm and power that's expected to carry him through the ORGANIZATION ranks and to the big leagues one day.At the plate, PERSON has a good rhythm and a short, compact swing with plus bat speed. He has a chance to be an above-average hitter with above-average power. There's still some room to grow and get stronger, which leads some evaluators to think PERSON will eventually move from shortstop to third base and still develop into an above-average defender. He's been praised for his solid actions on defense and good body control. PERSON is from ORGANIZATION, GPE, and trains with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign the young infielder.

GPE is the oldest player on The ORGANIZATION and he's only here, despite a career rife with injury and inconsistency, because his stuff is so good. He's among the hardest throwers in professional baseball and also one of the best at spinning the baseball. He is wild and the quality of his secondary stuff is inconsistent, but at times he looks unhittable. He struck out 33 in 23 big league innings last year, but he's currently on the ORGANIZATION with a forearm strain. He could one day pitch his way into high-leverage innings as long as he has this kind of stuff, which he has maintained despite the many maladies.

The FACILITY Sox have been rebuilding their Latin GPE program since a bonus-skimming scandal ruined it in 2008, and their biggest move since then came in July 2013. PERSON landed PERSON, ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION. 2-ranked international prospect, for $1.6 million. He's still just 18, and scouts inside and outside the organization speculate that he could have been the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in the 2015 Draft if he were a GPE high school senior.Adolfo has immense power potential that results from bat speed, long levers, good loft in his right-handed swing and projectable strength. He's still learning at the plate, as evidenced by his Rookie-level ORGANIZATION League-leading 85 strikeouts in 46 games in his pro debut. He'll need to improve his pitch recognition to fully tap into his all-fields pop.Adolfo's arm strength is nearly as impressive as his raw power, making him a natural for right field. That's where he played in his debut, though he showed the aptitude for center field during instructional league and will get time more there in 2015. Presently a solid runner, he figures to lose a step once he matures physically.

One of the taller and more projectable pitchers in the 2019 high school class, PERSON performed well while hitting most of the major stops on the showcase circuit last summer. Like most prep arms from the LOCATION, he's far from a finished product, but his potential is obvious. The ORGANIZATION clearly saw that, spending nearly twice the pick value in the third round with a bonus of nearly $1.25 million to sign the right-hander away from his commitment to the ORGANIZATION of Virginia.PERSON has an 89-93 mph fastball that tops out at 95 with riding life up in the strike zone. His 6-foot-6 frame and high-three-quarters arm slot provide plenty of downhill plane, and his size also creates extension that adds to the quality of his fastball package. He has high spin rates and good depth on his mid-70s curveball, which could be a hammer once he gains more velocity.PERSON has some sink on his changeup and while it's often too firm, it should improve as he throws it more often. Many tall, young pitchers have trouble keeping their deliveries in sync, but he repeats his mechanics well and provides strikes.

The only player to appear on three world championship teams for ORGANIZATION, GPE, as a draft-eligible sophomore at FACILITY, was viewed as one of the more well-rounded college shortstops in the 2016 Draft. The ORGANIZATION selected him with the ORGANIZATION. 87 overall pick in the third round last June, signing him for $700,000.GPE does a lot of things fairly well, though no single tool is plus. He has a solid approach and makes consistent contact from the right side of the plate, albeit without power, and he can steal some bases now and again. He's a capable defender at shortstop, though most believe he'll need to move over to second base, where his below-average arm strength is a better fit, to have the chance to be an everyday player. He saw time at both middle-infield positions during his pro debut in the LOCATION, and that continued with the move up to full-season ball in 2017.The ORGANIZATION intend to give GPE the chance to stick at short, but his ability to play second should work in his favor and ultimately could help him carve out a role as a quality backup at both spots.

Though PERSON was a left-handed pitcher with a fastball that could reach 94 mph, the ORGANIZATION preferred him as a hitter and spent $800,000 to sign him as a sixth-rounder out of a GPE high school in 2011. He fractured his right kneecap in his first pro game and missed all of 2012 after it didn't heal properly, though he made his way to Triple-A by age 22. The ORGANIZATION made him the ORGANIZATION. 2 overall pick in the 2015 Rule 5 Draft yet couldn't keep him, and GPE's glut of outfield prospects forced him to begin each of the last two seasons back in Double-A, but he has continued to persevere.While PERSON doesn't have a plus tool, he also doesn't have a glaring weakness. He has hit for average throughout the Minors, making consistent hard contact and using the entire field. After hitting just 11 homers in his first three full pro seasons, he has done a better job of using his lower half to generate power and set a career high for homers in 2017 despite missing most of the first month recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his left knee in March.PERSON's solid speed and average arm allow him to play all three outfield positions. After spending most of his time in center field earlier in his career, he has gotten most of his action in left field the last two years. While he may have a hard time claiming an everyday job with the ORGANIZATION, he could be a useful fourth outfielder.

PERSON racked up 40 saves during his four years at ORGANIZATION and dominated for two summers on the Cape before signing with the ORGANIZATION as a 10th-round pick in 2017. He's enjoyed similar success in the professional ranks so far and began to move quickly in 2018, ascending three levels to reach Double-A in his first full season. The ORGANIZATION assigned him to Triple-A to open 2019, though early struggles in the ORGANIZATION led to a demotion back to Double-A Binghamton in June. PERSON' fastball is below-average from a velocity standpoint, sitting mostly in the upper 80s, but he consistently gets it past hitters thanks to deception created by his low arm slot. Said slot gives his effective slider broad sweeping action, while his changeup drops off the table as it approaches the plate. The change is the better secondary offering, one that receives above-average grades from scouts, and was instrumental in him holding left-handed hitters to a .167/.254/.294 clip in 2018. He's an adept strike-thrower with all three pitches, demonstrating above-average control and command against hitters on both sides of the plate.But perhaps what's most intriguing about PERSON is that he can induce whiffs with relative ease. Working 66 2/3 innings in his first full season, he struck out 37 percent of the hitters he faced while averaging 13 strikeouts-per-nine. PERSON doesn't fit into a neat box as a big league reliever, but there's something to be said about his sustained dominance, and it would surprise no one in the organization if he continued his accelerated climb towards the Majors.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON as a left-handed pitcher in the 31st round in 2014 out of GPE (Mo.) JC, where he was a two-way player, but he turned them down to transfer to PERSON. He led the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION with 83 RBIs during his first full pro season and ranked second in the high Class A GPE League with 92 last year while also hitting 21 homers and stealing 37 bases.He's a tooled-up, left-handed-hitting right fielder, prompting one club official to compare him to PERSON, though PERSON isn't nearly as polished at the plate as the greatest hitter in franchise history. His extra-large frame gives him an extra-long swing that resulted in 359 strikeouts in his first 320 pro games. He has 20-20 potential, with plus raw power that he began to tap into more last year when he began hitting more fly balls and the speed to match.Though he runs well enough to at least fill in as a center fielder, PERSON fits better in right. His arm delivered 88-92 mph fastballs in college and gives him a third plus tool.

The ORGANIZATION have a terrific young catching tandem in PERSON and ORGANIZATION, who we project to play a glove-centric second fiddle to PERSON's bat for the next half decade. ORGANIZATION has been lauded for his defense since high school, and he remains excellent back there, and has a plus arm. He has struggled in the past to lift the ball, and while he showed some movement in that regard last year, it's unlikely that ORGANIZATION hits enough to profile as an everyday catcher.

PERSON was a "famous name" entering the summer showcase circuit last year, one with major raw power at the plate, but whose future is most certainly on the mound. He was a bit inconsistent last summer, and then was pitching better for his GPE area high school to put an up arrow next to his name. A mild shoulder strain that shelved him for a while did put a damper on his spring.The 6-foot-4 southpaw has the ideal pitcher's body, with room to fill out and see his stuff tick upward, especially once he stops being a two-way player. His velocity fluctuated over the summer, but was up to 94 mph this spring with good arm-side movement. He'll flash an excellent slider, though he can get underneath it at times, impacting it's consistency, and he has good feel for an above-average changeup as well. While he was stronger this spring, PERSON still throws from a lower slot than some scouts would like. He struggles repeating his release point, which can lead to command issues.That arm slot does create deception in his delivery, though, often making him tough to hit. PERSON willing to take him early and sign him away from his ORGANIZATION of GPE commitment would have to believe there's more in the tank and that they can work with the lefty to clean up his delivery once he becomes a pro. But he was shut down for a period of time leading up to the GPE, leading many to believe he could end up heading to GPE.

Sometimes, young prospects struggle when they make their GPE debut. PERSON, on the other hand, stood out immediately as a 20-year-old in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League in 2014, then really took off in 2015 pitching across two levels of Class A ball and earning the organization's ORGANIZATION pitcher of the year honors. The jump to Double-A in 2016 proved to be a little more challenging.What makes PERSON's year stand out even more is the fact he did it while largely putting his best pitch in his back pocket. The right-hander has always been a strike-thrower with an outstanding changeup, but he bought into the ORGANIZATION' plan for him and focused on his slider all year, which undoubtedly hurt his strikeout rate. He'll show an average slider at times and the work he put into the pitch in 2015 should pay off in the future, moving it closer to his plus fastball and offspeed pitch. Clearly willing to do whatever it takes to make him a more complete pitcher, PERSON is learning what he needs to work on to succeed at the upper levels. The ORGANIZATION are excited to see what he can do there, with the hope they have a mid-rotation starter on their hands.

May is on the way to becoming the third big leaguer in his family, following his grandfather PERSON and great-uncle PERSON, whose power made them All-Stars. May reached that level in 2016, though he scuffled while battling an early-season oblique injury.One of the best athletes in a system loaded with toolsy outfielders, May is a switch-hitter whose game is built around plus-plus speed. He's more effective from the right side of the plate and will need to draw more walks to fit at the top of a big league lineup.May has the speed and instincts to create havoc on the bases, and he stole 18 bases in May 2015 before he sustained a concussion after colliding with teammate PERSON while chasing a popup. His quickness also helps him in center field, where he has improved his route-running since entering pro ball. His arm is below average but not a liability in center.

PERSON spent his first year plus at ORGANIZATION Poly coming out of the bullpen, but when he moved into the rotation 2017 during his redshirt sophomore year, teams sat up and noticed and his ORGANIZATION stock soared. Looking like a potential future big league starter, he landed in the second round and signed for below pick value with the ORGANIZATION, then impressed with his stuff during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League.The ORGANIZATION limited him innings-wise during that debut, but definitely opened some eyes by striking out 12.7 per nine over the summer. By the end, he was sitting 93-95 mph with explosive finish in the strike zone that allowed his fastball to play as well as anyone's in the system. He has an above-average slider and a solid cutter, and while his changeup is below-average he does have some feel for it. The right-hander generally threw strikes in college, though he struggled a bit with his control during his pro debut.PERSON's first impression with PERSON has the organization excited to see what he does for an encore. He attended strength camp last fall, with everyone eager to see what he can do when lengthened out over his first full season.

Released by ORGANIZATION after a just over a year in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON is now an interesting, bite-sized arm strength prospect. The ORGANIZATION seemed to have lowered his arm slot this year and he's throwing really hard and throwing strikes. He's likely a relief prospect, but it makes sense to develop him as a starter in hopes that either his curveball or shangeup become an out pitch.

PERSON possesses the footwork, actions and arm strength to remain at shortstop. He lacks any modicum of present strength at the plate and scouts need to project heavily on PERSON's body to see anything more than a bottom of the order hitter here, but some think the frame allows for it.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON committed to play for the ORGANIZATION after excelling for his PERSON team. A two-sport star, PERSON earned All-State honors in football as a defensive back, as well as All-Southern PERSON All-Stars honors and all-conference accolades on the diamond. The young infielder batted .465 with a slugging percentage over .700 for his high school and has played in numerous showcases. PERSON's arm is his best tool. He hit 98 mph again in the outing I went to on one scoutÃ¢â¬â¢s gun, hit 97 mph multiple times on every gun, sitting at 93-96 mph over his two innings. As you can see in the video (from his second inning when I moved down to get a closer look) the slider is plus and the changeup is surprisingly good, flashing 55, and PERSON used it multiple times in two strike counts and against right-handed hitters. While the command isnÃ¢â¬â¢t all the way there yet, heÃ¢â¬â¢s only 18 with new velocity that heÃ¢â¬â¢s still adjusting to, while the delivery, arm, frame and athleticism are all solid to very good with some flashes of feel to pitch already.

He projects as a starter, but the risk here is due to the uncertainty. PERSON has been throwing this hard for less than a year, scouts haven't seen him go deep into games or face high end minor league hitters. Sometimes young arms with velo spiking develop injuries or simply can't command it and we haven't seen enough to know if this sort of thing will happen to PERSON. He checks all the boxes for a pitcher of this age and youÃ¢â¬â¢d obviously like to see more than what scouts have seen, but that's the way this market works and PERSON will get paid even with little track record. It would be an unnecessary risk to expose himself to, and teams would rather handle his throwing program themselves than have an agent do it. ItÃ¢â¬â¢s too early to really know what heÃ¢â¬â¢s capable of, but the raw talent here is comparable to the top teenage arms in the world.

The buzz is PERSON already has a deal in place for $16 million with the ORGANIZATION and this type of buzz is sometimes wrong, but very often ends up pegging the right team and the right general range for the bonus. The ORGANIZATION' heaviest of hitters, president PERSON and ORGANIZATION were sitting about 20 feet behind me while I shot the video, were the highest-ranking scouts at the event and have already signed the other elite player that was on the field in GPE. PERSON projects as a potential frontline starter that would go in the top half of the first round in the domestic draft, but the uncertainty here is much higher than comparably-aged domestic prospects due to the lack of track record. After ten starts in pro ball, PERSON could be one of the top pitching prospects in the world, or just another teenage pitcher with a talented arm and feel issues to sort out at the lower levels of the minors.

Left-handed hitting third basemen are always a hot commodity, so when PERSON carried over a strong Cape Cod League season into his junior year at FACILITY, he became a sure-fire first-rounder, one who could eventually man the hot corner for the ORGANIZATION in the GPE. He has legit pop, showing it with wood in the Cape as well, and should hit for both average and power in the future. While some worried about his ability to stay at third in the past, PERSON showed good defensive improvement in 2013 and answered some of those questions. The ORGANIZATION certainly had no plans to move him and he should fit the profile of a run-producing third baseman very well.

Signed for $400,000 by the ORGANIZATION out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, PERSON made quite an impression in his professional debut the following summer as he led the ORGANIZATION in batting average (,348) and ORGANIZATION (1.023). He continued his success as he made his GPE debut in 2014, reaching Class A LOCATION as an 18-year-old. After the season, the D-backs acquired him in the three-team trade that sent PERSON to the ORGANIZATION. PERSON has an advanced approach for such a young player, showing deft control of the strike zone and the ability to hit line drives all over the field. As a bonus, he's a switch-hitter, and he has the potential to produce double-figure home run power once he adds strength. An average runner, PERSON fits best at second base but has also played shortstop in the ORGANIZATION. He has good defensive instincts and reliable hands to go with average arm strength and range.

As a ORGANIZATION high schooler in 2013, PERSON turned down seven-figure overtures from big league clubs and passed when the ORGANIZATION took him in the 31st round so he could attend GPE. After looking like a potential future first-rounder during his first season and a half with the ORGANIZATION, he blew out his elbow and needed PERSON surgery in mid-2015. He sat out the entire 2016 season, turned down GPE again (this time in the 21st round) and returned to GPE and reasserted his status as a prospect this year en route to a second-round selection by the ORGANIZATION.PERSON has regained his velocity after having his elbow reconstructed, working at 92-95 mph and hitting 97 with nice sink. His curveball can be a plus pitch, thrown with power and depth when it's on, and he also can miss bats with his slider. His changeup shows some promise of becoming another solid offering, though it too requires more consistency.PERSON has a history of throwing strikes and had no problems regaining his command this spring. His large frame earns him PERSON comparisons, and while he's not terribly athletic, his delivery works well. The ORGANIZATION may bring him along slowly given his medical history and spring workload, but PERSON has the size, stuff and feel to develop into a mid-rotation starter.

There is no question PERSON's glove is good enough to play in the big leagues. What kind of player he'll be in the long run will likely come down to how much the offensive side of his game develops.Signed out of GPE in 2011, PERSON is the best defensive shortstop in the system currently and perhaps in recent memory. He has a very strong arm and outstanding range to both sides. He's worked hard to improve his running, with his modest strength gains helping in that regard, and he's become a basestealing threat. With a smallish, lean frame, there's a limit to what he's able to add, but more good weight and strength will be necessary for him to hit at higher levels. He does have a good swing and barrels up balls fairly consistently, so if he can get stronger, he has a chance to hit enough.With his defensive ability, he doesn't need to hit a ton. Showing he's not going to have the bat knocked out of his hands might be enough for him to be a glove-first everyday shortstop in the big leagues.

PERSON had a spectacular breakout 2017 campaign, hitting 32 homers and 32 doubles split between Hi and Double-A, prompting GPE to give him a look in the Majors in September. His hands are electric and allow PERSON to turn on just about everything, and he tries to, which prompted big league pitchers to work him down and away. It may take an approach adjustment for PERSON to max out his offensive potential as he's overly aggressive and his style of hitting may be exploited in the Majors. But he has bat speed and power and should play an above average right field (or be better than PERSON in center) fairly soon.

Signed out of GPE in 2010, PERSON spent two seasons in the ORGANIZATION before finally making his stateside debut as a starter in '13. The ORGANIZATION hoped that a move to the bullpen the following year at ORGANIZATION A PERSON might accelerate his development. Instead, the right-hander's control problems worsened, ultimately limiting him to just 51 2/3 innings over 35 appearances from 2014-15. PERSON put all of that behind him in 2016, when he enjoyed a breakout campaign in the ORGANIZATION A Advanced California League and then added to his workload in the ORGANIZATION, where his fastball was consistently 97-100 mph and touched 102. His power curveball in the low 80s has come on strong in the last year as well, giving him the necessary two pitches to profile as a late-inning arm in the big leagues. The gains PERSON made last season with his control may have been significant, but his overall efficiency, especially in terms of getting ahead of hitters, leaves much to be desired. That being said, even a modest improvement in that department could help PERSON, who's already on the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster and likely to begin the season at ORGANIZATION, surge towards the Majors in 2017.

GPE tied a GPE high school record by hitting 25 homers in 2011. He has hit 31 long balls in three seasons at ORGANIZATION while playing three different primary positions: third base as a freshman, catcher as a sophomore and shortstop (because the team needed him there) as a junior this spring.GPE has two tools to bank on: raw power and raw arm strength. He has a short, handsy stroke and a mature approach at the plate, which should allow him to tap into his pop in pro ball. Though he had a long release as a catcher, he still threw out 51 percent of basestealers in 2013, when he capably handled first-round pick PERSON Gonzalez.The downside to GPE catching is that he wore down behind the plate and his offense suffered. He's definitely not a shortstop, because he lacks quickness and throws from a low slot while there, though to his credit he made just two errors in 56 games this season. Some scouts think he might be able to make it as a power-hitting second baseman, and his work ethic will help him wherever he winds up.

It's possible PERSON would have been PERSON's best everyday option at catcher toward the end of last year, but a desperate need for pitching depth facilitated his trade to PERSON for PERSON. PERSON is an athletic catcher with a plus arm, average receiving skills, and some feel to hit. After struggling to perform with the bat during the first several years of his career, PERSON has two straight season of league-average offensive performance at ORGANIZATION and Triple-A. He has a pull-and-lift style of hitting, but not enough raw power to optimize that kind of approach. He's a safe bet to be a quality backup and has a non-zero chance to hit a little more than we expect and be a low-end regular.

PERSON has a long track record of producing at top amateur events, including getting two hits off GPE's PERSON (now with the ORGANIZATION) in the gold-medal game of the 2014 15-and-under World Cup. He led Deerfield-Windsor High (PERSON, Ga.) to state 3-A titles in 2015 and 2016 and to the semifinals this spring. A club that believes he can stay behind the plate could take him as high as the third round, though there are enough questions about his defensive ability that he could wind up sliding far enough to follow through on his commitment to Auburn.There aren't many worries about PERSON' offensive ability. With his sound left-handed swing, bat speed and strength, he could hit for both average and power. He has enough offensive upside that he could profile at an outfield corner or first base if he doesn't make it as a catcher.PERSON has the strong arm and the desire to make it as a catcher, but his receiving will need a lot of improvement. Some teams wonder if he'd be better off focusing on his hitting and moving to the outfield. He has enough arm for right field, though his below-average speed might make him a better fit in left.

He could have gone in the top three rounds in 2016 had he been signable as a GPE high schooler, but PERSON withdrew his name from the ORGANIZATION because he wanted to attend PERSON. He has performed capably for three years with the ORGANIZATION, though he never has dominated as much as hoped. He ascended to the front of ORGANIZATION's rotation this year but got knocked around in GPE Coast Conference play.PERSON can display four pitches that earn solid or better grades at their best. As a starter, he works at 90-92 mph and reaches 94 with his fastball, creating some armside run with some crossfire in his delivery. He uses his high-three-quarters arm slot to stay on top of an upper-70s curveball that is often his best pitch, and he also can manipulate it into a harder, more lateral-breaking slider in the low 80s.PERSON also has at least an average changeup with some fade and is doing a much better job of throwing strikes in 2019, enhancing his chances of remaining a starter in pro ball. He has a high floor as a potential No. 4 starter with a fallback of becoming at least a seventh-inning reliever. He has reached 97 mph with his fastball coming out of the bullpen and could have a more consistent plus curveball in shorter stints.

Counting a big league contract for since-traded Hector PERSON, bonuses and tax penalties for blowing past their allotted pool, the ORGANIZATION agreed to pay more than $150 million to sign international players in 2015. Their spending spree continued into November, when they landed PERSON for $15.5 million (plus a matching amount in tax penalties). That was just GPE' third-biggest outlay of the year for a GPE defector, behind $62.5 million for PERSON and $32 million ($16 million bonus plus matching penalty) for right-hander PERSON Alvarez.PERSON hit .348/.448/.440 in 2014-15 as an 18-year-old in GPE's top league, the ORGANIZATION, and was the favorite to win PERSON of the Year honors before he defected in April before the award was given. His most impressive attribute may be his hand-eye coordination, which combined with his quick right-handed bat, allows him to barrel balls. He mainly focuses on lacing line drives from gap to gap but has the strength to provide some power if he opens up his approach. A good athlete, PERSON has plus speed and solid arm strength. He should be able to stick in center field and is capable of playing all three outfield spots.

PERSON spent two summers in the ORGANIZATION after signing out of the GPE in 2011. The slightly undersized right-hander didn't disappoint in his highly anticipated stateside debut in 2014, when he showed the ability to miss bats with electric stuff en route to recording 10.1 strikeouts per nine innings in the Rookie-level PERSON. The ORGANIZATION expected big things from him in 2015, though he was unable to take the next step as an avulsion fracture in his elbow limited him to just 20 innings. He finally made his full-season debut in 2016, pitching as part of a loaded piggyback starting rotation at ORGANIZATION A Wisconsin. In December, he was selected by the Twins with the first pick in the Rule 5 Draft, only to be traded to GPE.  When healthy, PERSON's lightning-quick arm generates a fastball in the mid-90s with late movement from a high three-quarters slot. His slider, thrown in the 75-77 mph range with good lateral action, has the chance to be an out pitch if he can throw it for strikes. His changeup lags behind his two other offerings, but club officials believe it will become an effective third pitch for him once he creates better velocity separation relative to his heater. He has the ability to miss bats naturally, though his control and command require refinement, as does his mechanics. PERSON's elbow injury required subsequent surgery, but he was not limited by the injury in 2016. Although the ORGANIZATION may continue to develop him as a starter, his fastball-slider pairing gives him undeniable upside in a late-inning bullpen role.

PERSON signed with the D-backs for $1.85 million at the outset of last year's international period after he had ranked as the ORGANIZATION. 19 prospect in his class. He impressed evaluators as a GPE amateur with a combination of athleticism and overall tools that could help him stick in center field. PERSON has a pair of standout tools in his speed -- he was clocked at showcases in the 6.6- to 6.7-second range in the 60-yard run -- and arm strength that might have been the best among players in his class and is expected get even stronger as he develops. Projecting his impact at the plate will require more time, as PERSON won't make his pro debut until 2019, but he shows the signs of having the requisite athleticism and skills to develop a promising speed-power combo. PERSON is all projection right now, but he has the type of athletic body scouts covet, not to mention defensive abilities that could keep him on the field even when he struggles at the plate.

GPE PERSON has sent two dozen players to the big leagues in the ORGANIZATION era but has never had a first-round pick, a void that PERSON will fill in June as one of the first college position players selected. Undrafted and lightly regarded as a ORGANIZATION high schooler, he reached double figures in homers and steals as a sophomore in 2016. He also impressed with PERSON last summer, with some scouts considering him the best position prospect on the squad, and continued to show all-around tools this spring.PERSON is an on-base machine thanks to his speed (which earns well-above-average grades from some evaluators) and patient approach. A left-handed hitter, he does swing and miss a bit much for a player with a leadoff profile because he can get overly aggressive at times, especially against breaking pitches. Though he didn't go deep in 64 at-bats with wood bats on PERSON, he packs some sneaky power in his athletic frame and could produce 20 or more homers per season in the big leagues.PERSON also uses his quickness well to steal bases and track down balls in center field. He throws better than most players at his position -- his fastball reached 92 mph when he was a high school pitcher -- and his makeup is another positive in his favor. The most common comparison is PERSON, though PERSON had less pop and more speed at the same stage of his career.

ORGANIZATION went from two homers as a ORGANIZATION sophomore to 18 (fourth in ORGANIZATION Division I) as a junior in 2015, and his power surge propelled him into the sixth round. He has continued to mash as a pro, smacking 51 homers in his first two full seasons while reaching Triple-A. Unfortunately for him, he's blocked by All-Stars Cody Bellinger and PERSON at his two best positions.With strength and solid bat speed, the left-handed-hitting ORGANIZATION creates power to all fields that plays against both lefties and righties. Though he's very aggressive and doesn't have much of a gameplan at the plate, his hand-eye coordination allows him to make consistent hard contact. He may never walk much, but he can hit for power and average.ORGANIZATION has a strong arm but lacks speed and quickness and thus defensive value. He spent most of his first two years as a pro at third base but had limited range and was error-prone. He works hard enough to become adequate at first base, where he saw more action in 2017, when he also looked better than expected if not particularly rangy on the outfield corners.

There's nothing like a no-hitter at a Regional to raise your profile a bit. Truth be told, PERSON would be high on radar screens anyway with his pure stuff, though some inconsistent performances during his junior season kept him from being among the top few college pitchers on this list. He has a plus fastball that can touch 96 mph and throws a hard breaking ball to go along with it, a combination he used well for PERSON over the summer. PERSON is strong with a good delivery and arm action. As big as his stuff is, though, he will have to learn to soften it up somehow in the future. Everything he throws is hard, and the ability to change speeds more effectively will be a necessary skill to refine going forward.

PERSON entered last summer as perhaps the top player in the entire class, and certainly among the high school set. A combination of a relatively pedestrian summer showcase performances and an extremely high expectation bar, a trend that has continued this spring, caused his star to fade, though he's still one of the better prep players in the nation.PERSON does everything fairly well, though a lack of a true plus carrying tool is one reason why scouts were a bit down on him. Most feel he has the chance to be a plus hitter with an advanced approach at the plate using a high-contact, line-drive spray kind of approach. With a lean frame, there is some question about how much strength he'll add, with believers thinking power will come. Most feel he is a long-term shortstop, though some don't see it as a slam dunk. Some feel PERSON suffered more from being seen for so long that he was bound to get knocked simply for not being the best player on the field at all times. Others haven't seen him dominate the way they feel a top-of-the-Draft prospect should in high school. He is committed to ORGANIZATION, which could become an issue depending on when he's selected.

PERSON went to ORGANIZATION planning to play both football and baseball, but the school's football program was shut down when he got to campus, and he was drafted and signed by PERSON before it was reborn. He practiced with the team, but never suited up for a football game. 
2018 was his first year of full-time baseball and he hit .307/.378/.552 with 17 homers and 29 steals, albeit as a 22-year-old at Low-A. His strength/raw power and straight-line speed are what you'd probably expect from a college wide receiver, but PERSON's compact, in-game swing prioritizes contact. He's predictably raw and somewhat stiff rather than graceful and coordinated but he has physical ability, he plays really hard, and there's a chance some of the skill-based parts of the game come to him in his mid-20s.

There are amateur shortstops that can stay up the middle. Then there are those who will likely need to move to third base. PERSON fits in the latter category, but it looks like he has the profile for the hot corner.Big and strong, PERSON was putting up gaudy numbers during his junior season to move up ORGANIZATION boards as the spring progressed. The ball jumps off of his bat, and he projects to have plenty of power for the position. He has good defensive reactions, which should work just fine at third, and he has a very strong arm.PERSON looks the part, a tall and lean athlete who used to play quarterback in the GPE high school ranks. He's not among the few elite college bats in this class, but he's not too far behind them, either.

GPE's early-season domincane of Double-A should be taken with a grain of salt as he was significantly older than is usual for prospect at that level. As a left fielder, his bat might fall just shy of profiling and he could be best used as a utility or platoon option.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite MLB Team: GPE ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON commit, PERSON is touted as a catching prospect, though he has played multiple positions in high school. He was named to the 2016 Underclass 2nd Team and has played in two ORGANIZATION World Championships in the past.PERSON has a high leg kick at the plate and will over-swing at times, but he makes decent contact, and scouts note his aggressive approach. In the field, he has a slightly below average arm, but it should get better as he has more time to develop.

PERSON has done nothing but impress since the ORGANIZATION signed him for $225,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013. In his stateside debut last season, the 18-year-old tore up the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League to force a promotion to Class A Short-Season Auburn, where he was the youngest everyday player in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. PERSON' stock has continued to soar this year in his full-season debut, as he was promoted to Class A Advanced Potomac after just 64 games with PERSON. PERSON is a potentially special talent who showcases all five tools along with elite athleticism on a daily basis. He shows the makings of a plus hit tool, thanks to his compact but explosive swing and feel for using the whole field, and scouts rave about his advanced approach and strike-zone judgment. A plus-plus runner, PERSON' speed enables him impact games on the bases as well as in center field, where he has range for days in all directions and arm strength that's among the best in the Minors at the position.Beyond the athleticism and physical tools, the ORGANIZATION love PERSON' makeup and overall baseball aptitude, both of which make him a leader in the clubhouse. He might still be a few years away from reaching the ORGANIZATION, but there is reason to be excited about the kind of player he could become.

After his freshman year at GPE, PERSON seemed like a sure-fire top-of-the-Draft prospect for 2017. An inconsistent 2016 season, combined with a lack of work behind the plate, leaves his status a little bit more up in the air.The son of one-time big league pitcher PERSON, J.J. still has tremendous offensive potential. He's shown he has raw power to all fields. While there was swing-and-miss to his game in 2016, he also showed a willingness to work walks and get on base. He has the tools to catch, with good hands and a solid average arm, but he hasn't, and won't, catch that much because of PERSON's presence on the ORGANIZATION. PERSON went to the Cape last summer to catch, but he left after 13 games due to a minor injury.If PERSON gets some time behind the plate and shows he can catch, that will obviously help his value. But even if not, if his bat returns to freshman form, he could be one of the first college position player to come off the board.

PERSON capped his trip through the showcase circuit in the summer of 2010 with an ORGANIZATION performance in the ORGANIZATION All-America Game at FACILITY. After a slow start to his professional career, he advanced to full-season ball for the first time in 2013.PERSON's power is his best tool. He creates good bat speed and he can drive the ball to all areas of the field. PERSON is a below-average runner, but he takes advantage of opportunities to be aggressive on the basepaths.PERSON made big strides on defense in 2013. Combined with his strong arm and his good makeup, the improvements PERSON made to his receiving give him a chance to be at least an average defender. With his power, that would make PERSON an all-around threat.

One of the best on-mound athletes in the 2018 AZL, PERSON is a converted shortstop with a delivery that looks an awful lot like PERSON's. The ORGANIZATION acquired him on 40-man crunch day from GPE for depth starter, PERSON. PERSON sits only 88-92, but that should tick up as he physically matures. His fastball has natural cut, and at times, he throws what looks like a true cutter in the 84-87 range. He also has a 12-to-6 curveball that flashes plus. 
PERSON could develop in a number of different ways. PERSON could make a concerted effort to alter his release so PERSON is more behind the ball, creating fastball life/rise that would probably play better with his curveball. Alternatively, they might nurture his natural proclivity for cut, and see what happens. Either way, this is an exciting athlete with workable stuff who'll be 19 all summer. He has a chance to start, which is why he's ahead of several other arms on this list who throw harder/are closer.

A 20th-round pick who signed for $20,000 out of ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION.) PERSON in 2012, ORGANIZATION enjoyed a breakout year in 2014. He earned ORGANIZATION honors at the low Class A ORGANIZATION All-Star Game and boosted his numbers after a promotion to Class A Advanced, though he then was suspended for 50 games after testing positive for an amphetamine. He came back to perform well in the ORGANIZATION before the ORGANIZATION acquired him in a trade that sent PERSON and ORGANIZATION to the A's in January.While ORGANIZATION draws praise for his ability to play bigger than his size and his tools, his physical ability shouldn't be sold short. He has solid speed and center-field skills, and he has controlled the strike zone very well in pro ball.The biggest concern scouts have with ORGANIZATION is that his swing tends to get long and they wonder how it will work against better pitching. He doesn't have much power and his arm is just fringy, yet he could fit the center-field profile well if he can continue to get on base.

Five years after PERSON went No. 1 overall in the PERSON, PERSON has another hard-throwing right-hander poised to go in the first round. Unlike PERSON, PERSON was a prospect in high school, too, though signability knocked him down to the 41st round in 2011. He can light up a radar gun like no other college arm in this year's PERSON, as he's capable of working in the mid 90s and hitting 98 mph with his fastball, with triple-digits within reach in shorter stints. PERSON has a lot of moving parts in his delivery and still is learning to control his 6-foot-6 frame, so he lacks consistency with the rest of his pitches as well as his control and command. His low-80s slider has the most potential of his secondary offerings, and he also throws a curveball and a changeup. PERSON moved to the bullpen this spring and was throwing well as PERSON's closer. If he can't develop a reliable second weapon and do a better job of locating his pitches, that could be his long-term role at the next level.
GPE and lean with dream-worthy frame, GPE is raw in all facets of baseball but at times shows glimpses of a future at shortstop and the body allows for projection on his bat.

PERSON had been a reliever during his junior year at ORGANIZATION when the ORGANIZATION took him in the third round of the 2012 Draft, but GPE developed him as a starter. After moving incrementally in that role, a return to the bullpen in 2015 had PERSON really pointing in the right direction when GPE sent him to the D-backs in the ORGANIZATION trade. PERSON gave him one start at the very end of the season.As a starter, PERSON would try to mix in four pitches, with a fastball, slider, curveball and changeup. As a reliever, he leaned largely on his fastball and slider, both of which are PERSON average offerings. He still mixed in a changeup on occasion to keep hitters honest. PERSON has always had solid control, but it ticked up a notch when he was throwing shorter stints. The 25-year-old right-hander doesn't have the stuff to close, with a middle relief role more likely if he sticks in the bullpen. For now, though, the D-backs are planning on giving him another crack at pitching in a rotation.

It's uncommon for a college hitter to have more walks than strikeouts during his career but PERSON' ratio during his junior season at PERSON was exceptional. He walked 52 times and struck out just 16 while also swiping an ultra-efficient 25 bases in 26 attempts. He's a nearly plus-plus runner and capable middle infield defender (probably at second) with premium hand-eye coordination and bat control. There was some concern that PERSON beat up on small conference pitching his entire career, and that he may not replicate that performance against pro pitching, but we're buying it. Once poised to perhaps move quickly through the system, PERSON had posterior labrum surgery in late-March and will miss much of the season.
Projectable frame, great body control and arm strength. Looks likely to stay at shortstop and might be plus there. Plus bat speed, has some swing and miss tendencies.

PERSON signed for $500,000, which puts him behind the top tier of signees in the 2017 class for the ORGANIZATION. But his tools are arguably just as exciting, though more riskier. He's 6-foot-5 or 6-foot-6 depending on whom you ask and is only listed at 205 pounds, but is north of that and will get bigger. If he doesn't have 80 raw power now, he will in the next few years, and he's actually an average runner underway, though his first step isn't great and he'll lose a step or two with maturity. PERSON has the arm to profile in right field, but down the road, he'll likely be an average glove there at best. There's obvious leverage to his swing and he hit 10 homers in 44 games in the ORGANIZATION as a 17-year-old, so it's not like he's sushi raw at tapping into his best tool. PERSON had similar tools at this stage, so that's one way this can go. Another would be former Tigers prospect PERSON, who played last year in GPE. There are also two massive corner outfielders with 80 raw power currently in the big leagues for the ORGANIZATION, so you know what PERSON looks like if everything goes perfectly, but a 42% strikeout rate in GPE ball isn't the best starting place from which to get there.

The younger brother of ORGANIZATION prospect, and 2015 third-round pick, PERSON, PERSON has been a bit of a pop-up prospect in northern GPE, with cross-checkers and scouting directors running in to see him as reports of his athleticism came in.A football standout who had verbally committed to play on the gridiron as a preferred walk-on at his brother's alma mater, the ORGANIZATION of GPE, PERSON changed courses before the spring and decided to commit to PERSON for baseball, where a scholarship is waiting. The way he's shown at times this spring, he may never get there. At 6-foot-4, 190 pounds, scouts love his athletic body and his power-speed combination. He can really fly, both on the bases and in the outfield, though a below-average arm might push him to left field. He has some ability with the bat as well, with some power potential, all of which could be unlocked if and when he focuses solely on baseball.PERSON is the kind of high-ceilinged athlete teams can dream on. With that potential does come some risk, but it's one several teams will be interested in taking in June.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON was named pitcher of the year as a sophomore in his district in PERSON and was a 2016 ORGANIZATION. The high school junior had interest from ORGANIZATION, PERSON and PERSON A&M, among others, before he committed to the ORGANIZATION Razorbacks.In late 2016, PERSON participated in the ORGANIZATION Training Camp and the 2016 Underclass All-American Games.

An eighth-round pick in the 2012 Draft out of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks, the ORGANIZATION gave PERSON $250,000 to forego his commitment to PERSON and sign. The ORGANIZATION emphasize athleticism when they look for catchers, so PERSON was an obvious target for them in the 2017 Draft. If ever there were an athletic contest in which players from across multiple leagues had to compete against one another in all of their respective sports, PERSON would be a top five pick. His issues with strikeouts weren't, in our opinion, caused by excessive movement in his swing but rather by things like breaking ball recognition, bat path, and hand-eye coordination. Those aren't things that can be remedied by mechanical changes, and we'd rather an athlete like this be moving a lot at the plate to help ensure he's getting to as much of that power as possible, even if it means living with a lot of strikeouts. There's a wide range of outcomes possible for a talent like this, ranging from PERSON to PERSON to B.J. PERSON to PERSON to PERSON. PERSON is a premium athlete with good makeup who should get plenty of opportunity to cure his own ills at the big league level. We think he's likely to be frustrating, but reasonably valuable, and possibly have some star-level seasons in his late twenties.

A converted outfielder, PERSON was up to 100 during extended and has mostly been sitting in the mid-90s with movement. In the four-prospect package obtained from the ORGANIZATION for PERSON at the 2016 Winter Meetings, the FACILITY Sox not only landed the consensus top prospect in baseball at the time (ORGANIZATION), but also a guy on the short list of the best pitching prospects (GPE). GPE's professional debut was delayed until 2013 because of a broken wrist that kept him out almost all of '12 and required surgery to repair. PERSON PERSON has produced its fair share of big league talent, though the bigger names, PERSON and PERSON, have come on the mound. He should grow into more over-the-fence power and his baserunning acumen will allow him to pick up extra bases when he hits the gaps. Evaluators look at PERSON and see a prospect with lots of options and tons of upside.Will PERSON develop into a power-hitting shortstop or will he grow into a shortstop that hits for average? GPE was a shortstop in the GPE high school ranks who was immediately moved to the outfield once he signed with the ORGANIZATION, and he has some upside on both sides of the ball. Signed out of the ORGANIZATION by the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON compiled a 4.63 ERA in GPE ball during his first two years as a pro. He can light up radar guns like few other pitches can, however. PERSON stood out early in his high school career and colleges that recruited him regarded him as too talented to get to campus as early as age 15. As a sophomore at the ORGANIZATION of PERSON, PERSON began as a reliever, but gained confidence when given the chance to move into the rotation. PERSON PERSON is the most prominent example of a Dodgers prospect throwing harder upon returning from PERSON surgery but PERSON is the latest, as he was sitting 95 or better when he finally threw pro innings in 2018. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Player: PERSON in 2015, PERSON played a critical role on the way to ORGANIZATION's 6A state championship. Originally drafted in the 16th round by the ORGANIZATION, PERSON was a part of the package the ORGANIZATION received in the ORGANIZATION trade in 2012.
