He played mostly right field in his first two years at ORGANIZATION before seeing more action in left field this spring, and he needs to improve his reads and routes. His arm is fringy at best, making him better suited for left field than right.

PERSON hasn't let the fact that he came from GPE, with no high school baseball team, get in the way of working his way up the ORGANIZATION organizational ladder. The 2011 first-round pick reached Double-A in 2014, at age 21, putting him way ahead of the curve.PERSON's advanced approach at the plate belies his years and his experience. He is extremely patient at the plate, as his career .387 on-base percentage heading into 2015 would attest, and he cut down his strikeout rate quite a bit in 2014, showing an ability to hit to all fields. PERSON has gotten bigger and stronger as he's matured and his power has started to show up a bit more consistently. He's a solid runner with good instincts and his defense has improved in center field, as has his arm. He may have seemed like a long-term project when he was drafted, but PERSON isn't too far off from helping out in GPE's outfield. An ability to play all three spots won't hurt his chances of getting that first callup.
Depending on the look, some scouts think he can play center field, others think he'll get bigger and shift to right field, but everyone sees a hit tool and power projection.

One of the most projectable pitchers in the ORGANIZATION system, PERSON carried 170 pounds on his 6-foot-4 frame when he signed out of the ORGANIZATION for $250,000 in 2012. His combination of stuff and feel for pitching gives him a chance to blossom into a No. 3 starter.PERSON has added velocity since signing and now works with a 90-93 mph fastball that should continue to get stronger. He shows the aptitude for spinning a curveball that will be a solid pitch once it adds more velocity, and his changeup has similar upside.PERSON throws strikes and keeps the ball down in the zone with ease, thanks to a stress-free delivery that he repeats well. He's advanced enough to handle a jump to full-season ball at age 19, though PERSON will continue to handle him carefully while he adds strength to his slender build.

PERSON could be the next ORGANIZATION of GPE left-hander to become an All-Star, following in the footsteps of PERSON and PERSON. He has a ceiling as a No. 2 or 3 starter if he can improve his changeup and command, and if not, he has enough pure stuff to be a closer. The 2013 second-rounder was sent to GSP, along with fellow pitching prospect Zach Eflin, for PERSON in December.PERSON's best pitch is his nasty slider, which reaches the mid 80s. He can drop it in on the hands of left-handers or on the back foot of right-handers. After working at 90 mph to 94 mph with his fastball during his junior season with the ORGANIZATION, PERSON pitched more at 88 mph to 92 mph in his pro debut. Lengthening his stride during instructional league helped him reclaim that lost velocity.PERSON's delivery looks a little stiff, and it features some recoil, leading some scouts to question whether he can develop the third pitch and control to remain in the rotation. PERSON is starting to throw his changeup more often, and it has made some progress.

PERSON had back issues in college and scouts weren't enamored with his conditioning, but he had premium velocity, a plus slider and he performed at against ORGANIZATION hitters. He somewhat surprisingly fell to GPE's 6th overall selection in the 2016 draft. Reports were even stronger in 2017. PERSON is remarkably athletic for his size and he's more balanced throughout his delivery now than he was in college. His command has improved and now projects to average or a tick above. PERSON also rebooted a curveball he had shelved at ORGANIZATION and is flashing a plus changeup at times. He's going to have command of four above average or better pitches and rare lefty starter velocity. He has #2/3 starter ceiling and could reach GPE this year.

PERSON's arm strength and slight frame stand out the most to scouts. He is best described as having a "loose arm" with quick arm action and a good fastball that can reach 94 mph. PERSON also pounds the strike zone with all three pitches, including a changeup and a power curveball. He works fast and has the potential to have an above-average tailing fastball.A star for the ORGANIZATION, PERSON drew a lot of attention for his aggressiveness and fearless approach on the mound during ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION in January, but some wonder how his body will hold up over the course of a long season.

The son of former big league pitcher PERSON, PERSON was making the most of his first year of post-high school pitching following PERSON surgery. Pitching in controlled outings at ORGANIZATION's old stomping grounds at ORGANIZATION of LOCATION, the right-hander opened eyes all season.Working in stints of four or five innings, GPE showed the makings of a very good three-pitch mix. He was throwing his fastball in the 92-95 mph range and his curve has shown glimpses of being an above-average breaking ball. His changeup could give him a third Major League average in time. Despite having needed elbow surgery, he has a relatively easy and clean delivery. That should help him command the ball better in the future.It's easy to project more from GPE because of his delivery, his bloodlines and the further he's removed from surgery. He could be a decent bargain for a team in the top five rounds.

In his first season with the ORGANIZATION after joining them via the ORGANIZATION trade, PERSON managed to throw just 78 1/3 innings because of shoulder issues. PERSON to prove his worth to the team that dealt for him, PERSON did just that in 2014, staying healthy and throwing well in Triple-A while also pitching in the ORGANIZATION in what he hopes to be his home park, PERSON Field.Coming from his huge 6-foot-9 frame, PERSON's upper-90s fastball gets on hitters in a hurry. He throws downhill, with sink, consistently, leading to groundballs when he isn't missing bats. His sharp slider adds to the strikeout rate, 10.4 per nine innings through 2014, and his changeup has improved, giving him another sinking weapon. PERSON still struggles with his command -- his walk rate jumped back up in 2014 -- largely because so much can go wrong with a delivery from a pitcher this tall. That, along with shoulder fatigue at the very end of the season, may have been the reason why the ORGANIZATION didn't bring him up last September.The 25-year-old PERSON is ready for a shot and could make a big contribution to a young rotation in 2015. If he can harness his stuff a bit more consistently, he could stick around for a long while.
Bins projects as a strong backup catcher that's also a solid athete.

PERSON put himself on the prospect map by leading the LOCATION with nine homers and 33 walks as a Sacred Heart sophomore in 2015, only to slump in the ORGANIZATION that summer and again as a junior. He fell to the 17th round of the 2016 Draft, signed for $80,000 and didn't do much in his pro debut. But he has opened eyes since with his power and patience, combining for 30 homers and 176 walks in his first two full seasons while reaching Double-A.PERSON has quick hands and a pull-heavy approach, giving him more pop than a typical 175-pounder. He's an extreme flyball hitter who makes a lot of loud contact from the right side of the plate, though the ORGANIZATION would like to see him cut down his swing and make more regular contact. He works deep counts and draws a lot of walks, giving him healthy on-base percentages despite subpar batting averages.With solid speed and an aggressive nature, PERSON can steal an occasional base. Some club officials believe he's the best defensive infielder in the system, and his quickness and arm strength allow him to play second and third base and serve in a utility role if needed. If he can put the bat on the ball more consistently, he could be an everyday shortstop in the mold of ORGANIZATION.

In his three years at FACILITY, PERSON went from a wild freshman to an all-conference closer as a sophomore to an important member of the rotation. That evolution helped him go from being a 29th-round pick (signability played a role) as a GPE-eligible sophomore in 2017 to the 43rd overall pick in 2018, when the ORGANIZATION signed the right-hander for full pick value. PERSON was suspended 50 games in December after a second positive test for a drug of abuse.PERSON' calling card is his slider, considered to be the best college breaking ball in his GPE class. It's a mid-80s breaker with a high spin rate and so much break some saw it as a power curve, and it was a pitch he leaned heavily on in college. When PERSON is starting, he typically throws his fastball in the 90-95 mph range, but he sat in the mid-90s and touched 97 when he was relieving in 2017. He flashes an average changeup with some fade, a pitch he'll need more to succeed at the next level.Whether PERSON can remain a starter will depend largely on his command, which did improve in 2018, and whether his stuff will hold up over the course of a full season in a rotation. The Cards are committed to developing him in that role, with the knowledge his fastball-slider combination does look very good in shorter stints out of the bullpen.

Wire-to-wire shoulder issues kept PERSON off the field for nearly all of the 2018 regular season. He was limited to fastball/changeup-only bullpens in the spring but didn't really got going until late in the summer, when he made two starts in GPE and showed stuff that was slightly beneath where he was earlier in his career, with his fastball residing in the 92-94 range. Poised to pick up innings in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON once again had shoulder discomfort and was shut down for the year. The A's still felt compelled to add him to the 40-man this offseason rather than let another team take a $100,000 flier on him in the Rule 5 and hope his fastball/slider combination stuck in their bullpen. 
At his absolute best, PERSON will sit 93-96 with a plus slider and average-flashing changeup, a No. 4 or 5 starter if his change and command improve. Of this triumvirate of injured arms, PERSON is the most likely to be a reliever, but his injury history is the least lengthy. He was on the same bullpen schedule as PERSON early in camp but still hasn't pitched in a spring training game.

After a breakout 2017, PERSON took his fastball/curveball combination to Bowling Green and made 15 mostly unremarkable starts there before tearing his ORGANIZATION. He had PERSON near the end of July. We likely won't see PERSON again until late next year, and he might end up throwing the bulk of his innings during instructs or ORGANIZATION. The time off means missed reps with a third pitch, and a greater likelihood that PERSON ends up in relief, which was already a possibility given his delivery and limited control.

Since being a top 10 pick back in 2013, PERSON' pro career has been one of contradiction. On the one hand, the toolsy outfielder has had trouble staying healthy, with hamstring issues, a broken orbital bone and an oblique injury that prevented him from going to the ORGANIZATION in 2016, all keeping him off the field. At the same time, the GPE native reached Triple-A at age 21, which is well ahead of the curve.The main reason PERSON has been able to move so quickly despite the interruptions has been his advanced approach at the plate and his innate ability to hit for average regardless of time away. He has a very smooth left-handed swing, one that has largely featured a hit-first approach, though the power started to show up a bit more in 2016. He draws walks and does not strike out a ton, though he struggled a bit in Triple-A for the first time. PERSON' reads and routes in center field have improved, and he should be an outstanding defender there with an accurate, albeit slightly below-average, arm.Part of the reason rumors spread about the ORGANIZATION' willingness to trade PERSON during last offseason was because PERSON is nearly ready, though repeated hamstring issues in 2017 kept him from banging down that door.

PERSON entered the spring as one of the more intriguing high school bats in the country, one who many thought had first-round potential. An up-and-down spring has made him a bit more of a polarizing prospect than that, with opinions on him varying greatly.PERSON' offensive potential is what had scouts interested in the first place, so if you saw him when he was swinging the bat well, you like him. He hasn't done that as consistently as some would have liked to see. He does show good bat speed and has definite power potential from the right side of the plate. PERSON isn't overly athletic, so even though he plays shortstop for his high school team at ORGANIZATION, he will likely have to move to third at the next level, with some thinking he has the hands and arm strength to handle the hot corner.PERSON did miss some time this spring with a quad injury, but he certainly has been seen enough over the summer and at events like the ORGANIZATION. He reminds some of PERSON in terms of body type, and he's also drawn a ORGANIZATION in high school comp. A team believing his bat will play will give the ORGANIZATION commit a shot in the opening few rounds.

PERSON's father, GPE, hit .288/.397/.436 as a 10-year minor league first baseman, and may have gotten a shot had he played during an era that better appreciated his on base skills, or had he not been blocked by PERSON in '95 and PERSON in '96. PERSON is a totally different baseball entity, standing apart not just from his father but from the rest of the minors, and access to such a unique skillset is partly what motivated the curious Rays to draft him in the second round in 2018. PERSON was ORGANIZATION's two-hole hitter, starting center fielder, and closer. If forced to chose a traditional developmental path, teams would have overwhelmingly preferred PERSON on the mound, where his stuff is commensurate with a typical middle reliever. But PERSON is also a plus-running switch-hitter, with some natural lift as a right-handed hitter and good barrel control as a lefty. The Rays want to take advantage of all of PERSON's skills and asked that he be announced on draft day as a two-way player. At ORGANIZATION, PERSON would often warm up his arm in center field, sometimes very little, before coming in to pitch in save situations. In pro ball, he pitched once every seven days, would have a bullpen day at the midpoint between outings, and either DH or play CF on the other days. Developing as a two-way player is actually less labor intensive than existing as one in college, where PERSON's schedule was more variable. Neither of PERSON's individual roles projects to be one of impact. On the mound he looks like a middle reliever; with the bat he looks like a fourth outfielder. But if he performs like a standard 40-inning reliever, like PERSON, and quintessential fourth outfielder, like PERSON, he'll generate 1.5 to 2 annual WAR, combined.

After losing his spot at GPE, PERSON became a walk-on at the ORGANIZATION of GPE and was forced to step right into the starting lineup as a freshman. Over his first two years, he was a glove-first backstop, but his GPE profile really jumped when his bat caught up to his defense as a junior, landing him in the third round. He was tired during his pro debut and the ORGANIZATION think they'll be getting a look at the real PERSON in 2018.PERSON built a strong defensive reputation at GPE, showing good receiving and blocking skills and an above-average arm. It looked more like average during his summer pro debut, though he still threw out just over 30 percent of potential basestealers in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. While he was a much better hitter in his junior season, it remains to be seen how the bat will play at this level. He makes consistent contact, but didn't show much in the way of the extra-base ability that raised his profile in college. PERSON will have to show how he can stand up to the rigors of a long season, while continuing to add strength and showing he can be an all-around catcher. If not, a future backup role seems extremely feasible.

Will be highest paid GPE amateur ever, with $1 million to PERSON being the number to beat. 6-4, switch-hittimg shortstop with feel to hit even though he hasn't grown fully into his body. Young for the class and still raw at the plate, with some reports of trouble vs. velocity.

Entering summer showcase season, PERSON was known as something of an oddity: a switch-hitting, switch-throwing catcher who was also an ambidextrous reliever when needed. As the summer wore on, PERSON grew on scouts, was chosen as the backup catcher for PERSON, and quickly took the starting job from eventual PERSON second rounder PERSON. PERSON was able to do this (and eventually become a first round pick) due to his innate present feel for contact at the plate and receiving behind it. In addition to solid contact skills, PERSON also started to lift the ball in games closer to the draft and get to all of his fringy raw power. This polish helped to make teams less worried about his advanced age relative to his prep peers, and some scouts thought he was among the top 5-10 players in the entire draft. 
PERSON had a solid pro debut that was in line with the expectations of any of the pro scouts we talked to who watched the ORGANIZATION' ORGANIZATION club. He's an average runner and an above-average athlete for the position, projecting as an above-average defender with a 65-grade arm. Some clubs don't like the recent track record of prep catchers and considered taking PERSON and then moving him to third base, but his feel for catching is too advanced to throw away. There are some similarities to another prep catcher from the prior draft: M.J. PERSON of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON is a little twitchier while PERSON is a little more advanced in terms of skills. PERSON's mother is PERSON and he would be the first Native GPE big leaguer to debut since PERSON and the second ever from the ORGANIZATION, joining PERSON.

At 6-foot-1 and 185 pounds, PERSON's mature build has drawn praise and some criticism from scouts.Evaluators like his bat - he's been called one of the most "pure bats" on the market - and his power in batting practice and games. PERSON also like the switch-hitter's rhythm in the batter's box and approach at the plate, although there's a belief he's a better hitter from the left side.On the other side of the ball, PERSON has displayed good hands and a strong throwing arm in front of scouts in games and tryouts, making him one of the top defensive players in the ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION) this year. He is still working on his footwork and defensive actions, but his overall game is expected to improve with more instruction. In the end, it's PERSON's athleticism and body type that sometimes come into question, but there is no denying that he's one of the top players available this year.

Like his 2015 Draft classmate PERSON, PERSON pitched briefly, and in relief, during his pro debut after being taken in the second round. He spent his first full year as a starter, and outside of what the organization termed arm fatigue that shut him down for a month, he had a successful season. While PERSON passed him a bit by reaching Double-A in 2016, PERSON got to that level in 2017, though he had more difficulty sustaining that success. He still has the stuff to succeed as a starter at the highest level. PERSON did see the velocity of his fastball back up a tiny bit as a starter, though he still touched 91-92 mph. His bread and butter is his plus slider, the one offering he has that can miss bats, though he's more of a pitchability, control-type lefty. His changeup improved with the reps he got as a starter, giving him a third average offering. He throws all of them for strikes. PERSON does have bullpen experience thanks to his time at ORGANIZATION, but there's nothing that says he can't be a back-end starter at the big league level.

Few players in the 2014 Draft could match GPE's combination of power and speed, but he still lasted 37 picks because he never put up big numbers in three seasons at GPE. Signed for $1,534,100, he went deep just twice in his pro debut but had 22 homers and 31 steals in his first full pro season last year. PERSON still aren't sure what to make of GPE, however. He has a pretty left-handed swing to go with considerable bat speed and raw power, giving him middle-of-the-order upside and 20-20 potential. Yet his feel for hitting isn't as impressive as his physical tools, and he swings and misses more than would be expected.GPE has well above-average speed that plays better on the bases than it does on defense. He has split his pro career between center and left field, but he's destined for the latter position because his lack of instincts negate his athleticism. His arm is his worst tool and is best suited for left field as well.

It seemed like the runway was clear for ORGANIZATION to begin a pro career after graduating from FACILITY. But about a month before he walked, the ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION began once again requiring at least two years of active duty before graduates could apply to serve out their time in reserve status for the purpose of playing pro sports. Then baseball was reinstated as an Olympic sport, and ORGANIZATION found an avenue to pro ball through the World Class PERSON, a military unit focused on training for the Games in the two years leading up to competition. So ORGANIZATION, having sorted out some arcane rules about FACILITY personnel being unable to have second streams of income, is technically an FACILITY lieutenant training for the 2020 Olympics, while the ORGANIZATION pay for his development, but don't pay him.
ORGANIZATION was 89-94 throughout the 2018 Fall League, with his secondary stuff about average, flashing above (especially the change). He could be a fifth starter, but if his fastball ticks up in short relief, he'll fit in a mid-inning bullpen role. It's unclear what happens to ORGANIZATION and his military commitment after the 2020 games conclude.

The ORGANIZATION weren't able to sign 2013 first-rounder PERSON but helped to make up for that loss by going well above pick value to land PERSON. He has established himself as one of the best all-around hitters in the system with a fine 2015 campaign. PERSON has been known for his big raw power since high school, when he wowed scouts with his big home runs on the showcase circuit. He began to deliver on that pop with home runs in game action this year and has already shown he knows how to control the strike zone and use the whole field to hit.PERSON is a well-below-average runner, limiting him defensively to first base. He's a capable defender there, but the pressure will always be on him to hit. He will go as far as his bat takes him.

GPE entered his high school senior season in 2012 as a potential first-round pick, but a lackluster spring and a strong commitment to PERSON dropped him all the way to the 39th round before the ORGANIZATION took him. He barely pitched in his first two years with the ORGANIZATION, redshirting in 2013 following thoracic outlet and PERSON surgeries and making just one appearance last season because of a stress fracture in his back. Finally healthy again in 2015, GPE has regained his stuff. He's pitching at 90-94 mph with his fastball, which features heavy run and sink. His 83-84 mph slider shows flashes of becoming a plus pitch.GPE pounds the strike zone, though he'll need to refine and trust his changeup to remain a starter in pro ball. He's more massive than athletic and has yet to establish any track record of durability, so he could be destined for the bullpen anyway.

PERSON was primarily a shortstop during his first year of junior college and pitched just eight innings. He moved to the mound in 2014 and helped PERSON reach the ORGANIZATION II Junior College World Series, pitching his way up ORGANIZATION boards in the process. The A's selected him in the fifth round that year and he signed for $305,000. He had the best season of his pro career in 2017, finished second in the Double-A PERSON in wins (11) and fifth in GPE (3.49), then came to PERSON in January along with PERSON in exchange for PERSON and PERSON Buchter.PERSON has a quick arm and typically throws his fastball in the 92-96 mph range with good sinking action that nets him ground-ball outs and results in few home runs. He has a pair of above-average secondary offerings in a curveball, which he throws with tight spin and late bite, and a changeup, a pitch he made big strides with last season. Improved feel for repeating his delivery has led to him throwing more strikes, though he regressed with both his control and command in his first full Double-A campaign.With his athleticism, big arm and feel for three average-or-better pitches, PERSON has the ingredients to become a No. 4 or 5 starter in the big leagues.

It's still unclear to us whether or not anyone knew PERSON was draft-eligible as sophomore in 2016. At the very least, he was overlooked playing on a weaker team in a lightly-scouted conference. He went undrafted, which allowed him to play for PERSON, who only found out about him from a fortuitous tip, later in the summer. PERSON was the sparkplug on the heavily-scouted team that included multiple future first round picks, and a bidding war for him amongst teams that hadn't yet spent their entire 2016 draft pool ensued toward the end of ORGANIZATION USA's run. PERSON is a plus-plus runner with good baseball instrincts and a contact-first approach at the plate. He has sneaky raw power that he may tap into with swing adjustments. Somewhat similar to PERSON, both have outcomes that range from upper-level 40-man occupant to low-end regular, but PERSON's bat is more stable and he's left-handed, so we have him ahead. He's almost a lock to hang around the big leagues for at least a few years in some role, even if it's as a fifth outfielder.

GPE's top high school pitching prospect in 2013, PERSON could have gone in the top five rounds had he been signable, but he ultimately turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 28th-rounder. Now he's the ORGANIZATION of GPE's best starting pitching prospect since PERSON went sixth overall to the ORGANIZATION in 1987. He's inconsistent but can be spectacular at times, such as when he came within one out of a no-hitter against PERSON and outpitched potential No. 1 overall pick A.J. Puk in a matchup against GPE in a span of four April starts.PERSON has one of the best fastballs in the 2016 Draft. He can sit in the mid-90s and reach 100 mph as a starter, and on his worst days he operates at 92-95. PERSON's heater is even tougher to hit because it has good run and sink and he throws it on a steep downward plane.PERSON will flash a plus changeup with some fade and sink, but he hasn't demonstrated much feel for spinning a breaking ball and now works with a knuckle-curve. He has trouble repeating his mechanics and throwing quality strikes on a regular basis, and many scouts believe he'll wind up in the bullpen. He stayed healthy in 2016 but had been shut down in each of the previous three seasons, missing three months last year with a forearm strain.

PERSON played mostly third base on PERSON last summer, while PERSON was at second and PERSON played shortstop. All three project as shortstops in pro ball and they may all go in the first round. PERSON is small and has toned down his swing a bit this spring to focus more on contact, but it's stilla  bit funky, relying more on his standout quickness and instincts in all phases of the game.

A two-way player who had started in ORGANIZATION's weekend rotation as a sophomore, PERSON served as the ORGANIZATION' closer this past season during their march to the ORGANIZATION World Series. The ORGANIZATION, in taking him No. 19 overall in the 2014 Draft, think he might have the chance to head back into a rotation.As a starter, both at ORGANIZATION and in the ORGANIZATION, PERSON would throw his fastball in the 90-93 mph range, occasionally touching 94. In short relief, he's been up to 95-97 and has been touching 98 mph. PERSON's mid-80s slider has tilt and bite when it's good, but it can get slurvy at times. He doesn't use his changeup much, and it's the development of that third pitch, along with refined fastball command, that will determine if the athletic PERSON can start at the next level.Cincinnati has had some success turning former college relievers into starters and getting them to the big leagues, so this process is worth watching.

PERSON has been traded twice: first from GPE to GPE for PERSON, then to GPE in the ORGANIZATION deal. His control regressed pretty badly in 2018 and this, combined with his addition to the 40-man, make it more likely that he ends up in a relief role. Both the quality of his breaking ball and his fastball velocity vary pretty dramatically, but when they're both dialed in, PERSON can dominate without throwing a lot of strikes, mostly by bullying hitters with his heater. He is stiff, oddly postured, and may not have the necessary athleticism to repeat his delivery. The ORGANIZATION should continue developing him as a starter so he gets more reps with both his change (which got better in 2018 and has a chance to miss bats one day) and breaking ball, but we think they'll pull the ripcord eventually and let PERSON breath fire in late innings.

When the ORGANIZATION made PERSON a second-round pick in 2011, they saw him as a projectable outfielder with a big league body and the chance for plus power, speed and arm strength. But he hit just .221/.254/.275 during his first three pro seasons, prompting his move to the mound in 2014. He reached Double-A a year after making his first pro pitching appearance and claimed a spot on the 40-man roster last November.PERSON has one plus pitch in a fastball that sits at 91-94 mph and touches 97 with mild sink, and the potential for another in his slider. His low-80s breaking ball improved in his second year as a pitch and flashes good tilt. He also has made progress with his changeup but projects more as a two-pitch reliever.While PERSON always had a strong arm and drew some scouting interest as an amateur pitcher, his quick transformation into a potential setup man has been surprising. He almost immediately regained his feel for pitching, showing the ability to repeat his delivery and throw strikes, though his control regressed in 2016. Once he improves his ability to locate his pitches, which got exposed a little bit when he got to Double-A, he'll be ready to help in GPE.

As twitchy as catching prospects get, PERSON posts plus-plus pop times thanks to a combination of plus raw arm strength, efficient footwork and a transfer so quick it qualifies as slight of hand. He's also a promising receiver and, while physically projectable, scouts don't anticipate PERSON will get so big that he needs to abandon the position. He also has plus raw power projection and a good chance to get to much of it as a right-handed hitter, though his left-handed stroke is somewhat stiff and upright. PERSON is the best J2 catching prospect since PERSON (PERSON had more power projection and pure arm strength) and, ignoring hindsight, there's an argument that PERSON is superior because of how likely he is is to remain behind the plate (PERSON had mobility and receiving issues) and grow into a well-rounded, impact defender.

Like ORGANIZATION Whitley two years ago, PERSON is a PERSON prep right-hander who will land in the first round after improving his physical conditioning and seeing his stuff and stock take a significant step forward. He led ORGANIZATION (Nacogdoches) to the PERSON state 3-A title as a two-way star in 2017, then consistently worked in the low 90s on the showcase circuit. This spring, he repeatedly has topped out at 97 or 98 mph.PERSON's fastball sits at 92-94 mph with heavy life that should turn wood bats into kindling. He has an array of promising secondary pitches, with most scouts preferring his low-80s slider to his mid-70s curveball, though the latter has nice shape. He hasn't had much need for a changeup but shows the potential to have an average one.PERSON is a decent athlete who uses a controlled delivery that allows him to provide strikes on a regular basis. His 6-foot-5 frame and high-three-quarters slot create steep downhill plane with his pitches. His emergence this spring makes it unlikely he'll follow through on a commitment to PERSON A&M.

PERSON won't be able to match the GPE status of his uncle PERSON, the ORGANIZATION. 2 overall pick and the ORGANIZATION winner in 1982 who's currently the head coach at ORGANIZATION III Carthage (Wis.). Nevertheless, he's a top prospect in his own right and has a chance to become the highest-drafted PERSON position player since the ORGANIZATION popped PERSON in the second round 31 years ago. The second-best high school shortstop available, trailing only PERSON's PERSON, PERSON was generating first-round buzz as the GPE approached.Because he grew up around his uncle's program, PERSON has advanced instincts in all phases of the game. His tools are catching up, as he has improved his strength, swing, speed and arm in the last year. He has worked to eliminate a hitch in his left-handed stroke, which has enough bat speed and leverage to produce 15 homers per year.After previously seeming destined for second base, PERSON now should be able to remain at shortstop. His arm strength and speed are at least solid -- some evaluators grade them as pluses -- and he has reliable hands. He's committed to PERSON but figures to get drafted too early to make it to GPE.

Scouts have praised PERSON's athleticism and they like his projectable body. In the batter's box, PERSON has gained a reputation for making good contact, especially in the inner half of the plate. Like most prospects his age, PERSON still needs to improve on his hitting mechanics and approach at the plate. He's expected to be able to drive the ball to all fields once he improves on the minor flaws in his batting technique.On defense, PERSON has shown decent footwork and good hands. He has the range to make the routine plays and his overall skill set on defense is expected to improve once he is placed into an academy and receives more instruction. He has also shown a strong arm.PERSON has displayed the ability to use his skill set in games. The ORGANIZATION teen racked up five hits and scored four runs in three games during PERSON's ORGANIZATION in February. He also walked twice.PERSON is trained by his father, PERSON.

Thought not especially projectable, PERSON has loose, quick wrists as well as natural feel for contact. He loads his hands low, allowing his bat to mirror that path of pitches and lift them in the air. He has some of the best natural hitting ability in the class and, as a corner outfield prospect without huge power projection, it will have to carry him.

A college reliever taken in the 15th round doesn't bring much in the way of expectations with him to the pro game. The ORGANIZATION product will throw four pitches, all average and sometimes a tick above, for strikes. He'll use different arm angles to give hitters very different looks, making it tough to pick up the baseball. PERSON will pitch with an average fastball that will touch 92-93 mph on occasion, an average slider and a curve that will be better than average at times. He can even turn his changeup over against right-handed hitters. He'll drop down to sidearm, making it even tougher to have a comfortable at-bat against him. PERSON made his full-season debut in 2015 in the hitter-friendly GPE League and was closing games for GPE Empire before earning a promotion and doing the same thing in Double-A. He profiles more as a middle or set-up man at the highest level.

PERSON, a former GPE ORGANIZATION star, spent his first full professional season with PERSON. Though he remains somewhat raw, his big arm and prototypical starter's build entice scouts. Having made it up to Double-A in 2015, he clearly intrigued the ORGANIZATION, who got him from the Nationals in return for PERSON just prior to the non-waiver Trading Deadline.There's still some projection left for PERSON, and he could end up pitching with a tick more velocity than he has now. His fastball typically sits in the low 90s, occasionally reaching 96 mph. His secondary stuff is still inconsistent, but he has the makings of a solid curveball and changeup. He's still learning to consistently repeat his delivery, but at his best he fills up the strike zone with all his pitches. PERSON is far from a finished product, but he has the upside to develop into a Major League starter in time.

ORGANIZATION is the son of former big league reliever PERSON and has been a known prospect of interest since his sophomore year of high school. Though he's not built like most prep prospects, ORGANIZATION is remarkably athletic and a dynamite high school basketball player. His stuff has waxed and waned this spring, but when it's good, ORGANIZATION has arguably the best present three-pitch mix and pitch usage in the class. He's a short-strider, so the fastball is going to play down a bit due to poor extension, but otherwise he projects as a mid-rotation arm due to the quality of his secondaries, and is, potentially, a quick-moving one. He's in play as early as pick #7, then there seems to be a gap before his name starts coming up again in the late teens and early twenties.

PERSON was the best position player prospect on the ORGANIZATION' Gulf Coast League team that went 49-9 in 2013. The GPE native moved up to Class A Hagerstown in 2014 and earned a spot on the LOCATION postseason All-Star team. He missed most of the first three months of the 2015 season after breaking a finger on a slide during the opening week. PERSON's speed is his best tool and he uses it well on the bases and in the outfield. He stole 69 bases in 2014, the second most in full-season ball. But he doesn't just run indiscriminately. He has good instincts on the bases and will bunt for a hit. Defensively, he takes good routes and tracks down an impressive amount of fly balls in center field. While PERSON's speed and defense give him two plus tools, he'll have to prove himself offensively as he advances in the ORGANIZATION. He has some on-base skills and has a good approach at the plate, albeit without much power.

During college, PERSON was used primarily as a reliever, but both at ORGANIZATION and in two summers in the ORGANIZATION. After drafting him in 2012, the ORGANIZATION gave him a chance to start, but they scrapped that plan in 2013. His fastball plays up out of the bullpen and has touched the upper-90s. More typically, PERSON throws in the low- to mid-90s and mixes his fastball with a hard curveball. He throws from a good downhill angle and gets lots of groundballs as a result. Dating back to college, however, PERSON has suffered from control problems, stemming from his extreme overhand arm action and unorthodox delivery. If he can improve his command, PERSON would fit well into the back of a Major League bullpen.

A senior sign in the 15th round out of ORGANIZATION, PERSON jumped on the prospect map during his first full season in 2014 and continued to impress with a move to Double-A in 2015. He capped it off with a very strong performance in the ORGANIZATION, but did not keep the momentum going, struggling in 2016 back in Double-A.Since joining the organization, PERSON has developed into a much more viable offensive threat. He came out of the college ranks with a very bad and choppy swing, almost with a downhill swing path. He's worked since to get some usable length to his swing to allow him drive the ball through the middle of the diamond, rather than just chop at it and use his legs to get on. He'll never be a big power guy, but he should be able to drive the ball to the gaps. He runs well and is a basestealing threat and offers excellent range in the outfield. He's always taken pride in his defense and can play all three spots.PERSON missed time in 2015 with a thumb injury, but made up for it with his outstanding ORGANIZATION turn. There was hope he could use that to springboard to the top of the system, but he'll have to get past his 2016 struggles first in order to reach his ceiling of a valuable fourth-outfielder type.

GPE high schools have spawned a number of talented left-handers in the last 15 years. PERSON was a first-round pick as a prepster; PERSON got first-round money at the same stage; and PERSON, PERSON, PERSON, ORGANIZATION and PERSON all became first-rounders or supplemental first-rounders after three years of college. PERSON has reached the big leagues and PERSON will be an early-round choice next year after emerging as PERSON's best starter as a freshman this spring.The latest in the line of ORGANIZATION State southpaws is PERSON, who may be unsignable but could blossom into another first-rounder after three years at ORGANIZATION. One of the more projectable lefties in the entire Draft, he already can reach 94 mph with his fastball and could park in the mid-90s once he fills out his skinny 6-foot-5 frame. He has some shape but lacks power with his curveball, which also could be helped with more physical development.PERSON has some fade to his changeup but needs to do a better job of selling it to hitters. He uses his height and high three-quarters arm slot to create steep downhill plane and has a feel for throwing strikes. Though he still needs a lot of polish, he could be enticing as early as the third round if a team thinks it can divert him from the ORGANIZATION.

GSP was moved to the bullpen in 2018 but a lot of teams think he has the repertoire depth and command to start, assuming he retains the same quality stuff for multiple innings. The sizable strikeout totals GSP has posted come from his ability to locate his slider and changeup rather than from high-quality stuff, and he'd likely max out as a fifth starter if re-introduced to the rotation.

After logging 39 innings as a true freshman in 2016, PERSON garnered Mid-American Conference pitcher of the year honors as both as sophomore and junior, going a combined 15-3 in 30 starts with 251 strikeouts in 170 2/3 innings between the two years. The ORGANIZATION selected PERSON in the eighth round of the 2018 Draft, signed him for $169,600 and watched him continue to dominate in his pro debut. PERSON's first full season brought similar results, as he made just six starts at ORGANIZATION A Lansing before moving up to ORGANIZATION A Advanced Dunedin.PERSON's effectiveness is routed in his invisible fastball. He throws his heater with below-average velocity, usually working at 88-92 mph, and sometimes works in the lower side of that velocity band. But the pitch plays above its velo because he's incredibly deceptive, employing long arm action on the backside and an explosive delivery that enables him to induce a ton of whiffs inside the zone. He also demonstrates feel for throwing both a mid-70s curveball and a harder slider, with the latter projection as the better secondary pitch, and he'll also mix in a changeup. PERSON doesn't fit into a neat box as a right-hander who lacks physical projection, pitches with below-average velocity and lacks a put-away secondary pitch, but there's something to be said for the effectiveness of his fastball and the sustained success he's had as a result. Whether he's able to navigate Double- and Triple-A lineups should offer more insight into whether PERSON can stick as a starter, but the early returns are encouraging.

PERSON whetted scouts' appetites when he threw in the mid-90s during fall practice in 2016, but he became academically ineligible and missed his entire sophomore season at FACILITY A&M-Corpus Christi. He built up more anticipation with a brief summer stint in the ORGANIZATION and another strong fall last year, then created all kinds of buzz by touching 98 mph and fanning a combined 27 in his second and third starts this spring. He hasn't been that dominant on a consistent basis, but he'll still easily surpass PERSON (ninth round, 2012) as the highest-drafted player in GPE history.PERSON has a lightning-quick arm that delivers 92-98 mph fastballs with sink, and he maintains his velocity into the late innings. He also has three secondary pitches that grade as plus at their best. His mid-80s slider is probably the most reliable, though some scouts prefer his tumbling changeup and his low-80s curveball features depth.Despite his quality stuff, PERSON gets hit harder than he should. He's not particularly tall and has an uphill delivery, costing him plane on his pitches. His command also fluctuates, and his ability to locate his pitches where he wants ultimately will determine if he can make it as a starter.

While PERSON has hit pretty much everywhere the ORGANIZATION have sent him since drafting him in the third round in 2010, he scuffled upon reaching Triple-A in 2015. He still made his big league debut in GPE, and a shoulder injury forced him out of action for over a month.A compact swing and quick hands allow PERSON to make consistent hard contact. He can occasionally turn on a ball and drives the gaps well, but power is not a big part of his game. He knows how to take advantage of his plus speed and can be disruptive on the basepaths. He has made significant strides on the defensive side of the ball as a professional and profiles well at second base. PERSON endears himself to scouts with his hustle and hard-nosed style of play. Though his height makes it easy to label him a grinder, his tools give him a good chance to be a solid regular in the ORGANIZATION.

GPE isn't toolsy but he has good feel to hit from both sides of the plate and terrific defensive instincts in center field. He's stout and not very projectable, but already looks like a potential bench out field type who can play all three spots and let you match up late in games.

PERSON' older brother ORGANIZATION signed for $1.1 million with the ORGANIZATION last year out of the same high school, ORGANIZATION went in the 3rd round to the D'Backs and, next year, ORGANIZATION is looking like a top two round caliber arm from the same school. PERSON doesn't have much projection, but has solid feel of three pitches that have all been above average at times.

A junior college reliever, PERSON is a very interesting arm strength/physical projection developmental prospect. He was still just 18 on draft day and is already throwing 90-95, and his gangly 6-foot-6 frame portends more velo. He has some nascent breaking ball feel but is understandably behind fom a development standpoint due to his college role. He's a long term project but has ingredients with which to work.

Selected in the sixth round of the 2012 Draft, PERSON was named the ORGANIZATION of the Year in 2014 after he posted a .905 OPS with 153 hits, 87 runs, 17 home runs and 23 steals in 130 games between Class A Quad Cities and Class A Advanced Lancaster. He began 2015 back in the GPE, where he hit .320 with 15 home runs in 66 games, but his power dropped off considerably after moving up to Double-A. In GPE, the ORGANIZATION traded PERSON to PERSON in the ORGANIZATION Gomez/Mike Fiers deal, and he spent two weeks on the shelf in late August with an irritated nerve in his thumb.PERSON has a short, compact swing from the left side that produces hard contact across the whole field, though he does have a tendency to get pull happy. He won't hit as many home runs as he moves up the organizational ladder, but the bat and approach are good enough for him to offer average power at maturity. PERSON' above-average defense and cannon arm are fits in either center or right field, and he split time between both positions in 2015. Though he'll have a chance to remain up the middle, some scouts think he's better suited for right field long-term. Though he's struggled this year in his return to the Double-A level, PERSON' above-average speed gives him an intriguing blend of power, speed and hitting ability, the combination of which could make him a dynamic top-of-the-order hitter.

Every team in the big leagues would like a player like PERSON in their Minor League system.PERSON has a good build for a shortstop, and he has the defensive actions that will allow him to stay at there -- at least at the beginning of his professional career. Some scouts project that his body will force him to move from shortstop to third base, but there's also chance he stays at his original position. PERSON is a strong teenager. He has plus raw power and plus arm strength, and he's shown the ability to hit in games. It's his hit tool that has some scouts thinking that PERSON will be a middle-of-the-order type of player. Overall, he presents an interesting package of tools to scouts, but many evaluators want to see him display those talents more consistently. Other scouts believe he is the best all-around player in the class. PERSON signed with the ORGANIZATION for $4 million.

PERSON had PERSON surgery as a freshman at ORGANIZATION, returning as a redshirt freshman in 2016 and pitching out of the bullpen. He pitched largely in relief in 2017, mixing in a few starts, and was drafted in the 35th round by the ORGANIZATION. But PERSON opted to return to PERSON to pitch in the rotation for his junior season. He threw well enough to land in the fifth round of the 2018 Draft and while he didn't pitch much in his first summer, he did reach full-season ball, though he was too fatigued to throw at instructs.Big and strong, PERSON has an interesting three-pitch mix to work with, starting with a fastball that touched the mid-90s in his final college season, but sat more at 91-92 over the summer. It has a high spin rate and he can miss bats with it, though he also can keep it down in the zone with sink to elicit ground-ball outs. Both his slider and his changeup flash above-average at times, with his slider the more consistent of the two secondary offerings. PERSON has always been a strike-thrower, but didn't always command the ball well within the zone, leading to a higher hit rate in college than you'd expect given his stuff. That wasn't the case in his small sample size in pro ball, so the A's are intrigued to find out if he can continue that trend over 140-150 innings in a rotation.

The last product from PERSON to make it to the big leagues was reliever PERSON. The last position player from the ORGANIZATION school to make it was PERSON, who last played in 1972. PERSON is hoping to follow in their footsteps.The 14th-round pick is a left-handed hitting outfielder who could profile well in center field and atop a lineup if his bat continues to develop. It has made strides since he's joined the organization, and he hit well enough in the GPE League to start the 2015 season to earn a promotion to Double-A after a 2014 campaign that was interrupted by back problems. He has no power to speak of, but he can really run, which allows him to be a base-stealing threat and cover a lot of ground in center field. He's one of the better defensive outfielders in the system.PERSON may profile best as an extra outfielder, and he has seen time in the past at all three spots, but if his ability to make contact and get on base can improve, there might be a bit more than expected to come.

PERSON is one of many whiff-heavy corner bats with huge power who floats around the upper levels of the minors, putting up big power numbers while struggling to find a big league role if their parent club has someone at 1B/DH. The ORGANIZATION have tried PERSON in the outfield but scouts don't think he's playable out there. PERSON has the advantage of hitting left-handed, but unless the ORGANIZATION make a concerted effort to give him reps soon (they demoted him to Double-A to start 2019, so not a great sign) he'll probably bounce around on waivers until a team with 40-man space -- and the time to see whether or not PERSON can hit big league pitching -- gives him a chance. Sometimes this is how clubs fall into PERSON and PERSON, but it's also the fate of many a Quad-A hitter.

PERSON was an early-round prospect for the 2017 before he chose to reclassify for the 2016 Draft a year ago. ORGANIZATION approved that decision, making him part of a banner high school crop in GPE. PERSON, who will turn 18 three weeks before the draft, is the state's best position prospect since PERSON went fifth overall to the Royals in 2011. A homeschooled student who takes a class and plays at ORGANIZATION (ORGANIZATION, Kan.), PERSON offers an exciting array of tools. He has well above-average bat speed and foot speed and plus raw power and arm strength. He has committed to switch-hitting and while his natural right-handed stroke is quicker and more fluid, his lefty swing is fast and loose.PERSON already is bigger than the typical big league shortstop and lacks classic actions for the position, so he'll likely need a new defensive home in pro ball. The ORGANIZATION State recruit has the quickness for second base and the arm strength for third base, though some scouts question his hands and think he's destined for center field. He has the offensive upside to profile at any of those spots, and the work ethic to make the most of his tools.

After redshirting in his first year at ORGANIZATION and working just 12 innings in his first season on the mound, PERSON led ORGANIZATION Division I by averaging 4.1 hits allowed and 15.2 strikeouts per nine innings in 2016. Since signing for $275,000 as a 10th-round pick that June, he has continued to avoid bats. In two pro seasons, he has compiled a 1.16 ERA, 11.5 strikeouts per nine innings and .159 opponent average while allowing just two homers in 93 1/3 innings.With his 6-foot-7 build and those strikeout numbers, it would be easy to suspect that PERSON is a power pitcher who blows fastballs by hitters. While they don't catch up to his heater, it usually arrives at 89-93 mph. It has fringy velocity, but 80-grade deception, as his size, extension and his low arm slot combine to make it appear much quicker than its radar-gun readings.PERSON' tricky fastball is his only real weapon, so he projects as a reliever only. His changeup can be a solid pitch at times and rates better than his slider, but he'll probably need a more reliable secondary pitch to keep more advanced hitters off balance. He'll also need to throw more strikes after his walk rate jumped from 1.8 per nine innings in his pro debut to 4.2 in his first full season.

PERSON and his older brother PERSON teamed to help ORGANIZATION (GPE) reach the 2017 ORGANIZATION World Series, with PERSON ranking among the national juco leaders with 19 homers and 82 RBI, before both were drafted in the 36th round. PERSON turned down the ORGANIZATION and transferred to GPE, while PERSON returned to the ORGANIZATION as the consensus top juco prospect for 2018. He has maintained that status despite elbow issues that prevented him from catching for a month and have limited his appearances on the mound, where he has been clocked as high as 100 mph.GPE has well above-average raw power to all fields and an aggressive right-handed swing that generates uncommon bat speed. He has a maximum-effort approach at the plate (and on the mound), and while he doesn't strike out excessively, his lack of patience is a cause of concern. He did show that his pop plays with wood bats and against better pitching when he finished fifth in the ORGANIZATION with six homers last summer.Scouts were skeptical of GPE's ability to stay at catcher when they saw him as a freshman, but he has improved defensively and projects as at least an adequate receiver. His arm strength is an asset behind the plate, though the ORGANIZATION commit needs to improve his throwing accuracy. Despite his impressive radar-gun readings, his violent delivery would make it difficult for him to hold up as a full-time pitcher.

The top pitcher out of GPE and arguably one of the best prospects in the class overall, PERSON is a talented young player with tons of potential.First of all, he has the look scouts covet. PERSON has the prototypical pitcher's build: long and lean. He's strong and athletic with room to grow. He's aggressive on the mound and has good feel for his pitches and how to attack hitters.PERSON's best pitch is his fastball and it sits in the 93-97 mph. range. He shows good sink and movement with the pitch along with excellent command. He also throws a changeup and his slider continues to improve. PERSON trains with PERSON in GPE. The ORGANIZATION are the favorites to sign him.

PERSON's power is derived from a combination of bat speed and strength, while his lofty barrel path through the zone enables him to generate backspin consistently. A right-handed hitter, he can get pull happy at times but did a better job of using the whole field in 2015. PERSON also made huge strides toning down his aggressive approach, posting a career-best walk rate in his first taste of Double-A while also reducing his strikeout rate by near five percent.PERSON's power is derived from a combination of bat speed and strength, while his lofty barrel path through the zone enables him to generate backspin consistently. A right-handed hitter, he can get pull happy at times but did a better job of using the whole field in 2015. PERSON also made huge strides toning down his aggressive approach, posting a career-best walk rate in his first taste of Double-A while reducing his strikeout rate to 15.9 percent from 20.1 percent the previous year. Defensively, PERSON has the arm strength and glove to handle third base, but he lacks the range and first-step quickness, with speed that grades as well below average. He saw playing time at first base for the first time in 2015 and could move there full-time down the road, although it would place additional pressure on his offensive development.

This is probably a right-hitting first baseman in the end, and PERSON's frame is not as projectable as his measureables might indicate, but he's young and already has sizeable raw. He's also shown all-fields in-game power and has surprising straightline speed for his size, a 50 runner underway.

A second-round choice in consecutive Drafts, PERSON turned down the ORGANIZATION as when they didn't offer him the full $680,400 assigned value for his No. 75 slot in 2012. The highest unsigned high schooler that year, he went 30 picks higher after a year at ORGANIZATION State (Okla.) JC. He originally agreed to a $1.1 million bonus that got discounted to $915,000 after a physical revealed he had been born without a right pectoral muscle.PERSON has had no health issues and has thrown strikes with ease since turning pro. He mixes four pitches while working off a fastball that sits at 91-93 mph and touches 95 with life and command. His slider shows flashes of becoming a plus pitch but needs more consistency, as do his curveball and changeup. PERSON repeats his drop-and-drive delivery well, allowing him to pound the bottom of the strike zone. He's on his way to becoming an innings-eating No. 4 starter, perhaps more if he fills out his projectable frame and his stuff picks up.

PERSON is extremely athletic with a projectable body and lots of raw talent. PERSON love his upside. In fact, some evaluators believe he has the potential to have plus tools across the board. Overall, the teenager profiles as a center fielder and he has impressed scouts with his defensive actions in the outfield and how well he covers ground. He has plenty of arm strength for the position and could probably play all three outfield positions if needed. A decent runner, PERSON has the potential to be a base-stealer. Like most prospects his age, PERSON is far from a finished product and will benefit greatly from the daily instruction he receives once he signs with a club and enters a team's academy.PERSON's recent development has been slowed by an arm injury, but he has since recovered.The teenager is trained by PERSON in GPE, PERSON.

Rather than being one of the oldest prep players in the 2014 Draft class, PERSON expedited his graduation and was granted eligibility for the '13 Draft by PERSON, leading to his selection by the Nationals in the third round. The GPE native had an impressive full-season debut the following year as a teenager in the ORGANIZATION A GPE ORGANIZATION, but failed to take a step forward at ORGANIZATION A Advanced ORGANIZATION in 2015, and then had a subpar showing in the ORGANIZATION. He got back on track in 2016, though, earning All-Star honors at ORGANIZATION before moving up to Double-A at age 21. PERSON's approach has been more advanced and consistent than anticipated; he's proven to be a patient hitter who sees a lot of pitches and takes his walks, though his knack for working deep counts, on top of his natural swing-and-miss tendencies, has led to high strikeout totals to begin his career. And while raw power was his calling card as an amateur, the left-handed hitter has struggled to apply it in games as a pro.After playing shortstop in high school, PERSON was shifted to third base upon turning pro, where he shows an above-average arm. However, some scouts already doubt that he'll be able to stick at the position long term, with his stiff actions and below-average range portending an eventual move to first base.

If a player can get to the big leagues on work ethic alone, PERSON should have a lengthy and successful career. Whether or not it can make up for the lack of pure stuff remains to be seen.The hardest worker in the organization, PERSON pitches without any fear and shows a willingness to pitch inside better than any other pitcher in the system, getting outs as a result. And he does it with a fringy fastball, at best, one that sits in the 87-89 mph range and can touch the low-90s. PERSON moves the pitch in and out, up and down, generating a ton of groundball outs along the way. His changeup is his best pitch, an easily above-average offering he will throw at any time. While it still needs refinement, he can throw his breaking ball for strikes. Don't look for strikeouts from PERSON, but he also rarely hurts himself with walks.Full-season ball should be a good test for PERSON to see if his pitchability and moxie can continue to get people out. He could develop into a solid No. 4 or 5 starter in the future.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON, an ORGANIZATION commit, has done nothing but hit at ORGANIZATION (Ariz.). The senior hit .330 as a sophomore and bumped it up to .404 with 24 RBIs in 34 games as a junior.With a slightly open stance and level swing, GPE sprays the ball to all fields but has trouble with offspeed pitches.GPE has a lean projectable frame and a solid glove. The middle infielder currently rates average on defense and has the tools to stay up the middle in the future.

GPE's older brother PERSON went fifth overall in the 2012 Draft and reached Double-A in his first full pro season. PERSON won't go quite that high but looks like a first-rounder and also could move quickly through the ORGANIZATION. He performed well last summer, leading the GPE college national team with 11 steals and winning playoff ORGANIZATION honors in the ORGANIZATION League.GPE has a nice package of tools, with his bat standing out the most. He has a sweet left-handed stroke, and he manages the strike zone and recognizes pitches well. His body has enough strength and leverage to possibly produce plus power if he were to add some loft to his swing, though he's content to spray line drives all over the field for now.He enhances his solid speed with keen instincts, which make him an asset on the basepaths and in the outfield. He has a chance to play center field, and if not, his strong arm will fit well in right.

The ORGANIZATION lost a pair of outfield prospects in the 2015 Rule 5 Draft in PERSON, whom the ORGANIZATION selected with the ORGANIZATION. 1 pick, and PERSON. Originally a ninth-round Draft pick out of GPE in 2012, PERSON was left off the ORGANIZATION' 40-man roster in spite of a breakout 2015 campaign in which he hit .321/.427/.447 with 38 extra-base hits and 23 steals across three levels, finishing the year in Triple-A.A right-handed hitter, PERSON has a short, quick swing that yields a lot of contact, and he does a good job of using the whole field. His on-base skills have improved as he's moved up the ladder, thanks to a mature approach and advanced feel for the strike zone, and he knows how to use his plus speed when he gets on.PERSON's speed also makes him a rangy defender in the outfield, and he's capable of playing all three positions. He spent the offseason playing winter ball in the ORGANIZATION, where he paced the league in total bases and ORGANIZATION and ranked second in home runs and doubles. And while PERSON has played just 29 games above the Double-A level, the ORGANIZATION see him as a capable bench outfielder for the 2016 season.

PERSON and GPE Thomas More High (ORGANIZATION) left-hander PERSON were supposed to be the top two high school prospects in GPE this year, but PERSON' velocity dropped precipitously and PERSON's also declined under a heavy workload. PERSON now seems certain to attend GPE-ORGANIZATION, and PERSON could join him there if he doesn't get picked high enough to sign.After pitching at 91-95 mph on the showcase circuit last summer, PERSON has operated with an 88-91 mph fastball for much of the spring. He still reaches 94 mph on occasion, and his fastball can break bats with its running, sinking action. His projectable frame hints at more and more consistent velocity in the future if he isn't overworked.PERSON lacks a reliable second pitch. He flashes an average curveball but gets under or around it too often, and he doesn't trust his changeup. There are a lot of moving parts and effort in his delivery, creating concerns about his ability to stay healthy and command his offerings.

PERSON's first full professional season saw him start the All-Star Game for the GPE League before moving up to Double-A Pensacola for the second half. After his breakout year, the ORGANIZATION traded him to the Phillies in exchange for PERSON. None of PERSON's pitches jump off the page, but he does have four of them that he can throw for strikes. His fastball can touch 93-94 mph, and his slider shows signs of being a potential above-average pitch, as well. PERSON mixes in his curve and changeup well to keep hitters guessing. All of his stuff plays up because of his unusual delivery in which his arm stays hidden, making it tough for hitters to pick up the ball.  When he was a member of the ORGANIZATION' system, PERSON was often compared to PERSON for his stuff and deception. It didn't take long for PERSON to get to the big leagues and PERSON could be on a similar track.

PERSON was Draft-eligible for five straight years at an ORGANIZATION high school, PERSON (Ariz.) CC and PERSON and he distinguished himself with wood bats in summer college leagues. Bukauskas and PERSON from the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal.PERSON has made consistent contact from the left side of the plate since turning pro but is doing more damage in 2019. PERSON took over the closer role at the ORGANIZATION of GPE as a freshman and never let go of it. Because of the local weather, high school baseball in GPE doesn't get underway until late May, which would have made PERSON impossible to scout were there not alternatives. ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON PhillipsSlated to play next year at ORGANIZATION (Ariz.), PERSON has a slight build with narrow shoulders and hips.Offensively, he has limited bat control and speed but still manages to produce line drives from the left side of the plate.Behind the plate, PERSON can effectively throw out would-be basestealers.

PERSON made just four appearances for FACILITY A&M as a freshman before leading the Aggies with eight saves last spring. PERSON tapped LOCATION A&M JC for a pair of GPE picks in 2014, grabbing right-hander LOCATION in the 11th round and GPE in the 16th. PERSON was up to 96 in high school, often sitting in the low-90s. He was 90-92 this fall with an average slider that has horizontal wipe during instructs. He's a big-framed projection arm whose stuff hasn't ascended yet.

GPE first arrived on the national scene as a sophomore when he tossed a complete-game win in the opening round of ORGANIZATION's 2012 ORGANIZATION. Undrafted out of high school and after his first year at FACILITY (ORGANIZATION.) ORGANIZATION, PERSON went 17th overall in June 2013 after leading PERSON junior college players in hitting (.495) and on-base percentage (.568). The Friday night starter for the ORGANIZATION of GPE as a sophomore and junior, PERSON helped lead the Cavaliers to their first ORGANIZATION title in his first year in that role, then followed it up with a strong junior campaign. PeÃ±a missed all of 2015 and 2016 due to injury and is a bit behind other 21-year-olds, having thrown just 30 innings above rookie ball thus far. But he has three big league offerings and filled up the strike zone in 2018, so he could move quickly if he stays healthy. He started last year but we like him as a three-pitch middle relief prospect.

PERSON was having a fine start to his 2012 season with short-season Vancouver when a broken hand knocked him out of action after just 11 games. PERSON stood out as a prep sophomore for his big raw power and arm strength, both as a catcher and a pitcher in the low-90s on the mound. PERSON' father, PERSON, is a longtime college coach, allowing PERSON to spend a lot of time around the diamond. His upbringing shows and he has a good feel for the game. PERSON was a two-way prospect in high school, but the ORGANIZATION will develop him as a position player. His range and size are well suited for third base. Thanks to his all-around profile, the ORGANIZATION will give him plenty of opportunities to make the necessary adjustments.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

After impressing during his full-season debut in 2012, PERSON was hampered by injuries in '13. He missed the first half of the season after undergoing surgery during Spring Training to repair a torn meniscus.PERSON is now back to full strength and looks as good as ever. He throws his fastball in the low-90s with heavy sinking action, mixing it with a solid slider and a changeup. PERSON does a good job of throwing strikes and keeping the ball down in the zone.PERSON was a part of the same Oklahoma high school class as PERSON and PERSON. Though he doesn't have their upside, PERSON has what it takes to be a big league starter.

While at GPE (Wash.) JC, GPE underwent PERSON surgery in the fall of 2010 and missed all of 2011 and much of 2012 as a result. His arm strength returned in 2013, impressively enough for the ORGANIZATION to draft him in the fourth round. After a good start to his first full professional season, the ORGANIZATION acquired him in July as part of their return for PERSON. GPE' best pitch by far is his fastball, which sits in the low 90s, can reach 95 mph and features life as well as velocity. His secondary pitches are more works in progress, with his spike curveball showing more promise than his changeup. At 6-foot-4 and 205 pounds, GPE has the build to be a starter and has pitched well in that role after spending most of his debut as a reliever. To remain in the rotation, he'll have to throw more strikes and refine his curveball and changeup.

Injuries robbed PERSON of much of his last two seasons and brought about a move to the bullpen in 2018. While lightning quick, his arm action is quite violent, which detracts from PERSON's command and has created a perception of heightened injury risk. But he also has an upper-90s fastball and plus changeup when healthy and reached Double-A as a 21-year-old last year. The Cardinals are incentivized to extract big league value out of PERSON while he's healthy and has good stuff, so it's possible we see him and his high-leverage offering as early as next year.

Former big leaguer PERSON has done a tremendous job since he took over as head coach of GPE Canyon University, moving the school from ORGANIZATION II to a successful ORGANIZATION I program and seeing eight of his players get drafted along the way. None of them has been taken before the ninth round, but GPE, who moved from the bullpen as a freshman to the Friday night starter the last two years, should easily surpass his predecessors.GPE has a solid enough three-pitch mix that he should be given every opportunity to start. He will throw his fastball in the 90-94 range, sitting around 92-94 consistently, while occasionally touching 96 mph occasionally. His fastball has been fairly true without a ton of deception to it this spring, so he does get hit at times more than you'd think. His changeup might be the better secondary offering. He sells it well with arm speed, some arm side fade, showing more deception with that than he does his fastball. His slider is average, with some late break to it.GPE throws strikes and has a solid feel for pitching, which gives him a chance to start. He did pitch out of the bullpen while on the GPE, with an uptick in velocity, providing a solid backup plan. But a team taking the right-hander in the top few rounds will see him as a future member of a rotation.

PERSON didn't generate any headlines when he signed for $225,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, but he has attracted plenty of attention since making his GPE debut two years later. He started drawing comparisons to Jose PERSON and teams almost immediately started asking for him in trade talks.
