A.J. PERSON might be the more "famous" ORGANIZATION of GPE starter, but it's been PERSON who has been the ORGANIZATION' Friday night starter for all three years of his college career. He's more about pitchability than stuff, but that's led to a ton of success in the ultra-competitive SEC.Strong and durable, PERSON is a strike-throwing machine with a potential three-pitch mix. He typically works with an average fastball velocity-wise, but it plays up because of his command. His best pitch is his changeup, which he locates and sinks extremely well. Even when hitters know it's coming, he still gets outs. PERSON's breaking ball is slurvy and a bit inconsistent. When it's on, it can be virtually unhittable and has the potential of being a third Major League average offering.The lack of an explosive fastball limits his ceiling and, as a result, his ORGANIZATION stock. There's no question PERSON is the first Gator pitcher to go off the board and some others could pass PERSON by because of the fastball, but whatever team takes PERSON will be getting a college performer who should be quick to the big leagues as a back-end starter.

PERSON was known more as a pitcher early in his amateur days, even getting drafted as a left-hander by the Twins when he was in junior college in 2014. His bat came alive the following year after he transferred to PERSON and his upside as a hitter got the ORGANIZATION to take a chance on him with a 15th-round selection. He's shown glimpses of putting his tools into production, playing 2018 in Double-A, then really standing out with a strong ORGANIZATION performance to earn a spot on the 40-man roster.On any given day, PERSON will show all five tools. Given that he didn't really start focusing on his offensive game until college, he's still learning to hit. He made some adjustments to his swing at the end of his 2018 season, adding a small leg kick to replace a toe tap with strong results, especially in the ORGANIZATION. It allowed him to keep his weight back, wait on breaking balls more and lay off of ones out of the strike zone, something that has previously plagued him. It should help him tap into his easily plus raw power more consistently. He runs very well for his size and while he has seen time in all three outfield spots, he fits the profile of an athletic power-hitting right fielder with a plus arm.Because of his size, athleticism and tools, PERSON sometimes gets PERSON comps, minus the plus hit tool. That's an unfair standard obviously, but there is ceiling for PERSON to still grow into.

GPE was the second college catcher taken in the 2013 Draft, largely because of his defensive ability. He's been as good as advertised, if not better, with the hope that perhaps there's a little offense to come, though he struggled with the bat as he moved up to Double-A in 2015.It will be GPE's glove that gets him to the big leagues. He's a very good receiver who handles a pitching staff well and has a good feel for calling a game. His strong and accurate arm has allowed him to throw out better than a third of would-be basestealers, and he has the natural leadership qualities teams love to have in a catcher. GPE made some progress at the plate early in his pro career, making consistent contact, and there is strength for him to tap into some moderate raw power. Even with his offensive progress stalled, GPE has the skills to be a defensive-oriented backstop. If the bat can come alive again, he might have the goods to be a starting one in the big leagues in the future.
PERSON is an above average runner underway with a long, projectable frame and future plus power but limited track record of performance.

Sometimes amateur players are late bloomers, especially on the mound. GPE wasn't drafted out of high school but moved up ORGANIZATION boards as PERSON's Friday starter.Tall and lean on a 6-foot-5 frame, GPE has some room to fill out. And what he has is already pretty good. The left-hander pitches downhill with natural cutting movement on his fastball. His short, sharp slider is an out pitch at times. He has solid feel for a changeup, though it's still a work in progress. GPE is generally around the plate with all of his pitches and has been one of the nation's top strikeout pitchers.There's still some upside to GPE as he continues to fill out, giving him the chance to be in a big league rotation in the future.

The ORGANIZATION took a flier on PERSON in 15th round of the 2012 Draft even though the left-hander had suffered an elbow tear during his senior year at GPE (Ill.) High. He signed for $426,000 and ultimately underwent PERSON surgery later that year, costing him all of 2013. Though he returned to the mound the following year, injuries plagued PERSON once again in 2015, as he missed time with both elbow and shoulder pain. PERSON healthy in 2016, PERSON struggled out of the gate at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Dunedin but dominated following a demotion to ORGANIZATION A Lansing, finishing second in the ORGANIZATION in GPE (2.41). He fared considerably better in his return to the ORGANIZATION State League this season, ultimately earning a promotion to Double-A in July.PERSON has an 88-92 mph fastball that peaks at 94, with late movement that helps him to generate ground balls. His plus changeup plays nicely off of his heater because he throws it with similar arm speed, and it gives him a chance against right-handed hitters. PERSON's slider is less advanced than his changeup, with varying shape and pace, but it has the potential to be another Major League-average pitch. Despite missing parts of three seasons due to injury, PERSON has never lost his feel for pounding the zone with his entire arsenal.PERSON had just 68 2/3 career innings to his name before the 2016 season, but he answered questions about his durability by pitching 135 2/3 frames and making 26 starts. He's on pace to surpass that total in 2017 as he continues to show the ingredients needed to develop into a back-end starter.

PERSON's exciting GPE debut in 2013, followed by his ability to hold his own in the LOCATION League in 2014, has the organization excited about his potential to become an everyday shortstop, even if it's way off in the future.Signed in 2011, PERSON performed very well in the short-season PERSON in '13. A left-handed-hitting shortstop, he has good bat speed at the plate, though added strength and a better knowledge of the strike zone will help his offensive game. PERSON has excellent speed, which should help him on both sides of the ball. He has the range and the arm to stay at shortstop long-term. PERSON is not going to move PERSON off of shortstop anytime soon, and the ORGANIZATION will be sure not to rush him, but PERSON does give GPE a middle infielder who will definitely stick at the premium position long-term.

PERSON GPE hasn't had a player drafted since 2002, and none of the six Hornets selected have been taken before the 24th round. That will change this June, when PERSON's defensive prowess should make him a second-day pick in a Draft light on legitimate shortstops.The 2014 LOCATION Conference player of the year, PERSON has all the tools to play shortstop in the big leagues. He has smooth actions, quick hands and a strong, accurate arm. Though his pure speed doesn't grade as better than average, he still offers plenty of range at shortstop.The PERSON Rican-born PERSON stands out much more in the field at the plate. He's a switch-hitter who's better as a right-hander, though he'll need to tone down his approach to hit for a decent average. He won't provide much power and probably will fit toward the bottom of a lineup.

GPE will make his GPE debut in 2013 after striking out 9.6 per nine in the ORGANIZATION. The athletic and wiry right-hander has electric stuff and can crank it up to 99 mph, maintaining that kind of velocity deep into starts. His slider has the chance to be a wipeout pitch. He handled his first visit to the GPE, at instructs, well, so the ORGANIZATION are hopeful he'll adjust easily. The key for him will be throwing strikes as well as developing a changeup. He'll begin as a starter, but there's a chance that he ends up in the back end of a bullpen someday.

A young, polished, but relatively unexplosive high schooler, GPE was a bit of a surprise second rounder in 2017 but has quickly become much more interesting thanks to a sterling 2018 season with PERSON. As a 19-year-old, he hit .352/.405/.511 for the ORGANIZATION, torching even the loftiest of expectations set by scouts who saw him during extended spring training and mostly considered GPE a future utility man. Fundamentally sound at short, he lacks the explosiveness and big arm strength scouts look for at the position, and we wonder if GPE will hit for enough power to be an impact player at any other position. 
His early career strikeout rate (7.5% in about 450 PA) suggests his bat-to-ball skills are even more promising than amateur scouts anticipated, though he's also an aggressive swinger who has been hit by nearly twice as many pitches as he has walks so far. When scouts talk about a player having 'feel, polish, instincts' and the like, and the player has numbers like GPE's contact rates, we typically round up on that player. In GPE's case, we remain cautious because the eyeball scouts are so resolute in their skepticism of the power projection.

PERSON made a splash in his professional debut, winning the ORGANIZATION MVP Award in 2012. But he was unable to build on that success in 2013. PERSON played on Opening Day in Class A Asheville, but he was then sent back to extended spring camp for disciplinary reasons. He returned to Asheville three weeks later, only to tear his right hamstring, ending his season in early May.PERSON is a pure hitter with an innate feel for putting the bat on the ball. He has some pop in his bat already and could develop above-average power as he physically matures.Before the injury, PERSON had above-average speed, and he used it well offensively and defensively. He covers ground well in the outfield and has a strong arm. PERSON appears to have recovered from what was essentially a lost year for him, getting back on track in 2014.

PERSON wasn't a high-profile signing when he turned pro out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011, and his career has taken a while to get going. He repeated the Rookie-level ORGANIZATION in his first two years as a pro and the short-season LOCATION in the last two seasons. He emerged as one of the more intriguing lefties in the ORGANIZATION system in his return to the ORGANIZATION this year, leading the league in GPE (0.51), opponent average (.156) and K/BB ratio (12.3) before his first-ever promotion to full-season ball.In a year in which several of GPE's best southpaw pitching prospects have seen their stuff regress, PERSON has stood out with a lively 91-94 mph fastball that can reach 96. Both of his secondary pitches need more consistency, but his hard slider shows flashes of becoming a plus offering, and his changeup has a chance to become at least average.PERSON has matured significantly on the mound in 2016, doing a better job of challenging hitters and throwing strikes. He's gaining an understanding of sequencing pitches and recognizing swings that he has lacked in the past. Though he still has to prove he can sustain success, the progress he has made this year has been encouraging.

A vanilla, but well-rounded college infielder. Best defensive fit is at third but is fundamentally sound enough to stand at a middle infield spot if needed. Conservative, contact-oriented approach, limited raw power. PERSON infield/Utility type.

Though PERSON shows no signs of ever slowing down, the ORGANIZATION invested in a pair of promising young third-base prospects in 2016. After signing PERSON for $675,000 as a third-round pick in June, they landed PERSON three months later for $1.1 million. He played two seasons in GPE's top league as a teenager, batting a combined .259/.335/.328.Like PERSON, PERSON doesn't have one standout tool but does possess the potential to contribute across the board. His raw right-handed power attracted the most attention from scouts, and he has the approach and hitting ability to translate it into game production. His speed reportedly has improved since he left GPE, with some evaluators now giving it above-average or plus grades.PERSON played five positions in GPE's PERSON: third base, first base, second base, right field and left field. He has average arm strength and should have enough quickness to stay at the hot corner. If he can't handle third base, the outfield corners are his likely next destination.

A GPE product, PERSON ranked as one of the best pure high school hitters in the 2012 Draft, but slid to the ORGANIZATION in the 29th round because of his steadfast commitment to PERSON. The consensus national freshman of the year in 2013, he's now one of the top bats in this year's college crop.PERSON has an unconventional right-handed swing, but it works for him because he has a very quick bat and controls the strike zone well. He has some pull power and could develop average pop if he adds some loft to his stroke. He has average speed that plays up because of his instincts.Because of his size, tools and aggressive nature at the plate, he regularly gets compared to PERSON. Like PERSON, he appeared to be a college shortstop headed for second base in pro ball, but PERSON has looked better defensively this spring and may be able to stick at short. His arm and instincts allow him to make plays there, and he shows range to both sides.

/15: PERSON to miss 2017 season after PERSON since PERSON joined the ORGANIZATION organization by moving to the ORGANIZATION from GPE and circumventing the Draft in 2012, he's had future frontline starter written all over him. Reaching Double-A and excelling in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 has him much closer to fulfilling that potential, though a 50-game suspension for marijuana use put a damper on the year.Assuming it's not a long-term issue, the suspension shouldn't derail PERSON for long. The big right-hander has serious swing-and-miss stuff, with a fastball that touches the mid-90s consistently and can hit triple digits to complement a devastating power curveball. Unlike some young pitchers, PERSON is willing to throw his changeup and understands the value of having it to make his two plus offerings better. Though it's behind the other two, it should be PERSON average in time.Command and control have been PERSON' biggest obstacles, but he's improved tremendously over the past couple of seasons, particularly in terms of his fastball command. If his progress continues, it won't be long before big league hitters will have to try and figure him out.

PERSON was projected to be PERSON's top starter in 2014 before undergoing PERSON surgery, sidelining him for a part of the '15 season as well. However, he pitched well enough after his return to convince the FACILITY to select him in the fifth round of last year's Draft. PERSON healthy, PERSON impressed during his professional debut between the ORGANIZATION and GPE leagues and then followed it with a strong instructional league, showing a 93-96 mph fastball and a plus curveball. He also features a slider with average potential and has feel for a changeup. PERSON' 6-foot-1, 190-pound frame raises questions about his durability, though he hasn't had problems holding his velocity as a professional.While the FACILITY expect to deploy PERSON as a starter at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Winston-Salem in 2016, his two plus pitches also give him potential as a late-inning reliever, one who could move up the ladder quickly with a shift to the bullpen.

PERSON got hot late in the year (he had a .400 OBP in July and August) and ended 2018 with a .302/.381/.438 line at ORGANIZATION. The leg kick he had while with PERSON is now gone, and the strength of PERSON' hands and his ability to move the bat head around the zone have led to sufficiently hard contact without it. 
Much of PERSON' profile depends upon his ability to stay in center field and the general consensus is that he's a 45 or 50 defender out there. We keep waiting for PERSON' ORGANIZATION to regress (it hasn't), and we expect his unusually high walk rate from 2018 to do eventually so as well (though, he was very selective in the ORGANIZATION), but ulimately he projects to be an average offensive player who is fine in center field, which would make him an everyday player of some kind. He turn 24 in January.

PERSON was an intriguing two-way athlete on the showcase circuit, then hit 97 mph repeatedly early in his draft spring and moved into top two round contention. His stuff backed up a bit down the stretch. PERSON had not thrown as much as many of his peers and lacked their stamina, though this could be spun into a positive, namely PERSON's arm being relatively fresh. Late in the spring, he was working more in the low-90's rather than 93-96 mph, and his shorter stature and stride length led his fastball to be hittable. The Reds are gambling on the plus fastball returning as he builds strength, experience, and stamina in his arm in a starting role, and he has no. 3/4 starter potential with good, clear checkpoints to watch that will indicate improvement, including fastball rebound and maintaining his stuff into the summer.

Plus-running infielders with some power aren't readily available, which made PERSON' acquisition an 11th round coup at $500,000. His frame and limited lateral agility made him likely to move off of shortstop, and PERSON is already seeing most of his playing time at third base. In possession of notable physical tools at age 20, but with relatively raw feel to hit, we have PERSON valued the way we would a good junior college prospect, and think he's an interesting developmental flier.

A standout at GPE, where he was the ORGANIZATION of the Year, PERSON was nabbed in the fourth round of the 2013 Draft by the ORGANIZATION and showed athleticism and some ability to swing the bat during his first full year of pro ball.The Mobile native has played both first base and the outfield, seeing most of his time in right field in 2014. He has the athleticism for the position and perhaps the power profile from the left side of the plate. His solid first full season should be taken with a grain of salt as it came at a home park in GPE that is one of the most extreme hitters' parks in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON, however, do like his swing and think he has the chance to hit. Big and strong, PERSON also has the chance to develop more pop in the future. He has easy actions in the outfield and enough speed to be a bit of a base stealing threat.How PERSON's bat develops will ultimately determine what kind of role he has in the future. If the power does come, he has the chance to fit the profile of a prototypical right fielder down the road.

PERSON dominated at the 18-and-under World Championships in the fall of 2012, but his stuff and delivery regressed when he pitched for GPE at the World Baseball Classic the following spring. That didn't deter the Cubs from signing him for $1.625 million as part of their 2013 international signing spree. He looked more like his old self during his 2014 pro debut, when he demonstrated the best pitchability in GPE's farm system.PERSON pitched in the low 90s early last season before settling in at 88-92 mph and a consistent peak of 94. Though he can locate his fastball on both sides of the plate, it may be just his third-best pitch. He has advanced feel for his changeup and can spin a tight curveball, both of which are plus offerings at their best.Though his frame is fairly mature, PERSON needs to build up his strength so he can maintain his stuff throughout a full season. But even when he tired in the second half last year, his command and his competitiveness allow him to continue to succeed. He had a 1.64 ERA in the final two months and won both of his playoff starts.

ORGANIZATION started his ORGANIZATION career as a catcher/reliever, but he gave up being a backstop after his freshman year. He closed games as a sophomore and then began this year in the bullpen as well, but a transition into GPE's rotation has positively impacted his GPE stock.ORGANIZATION took over the team's Friday night rotation spot and showed he might have what it takes to stay in a rotation. He'll throw his fastball in the 91-94 mph range and holds his velo deep into his starts. Both of his secondary offerings are average and flash above-average, with perhaps more improvement to come if he gets the chance to develop as a starter. While he does not have the typical starting-pitcher build at 6-foot-1 and 210 pounds, he's strong and maintains his stuff. His control has taken a big step forward this spring as well.It's possible ORGANIZATION might be best-suited for the bullpen, where his fastball-curve combination could play up, though a team taking him in the top six rounds might want to send him out as a starter. Either way, he could be the best catcher-turned-pitcher to come out of GPE since PERSON, who moved from behind the plate to the mound at the pro level.

Drafted by the ORGANIZATION in 2010, PERSON was traded to the ORGANIZATION as a part of the two teams' 10-player deal in July 2012. His progress was slowed in 2014 by a strained lat that sidelined him for much of the first half, but he has been healthy this year and made his big league debut in April. PERSON throws his fastball in the low 90s, using both sides of the plate effectively. He mixes in a slider and changeup, but lacks a true out pitch. He works around the zone with his whole arsenal and does a lot of little things well, helping him to succeed without premium stuff. PERSON has been a starter throughout his career, but might end up fitting better in the bullpen in the long run. He appeared to be on the cusp of reaching the big leagues before his injury in 2014 and could soon be ready for his shot.

After he looked like a newly-drafted force of nature during the summer of 2017, PERSON' physical tools actually regressed last year. The bat speed and quality of contact both dipped, and PERSON was noticeably out-shined by the other (mostly older) PERSON participants during batting practice. PERSON developed some feel for opposite field contact during this span, something he retained as the power returned this spring. He's hitting lasers to all fields now, adept at peppering the right center field gap. 
Built like, and as fast as, a bowling ball SEC running back, PERSON is going to stay in center field for a while but most scouts think he'll eventually move to a corner. That could be a problem if such a move occurs sooner than anticipated, as PERSON has had whiff/discipline issues in the past, though they've been much more palatable this year. He has Mitch Haniger/Randall Grichuk-ish tools. Staying in center will be important, as will retaining some of this new plate discipline. If both happen, PERSON is going to be a highly entertaining star.

PERSON's prospect stock peaked when he was a dominant college sophomore at GPE. PERSON and a downtick in stuff plagued him as a junior and he fell to the fifth round of his draft. PERSON has traversed the whole of the minors as a starter but ultimately might fit best in relief due to some of his stuff's limitations. He has a funky, low-slot delivery that creates cuttery, horizontal movement on his slider. It's his best way to miss bats. His changeup and fastball (which was only in the upper-80s for much of his time in the ORGANIZATION) are both fringy on their own but play up a bit due to the deceptive funk in his delivery. PERSON fits in a No. 5 starter/swingman relief role, and could be ready in 2019.

PERSON went undrafted out of a GPE high school in 2013 and then played sparingly as a freshman for ORGANIZATION before nearly winning the LOCATION Triple Crown and then starring in the ORGANIZATION in 2015. He repeated as ORGANIZATION player of the year in 2016 and ultimately took home the prestigious ORGANIZATION after contending for the ORGANIZATION Division I lead in batting (.395), on-base percentage (.535), home runs (20) and runs (70). The ORGANIZATION were elated to find PERSON still on the board with the 11th overall pick, and they signed him for slot value at $3,286,700 two days later. PERSON got off to a strong start in the LOCATION only to have his pro debut come to an abrupt end when he tore his ORGANIZATION, medial and lateral meniscus in his right knee during a home-plate collision on July 19, resulting in season-ending surgery for the ORGANIZATION' top pick. With his leverage and bat speed, PERSON has easy pop to all fields. His swing is busier than most scouts would like, but his approach is generally sound and he ranked second among D-I hitters with a program-record 66 walks during the spring.PERSON is a fringy runner out of the batter's box, but he has solid speed once he gets going. Some evaluators think he has a chance to stay in center field, but most believe he's destined for right field, where he could develop into a serious home run threat with average or better tools across the board.

Signed out of GPE back in December 2012, PERSON had been slow to adjust to pro ball, though he was showing signs of life as a 19-year-old in the short-season LOCATION in 2015.PERSON has shown a pretty good approach at the plate from the left side, and it has started to translate into performance. He's not afraid to work counts or to take walks, and he's added some strength, which has given him more extra-base power and could result in solid home run pop as me matures further. PERSON has good speed and is an instinctive outfielder. He has the skills to play center, but sharing the outfield with draftee PERSON has pushed him to a corner, where his arm plays just fine.PERSON doesn't turn 20 until December, so there's plenty of time to be patient. The tools are all there for him to be solid big league outfielder in due time.

PERSON's powerful right arm has enticed scouts since his amateur days in the ORGANIZATION. But he has struggled to harness his stuff and will have to sort out his control issues as he advances in the ORGANIZATION. He was making some strides in the ORGANIZATION State League when he was one of two arms sent to the Phillies in the ORGANIZATION Revere trade.PERSON throws his fastball in the low to mid 90s and is capable of touching 98 mph. His slider and changeup both show promise, though both pitches remain inconsistent. PERSON never has thrown many strikes as a professional. His wildness and smaller frame may make him better suited to be a reliever in the long run, and ORGANIZATION moved him to that role in high Class A in 2015.

Announced as a second baseman when the ORGANIZATION drafted him, and deployed primarily in left field as a pro, PERSON's stiffness and immobility will likely limit him to first base, where he played in college. He has sufficient power to profile there but there have been questions about the contact since high school. He clubbed 22 homers in 2018, mostly at Hi-A, and will force some re-evaluation if he has a big year at Double-A. For now, he projects as a bench bat with limited defensive flexibility.

PERSON PERSON got most of the buzz as the toolsiest high school outfielder in the 2012 Draft class, but PERSON wasn't far behind. The GPE prepster, who starred for ORGANIZATION on numerous occasions, has excellent bat speed and can drive the ball to all fields. While he's not the biggest guy on the field, he has surprising pop and should grow into decent power down the road. PERSON is an excellent defensive center fielder with good range and a strong arm. Beyond his physical skills, PERSON's top tools are his instincts and his makeup, both of which are off the charts and allow his already-impressive abilities to play up even more.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

The ORGANIZATION landed PERSON at the outset of the 2014-15 international period, signing him one day after they had inked current top prospect PERSON. The right-hander pitched well in his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION to earn a promotion to the Rookie-level Gulf Coast League in late July, and he continued to make progress in the GPE League last season before wearing down physically late in the year.Though he's an undersized right-hander, PERSON's athleticism and fast arm generate a fastball that can reach 95-96 mph, though he typically operates in the low 90s. His heater has better movement -- sinking action, in particular -- in that range, though at times it does linger up in the zone. PERSON's secondaries lag well behind his fastball, but he does have some feel for a breaking ball, and will flash an average changeup.PERSON's walk rate jumped last season because he struggled to locate his heater, and it also made him vulnerable to the home run ball. His athletic frame and clean, repeatable delivery portends improvement in that regard, and club officials believe he's poised to take a step forward in 2017.

The best college left-hander since PERSON, PERSON entered 2014 as the favorite to go No. 1 overall in the First-Year Player Draft after leading PERSON State to its first PERSON Series berth in 45 years and topping ORGANIZATION Division I in strikeouts the year before. PERSON didn't dominate as much as expected, and he lasted until the third pick, where the FACILITY gave him a $6,582,000 bonus -- the largest in franchise history and the largest ever for a lefty.PERSON's best pitch is a true wipeout slider that usually arrives in the mid-80s and probably could abuse big league hitters right now. He relied on it too heavily during his junior season, which cost him some fastball velocity. PERSON operated in the low 90s for much of the spring, but he has shown the ability to reach 97 mph.PERSON's changeup regressed some, as well, but it can overmatch hitters when it's at its best. Once he stops using his slider too much, his fastball, changeup and command are all expected to improve. Add in a strong frame built for durability, and PERSON could be a future No. 1 starter.

Arguably the best right-handed hitter on the market, GPE has tons of raw power, a short stroke and good balance at the plate.He's known for spraying line drives all over the field, but he also has home run power, especially to his pull side. GPE has impressed scouts with his ability to square the ball up and make hard contact every time he gets into the batter's box. However, some wonder if the teen has a true position on defense. For now, GPE is at third base, but that could change in the future.A regular in the ORGANIZATION, GPE was a standout at the ORGANIZATION in January, notching four hits in seven at-bats. One of the youngest players on the market, GPE won't be able to sign until he turns 16 on Aug. 9. Scouts like his makeup, aggressive nature and approach to the game.

GPE has done nothing but relieve in his three years at ORGANIZATION, and each year he's gotten better while taking on more responsibility. He took a nice step forward as a sophomore setup man, then was absolutely dominant during an All-Star Cape Cod League performance, where he didn't give up a run over 12 appearances. He used that as a springboard to become one of the best college closers in the nation and make a run at the school's single-season saves record.GPE is the prototypical power short reliever and his stuff will play at the next level. He'll throw both a two-seam and four-seam fastball, the former thrown 92-94 mph with good sink and the latter sitting 95-98 mph consistently. He does have a tendency to rush to the plate, which forces him to get on the side of his slider. Once he learns to stay back consistently and stay on top of the hard breaking ball, it should be a plus out pitch for him.The right-hander has struggled with finding the strike zone in the past, but has lowered his walk rate each year and has been going right after hitters in his junior season. He could be the first pure reliever taken in the ORGANIZATION and has the chance to pitch late in games in a big league bullpen in the future.

The ORGANIZATION went over slot to sign PERSON away from the ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION in 2010, and they liked his stuff and pitchability enough to send the ORGANIZATION high school product to full-season ball in his first full professional season. He rebounded from a disappointing 2012 to reach Double-A in 2013 and lead all ORGANIZATION PERSON with 160 strikeouts. He was then dealt to GPE in December as part of the ORGANIZATION' package for PERSON. While PERSON doesn't have the highest ceiling, he projects as a pitchability lefty who can make a living in the back of a big league rotation. He still needs to tighten his command but projects to have average control in the future. His average fastball has good sink to it, and he'll show an average sinking changeup and slider that has occasional bite.

PERSON was a tough sign out of an ORGANIZATION high school in 2014 due to a ORGANIZATION commitment and the ORGANIZATION made a significant offer that came up just short, but they got their man with the 5th overall pick in 2017 after a dominating three year career in GPE. PERSON had a rocky start in 2017, finding his arm slot weeks before the draft when he would take grounders at shortstop and found his natural slot was lower than where he'd been pitching. He pitched 95-99 mph for the first half of a start against Arkansas a few weeks later and hasn't looked back since; he likely won't spend long in the minor leagues and should join the ORGANIZATION young pitching in the big leagues at some point in 2018.

Known as a defense-first catcher out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE, GPE was having a surprise season offensively during his 2014 pro debut when a broken hamate bone ended his season in the ORGANIZATION at the end of July. He struggled during his first full season, hitting just .183 in the ORGANIZATION State League, but rebounded at the start of 2016 back with GPE, earning a June promotion to Double-A.It's surprising enough to see GPE as a good defender, given his 6-foot-6 frame. He has a solid throwing arm and receives well, with agility in his lanky frame. His ability to swing the bat may shock even more people, especially after a college career that saw him hit just .278. But GPE is capable of having a short swing, especially for his size, and he made some adjustments heading into 2016. There is some raw power for him to tap into.GPE needs to swing the bat well over the course of a full season to suggest that he can do it long-term. If he can do that, he has the chance to be a big league regular, with a backup role perhaps more realistic.

When the A's acquired PERSON in December 2011 as a part of the trade that sent PERSON and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION, he had just celebrated his 19th birthday and was coming off an impressive stateside debut. He emerged as one of GPE's better pitching prospects in 2013 and moved up to Double-A the following year, only to have his season all but wiped out by PERSON surgery in May. He returned to the mound last June at ORGANIZATION A Advanced GPE, but was held to a strict 60-pitch/four-inning limit as he continued to work his way back from surgery.PERSON's velocity was down during his initial starts at GPE, but, by the end of the season, the right-hander was back sitting in the 92-95 mph range and bumping 96 with his fastball. His changeup has above-average potential and complements his fastball well, and he'll also mix in a show-me curveball. His slider was inconsistent but showed the makings of becoming a third average-or-better offering up until he blew out his elbow. The A's didn't have him throw it in 2015, though, as they instead emphasized building up arm strength and regaining feel. Throwing strikes has never been a problem for PERSON, who has walked just 1.9 batters per nine innings as a professional.PERSON returned to PERSON in 2016 but was inconsistent across his starts for GPE. He began to show signs of finally turning the corner in late July, which is when the A's promoted him to Triple-A. The right-hander had made significant strides in the year before his injury, and if he's able to fully recapture that ability and develop a more consistent breaking ball, he has a chance to become a solid Major League starter.

GPE (GPE) PERSON hasn't had a player drafted since the ORGANIZATION selected PERSON seventh overall in 2004. That will change this June, as GPE figures to go in the second or third round. His present stuff is solid, and scouts love his projectability, makeup and bloodlines.GPE already throws 88-92 mph, and he's still filling out his lanky 6-foot-5 frame, with his 18th birthday a week before the GPE. His fastball is more notable for its angle than its life. He has a feel for spinning the ball but needs to add more power to his curve. He also could use more deceptive arm speed with his changeup, though it has some promising fade.GPE has a loose arm that works well, and he could have three solid or better pitches once he gets stronger and maintains a consistent arm slot. His father PERSON starred at ORGANIZATION, and his uncle PERSON was an All-America pitcher at ORGANIZATION, where PERSON has committed.

PERSON honored his commitment to GPE rather than sign with the ORGANIZATION out of high school as a 28th-round pick in 2014. Three years later, after a huge step forward during his junior season that included a 20-strikeout performance, PERSON landed in the first round, going to the ORGANIZATION with the ORGANIZATION. 20 overall pick, and signed for full pick value. After having his pro debut shortened by an ingrown toe nail and then beginning his first full season behind schedule due to a minor knee injury, PERSON breezed through the LOCATION, posting a 1.82 ERA in nine starts at ORGANIZATION A Columbia before advancing to the ORGANIZATION A Advanced PERSON League.PERSON's fastball is average in terms of velocity, as he'll sit at 89-91 mph and touch 93, but few starters in the Minors can sink and command it as well as he does. Logging 127 1/3 innings in his first full season, PERSON yielded only two home runs (0.14 HR/9) and posted the third-best ground-ball rate (64.5%) in the Minors among qualified pitchers. He combines his heater with an above-average slider that nets him whiffs as an out pitch, while his changeup, which flashes above-average, gives him a weapon against right-handed hitters. He fills out his four-pitch mix with a fringy curveball that he can throw for a strike.Despite a lower arm slot from his 6-foot-6 frame, PERSON has demonstrated outstanding control of all his pitches, even if he can stand to refine his overall command some. Average bat-missing ability and a knack for inducing weak, ground-ball contact points to more of a floor than a ceiling for PERSON, but it might not take him that long to reach his potential as a ORGANIZATION. 3 or 4 starter.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 21, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON TroutAfter undergoing PERSON surgery on his right elbow in 2015, PERSON commit ORGANIZATION earned ORGANIZATION honors on the ORGANIZATION's All-Area Team in '16. He led PERSON to the Class 2A regional semifinal and garnered PERSON All-State honors at shortstop. ORGANIZATION played in the ORGANIZATION and participated in the 2014 Breakthrough Series. ORGANIZATION has a thin frame and has room to add muscle, but he flashes quick hands and wrists, allowing him to take the proper angle to the ball at the plate. His upside has scouts intrigued.

The FACILITY likely landed 40 percent of their future rotation with their first two picks in the 2014 Draft. No. 3 overall pick PERSON needed just 34 2/3 Minor League innings before he was ready for the Majors, while second-rounder PERSON could prove to be an outright steal after signing for $1,282,700 as the 44th overall pick. He has lived up to his reputation as one of the most athletic, projectable and polished pitchers from the 2014 high school crop.Though PERSON worked with a 92-96 mph fastball and flashed a plus slider as a prep senior, his stuff hasn't been as sharp as he has adjusted to the rigors of a full pro season. He pitched mostly at 88-92 mph and had a less devastating slider, though his feel for those pitches remained intact. He also has the makings of an average curveball and changeup.PERSON has posted a 155-22 K-BB ratio in his first two years as a pro, a testament to the ease with which he repeats his loose, effortless delivery at will. A former three-sport star in high school, he should add more power to his pitches once he adds strength to his slender frame. He has both a high ceiling and a high floor, and his strong makeup should allow him to make the most of his ability.

PERSON was a max-effort 94-97 in college, had scattershot fastball command, and a plus changeup. His velo is down and neither of his two breaking balls has great movement. We think he's a Tyler Clippard-style changeup reliever so long as the velocity returns.

The ORGANIZATION have been fairly aggressive in pushing PERSON, who they signed in August 2010, sending him to the advanced short-season LOCATION for his GPE debut in 2012 and then to the full-season ORGANIZATION in 2013. The ORGANIZATION felt the teenager could handle the assignments largely because of his defense. He flashes an outstanding glove and uses his excellent speed to have good range. He runs well on the basepaths, too, and should be a base-stealing threat. He's never going to hit for much power, but the switch-hitter has shown an ability to make consistent contact.

Since signing with the ORGANIZATION out of the ORGANIZATION in 2009, PERSON made slow and steady progress at the lower levels of GPE's system. After a breakout 2014 with PERSON that was highlighted by a trip to the ORGANIZATION All-Star PERSON, he was traded to the ORGANIZATION in December in the deal that sent PERSON and PERSON to GPE.PERSON stands out because of his combination of upside and ceiling with feel for pitching. He has a three-pitch mix. PERSON's fastball is a power sinker that sits in the 91-94 mph zone. His best secondary offering is his above-average changeup, and he has an advanced feel for the offspeed pitch already. PERSON's slider is a work in progress, thrown at 81-84 mph, but it's still a little too slurvy at the moment. He's generally been a strike-thrower throughout his brief PERSON career. PERSON still remains somewhat raw, but his powerful arm should help him start to move through the ORGANIZATION faster as he builds on his success.

It looked for a while in 2016, two years after he was taken in the second round of the Draft out of the ORGANIZATION high school ranks and signed away from his GPE commitment, that PERSON's career was in trouble. He struggled so much in his full-season debut that the ORGANIZATION removed him from competitive pitching and sent him back to their Minor League complex in GPE to start over. A year after that, in a story of resiliency, PERSON pitched his way from the ORGANIZATION up to the GPE League by season's end. PERSON made a living in 2017 getting hitters to beat his low-90s two-seamer into the ground. His curve can be at least above-average; it's a weapon he needs to commit to using as an out pitch more frequently in the future. That's especially important because he's yet to develop a consistent feel for a third pitch. While the progress has been encouraging, the right-hander will have to improve his control and command as he moves forward, issuing too many walks for a pitcher who doesn't miss a ton of bats. The ORGANIZATION will let PERSON continue to start in 2018 and he's plenty young enough to continue to improve. There may come a time, however, when the organization will want to see what the sinker-curve combination looks like coming out of the bullpen.

The younger brother of big leaguer PERSON, PERSON is an entirely different style of player. PERSON is a speedy utility infielder while PERSON's tools fit the classic profile of a right fielder. To fill that role in the big leagues, he'll have a shake off a 2014 season in which he set career lows with a .230/.302/.309 performance in Double-A.PERSON has the bat speed, strength and hand-eye coordination to hit for average and power. He has yet to turn on many pitches and excels at hitting the ball the other way, so he has stood out more as a hitter than a slugger in the ORGANIZATION. He got in trouble trying to hit home runs last year instead of letting his power develop naturally, which the ORGANIZATION believe will happen once he does a better job of incorporating his lower half in his swing.If he gets back on track offensively, PERSON could have average or better tools across the board. He's an average runner and a solid defender in right field, where he showcases a plus arm.

PERSON battled the strike zone in two years at ORGANIZATION before boosting his stock by leading the ORGANIZATION with 10 saves and reaching 98 mph with his fastball during the summer of 2016. He decided to transfer to ORGANIZATION II power PERSON, where he continued to struggle to harness his power arsenal. That continued after the ORGANIZATION signed him for $417,200 in the fourth round last June.PERSON usually works with a 94-96 mph fastball that features armside run as a reliever and with a little less velocity when he starts. He also can miss bats with a pair of breaking balls, a low-80s curveball with good depth and an upper-80s slider/cutter, though he can't always land them in the strike zone. He also uses a changeup that might give him a decent offspeed pitch if he uses it more often.Though PERSON drafted PERSON with the idea of trying to develop him as a starter, club officials concede that his never-ending search for command means he'll likely be a reliever. He has cleaned up his delivery some since high school but it still contains a lot of effort and he has difficulty keeping it in sync. Coming out of the bullpen, he'd have late-inning upside if he could throw enough strikes.

After pitching just 7 2/3 innings as a freshman in 2015, PERSON emerged as the closer for GPE and the GPE collegiate national team last year. He also struck out 11 in a complete-game five-hitter in his lone college start in the ORGANIZATION regional playoffs and some scouts thought he might be able to handle a move to the rotation full-time. The Gamecocks have plenty of pitching depth, however, so they've kept him in the bullpen.PERSON is well equipped to handle the late innings. He operates with a 92-97 mph fastball that reaches 99, and while it doesn't feature a lot of life, he commands it well. He backs it up with a hard slider that peaks at 85 mph with nice bite when it's on, though it gets slurvy at ORGANIZATION has the makings of a changeup, though he doesn't use it much as a reliever and will have to refine it if a pro team decides to deploy him as a starter. Though he has the athleticism to handle a shift to the rotation, that may be less likely to happen after he missed six weeks this spring with a sore arm. When he returned to the mound in mid-April, his fastball sat at 93-97 mph.

After pushing him very quickly at the onset of his pro career, in 2018 the ORGANIZATION throttled down PERSON' development and had him repeat Hi-A. He regressed statistically (his strikeout rate was down, and his walk rate stayed just below average after regressing in 2017) before he succumbed to a June elbow injury that cost him the remainder of his summer. PERSON started throwing harder in 2018 and remains a projectable, athletic 20-year-old with a great arm action and some changeup feel. That's still a lot of good stuff, even though other aspects of his profile have either plateaued or gone backward. We hope the fastball control comes back and think PERSON can pitch at the back of a rotation if it does.
GPE bat-first prospect. PERSON college prospect  who had strong freshman year, down sophomore campaign.

Teams who like college hitters who perform, especially in competitive conferences, will undoubtedly be giving PERSON a long look at ORGANIZATION' Draft-eligible sophomore has certainly raised his stock with his performance at the plate this spring. The outfielder has a smooth swing from the left side of the plate, showing the ability to consistently barrel up balls and make consistently hard contact. Not known for his power previously, the ORGANIZATION native has added some strength and was among the nation's leaders in home runs this season. PERSON has plus speed, which should allow him to be a basestealing threat and stick in center field.PERSON does have some leverage as a sophomore, but most around Little Rock feel he's going to be drafted early enough to forego his junior season at ORGANIZATION.

PERSON didn't pitch as a sophomore at ORGANIZATION (GPE) JC, then transferred to PERSON and set the ORGANIZATION' single-season (19) and career (27) saves records, surpassing current Pirates shortstop PERSON in the latter category. A $1,000 senior sign by the Athletics in the 22nd round of the 2014 Draft, PERSON recorded a 1.37 ERA in his first two years as a pro and saved 27 games in his first full season while reaching Double-A. He reached Triple-A in his first year in the ORGANIZATION' system after being acquired in a trade for PERSON, but he drew a 50-game suspension in the offseason after testing positive for a stimulant.PERSON may be small (5-foot-10, 170 pounds) and possess below-average fastball velocity, but he is effective because he's extremely deceptive, mixes four pitches and locates them where he wants. His fastball maxes out at 93 mph, but hitters don't punish it because it features good life and he works it to both sides of the plate and down in the strike zone. His best offering is his solid curveball, and he also can get swings and misses with his average slider and changeup.Throwing from a variety of arm slots to keep hitters off-balance, PERSON has dominated left-handers as well as right-handers. He's a good bet to become at least a middle reliever in the big leagues and could ascend to that role in 2016.

PERSON played for the national team in 2011 and '12 as a shortstop, helping PERSON to gold medals each time. But he moved behind the plate this spring at ORGANIZATION and has become one of the ORGANIZATION's most intriguing catching prospects. He isn't especially toolsy, but PERSON plays above his talent level, thanks to his feel for the game. He has a good approach as a hitter and provides gap power but probably won't ever be much of a power hitter. He is still learning behind the plate, but is eager to improve.

Signed as an undrafted free agent out of GPE, PERSON has reached Double-A and performed at each stop, accumulating a 140:26 strikeout-to-walk ratio in 115 pro innings. He's a low slot lefty with below-average velocity, on the surface appearing to be of the ORGANIZATION endangered species. But PERSON can really spin a breaking ball, and has a four-pitch mix that you could argue plays like a six-pitch mix because he likes to vary his arm slot. He could be a non-traditional bullpen mainstay.

After he was unable to accrue playing time at ORGANIZATION, PERSON transferred to GPE and spent 2019 dominating ORGANIZATION hitters. He's a physical beast with some of the best velocity and breaking stuff in the draft, but there are questions about his build, athleticism, and injured hips. Despite lacking a changeup, PERSON has the pitch mix and pitch utility to start. In addition to solid east/west fastball command, he can drop his curveball in the zone for strikes and back foot either of his breaking balls to lefties. Several teams in the eight through 14 range had PERSON in their mix as the draft approached.

PERSON signed for $275,000 in the 2016 signing period and has steadily progressed to be among the best homegrown Latin prospects GPE has, arguably with PERSON and GPE for some observers. There's a shot for average all-around offense, and most see PERSON as a hit-over-power prospect, evident through the high-contact numbers he showed 2018 in the ORGANIZATION, while some see potential above-average power and that PERSON will prioritize over contact down the road. He's also a good enough athlete to stick at third base at the moment, though that may change depending on how his body matures. PERSON was already pretty filled out at 16 and may outgrow third. The offense will dictate his future and there are some exciting elements already present, especially for a lower-bonus prospect who signed just two years ago.

Not long ago, PERSON was an undersized GPE shortstop who would pitch once in a while. The ORGANIZATION liked his athleticism enough to sign him and move him to the mound full-time. He's added a full ten ticks to his fastball over the last two and a half years, and now is not only one of the best on-mound athletes in the minors, but a hard worker and team leader with infectious charisma. PERSON's velocity came as he got in the weight room and added about 25 pounds. He was so dominant during his first few pro starts in the ORGANIZATION that the ORGANIZATION quickly pushed him stateside for the remainder of 2017, then to the ORGANIZATION at age 18 the following year. 
Not only does PERSON have premium arm strength, but he has natural feel for spin, and is a curious learner who quickly actualizes instruction on the mound. He has already begun to vary the cadence of his delivery to mess with hitters' timing, and has mapped aspects of ORGANIZATION's delivery to his own, just to see if it works for him. He's still a little too confident with his breaking ball in the zone, but it's hard not to expect an athlete with work habits like these (PERSON has already learned and is fluent in GPE) to get better at everything. You can go nuts projecting on his secondaries and command the same way scouts did with PERSON when he was in high school, and PERSON's breaking stuff is further along than GPE's was at the same age. He likely won't grow into more velo because the frame for that isn't here, but he's already got plenty of heat. Conservatively, PERSON has mid-rotation upside, but how the changeup and breaking ball command develop matter because that's where there's room for significant growth.

The ORGANIZATION isn't known as a huge baseball conference, but it's had its fair share of GPE prospects, most of them pitchers. PERSON has the chance to be just as good as guys like PERSON, PERSON or PERSON' best attribute might be his arm strength, with the ability to get his fastball up into the mid 90s, though it plays better when he sits in the 92-93 mph range. He has plus action on his curve, though he has trouble commanding it at times. PERSON also throws a cutter-type pitch and a changeup, both of which are below average currently.PERSON' ability to improve his offspeed stuff and his overall command will dictate whether he can start long-term. The team that takes him will likely send him out as a starter, knowing he has the power arsenal that would work well in short relief.

PERSON was identified as a potential high first round pick as a high school underclassman, showing mid-90's velocity and a long, lanky, athletic frame in tournaments. He held serve as an elite arm over the next few years, going 4th overall in 2016 and continuing to show some of the best stuff on the planet: two 70's and two 60's on some days. The issues are with just about everything else I haven't mentioned, as PERSON doesn't have much deception, he has too much effort/head whack in his delivery, his fastball doesn't have much life and he may generally just throw too hard to learn the finesse aspects of being a starting pitcher. His walk rates and contact allowed are worrisome, but the stuff and athleticism are still top of the scale, so the upside remains sky high, but scouts are getting less enthusiastic.

Based on raw stuff, PERSON shouldn't have even been available to PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 29 in the 2013 Draft. PERSON put himself on the map for 2019 as a sophomore the previous year by finishing second on the team in homers, slugging percentage and ORGANIZATION. The ORGANIZATION used their top two picks (both second rounders) in the 2015 ORGANIZATION on two of the best defensive outfielders available, PERSON's PERSON and ORGANIZATION high school product PERSON. The scouting industry has come a long way in terms of not looking past undersized players. His changeup remains in its rudimentary stages, and he still has little history of finding the strike zone or staying healthy. PERSON love his makeup and see closer potential if he winds up in the bullpen.

GPE established himself as an intriguing junior college lefty prospect in 2016 when he put an exclamation point on his collegiate career by striking out 15 in a complete-game victory to give GPE a ORGANIZATION championship shortly before the GPE. PERSON is widely believed to have a deal with the ORGANIZATION for $4.0 million, which I believe would be the highest July 2nd bonus of all-time for a shortstop.

Even without better command, PERSON could soon carve out a role in the GPE bullpen thanks to his powerful sinker-slider combination.

Your standard high school projection arm with a breaking ball, PERSON is back at Low-A to start 2019. PERSON PERSON in GPE has had three players taken in the ORGANIZATION over the years, but none earlier than the 21st round, and none have ever reached the big leagues. That should help him on the basepaths and gives him solid range while playing shortstop. It's possible he'll outgrow the position, where he has an average, sometimes a tick above, arm, once he physically matures, but he should be able to handle a move to third without a problem and his speed could work from the outfield. At the plate, he has good bat speed, strength and loft to his swing, though he's mostly been a line-drive hitter this year. He's struggled with good breaking stuff at times, but he has shown an ability to make adjustments in the past.PERSON picked up steam with a big performance in front of a lot of eyes, with decision-makers pouring in to see him. He had a definite up arrow next to his name and could see his name go off the board in the top four rounds.Prospect Development PERSON - PERSON

PERSON plays the game like a heady college infielder type, but was actually a 16th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION back in 2012 out of the GPE high school ranks. This is a very physical teenager with some of the best present raw power in his signing class and a good chance to play a premium defensive position at catcher. PERSON was the top college senior in the GPE class and, coming out of a program like PERSON, the hope would be that he could move through a system quickly. PERSON's speed should allow him to stay in center field, and he has a solid arm to boot. It's unclear just what kind of role he'll have as a big leaguer, but few doubt he'll get there fairly quickly.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

GPE potential from a strong, mature frame is what makes PERSON a Draft prospect. He can get a little pull-happy at times, hurting his overall ability to make consistent hard contact. He fits in a corner outfield spot, with fringy speed, though he's a solid defender. His arm might best be suited for left field when all is said and done.GPE-hitting corner outfielders will always draw interest, but it might take a team selecting PERSON fairly early on to lure him from playing for the Gators in 2016.

Pitching under the glare of immense expectations, PERSON lived up to them when he returned to Stanford for his senior year rather than sign with the Pirates in 2012, allowing him to be the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick of the Astros a year later. GPE has lots of natural loft in his swing and his frame has significant projection so there's a chacne he grows into huge raw power. He's likely to move to a corner outfield spot and here are questions about how much he's going to hit because of how overmatched he looked at times last summer against elite pitching, but he's hitting more this spring.

PERSON was one of the best two-way college players during his career at ORGANIZATION, where he served as the ORGANIZATION ace and first baseman. PERSON may get more action at short after PERSON sent PERSON to PERSON in the PERSON trade, and his future destination may be third base -- just like his uncle. PERSON was PERSON GPEâs leadoff hitter during the 2017 WBC (he hit two homers and a double in six at-bats) and spent 2015-'17 crushing the ORGANIZATION. PERSON acquired him for fringe 40-man relief depth in the offseason. Smaller-framed middile infielder with plus defensive hands and actions. Could be contact/glove oriented regular if hit tool would can carry him there.

Long considered the best player in the world not affiliated with a Major League organization, PERSON sparked interest from virtually every club when he announced his intention to come to the GPE for the 2018 season. Signing with an ORGANIZATION team affords him the ability to DH, which will allow him to get more at-bats and conserve energy for pitching.

PERSON was a raw, toolsy catcher when he was a high schooler in GPE. GPE is large for shortstop but is a plus runner with an above average arm and should stay there for a while. If anything is going to kick him over to third, it's a lack of flexibility and agility. PERSON entered the 2012 season as a candidate to go No. 1 overall in the draft, but a slump dropped him to the ORGANIZATION at the 24th pick. The ORGANIZATION found three of their best prospects during the 2012-13 international signing period. In addition to right-hander PERSON and outfielder PERSON, they also landed PERSON. GPE seniors have done well with the new Draft rules as teams try to find ways to strategically use their bonus pools. GPE seniors typically are value picks, but PERSON has the chance to go in the early rounds based on his size and stuff alone.

PERSON starred at GPE, setting single-season and career records for wins (13 and 30) and strikeouts (138 and 307), but an early-season slump in 2016 dropped him out of first-round consideration. His fastball isn't overpowering at 90-94 mph with some run and sink, but he'll bust it inside against right-handers and then sweep sliders and cutters away from them. He can back-foot his slider against left-handers and also hold them in check with his fading changeup.PERSON's low-three-quarters arm slot adds deception and life to his pitches without hampering his ability to throw them for strikes. GPE body and swing, could be high-contact ORGANIZATION with speed

The younger brother of one-time Mariners first-round pick D.J. PERSON, PERSON went in the second round of the 2013 Draft out of his ORGANIZATION high school to the ORGANIZATION. A native of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON made an impressive full-season debut in 2013 at ORGANIZATION A Hagerstown. He continued that success the next season with PERSON and in the ORGANIZATION. As he moves up to the upper levels of the ORGANIZATION, his advanced defensive ability will allow the Nationals to be patient and allow his offense further develop.

PERSON had more offensive upside than most of the high school catchers in the 2017 Draft, but the ORGANIZATION product resisted seven-figure overtures from big league clubs in order to stay home and attend ORGANIZATION. He looks quicker and more agile than he did in high school, though his receiving skills are fringy and need more work. The grandson of former big league catcher PERSON, PERSON caught the eye of scouts by pitching well in the ORGANIZATION during the summer of 2015 and as a junior at FACILITY's (Calif.) the following spring. PERSON put up video-game type numbers at ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION this spring, raising his Draft profile in the process, then created a huge amount of buzz by hitting triple digits consistently in a bullpen session in late May. PERSON parlayed a strong career as a starter at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, including a championship in his sophomore year, into becoming a second round pick in the 2016 Draft. PERSON was more polished than most high school hitters, and GPE happily took him with the sixth overall pick in 2012. PERSON was so advanced as a prep star in GPE that scouts viewed him more like a college pitcher than one in high school. PERSON's curveball and changeup have both improved, and they have plus potential. PERSON is an exceptional athlete and his work ethic and makeup are very well regarded. PERSON is extremely polished for his age, in large part because he grew up around the game as the son of Dodgers scout PERSON. Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in 2013, PERSON put himself on the radar two years later in the Class A Short PERSON York-Penn League, where he was named an All-Star after posting the circuit's fifth-highest average (.305) and tying for the league lead in doubles (21). He's gone on to earn All-Star honors in back-to-back years with PERSON and Class A Advanced Potomac, respectively, though the remainder of his '17 campaign is now in jeopardy after he suffered an ankle injury he suffered in June.PERSON's feel to hit has improved in each of his four pro seasons. He moves well for his size at the hot corner, showing athletic actions and plenty of range, while his plus arm is a clean fit at the position. After committing 25 errors in 2016, which club officials attributed to a lack of a focus, PERSON has been incredibly consistent this season, leading evaluators to peg him as an above-average defender.

After PERSON tore the anterior cruciate ligament and meniscus in his left knee last May, he missed the entire showcase circuit last summer and fall. The LOCATION recruit has gone from forgotten prospect to potential top-10-overall pick.PERSON generates well-above-average bat speed from the right side of the plate. He should be a solid defender as well, though his instincts draw mixed reviews and he may wind up in right field rather than center.The one thing PERSON doesn't have is a history of solving quality pitching while swinging a wood bat. Some scouts worry that there's a lot going on his swing and believe he'll have to streamline it. If he hits and taps into his power, he has 25-25 potential and should become a star.

Though he missed much of the 2015 season following ankle surgery, the ORGANIZATION were sure to have ORGANIZATION included in the big Cole Hamels trade at the ORGANIZATION in GPE, hoping he could fulfill the potential seen in him since he was handed a $1.3 million bonus, a record for a player from GPE has two plus tools as his calling cards: his power bat and his power arm. ORGANIZATION has as strong an arm as just about any catching prospect in the game, but the rest of his defensive tools remain a work in progress. Injuries have certainly stunted his development. ORGANIZATION has played some first base in games and done some work in the outfield, and he is athletic enough to handle such a move if it's necessary.The PERSON got their first real look at ORGANIZATION in 2016, and they had to like what they saw. There's time for him to still develop into a big league regular behind the plate. A full, healthy season would help him receive the needed reps to get there.

A two-way talent at GPE, PERSON impressed scouts with his left-handed power potential but most teams liked him better on the mound. His sharp curveball is his best offering and can be a plus pitch at its best. His lively fastball sat in the upper 80s last year but had previously resided in the low 90s. His sinking changeup wasn't quite as deceptive as it had been, while his cutter mainly served to give batters a different look.PERSON has the best feel for pitching among ORGANIZATION farmhands, so he doesn't have to overpower hitters to succeed. He can add and subtract from his pitches and locate them where he wants, usually down in the strike zone. Whether or not his stuff ticks back up with determine if he's an option for the middle or back of a rotation.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON after his 2017 freshman season, but he went back to school, raised his stock, and was the first ORGANIZATION arm off the board the following year. He has power stuff -- 93-96 with cut action at times, and a plus curveball -- but is wild and may be a reliever, though probably a very good one.

PERSON led the ORGANIZATION in strikeouts in 2013. He also led that circuit in walks, a quick way to sum up what this young left-hander is about right now.PERSON has big-time stuff from the left side, with a fastball that will touch the mid-90s. He has a well-above-average changeup to go along with that heater. PERSON's curveball is behind the other two pitches, but it has the chance to be a usable weapon. He needs to learn to trust his considerable stuff in the strike zone more, and when he commands that breaking ball, he's awfully tough to hit.PERSON finished the 2013 season with a very strong August, something the ORGANIZATION hope carries over as he continues to get work as a starter in '14. If his command doesn't improve, a career as a lefty power reliever could be in his future.

A left-handed-hitting infielder from eastern GPE, PERSON had a very good summer on the showcase circuit, playing well at both the LOCATION Pro Showcase in GPE and the ORGANIZATION held at ORGANIZATION in GPE. He saw time at first, third, left field and even shortstop during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION, before getting a bump up to the GPE.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON for $800,000 out of GPE, they knew he'd be a project. The ceiling is there, now he needs to show it can translate to performance.
PERSON didn't sign as the 10th overall pick of ORGANIZATION two years ago after failing a physical, which teams are still curious about despite the mid-rotation stuff he's shown the last two years.

PERSON entered 2018 as a potential top ten pick after he perfomed in front of decision makers who were in to see PERSON last year. As a junior, PERSON's approach became very pull-heavy and opinions on his defense have shaded toward third base. He may need to rework how his hands set up, because they're currently very stiff. He has big raw power for a prospect who is likely to play on the infield and some of what plagued him as a junior seems correctable, so his market probably starts toward the back of round one amoung teams smitten with his Trackman readout.

Yet another talented ORGANIZATION prospect with deep baseball bloodlines, PERSON is the son of four-time All-Star PERSON and the brother of ORGANIZATION farmhand PERSON, whom the ORGANIZATION took 51st overall back in 2011. PERSON proved an advanced hitter during his amateur career, and his raw power was on display when he won the Under PERSON All-American Game home run derby in GPE. He combines plus bat speed with a violent-but-controlled swing to produce tons of hard contact from line to line, and scouts like his chances of becoming a plus-or-better hitter with above-average power. He's an average runner with good range and instincts at shortstop, and the ORGANIZATION plan to keep him at the position for as long as they can. Some believe he's best suited for second or third base, or perhaps even left field, but so far he's passed every test at his natural position.Much like his teammate and friend PERSON, there seems to be no limit to PERSON's offensive ceiling. His career-to-date points to a bright future as a perennial All-Star who could regularly compete for batting titles.

The D-backs' 11th-round pick in 2014 out of GPE, PERSON struggled as a starter through his first full season of pro ball. A move to the bullpen for 2016 proved to be beyond wise, as the 6-foot-7 left-hander went from the Class A ORGANIZATION to Triple-A in one season. PERSON is a fringy runner who's an average defender in right field and has a plus arm, but he may bulk up and move to first base down the line, which would likely come with more power as well.

Signed by the ORGANIZATION for $55,000 in 2011, PERSON wasn't viewed as much of a prospect early in his career, as he spent four seasons between the ORGANIZATION and PERSON levels before reaching full-season ball in 2015. While he's yet to show the requisite over-the-fence power to profile as an everyday first baseman in the big leagues, PERSON' feel to hit and on-base skills could make him a bench option for the ORGANIZATION in the coming years.

PERSON proved to be a workhorse during his senior season at ORGANIZATION State as he logged 91 1/3 innings across a school-record 36 relief appearances. PERSON began his college career at FACILITY A&M before transferring to GPE, where he paced the LOCATION Conference in average (.382), home runs (12) and stolen bases (29) en route to ORGANIZATION player of the year honors in his second year with the Aggies. Considering that PERSON was almost exclusively a reliever during his career at ORGANIZATION, the fact the 2015 first-round pick made it to Double-A as a starter in his first full year is impressive. Most importantly, PERSON needs to get healthy before determining his future. As a starter, he could have the chance to be at least a mid-rotation starter. In relief, he could have both a 70-grade fastball and slider with the ceiling of a future closer, but that's only if he can stay off the ORGANIZATION.

The ORGANIZATION pushed PERSON to full-season ball aggressively to start the 2012 season, but the ORGANIZATION outfielder wasn't ready. To his credit, when he was demoted to the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League, he produced, finishing seventh in the short-season circuit in batting average. He was holding his own back in the ORGANIZATION when the ORGANIZATION sent him to the ORGANIZATION in return for reliever PERSON. He's played both outfield corners thus far, but seems to be settling into left field. It's his bat that will move him up the ladder and he's still exceptionally young, playing the entire 2013 season at age 19.Bernie Pleskoff's scouting report Â»

A year ago, a high school third baseman in LOCATION gained some helium and ended up going in the second round to the ORGANIZATION. He has strength and bat speed that should lead to plenty of power in the future. Running is not a part of his game, but he has the tools and actions to stick at the hot corner, highlighted by a very strong throwing arm. PERSON plays the game hard, with an aggressive approach. The team taking him, perhaps as early as the third round, could be getting a bargain in the process.

Acquired by PERSON from the ORGANIZATION at the ORGANIZATION in July 2015, GPE excelled at the Double-A and Triple-A levels in '16 to earn a big league callup in August at age 22. However, shoulder fatigue combined with a team-imposed inning cap limited the right-hander to just five starts with the ORGANIZATION, who then sent him and PERSON to the ORGANIZATION for '14 first-rounder PERSON in late November. He returned to the big leagues in 2017 with GPE, but also missed considerable time with leg and knee injuries early in the season before taking the rest of the year off in July to address mental health issues.GPE pitches with an average fastball, sitting at 90-93 mph, but it plays up thanks to heavy sinking action that yields a high number of ground balls. His curveball is his lone above-average pitch, and he also mixes in a slider and a usable changeup. The right-hander is around the strike zone with all of his pitches and knows how to keep hitters off balance and guessing by effectively changing speeds.With an advanced feel for four pitches as well as a bulldog mentality on the mound, GPE shows the makings of becoming a backend starter at maturity. Perhaps more importantly, GPE, after receiving treatment for depression and anxiety that affected him for much of 2017, has returned to the game as an advocate for mental health and hopes to change its stigma within the sport.

One of the best two-way talents in the 2014 Draft, PERSON preferred to play every day despite most teams believing he had a brighter future on the mound. The ORGANIZATION granted his wish after signing him in the second round for $914,600, and he has done nothing to make them regret that decision. He finished second in the Rookie-level PERSON batting race (.347) in his pro debut and won organization PERSON player of the year honors in 2015, hitting .385/.406/.659 after an August promotion to high Class A.PERSON is advanced at the plate for his age, showing precocious feel for understanding the strike zone and recognizing pitches. PERSON differ on his power ceiling, with some seeing the aptitude and strength for 20 homers per year and others wonder if he'll have enough pop to profile well if he shifts to an outfield corner.PERSON spent the majority of his first two pro seasons in center field, making up for average speed with keen instincts. He definitely has the arm strength necessary for right field if he has to move, having hit 94 mph as a high school left-hander and registering 24 assists in 122 games last year. Makeup concerns dogged him in the Draft but club officials credited him with maturing and acting like a professional during his first full season.

PERSON doesn't have overpowering stuff, succeeding instead thanks to his command and feel for pitching. He issued 78 walks in his first three professional seasons, averaging 1.7 walks per nine innings. That polish will give him a chance to stick with the Orioles after they selected him from the ORGANIZATION in the 2014 Rule 5 Draft. PERSON's above-average command helps his whole four-pitch arsenal play up. He throws his fastball in the low 90s, and he isn't afraid to come right after hitters with it. His slider is his best secondary offering, and he mixes in a curveball and a changeup as well. PERSON has been susceptible to home runs, partially because he has a tendency to leave his fastball up in the zone. PERSON's upside is limited by his lack of premium stuff. But his overall package give him a chance to fit into the back of a Major League rotation.

PERSON was one of the ORGANIZATION' breakout prospects in 2012, and he continued that progress in '13, finishing his second year of full-season ball with Double-A GPE. PERSON built on that momentum during a full season in GPE in 2014.PERSON has fast hands, helping him square up balls consistently from both sides of the plate. He has more power than his frame would suggest, and he can drive balls to all fields. He has good range and his infield actions are improved, but his arm strength is fringy. Scouts are divided on whether PERSON can remain at shortstop or if he is better suited for second base. No matter where he ends up defensively, PERSON's bat will play.

Including PERSON, PERSON has now had eight pitchers taken in the first round of the past 10 GPEs. He went from 87-90 mph in high school to 91-94 mph, with a high of 97. His best secondary pitch is a hard curveball that he employs against left-handers, and he mixes in a harder slider/cutter against righties. PERSON is also developing a solid changeup.PERSON's stuff could continue to get better, because unlike most top college pitching prospects, he still has a good deal of projection remaining. With his athleticism and arm action, he should have solid control and at least average command when he's fully developed, though he battled the strike zone at times as a junior. PERSON will be a frontline starter if he can master the location of his pitches.

For the last three years, a pitcher from the ORGANIZATION of GPE has been selected in the first round. PERSON A.J. PERSON went No. 6 overall in 2016, with PERSON Dunning going at the end of the round.
