His fastball will touch 96-97 mph, and he consistently reaches the mid-90s. But a lack of life has meant it's gotten hit hard when he throws it for a strike. He has struggled to throw his slider, which had flashed plus in the past, for a strike, and he hasn't been able to develop a reliable third pitch, so college hitters have been sitting on the fastball. He has a tendency to not drive through the ball and can be too rotational, giving hitters too good of a look at the ball coming out of his hand.Because of his struggles, scouts have a hard time projecting PERSON as a starter at this point. If he can refine his fastball-slider combination, some see a ceiling as a setup type who can pitch the seventh or eighth inning, though a team taking him early in the ORGANIZATION could send him out as a starter with the hopes of fixing what's ailed him this spring.

PERSON injured his elbow as a high school senior in 2011 and missed his first season at LOCATION while recovering from PERSON surgery. He was the best bullpen prospect in that year's ORGANIZATION League -- which he led with four saves as right-handers went 0-for-19 against him -- and then continued to impress in his first Triple-A campaign before going to the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION trade in July.After working in the low 90s as a college starter, PERSON now deals at 96-98 mph and touches 101 with his fastball. He also mixes in a mid-80s splitter against left-handers on occasion.Though there's not much effort in his delivery, PERSON didn't provide a lot of strikes in college and hasn't in pro ball. He sometimes overthrows and yanks his pitches out of the zone. If he can do a better job of harnessing his power stuff, he could serve as a high-leverage reliever and perhaps even a closer at the big league level.

PERSON was a two-way talent when the ORGANIZATION drafted him in the third round in 2010. PERSON originally made him a shortstop, but after two disappointing seasons in the ORGANIZATION, the ORGANIZATION moved him to the mound. PERSON threw 13 innings at ORGANIZATION PERSON in 2012 and struck out 23 batters. His prime weapon is a plus fastball that sits in the mid-90s and has touched 97 mph. PERSON also throws a changeup and curveball. The ORGANIZATION have a history of position players successfully transitioning to the mound and will put PERSON on a similar track.

The son of former big league shortstop PERSON, PERSON was one of the youngest players in the 2011 Draft class and after two summers of pro ball, he still has a long way to go. He has hands like his dad, but he has the chance to have a much better bat. Heâs also too big to play shortstop, with the ORGANIZATION moving him over to third. He should eventually have the bat to profile at the hot corner, though it may take him a while to grow into his power. Added strength will help, as will improved plate discipline so he can tap into that power when it arrives.

Like PERSON prospect PERSON did a few years ago, PERSON looked solid during summer showcases, then remade his body and saw his stuff explode the following spring. After touching 92 last summer, he's been up to 97 this spring and sitting 92-94. Rodrigueez generates this kind of velo with little effort, his pitches come in at a tough angle and he has great feel for a breaking ball. He's less polished than the prep arms ahead of him on this list but has similar pure stuff and could be off the board in the 10-15 range.

PERSON is the best overall player from GPE in the class of 2019. He's a pure hitter and natural athlete with solid baseball instincts across the board. He is also known for his physically projectable body and easy actions on defense and at the plate. PERSON has sound approach in the batter's box and has shown the ability to use all fields with consistent and hard contact. There's a nice rhythm and balance to his swing and although he's primarily a line drive hitter now, there have been flashes of power and it could increase as he develops. He has impressed scouts by performing well against pitchers throwing 93 mph to 95 mph during workouts and showcases.PERSON is a quality defender in center field now and he makes all of the plays, but it's uncertain if that's where he will stay because he's not a plus runner. He developed his game in the youth leagues of GPE and has a high baseball IQ.PERSON is from GPE, GPE, and trains with PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign him.

PERSON spent three years mostly starting for ORGANIZATION, with mixed results. But scouts always liked his pure stuff. That, plus a dominant turn in the ORGANIZATION in 2017 was enough for the ORGANIZATION to take PERSON in the fourth round of the 2018 Draft, and he responded to their faith in him by pitching very well in his brief pro debut in the rookie-level PERSON League.PERSON's composure and maturity have already made a strong impression on the ORGANIZATION, and he's shown, at least early, more feel to pitch than anticipated. He challenges hitters with a fastball that sits at 94 mph and touches 97 regularly. His changeup is his best secondary offering, thrown with fade and excellent arm speed deception. His slider currently isn't a true weapon, and he focused on improving his breaking ball over the offseason so it becomes more viable.PERSON showed better command than he had at ORGANIZATION, with an ability to work to all four quadrants of the strike zone. If that continues, he has the chance to start. If not, he showed that his stuff plays very well when he closed during that stint on the Cape.

PERSON had a breakout season in 2013, despite having to overcome a strained oblique that sidelined him for two months. As a 20-year-old at ORGANIZATION A San Jose, PERSON led all ORGANIZATION starters with 12.45 strikeouts per nine innings, and he pitched in the ORGANIZATION. He hasn't been as dominant in Double-A this year, though he has continued to pile up strikeouts.PERSON attacks hitters with his lively mid-90s fastball that reaches 98 mph. His breaking ball is a swing-and-miss pitch that looks like a hard-biting slider at its best. PERSON's changeup is still developing, but it gives him a chance for a fourth Major League average offering. He is still learning to repeat his delivery, and his command suffers as a result.PERSON earns comparisons to PERSON, and he has an excellent chance to join the ORGANIZATION' ace in the succession of homegrown pitchers to reach PERSON.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION in October 2010, PERSON made a slow but steady climb through GPE's system before breaking out in 2016, when he finished second in the LOCATION batting race with a .335 average at ORGANIZATION. Impressed by his development, the GPE selected PERSON in the ORGANIZATION phase of the Rule 5 Draft in December.Though undersized and lacking in terms of physical projection, PERSON is an excellent athlete who has long stood out for his plus speed and ability to play both outfield corners. He has good bat speed and a short stroke from the left side of the plate, with an approach that has continued to improve as he's climbed the ladder. And while he doesn't offer much in the way of over-the-fence pop, PERSON's combination of gap power and speed yields plenty of extra-base hits.With his solid collection of tools, PERSON shows the makings of becoming a fourth outfielder at the highest level, a role that the GPE hope he can fill for them in 2017.

There are moments when GPE looks like one of the more dominant lefty relievers in baseball. He'll touch 100, his fastball spins and has life, his slider is consistently plus, and he hides the ball well. At other times he's unplayably wild. The early parts of GPE's 2019 spring were encouraging but, at age 27, it's unlikely the issues that have plagued him for years have suddenly been remedied. He'll likely be a scintillating and terrifying low-leverage relief piece.

Selected in the second round of the 2013 Draft, PERSON hit .371 during his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION and then claimed the LOCATION batting title the following year in his full-season debut, batting .340 as a 19-year-old at ORGANIZATION A Delmarva. He hit over .300 again in the ORGANIZATION in 2015 and received a late-season promotion to Double-A GPE, where he was more than four years younger than the average player in the LOCATION. PERSON has continued to hit up a storm this season in his return to GPE, and he announced himself to a national audience when he homered in the ORGANIZATION Game in July. PERSON has already proven to be an advanced hitter for his age, demonstrating excellent feel for the strike zone and an approach which caters to his use of the whole field. He makes a lot of contact with a clean left-handed stroke and never tries to do too much at the plate. He's shown a more discerning eye as he's moved up the ladder, leading to perennially high on-base percentages and walk rates across his first four seasons. Although PERSON had a few more balls leave the yard in 2015, he profiles as more of a doubles hitter with below-average over-the-fence pop.PERSON has good arm strength but otherwise is raw behind the plate. He's worked hard to improve his footwork and catch-and-throw skills in the last year, and scouts have become less skeptical about whether he can develop the chops to be an everyday backstop. The ORGANIZATION have challenged PERSON since Day One, and the fact that he had significant Double-A experience entering his age-21 season speaks to his track record of surpassing expectations.

Scouts in the GPE became enamored with PERSON during 2016 extended spring training in GPE and PERSON poached him from the FACILITY before he had even suited up for a professional game. He was sent to full-season Fort Wayne as an 18-year-old in 2017 and hit .280/.390/.520 with 20 homers and steals and, perhaps most impressively for his age, a 14.5% walk rate. He also flashes occasional acrobatic brilliance at shortstop, though scouts are not unanimous about his long term prospects there because of the size of PERSON' frame.

Short but hyper-athletic righty who mitigates some of his size issues with a vertical arm slot. Sits 91-93 and will touch 95 with a long arm swing. PERSON changeup but stuff has otherwise been inconsistent this spring.

GPE of a Cathedral program that has produced big leaguers Jake PERSON and PERSON in recent years, GSP is in the mix to become the first high school pitcher drafted in 2015. He had a fine summer on the high school showcase circuit, repeatedly showing one of the more devastating two-pitch combinations in the prep class.Thanks to his fast arm and low-three-quarters slot, GSP imparts a lot of life on his pitches. He usually works at 92-95 mph with his fastball and when he stays on top of his 78-82-mph slider, it's a swing-and-miss offering with bite. With those two weapons in his repertoire, he rarely has needed a changeup against high school competition.His frame, athleticism and long hair draw some comparisons to PERSON, though some scouts wonder if GSP's slinging delivery might make him better suited for the bullpen. After verbally committing to PERSON as a high school freshman, he decommitted last summer and signed with PERSON A&M.

He's quite little, but GPE is an athletic backstop with catch and throw skills, as well as advanced feel for contact. He's twitchy and mobile, which bodes well for his ball-blocking future, and he's a fine receiver and pitch framer already, though he hasn't caught a lot of big league-quality stuff yet. It's possible the physical grind of catching will take an outsized toll on GPE's little body and he won't hit enough to be anything, but on tools, at the very least, he looks like a good backup catching prospect.

The biggest over-slot signing by the ORGANIZATION in the 2013 Draft, PERSON got $278,000 in the 18th round to pass up his commitment to PERSON. He has made steady progress, getting stronger and polishing his all-around tools to blossom into a potential five-tool player. A strong start in Triple-A this season earned him his first big league callup in late June, but he ruptured the patellar tendon in his right knee when he ran into an outfield wall in his first game with the ORGANIZATION and was lost for the year. Nearly a month after suffering the injury, PERSON was dealt to the A's with PERSON and PERSON at the ORGANIZATION for right-hander PERSON. PERSON makes repeated hard contact with a short, quick left-handed stroke. His bat speed, strength and plus speed give him 20-20 upside, though he's still learning to be an efficient basestealer. To reach his offensive ceiling, he'll need to get more selective at the plate because he walks infrequently and puts too many early-count pitches in play rather than waiting for one to drive.PERSON has made tremendous defensive improvement since turning pro. He has worked diligently with outfield instructor PERSON to refine his reads and routes, going from spending the majority of his time on the corners in his first two season to being a quality center fielder. He also has bolstered his arm strength to at least average.

When the ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the fourth round of the 2015 Draft out of the GPE high school ranks, they knew he had good stuff. But during that first summer, and even into instructs, the projectable lefty never showed it consistently. His '16 was a different story completely, showing more confidence and consistency from GPE Training through extended and two Minor League stops. While his 2017 season was initially delayed because of a shoulder impingment, he was throwing well during his full-season debut when his elbow required PERSON surgery in July.When healthy, PERSON has a ton of life on everything he throws. His fastball runs and explodes up in the zone, in the 92-97 mph range. He freezes hitters with his plus breaking ball, and the ORGANIZATION feel it might be a 70 power curve eventually. He's shown a good feel for his changeup, one that drops off the table at times. He has the chance to have three plus pitches when all is said and done, especially if he can continue to refine his command. There is a little funk to his delivery -- the deception adds to his effectiveness -- but he needs to make sure he doesn't get offline as much as he moves up the ladder.Right now, PERSON's primary focus will be to get healthy. He just turned 21 in June, so there's plenty of time, but he does need to show he can stay on the mound for a full season in order to reach his potential as a big league starter.

Signed back in December 2012 out of GPE, PERSON started out moving slowly, spending a summer in the ORGANIZATION and one in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION, pitching mostly in relief. He moved into a full-time starting role in 2015 in the ORGANIZATION, then had a breakout year in his full-season debut, earning PERSON honors. The move to the hitter-friendly GPE League began well, with another midseason All-Star invite, though he scuffled after a strong April and May.After leading the organization in ORGANIZATION in 2016, PERSON was too hittable as a 21-year-old in the ORGANIZATION, allowing 10.7 hits per nine and a .295 batting average against. At his best, the right-hander mixes his average stuff in and out and keeps it down the zone more effectively. He'll throw his fastball in the low-90s and complements it with a breaking ball and changeup, which are inconsistent, but show flashes of eventually being PERSON offerings. He did miss a decent amount of bats in 2017, finishing second in the system in strikeouts and continued to throw strikes, though he'll have to command the ball within the zone better to have a chance to succeed at the upper levels.PERSON will be 22 for nearly all of the 2018 season, so there's plenty of time for him to hone his craft. His ceiling might be as a No. 5 starter if his stuff ticks up at all, with a future in the bullpen a possibility.

PERSON has played a variety of positions since he set foot on the ORGANIZATION campus, but it's his bat that will get him drafted in the first five or six rounds.PERSON has played the outfield, third base and second base during his time with the ORGANIZATION. His ability to hit from the right side of the plate will truly dictate when he gets drafted. He shows signs of being able to hit for both average and power, with the ability to add strength a plus for future development at the plate. PERSON could be an intriguing offensive-minded second baseman, but if the bat comes along as some hope, he might profile better back at the hot corner or in an outfield corner. He has some raw power but his line-drive swing is more conducive to doubles than home runs.An average runner with subpar arm strength, PERSON played left field as a freshman before moving to second base. He has been erratic defensively this year and will have to work to become an average defender at the keystone. His overall package is reminiscent of PERSON's.

After hitting 13 homers as a sophomore last spring and then leading the GPE collegiate national team in all three slash stats at .372/.500/.535 last summer, PERSON positioned himself well in a 2018 Draft with a notable lack of catchers. But he has confounded scouts by not making more progress offensively, and they now wonder if his defense might be better than his bat. He still shows decent potential both ways, which along with his track record will make him one of the first backstops selected.PERSON's raw power is his best offensive trait, the product of strength and good-not-great bat speed, though there are questions as to how consistently he'll get to it in pro ball. He looks to crush everything to his pull side, leaving him vulnerable on the outer half of the plate. He has managed the strike zone well in college but his approach could get exploited by pro pitchers.PERSON has made strides behind the plate this spring, cleaning up his receiving and improving his framing skills. He has average arm strength that plays up a bit because he gets rid of the ball quickly and makes accurate throws. He does a nice job of running a pitching staff.

At ORGANIZATION, GPE sliced his ERA from 5.60 as a freshman to 3.70 as a sophomore to 2.22 as a junior this spring. He cleaned up his delivery, improved his velocity and control and pitched himself into the second round of the GPE, where he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $900,600.After peaking at 94 mph with his fastball in 2013, GPE now works at 92-94 and tops out at 98. The life on his fastball also has gotten better, and he uses his size and high-three-quarters delivery to throw it on a downhill plane. His slider has taken a step forward as well and shows signs of becoming a plus pitch. With the makings of an average changeup and a strong build, GPE projects as a possible mid-rotation starter. His command isn't nearly as strong as his control, however, so it's possible he could wind up as a late-inning reliever.

FACILITY PERSON seemed like the ORGANIZATION' version of PERSON, signing for $500,000 in November 2010 but not getting cleared to play until March 2012 because he had presented differing identities and birthdates during the signing process. He built more anticipation by blowing away Rookie-level ORGANIZATION hitters with a fastball that approaches 100 mph, and he did the same when he finally made his GPE debut at the start of 2013.When FACILITY PERSON got promoted to high Class A last June, however, he learned that he'll need more than sheer velocity to succeed at higher levels. He continued to average 93-94 mph with his fastball, but he got smoked to the tune of a 6.06 ERA because he had nothing else to help him survive.FACILITY PERSON has a rough delivery and struggles to repeat it, which compromises his secondary pitches and his ability to locate his offerings. He can run his slider up to 85 mph but it lacks consistency, and he has yet to show much feel for a changeup. He'll profile as a reliever unless he can add a lot of polish.

The ORGANIZATION went all in on the international market in 2011, handing PERSON a $15.6 million big league contract and spending another $12.8 million on bonuses for amateurs, including $4.95 million for PERSON. The most expensive pitcher in that crop was PERSON, who signed for $1.5 million out of GPE. Elbow problems and cautious handling slowed his development until 2016, when he rocketed from high Class A to Texas.PERSON owns one of the best changeups among pitching prospects, and its fade, sink and deception help him keep right-handers in check. He throws it with the same arm speed as he does his sinking 90-93 mph fastball, which peaks at 95 and might pick up a bit more velocity if he adds more strength to his lanky 6-foot-5 frame. His breaking pitches don't stand out as much as his other offerings, though he did make strides with his slider last year and it's now more effective with his curveball.PERSON had a history of filling the strike zone before he reached Triple-A and the Majors at the end of 2016, but his control hasn't been as sharp since. He doesn't have a huge ceiling but does have a solid floor and is a good bet to become a No. 3 starter. The only real question is his durability, because his 114 innings last year were a career high and he worked as many as six frames just three times in his first 59 pro starts.

PERSON turned down an offer from GPE out of high school worth well into the seven figures, which he'll almost certainly best this spring. He's a big, switch-hitting 6-foot-3 shortstop who can stick at the position in pro ball and has above average raw power from both sides. The issue is that he hasn't hit well with wood bats over the summer and has always had plenty of strikeouts to go with his homers in the spring (42 career HR, 20% career strikeouts). Some scouts worry that he'll be more of a 30-35 bat in pro ball who doesn't get to his power, making him a utility guy, while others see another candidate for an offensive adjustment that could make him a 45 bat, 55 power standout everyday player.

A 36th-round pick out of high school by the ORGANIZATION in 2014 and again as a freshman at LOCATION CC by the Rangers a year later, PERSON finally signed with the ORGANIZATION for $250,000 as a fourth-rounder last June. In the final year of the LOCATION program, he set school records for hitting (.419) and homers (16) in 2016. He continued to rake in his pro debut, leading the Rookie-level PERSON in runs (63), total bases (161) and ORGANIZATION (1.052). PERSON' strength and the leverage in his 6-foot-6 frame give him massive raw power from the right side of the plate. His size makes his swing exceedingly long when he gets overly aggressive, so he may not hit for high average after batting .351 in his first taste of pro ball. He does make a lot of hard contact and shows the patience to draw some walks.PERSON moves very well for a big man, showing average speed out of the batter's box and plus speed at times once he gets going. He split his time between center and right field during his debut and fits better at the latter position. Though he needs to refine his reads and routes, his strong arm is an asset.

PERSON made three trips to the ORGANIZATION in 2018 and he's had a few other issues that have caused the ORGANIZATION to throttle down his activity during the spring and fall. He has plus velocity, but loses a tick of perceived velo due to lack of extension, and his arm angle and spin direction are more conducive of sink/run that bat-missing rise. He will flash a plus changeup, and that pitch will likely be his best at maturity. The breaking stuff is closer to average. He was mechanically inconsistent this spring and has once again been placed on the ORGANIZATION with shoulder/back issues. There are days when PERSON's stuff and style of pitching resembles PERSON's, but the injury stuff might force a bullpen move.

PERSON parlayed a dominant junior season out of the bullpen for an GPE team that won 27 straight games this spring into becoming the top lefty in the GPE class and the ORGANIZATION. 6 overall pick. The ORGANIZATION gave him full pick value at $3,889,500, signing him quickly and sending him straight to the Class A Advanced PERSON for his debut.ORGANIZATIONt particularly physical at 6-foot-1 and 175 pounds, PERSON's fastball nonetheless works at 93-95 mph and peaks at 98 mphl, even when he has worked on consecutive days. He generates that heat with athleticism and a quick arm rather than an excessive amount of effort in his delivery. PERSON has a deeper repertoire than most relievers. His plus slider is his second-best pitch, and he also has a curveball with power and depth and shows signs of an interesting changeup.His array of pitches and control should lead the ORGANIZATION to develop him as a starter, though he began his pro career in the bullpen with a chance to move him up the ladder quickly if needed.

PERSON continues to improve and has positioned himself as one of the top players in this year's class.While some scouts think the infielder will eventually move from shortstop to third base, there are others who believe he has the tools to stay in the middle of the diamond. PERSON is very athletic, and some say he's one of the best athletes on the market. What's more, the teenager has displayed soft hands, good body control and solid range to both sides. He has also shown good arm and impressive actions on defense.He's still developing as a hitter but has already shown good bat speed and power potential. He destroys fastballs, and like most prospects his age, he's working on hitting secondary pitches. A line-drive hitter with some natural loft to his swing, PERSON can spray the ball to all fields.He is trained by PERSON in GPE. The Marlins are the favorite to sign him.

PERSON was the ORGANIZATION top signing in the 2018 July 2nd period and the club thinks they have one of the safer bets in the class, due to PERSON's feel to hit and instincts. Some scouts saw PERSON without much power and with fringy speed and arm strength, but as is the nature of international showcases, often clubs get a look or two at a player when he is 14 or 15 years old, then not see him again until instructional league almost 18 months later. In those limited and early looks, players can change significantly, while feel for hitting and defensive instincts are often not obvious unless the club puts in extra work, which not all clubs can do for every player. The ORGANIZATION and rival scouts see an above average bat, average speed, and feel for the game. Some clubs see that as a bat-first left fielder with limited projection, while the ORGANIZATION see a center fielder with a plus bat, a combo that can post a sneaky 3-win season every now and then.

In his brief time as a pro, PERSON has shown a knack for doing one thing very well: hit. And as most baseball people will tell you: If you can hit, you'll likely find a job in the big leagues.PERSON was raking in the ORGANIZATION State League during his first full season in 2013 before a broken wrist forced him out for a month. He has a knack for making consistent hard contact, and with a 6-foot-5 frame, he should add strength, which should lead to some of his doubles clearing fences. PERSON' other tools won't jump out at you, but he has the skills to be a decent corner outfielder.PERSON has played some corner infield in the past, and he could get another look there, but it's his ability to swing the bat that will continue to propel him up the ladder.

GPE is a stocky, 6-foot-1 shortstop with an explosive first step who has a good chance to stay at short and be an average defender. His hands and arm are both fine there, as well. He has one of the more advanced bats in the class and has some present pop due to his physicality, with room for a little more. This is the second year in a row PERSON's top two J2 targets have had precocious bat-to-ball skills and limited physical projection.

Though his surface-level stats -- .245/.340/.376 in parts of three pro seasons -- aren't impressive, PERSON is a 2019 breakout candidate. Switch-hitters with power are rare and PERSON has all-fields pop from both sides of the plate that, in 2018, was masked by the cavernous ballparks of the ORGANIZATION State League. A waist-high leg kick and loose, active hands provide much of the thump, and PERSON is athletic enough to make use of a swing with that much movement and not have it negatively impacted his timing. Though he has limited bat control, PERSON is adept at picking hittable pitchces to attack, and cut his K% down to 17% in 2018 while maintaining his above-average 11% walk rate. Defensively, PERSON projects in right field. He saw ample time in center in 2016 and 2017 but really only played in either corner last year. There's a non-zero chance he thickens substantially through his mid-20s and loses the mobility to play the outfield, but that might also mean he's grown into more power than we're projecting and fits at first base--offensively anyway. There's a good chance PERSON turns into a solid everyday outfielder immune to modern pitching staffs' desire to exploit hitters' handedness.

A year before the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick, PERSON was considered to be the top PERSON prospect in the 2011 Draft before ultimately going to PERSON in the second round. He scuffled early in his career before finally putting everything together in 2015, when he was named PERSON of the Year in the LOCATION and made his big league debut in September. But after such a promising campaign, PERSON has regressed across the board this season back in Triple-A. PERSON features an explosive 92-95 mph fastball that he threw for strikes more consistently last season, and he couples it with a plus curveball in the high 70s that has good shape and downer action. His changeup has steadily improved but still lags behind his two main offerings, although it does tend to play up because he repeats the same arm slot as his fastball. While PERSON's command has long left something to be desired, he previously had been able to mitigate those concerns by missing bats. That hasn't been the case in 2016, however, as he's walked nearly as many hitters as he's struck out in Triple-A. The ORGANIZATION have no choice but to remain patient with PERSON, whom they hope will be able to get back on track during the second half. But after such a promising campaign, PERSON has regressed across the board this season back in Triple-A, so much so that the ORGANIZATION demoted him to Double-A at the end of July.

PERSON improved in each of his three years at ORGANIZATION, earning Big GPE All-Conference honors as a junior. The ORGANIZATION took PERSON in the 12th round that June, signing him for $150,000. He's done nothing but produce as a pro, using his blend of hitting ability, speed and defense to move quickly through the ORGANIZATION' system. He was a ORGANIZATION All-Star in his first full season and played just five games at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Lakeland at the outset of 2018 before advancing to Double-A, where he was an LOCATION All-Star and produced a .317 average with 23 steals. After the season, PERSON continued to boost his prospect stock with a strong turn in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON has a good feel for what he's doing at the plate. His approach is geared toward hitting the ball back up the middle, and he does so often using a short left-handed swing. While PERSON's contact is mostly of the ground-ball variety, it actually plays into his strength because he's a plus-plus runner with well-below-average power. PERSON is a skilled bunter, with the ability to lay it down either line, and he's an aggressive, sometimes over-aggressive basestealer. He fared better against same-sided arms (.340 average) than righties (.301) in Double-A. PERSON's wheels enable him to play center field, and he's seen significant time at all three outfield spots in full-season ball. That versatility, along with his speed and bat, give PERSON a clear path to the Majors as a fourth outfielder.

PERSON is a physical, long-armed righty who throws really hard and is rather deceptive. His fastball gets some help from extension, but it enters the zone at a hittable angle and PERSON is fly ball prone. He also has a terse, upper-80s slider that induces weak contact more than it misses bats because it lacks length. It could be a weapon in on the hands of lefties, though, and PERSON has shown some feel for creating vertical action with it, though really onlt to his arm side. He's a relief prospect.

At first glance, it might be easy to dismiss the 25-year-old ORGANIZATION as an older prospect. But if you take into account that he was a two-way player at PERSON, then missed the 2011 season in the ORGANIZATION organization following PERSON surgery, he's not far behind, experience-wise. He's proved himself to be a solid starter and reached Triple-A Las Vegas in 2013. ORGANIZATION has a fastball that should be a plus pitch and combines it with a potentially above-average slider. He also throws a solid changeup. If ORGANIZATION can have even just average command, he has a future as a starter and could soon be Major League-ready.

PERSON was nearly anonymous as a prospect until 2018. He played at a high profile Atlanta-area high school (the same one as his brother PERSON, who the ORGANIZATION drafted in first round in 2016), played sparingly for a year at ORGANIZATION, then transferred to GPE PERSON's River junior college in GPE, ORGANIZATION, where he hit 17 homers, a feat that got him to ORGANIZATION for his junior season. He had a solid season for the Bulldogs but was a first base-only prospect with no pedigree who hit five home runs, so you can see why he lasted until the 13th round in the 2016 draft.  His hitability translated well that first pro summer and in 2017, which he split across both A-Ball levels at ages 21 and 22. The missing element here is that while PERSON had plus raw power the first time we saw him at ORGANIZATION, he didn't have the kind of swing or approach to get the most out of it. This untapped tool and his plate discipline are the reasons he was a 13th rounder and not a 35th rounder who went back to school for his senior year. In 2018, PERSON did a rare thing: he tried to do more damage at the plate and lift the ball a bit more, but was able to keep his contact rates the same while adding game power. PERSON did this in the ORGANIZATION farm system two years in a row and went from an untapped, toolsy prospect who was passed over in the Rule 5 Draft to a Rookie of the Year runner-up; PERSON went from the top of the 'Others of PERSON' section last year to one of the top 150 prospects in the game over a 12 month period. PERSON is a fine defender at first but the value here is all in the bat. Because he's left-handed, the downside is a platoon option at 1B/DH, though the ORGANIZATION cycle through those types very quickly. Underlying indicators and ORGANIZATION data suggest PERSON's very loud 2018 stats aren't fluky and he may just be a 50 bat with advanced feel for the zone and 60 game power, which is a solid regular. He might be big league ready in the middle of 2019.

PERSON's profile, that of a defensive-oriented backstop, has everyone penciling him in as a career backup. It might be a mistake, though, to typecast him just yet.There is little question PERSON's work behind the plate will earn him a Major League gig. He can really catch and throw, having thrown out better than 40 percent of would-be basestealers in his career. PERSON moves well behind the plate, and he is a natural leader with plus makeup. He's the kind of catcher who will grow on a big league pitching and coaching staff. A switch-hitter who's much better from the left side, PERSON does have the ability to spray line drives to all fields, but he has no discernible power.At worst, PERSON is about ready to embark on a long career as a valuable backup, something that started with several callups in 2014. In the right spot, though, he could be a big league regular.

PERSON and ORGANIZATION corner-infield prospect PERSON played together for four years at GPE, improving their numbers each year before turning pro as senior signs in 2015. A 19th-rounder who signed for $1,000 after hitting .395/.486/.682 in his fourth year with the GPE, he's battling PERSON to become the first position player in school history to reach the big leagues. He rose quickly through the ORGANIZATION system before stalling when he reached Triple-A in August.PERSON makes consistent hard contact with a sound swing from the right side of the plate. He's not a big guy but has average raw power and could translate it into 12-15 homers per season. He draws a fair amount of walks and makes the most of his average speed on the bases.Club officials rave about PERSON's baseball IQ. It helps him get the job done in center field despite fringy range, though he'll fit better on the corners in the big leagues. His average arm allows him to play all three outfield positions.

PERSON was a known prep prospect as an underclassman in GPE due to his 6-foot-6 frame and ability to touch 90 mph from the left side at an early age. The limitation here is that PERSON has essentially never had a plus pitch and doesn't project to have one, working downhill from a steep plane and great extension with a low-90's sinker and an above-average four pitch mix. He doesn't have high spin rates on his breaking stuff and pitches more to weak contact, looking like a steady, durable, roughly league-average starter even as a college player. His feel to pitch and mix offerings in different locations is advanced, so the expectation here is for PERSON to save the ORGANIZATION some money on that No. 3 or 4 starter that so many teams overpay for in free agency.

GPE ORGANIZATION hasn't had a high school left-hander taken in the first five rounds since the ORGANIZATION popped PERSON at ORGANIZATION. 5 overall in 1970. ORGANIZATION, a two-way star on PERSON's (ORGANIZATION) 2-A state championship team in 2017, is talented enough to break that drought. He also could blossom into a high pick three years from now if he attends ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION.While ORGANIZATION is more about projection than present stuff, he's a southpaw with life on his fastball and feel for spin. His fastball usually ranges from 86-92 mph with sink and should develop into a solid offering as he adds strength to his slender frame. His curveball already shows flashes of becoming a plus pitch with some power and depth.ORGANIZATION also has some aptitude for throwing a changeup. He's athletic and repeats his delivery well, working down in the zone from a three-quarters arm slot.

The ORGANIZATION of the 2012 ORGANIZATION II College World Series after tossing a pair of shutouts to lead LOCATION (Pa.) to the national title, PERSON signed for $65,000 as an 18th-round pick the following June. He has advanced rapidly, reaching Double-A early in his second full professional season before being sent to the ORGANIZATION in June in return for PERSON Aza.PERSON works from a low three-quarters arm slot that adds run and sink to a fastball that clocks at 90-94 mph when he's fresh. It also produces a sweeping slider that can be tough on right-handers. He also has a fringy changeup that he doesn't trust as much as his two main pitches. The ORGANIZATION had used PERSON as both a starter and reliever, and he's more likely to fill the latter role in the big leagues. He fills the strike zone and keeps the ball down, though he must prove he can maintain his velocity over a full year after it faded in the second half of 2014.

The ORGANIZATION gave PERSON slightly above pick value in the second round of the 2014 Draft to sign the ORGANIZATION high school standout away from heading to GPE. He was making slow, incremental progress, nothing out of the ordinary for a pitcher from the LOCATION, but the wheels fell off a bit in 2016 and he was sent from full-season ball to the ORGANIZATION complex in GPE. To his credit, he righted the ship and returned to the ORGANIZATION in 2017. The ORGANIZATION are hoping that hitting the reset button will allow PERSON to rediscover his stride, because they still believe in his stuff. His fastball is above average at times, even flashing plus, he'll show a plus curveball on occasion -- a true hammer of a breaking ball -- and he even shows a feel for a changeup. Throughout his ORGANIZATION career, he's been more hittable than he should be given his stuff, and he has really lost command of the baseball, both in and out of the zone. Most of that was because of inconsistencies with his delivery, and that was the focus upon his return to GPE, helping him be more athletic in his delivery. PERSON did show strides in making progress, and he came back to GPE early voluntarily to keep working on righting the ship, which helped him bounce back. He still has the weapons to be a starting pitching prospect if he can unlock them consistently.

When the ORGANIZATION realized PERSON, a high school shortstop from GPE, wouldn't be around for their second selection in the 2014 Draft, they went ahead and nabbed him at ORGANIZATION. 24 overall.PERSON is an athletic shortstop with a very good chance of staying at the premium position. A switch-hitter with a projectable body, PERSON is a better hitter from the left side right now. There isn't much power at the moment, but he does have room to add strength to his frame. PERSON's best offensive tool will always be his speed, which plays well on both sides of the ball. He has the range, hands, arm and instincts to hold his position as well. PERSON's defense is ahead of his offense right now, but there is projection in his bat.PERSON is praised for his work ethic and makeup, and although it might take a while for him to reach his potential, there's no question he won't be outworked trying to get there.

GPE's best pitching prospect since PERSON was a second-round pick in 2005, PERSON has struggled more than expected this spring. PERSON torched him for 10 runs in his third start of the season and he has battled his control and command for much of the spring. He did lead the Big GPE Conference in strikeouts for the second straight year, however, and still should fit in the first five or six rounds.PERSON uses both a low-90s sinker and a harder four-seam fastball, and he can maintain his velocity into the late innings. His curveball hasn't been as sharp as usual, though it still flashes good depth and he's throwing it for strikes. He masks his changeup well and it features some fade.PERSON has a clean delivery and repeats his high-three-quarters arm slot well. If he can regain the feel for his curveball and for locating his pitches that he has displayed in the past, he could have a solid three-pitch repertoire and make it as a No. 4 starter at the next level.

Prime's breakout in his full-season debut in 2014, during which he led the organization in home runs and tied for the system lead in GPE, may have come as a surprise to those outside of the organization, but the Rockies weren't shocked to see the big first baseman produce.One of the harder workers in the system, Prime greatly improved his ability to turn on inside pitches, hitting the ball out front in order to create power to his pull side. There's still a good amount of swing and miss to his game, and he needs to improve his plate discipline so he can continue to tap into his above-average raw power consistently. Prime is still growing, showing up to Spring Training a half-inch taller. PERSON 6-foot-5, Prime is more agile than you'd expect. He has quick feet and soft hands that work well at first base, which should allow him to be a solid defender. Prime might just be scratching the surface. As he grows into his already strong body, there might be more power to come, allowing him to profile very well at the infield corner position.
90-94 with average secondaries, the curveball more consistent than the change. On starter/reliever fringe.

Baseball development isn't always a straight path and sometimes prospects need to take a step back to move forward. That seems to be the case with PERSON, who wasn't ready for full-season ball in 2015, righted the ship after a move back to the Rookie-level Appalachian League, then handled the ORGANIZATION in 2016 by finishing ninth in batting average and tied for third in stolen bases. He jumped on the fast track in 2017, moving up to Double-A early in the season and even making his big league debut in May, and then joined the ORGANIZATION in December with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON as part of the ORGANIZATION trade.While PERSON could stand to refine his approach and draw more walks, especially since he profiles as a top-of-the-order type hitter, he does have a knack for making consistent hard contact. He doesn't have over-the-fence power, but PERSON has enough strength to hit the gaps. From there, his speed allows him to take extra bases and he should become a more efficient basestealer as he progresses. PERSON is an elite-level defender in center field, the kind who regularly makes highlight-reel plays, and he has a plus arm to boot.Seeing a young player show they can bounce back after struggling, that they can demonstrate and learn from adversity, is important in development. That skill, along with his natural tools, has allowed PERSON to make progress up the ladder.

PERSON first started to raise his profile in the ORGANIZATION in 2015, then with a strong junior season at ORGANIZATION in 2016. The top pure college hitter in that GPE class, he went No. 2 overall to the ORGANIZATION, signing for $6.2 million, the top bonus in the GPE, albeit below pick value. PERSON kept on producing during his pro debut, spending most of it batting over .300 in the full-season ORGANIZATION, then kept on hitting during his first full season, earning a promotion to Double-A.The right-handed hitter has both strength and bat speed to go along with an advanced approach at the plate. He uses all fields and draws walks, which should help him continue to hit for both average and power. His speed plays up thanks to outstanding instincts which allow him to be a base stealing threat. PERSON has worked hard on his defensive craft and there are no longer questions about his ability to stay at the hot corner long-term, with a strong arm, good hands and quick feet.PERSON has jumped on a fast track by reaching Double-A in 2017. Seeing him be the first bat from his GPE class to reach the big leagues certainly seems reasonable.

GPE love PERSON's 6-foot-1, 178-pound frame.He's lean -- some evaluators even describe him as lanky -- and he is athletic, with room to grow. On defense, some scouts view him as the ideal center fielder because of his ability to read balls off the bat and his defensive instincts. He has also impressed evaluators with his reactions to balls hit into the gaps.In the batter's box, PERSON is a natural left-handed hitter with a fluid stroke and a good approach in games. He has also shown some power.PERSON's arm is best described as playable, and he has enough arm strength to play his primary position in center field. He does have some experience playing in the infield, particularly at second base, but his future will be in the outfield as long as he continues to develop.PERSON signed a $2 million deal with the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON didn't stay in shape and pitched just 10 innings as an GPE freshman in 2012, but he improved his conditioning and pitched himself into the sixth round the following spring at FACILITY (GPE) CC. Signed for $300,000, he dominated in his first two years of full-season ball, posting a 181/34 K/BB ratio in 144 innings and holding opponents to a .190 average.PERSON can attribute his success to one pitch. He entered pro ball with a low-90s fastball but picked up velocity when the ORGANIZATION streamlined his mechanics following his lackluster pro debut. He now operates at 94-98 mph and reaches triple digits on a four-seamer that plays up even further because of its riding life and the deception in his delivery.He can mix in a two-seamer in the low 90s when he wants more sink, but PERSON still is searching for something reliable beyond his fastball. While he can run his slider into the upper 80s, it's a fringy pitch that lacks tilt, and he hasn't had much luck with a splitter. If he can find a second pitch, he could be a high-leverage reliever in the big leagues.

In an age when more and more teams are taking model-driven approaches to building a draft board, PERSON's age looms large. A player's age relative to his peers is a predictive variable for pro success (younger is better) and PERSON is older than a lot of last year's high scohol draftees. Not older than they were on draft day. Older than they are right now, and PERSON is two years older than Day 1 prospect PERSON. But tools-wise, he compares quite closely to Cardinals 2018 first rounder and top 100 prospect PERSON, and those tools belong in the middle of the first round. PERSON is big, strong, and has huge power and advanced feel to hit. He may not be an athletic fit at third base, especially long term, and is at risk of moving to first. The age issue slides him a shade beneath where we had PERSON's FV last year, and we consider PERSON's first pro summer, probably at an advanced rookie affiliate, to be of greater than usual importance in assessing his skills in an age-appropriate competitive environment.

PERSON led the ORGANIZATION with 12 homers (in just 27 games) in the summer of 2015, garnering some Kris Bryant comparisons while establishing himself as the best college power hitter available and a likely first-round pick in the 2016 Draft. He slumped as a junior at PERSON, however, making a greater impact on the mound as the ORGANIZATION placed second at the ORGANIZATION World Series. He looked like a steal after signing for an above-slot $650,000 as a fourth-rounder, batting .386/.427/.674 at short-season PERSON, but an old hamate injury sidelined him and contributed to a slow start in 2017.PERSON offers massive power potential, generating it with prodigious strength, bat speed and loft in his right-handed stroke and an aggressive approach. PERSON begins to separate himself from most catching prospects with his glove. A strong-bodied 21-year-old, the cement is likely dry on PERSON's stuff. His high three-quarters slot creates ride to his fastball as well as downward vertical action on his curveball, and those two traits typically pair well together. While PERSON's curveball is his prettiest pitch, his best secondary offering is the changeup. ORGANIZATION (Calif.) PERSON took a big step forward in 2014, his second season with the ORGANIZATION after coming from the Nationals in the ORGANIZATION trade. GPE has plus raw power and a chance to stay on the infield in some capacity, but not at shortstop. A move will necessitate more contact, but the power potential makes GPE enticing.

GPE's breakout season in 2015 led to his Major League debut, where he performed well in a small sample size. A plus runner, he can still improve his basestealing efficiency, and he's shown an ability to use that speed well in all three outfield positions, where his strong arm plays well.Just 24 for nearly all of the 2017 season, GPE could get another opportunity to show he can handle the highest level once he's healthy. GPE is an advanced receiver with advanced contact skills. He had a growth spurt in his late teens but still needs to add some strength and power to profile as anything more than contact-oriented backup.

PERSON was acquired from GPE in 2017 as one third of the ORGANIZATION' return for PERSON, along with PERSON and J.D. PERSON, both 35 FV type prospects. GPE ORGANIZATION never has had more than one player selected in the first five rounds of a Draft but could have three in June. PERSON doesn't throw hard--he sits 88-91 with a pretty straight fastball--but he's big and gets excellent extension down the mound, adding over two ticks of perceived velocity to his heater. He also knows how to operate up in the zone with his fastball, with good enough command to do it on the corners, and pair it with a big-breaking curveball, mixing in some changeups to keep hitters honest. There's a chance for a unique backend starter, especially if the velocity comes a little more, but it's more likely PERSON becomes a spot starter or long reliever given the limited margin for error with which he operates.

PERSON was an afterthought in the 2012 Draft, a 21st-rounder who signed for $2,500 after recording an 8.40 ERA as a ORGANIZATION Military Institute senior. 91-93 with tail, above-average curvebal. PERSON has long hook in the back, but stuff portends relief, at least.

As explosive as any high school outfielder in the draft, ORGANIZATION is a nearly elite runner with a plus arm and should grow into above average, strength-driven raw power. His swing can get long and stiff and not all scouts are sold on his bat.

PERSON graduated a semester early from PERSON (Fla.) and enrolled at GSP in 2012, bypassing the GPE in the process. PERSON PERSON went third overall in the 1985 Draft before winning 142 games during a 16-year big league career. PERSON was a pop-up PERSON prospect in 2015 as a closer at ORGANIZATION who set the ORGANIZATION single-season saves record. His stuff isn't strong enough to close like he did in college, but he could have a future as a setup man.

The way teams value PERSON depends on whether or not they feel confident the ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION will re-write service academy athlete policy. If teams think PERSON will have to serve and thus won't be able to pitch again until he's 24, he'll fall to Day 3.

After a bit of an up-and-down senior season, PERSON fell to the ORGANIZATION in the second round of the 2012 Draft. However, enough good things can't be said about his stuff and his ability to compete on the mound. He pitches to contact with three offerings that play up because of his ability to locate them on either side of the plate and down in the strike zone.GPE' best pitch is a tight 76-80 mph curveball. His fastball has good sinking action at 88-92 mph, and he'll cut at times to give batters a different look. He also can get outs with his deceptive circle changeup, which he masks nicely with fastball-like arm action. Though he struggled during his 2015 pro debut in the Class A Short PERSON York-Penn League, GPE has come into his own this year in the Class A Advanced PERSON, despite bypassing the Class A level entirely.

He also could stand to add some loft to his right-handed stroke because he put the ball in play on the ground too often.PERSON is an asset at third base as well as at the plate. He moves well, has sure hands and owns one of the strongest arms in the system. He has fringy speed and is aggressive on the basepaths.

More than a full year removed from all that intrigue and we still know relatively little about PERSON, largely due to a thumb ligament sprain PERSON dealt with throughout 2018. The ceiling is the same as it was purported to be before he signed: power, speed, offensive performance similar to PERSON's best years. There's just more risk that PERSON doesn't get there.

Ever since PERSON signed out of the ORGANIZATION for just $90,000 in 2009, he's shown glimpses of very exciting tools. The young infielder was hitting for average and decent pop, stealing bases and playing good second base. When he didn't get called up following injuries to PERSON and PERSON, PERSON wasn't happy, and it showed in his performance. PERSON continues to be the key to his inconsistencies. PERSON has the tools to be a top-of-the-order hitter with more extra-base power than you'd expect. To stick, he might have to break in as a super-utility type. But he'll have to earn his way there and prove he can handle the bright lights of the big leagues.

PERSON's huge junior season at ORGANIZATION enabled him to become one of the best left-handers in the 2014 Draft class and the highest-drafted player ever from the school when the ORGANIZATION took him No. 15 overall. PERSON used him mostly at first base and ORGANIZATION, while PERSON broke him into pro ball as a left fielder. The ORGANIZATION announced him as a second baseman on PERSON Day and plan to try him there in instructional league.

PERSON broke out in his first taste of full-season ball, winning ORGANIZATION of the Year honors while batting .322/.400/.559 and reaching Double-A in 2012.
