A corner infielder during his first two pro seasons, PERSON has found a home in right field, where he gets the job done and has a solid arm.

PERSON was drafted as a shortstop and then quickly transitioned to the outfield as a professional. His tools and athleticism give him vast potential if he is able to refine his approach at the plate. PERSON is susceptible to good breaking balls and too often swings at pitches out of the zone. If he can become more consistent at the plate, he has a wealth of raw power to tap into. That, combined with his plus speed, could make him an offensive force.  PERSON is much more advanced defensively. He has a solid arm and his speed allows him to effortlessly cover ground in center field. If his bat continues to come around, PERSON could become a solid everyday Major Leaguer.

PERSON's cross-bodied delivery compares closely to that of GPE righty PERSON, as both get way down the mound (PERSON gets nearly 7 feet of extension on his fastballs) and have lower arm slots that make right-handed hitters very uncomfortable. He makes heavy use of a hard slider that at times looks like a cutter. It has enough movement to miss bats if PERSON leaves it in the zone and he's been able to back foot it to lefties. Changeup development is paramount, and a fair number of scouts think PERSON ends up in the bullpen both because his change is quite a bit behind the typical 23-year-old's and because he throws exclusively from the stretch. While that's a possibility, the way PERSON's delivery enables his stuff to play up could make him viable in a multi-inning role. He reached Double-A in 2018 and has a chance to debut in 2019.

GPE by bad ORGANIZATION luck in 2018 (.226), PERSON's repeat tour of Double-A PERSON looked discouraging on paper. He still managed to pound out 27 homers, though, and he remains a strong power/lift/plate discipline prospect who could perform at the big league level soon. Players like this sometimes have seasons in excess of 2 WAR but are generally the type who bounce around the fringes of active rosters, like C.J. PERSON or PERSON.

PERSON served as a troubleshooting reliever on PERSON's PERSON Series club in 2017, the fourth straight year the ORGANIZATION reached PERSON. Though he was extremely valuable in that role, retiring 35 of the 39 batters he faced while recording two wins and a save during the ORGANIZATION postseason, ORGANIZATION shifted him into its rotation this spring. Though his stuff hasn't been as crisp as it has in the past and he missed time with back issues early in the season, he has still shown enough to factor in the first three rounds of the Draft.PERSON has four quality pitches and there's little consensus as to which is his best. He'll flash a well-above-average curveball at times, though there are other times when his hard slider is his superior breaking ball. He doesn't worry about radar guns, working at 89-92 mph with a quality sinker, though he can reach back for 95-96-mph heat when he needs to.As if that's not enough, PERSON can also unveil a solid changeup and fully trusts the pitch. Though he's not big, he's athletic and repeats his delivery, allowing him to throw a ton of strikes and boding well for his durability. He has advanced feel for pitching and mixes his pitches masterfully.

PERSON spent much of 2017 in GPE despite his lack of physicality because he was procedurally advanced for his age, especially on defense. He is athletic, fundamentally sound, and has perhaps the quickest defensive hands in the entire org. At the very least, PERSON projects as an outstanding multi-positional defender, but he also might just be plus at shortstop at maturity and need to play there every day. He also has advanced bat-to-ball skills and even though he has been physically overmatched for about 200 Low-A games over two seasons, he has somehow managed to maintain a strikeout rate in the low teens. PERSON has a little, 5-foot-10 frame and it's not clear whether he'll grow into the kind of physicality that would make him a viable offensive player. If he does, the feel for contact is already in place and he could break out. Though likely a switch-hitting utility man, PERSON has a sneaky chance to be an everyday shortstop.

By some measures, PERSON, who got $1.2 million to sign out of high school as a ninth rounder in the 2011 Draft, had a so-so first taste of Double-A. Considering it was his first full season back from PERSON surgery in May 2014, however, it was a success, and the ORGANIZATION added him to the 40-man roster as a result.PERSON is all about his power sinking fastball. He'll throw it in the low 90s and hitters consistently beat it into the ground, proven by his 2.94 groundout-to-airout ratio in 2016. Both of his secondary pitches, a curve and a changeup, have the chance to be PERSON average, and the breaking ball can miss bats at times, but he needs to land it in the strike zone more consistently. PERSON runs into trouble when he tries to be fine in and around the zone. He falls behind in the count when he doesn't need to, leading to him getting hit more, when all he needs to do is go after hitters early with his sinker and create weak contact early in counts.Officially out of rehab mode, PERSON' confidence could be skyrocketing with his addition to the 40-man roster. When he is efficient and challenges hitters, he has the look of an innings-eating, ground-ball machine.

PERSON was one of the top few pitchers in the class for a while, including all summer. He flashed 55 or 60 with all three pitches in short stints at multiple events, then came out this spring with more arm speed, sitting 93-96 and hitting 97 mph in most of his starts. His curveball also ticked up and flashed 65 or 70 on his best outings, and though he didn't throw his changeup much in high school, it did flash 55 over the summer. PERSON isn't very projectable and is an average athlete, while his command has been consistently below average with this higher octane stuff, so some teams worry this is a classic prep righty bust where clubs fall in love with the raw stuff. His velo would also sit 90-93 at times down the stretch and some teams are worried there could be a minor medical hiccup, which, combined with PERSON's $4 million pricetag and committment to GPE, could make him the second most likely prep player in the draft to go to college behind PERSON.

An athletic, toolsy outfielder, PERSON impressed in his first full professional season, reaching Double-A Harrisburg and finishing the year in the ORGANIZATION. He returned to both leagues in 2013 and had slightly better results.  PERSON knows how to get on base and, when he's right, uses the whole field to hit. He has worked to simplify his swing, but still has room for improvement, especially against left-handers. PERSON has some good pop, but his best tool is his plus speed. He uses it on the basepaths well and has the look of a future leadoff hitter. Defensively, he is solid in center field and has a good arm.  If PERSON can harness all his athleticism, he has the ability to become the ORGANIZATION center fielder of the future.

PERSON impressed scouts when he starred for GPE at the 18-and-under World Championships in the fall of 2012, but his stock fell when his stuff and delivery took a downturn at the World Baseball Classic the following spring. The ORGANIZATION still signed him for $1,625,000 as part of their 2013 international binge that also included since-traded stud prospects PERSON and PERSON. After PERSON made a successful 2014 pro debut in low Class A, his stuff regressed the next two years before bouncing back in 2017.PERSON's fastball dropped to the upper 80s in 2015-16 before climbing back to 90-93 mph this season. His fastball lacks life but he compensates by locating it well to both sides of the plate. He also has regained consistency with his changeup, his best pitch and a plus offering at its best.His tight curveball gives PERSON another solid secondary pitch. He's not afraid to challenge hitters and generally keeps the ball down in the strike zone, a must for a flyball pitcher with less-than-overpowering stuff. While he doesn't have a huge ceiling, he's one of GPE's more advanced rotation prospects and has a safe floor as a back-of-the-rotation starter.

At 6-foot-2 and close to 220 pounds, PERSON is one of the bigger prospects on the international market this year. He is also one of the best.PERSON has gained a reputation as a pure hitter and is considered the best hitter in the entire class by some evaluators. PERSON already like his plate discipline, and he is expected to improve in that area once he enters a team's academy and plays in games on a regular basis. PERSON has a knack for squaring up the ball and has also displayed the ability to hit for power to all fields during PERSON games.Physically, PERSON has a thick body and tons of raw power, and he has impressed scouts with his overall body strength. He will never be known for his speed on the bases, but his baseball IQ will keep him from running into outs while on the bases. PERSON agree that PERSON's offensive game is ahead of defensive game at the moment, but he has an accurate, above-average throwing arm and is expected to improve in the field with instruction and repetition.From PERSON, GPE, PERSON is trained by PERSON at ORGANIZATION PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are considered the favorite to sign the teenager.

Built like the prototypical GPE right-hander, PERSON was PERSON's Friday night starter this spring. His inconsistent results in that role didn't stop the Nationals from selecting him with their first pick of the 2013 Draft. Despite spending four years in college, PERSON is something of a project. He has a four-pitch arsenal, but is still more of a thrower than a pitcher. He throws his fastball in the mid-90s, but struggles to control it at times. He also throws a curveball, changeup and slider, all of which need more development. Scouts think PERSON profiles better in the bullpen, where his fastball would play up and he could concentrate on one off-speed pitch. For now, however, the Nationals are letting him develop as a starter.

The ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON in the 17th round out of a GPE high school, and he might have gone in the top five rounds if he hadn't been determined to pitch with his older brother PERSON at ORGANIZATION State. After a season with the the 49ers, PERSON spent one year each pitching with his twin brother PERSON at ORGANIZATION (Calif.) CC, where they won a state championship in 2014, and at FACILITY. A fourth-round pick last June, PERSON signed for $550,000.PERSON can reach 95 mph with his fastball but usually operates at 90-92 mph with a two-seamer that plays up because of its sink and his ability to command it. While his low-80s slider shows flashes of becoming a solid offering at times, he gets around it and turns it into a less effective slurve at others. He also needs more consistency with his splitter/changeup, though he trusts the pitch and can get swings and misses with it.PERSON has a compact delivery that he repeats well, allowing him to pound the bottom of the strike zone. His lack of a true plus pitch likely limits his ceiling to that of a No. 4 starter, but he's a good bet to reach it. The ORGANIZATION like the way he competes and also think he could become a seventh-inning reliever if needed.

PERSON has advanced quickly since the ORGANIZATION made him a fourth-round pick in 2013, playing in Double-A and PERSON last year at age 20. ORGANIZATION officials hail him as one of the smartest players and best leaders in their farm system, and his makeup and his game resemble those of former All-Star Walt Weiss.With quick feet and hands to go with solid arm strength, PERSON stands out more for his defense than his offense. He made 35 errors in 2015, up from 22 the year before, but GPE believes that he'll develop into a steady gloveman. He also has seen action at second base and eventually could be pushed there by PERSON, PERSON or PERSON Garcia.PERSON employs a contact approach from the left side of the plate, recognizing that he's not a power hitter and focusing on getting on base. He runs well and has a chance to make it as a No. 2 hitter, though he'll more likely fit toward the bottom of a lineup. He won't ever hit a lot of home runs, but he has added strength and began using his legs more in his swing during offseason work.

PERSON was an upside, cold-weather hitter to watch in the 2018 draft class but he exceeded expectations in the spring, rising into discussions for the middle of the first round. He landed near the top of a group of top-tier toolsy outfielders, flashing plus raw power, speed, and arm strength. He also went on a tear down the stretch in the ORGANIZATION state playoffs when high-level scouts were coming in for looks, hitting homer after homer. Some scouts were still uncertain about PERSON's ultimate upside, arguing that his style of hitting indicates a swing flaw. To possess premium bat speed and face pitching in the 80s and still hit opposite field homers indicates PERSON was late on subpar stuff, and his deep hand load (which helps create the power) means this approach and his ultimate upside might not work in pro ball. While it's too early to pass judgment on that opinion, PERSON struggled against good pitching in his pro debut and in instructional league, often exhibiting poor timing and ending up late on good fastballs. The Rays aren't worried -- expectations for cold-weather hitters are close to nil in their pro debut, not only because of the big jump in competition but also because they're playing the longest season of their lives. PERSON may start 2019 in extended spring training so the org can keep a close eye on his habits and challenges in a controlled environment, but his upside is still among the best in his draft class.

After going undrafted out of high school, PERSON spent the 2016 season at ORGANIZATION (Fla.) JC, where he showed dynamic athleticism and tools but produced uneven results. The ORGANIZATION still made him their 11th round pick that June, and he signed for $400,000.Much like they did with 2015 second-rounder PERSON, the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON with the intention of making him a switch-hitter. He's impressed the club with his aptitude in learning to hit from the left side, but, overall, he's a bit of a project at the plate. PERSON's elite speed is a weapon, both in center field and on the basepaths, but he needs to improve his basestealing technique. PERSON also has a well above-average arm, especially for center field. Team officials rave about PERSON's athleticism, speed and promising hitting ability, and the belief is that he'll eventually develop the necessary baseball skills.

Will the real PERSON please stand up? A star at FACILITY, PERSON entered pro ball as a first-round pick who was an advanced college performer at the plate, one who could hit for average and get on-base and he fit that profile during his first full season. When he got to Double-A for year two, however, he tapped into his raw power consistently, but at the expense of his hit tool. He capped off a year that saw him lead the organization in home runs and ORGANIZATION with a strong performance in the ORGANIZATION League.Few doubted that the big, strong PERSON had power to tap into as a professional, but they also knew that he wasn't focusing on that part of his game, instead relying on his ability to work counts and make contact. His decision to work on driving the ball did lead to run production, but also saw his strikeout rate go up and his walk rate diminish. The ORGANIZATION aren't overly upset that he's likely more power over hit now because, as an at least below-average runner, singles and walks aren't quite as effective.As PERSON changed his offensive profile for power, he was also working on his defense at first base, where it now looks like he'll be a solid defender with good hands and a strong arm. There's a chance PERSON could find a balance between his old and new selves at the plate, but the ORGANIZATION would be happy to see that kind of power production from the infield corner spot moving forward.

A bit of an enigma in college, PERSON dominated in the ORGANIZATION and PERSON college leagues during the summers but bounced between roles while battling his control during the springs at FACILITY A&M. He opened 2017 in the GPE bullpen before moving to the rotation in late March, pitching well until he tired in June. Drafted in the second round with a pick the ORGANIZATION received from the ORGANIZATION as punishment for the hacking scandal, he signed for a below-slot $1 million.PERSON worked with a 95-96 mph fastball and peaked at 98 as a Cape reliever, and he dialed it down to 91-95 to throw more strikes as a starter during the spring. His curveball can be just as overpowering, featuring both power and depth, and he also can miss bats with his mid-80s slider. He also exhibits some feel for a changeup that could develop into another solid offering as he uses it more often.There's no question that PERSON has enough pitches to make it as a starter. Recruited as a two-way player out of high school, he has athleticism that should help his control and durability. If he can't command his pitches well enough to stick in the rotation, he has late-inning upside as a reliever.

PERSON caught the attention of scouts when he hit 98 mph as a freshman in LOCATION, but he went just 8-17 in three seasons with the ORGANIZATION and lasted five rounds in the 2014 Draft. He recorded a 2.82 ERA in his first two full seasons as a pro starter, but struggled in a return to Double-A last year and moved to the bullpen in GPE. He made just six relief appearances before blowing out his elbow and having PERSON surgery that sidelined him for most of the 2018 season.After working at 92-95 mph with sink on his fastball as a starter, PERSON flashed upper-90s heat in his brief foray as a reliever last year. His mid-80s slider/cutter should play as a plus pitch more consistently in shorter stints. He has made progress with a sinking changeup, though it may never be more than an average offering and he won't use it much coming out of the bullpen.Though the ORGANIZATION have helped PERSON calm down his delivery since college, his walk rate has risen at every level as he has climbed through the Minors. He still could project as a No. 4 starter if he could improve his changeup and his command, but banking on his pair of power pitches and his competitiveness as a reliever is more realistic.

PERSON showed well in GPE's rotation as a sophomore but was unable to make progress the next year, spending much of the season in the bullpen with underwhelming results. The ORGANIZATION selected him in the 23rd round that June, and he pitched at both Class A levels during his full-season debut before advancing to Double-A in 2016 and making his big league debut early in the '17 season.A physically strong right-hander, PERSON pitches with a plus fastball that sits 94-96 mph and touches 97 with late sinking action that has resulted in strong ground-ball rates throughout his career. His low-80s slider plays well against right-handed hitters thanks to its depth and tilt, at times flashing above average, though his overall consistency with the pitch leaves much to be desired. PERSON holds his own against lefties in spite of his lack of a changeup, but he may need to add the pitch to his arsenal in order to retire them at the highest level.PERSON has the ability to work more than one inning, which he did in 23 of his 48 appearances (including four starts) in 2016. That stamina could make him a long reliever in the big leagues, though he does have the potential for a greater role if he can improve his slider and fastball command.

While the ORGANIZATION used some of their young pitching depth in trades during the offseason, that didnât leave that cupboard bare. As long as everyone can be patient, PERSON may help fill the void quite nicely. The nephew of former big league reliever PERSON, he will be just 18 years old for all of the 2013 season. PERSON has a plus fastball that can touch the mid-90s and he commands it pretty well. His slider will be solid in the future, though itâs a bit inconsistent right now and he has a better feel for a changeup than most teenagers. His overall command and pitchability is advanced for his age, which should enable him to continue to be young for his level, even if heâs developed cautiously.

An intriguing two-way prospect and athlete, PERSON had middling tools on both sides of the ball but had one of the biggest, most projectable frames in the draft. PERSON hoped he'd emerge during his junior spring, but PERSON fractured his elbow early in the season and was done for the year. He'll be a tough sign, but teams who think he could be a true two-way player may be motivated to pay him. He'll sit in the upper-80s on the mound and has a great curveball. Offensively, PERSON already has considerable power and will likely grow into more. He's also a massive, athletic target at first base.

PERSON was a well-known Atlanta-area prep prospect, who in high school was a strong statistical performer with easy plus raw power that showed up in games. He didn't have a clear positional fit as an amateur, and that's still mostly the case now--he was a shortstop in high school but wasn't an athletic fit there, tried catching but it didn't work, and scouts generally projected third base or first base long term. Though he has mostly played third, pro scouts see PERSON as a first base-only type, and he started seeing time there during the 2017 Fall League and again late in 2018. He missed much of 2018 with an 80-game ORGANIZATION suspension, which ominously came after a breakout 2017 campaign during which he hit 31 homers. He has now reached Triple-A, and had a strong half-season after the suspension was up, but scouts are wary of being all-in on a player whose entire profile is dependent on power and has also had a recent ORGANIZATION suspension. One-dimensional hitters who are limited on defense tend to end up in a first base platoon (and in this case, it'd be the lesser side of one) or as a low-end starter like PERSON. Either way, it seems unlikely a high-payroll, contending club like GPE would wait for a young player with limited upside to break in as an everyday player. We think PERSON is a low-end regular and that he may be trade bait once he further establishes his level of performance post-suspension.

The ORGANIZATION ace entered his junior season billed as the most advanced college pitcher in the class and he didn't disappoint, finishing among the ORGANIZATION Division I leaders in a host of pitching categories. That led to the Phillies taking him with the ORGANIZATION. 7 overall pick in the GPE. He signed quickly and made his professional debut all the way up in the ORGANIZATION State League.ORGANIZATIONt the biggest right-hander in the world, PERSON has tremendous command of his three-pitch mix. His fastball sits in the low 90s and appears even faster thanks to his low three-quarters arm slot. He locates to both sides and throws his fastball with plenty of sink. His changeup is plus at times and he throws his breaking ball for strikes at any point in the count.Among the 2014 pitching crop, PERSON is the best bet to reach his ceiling and likely will be the first starter to appear in the big leagues.

After a year of sitting 90-94, GPE's fastball velocity fluctuated pretty significantly both start-to-start and within individual games, often resting in the upper-80s like it did while he was in college. But he was also up to 95 at times, even reaching back for that kind of heat late in his starts. Some of the drop in velocity may have been artificial, a result of GPE working more on sinking and cutting his fastball rather than just throwing it hard. He's a plus on-mound athlete who we anticipate will be a sinker/changeup No. 4 or 5 starter relatively soon. His season ended in mid-July due to an oblique strain.

It's becoming fairly clear that PERSON is the type of guy who just plain hits. He may not profile well in any particular spot, but it's been said more than once that guys who hit get to the big leagues. He has a short, quick swing from the left side of the plate and shows the ability to make adjustments that could allow him to be an above-average hitter. He has more doubles/gap power, though there's the chance that he could maybe get to average power once he's big league ready. He's a fringy runner, at best, but his instincts have made him an excellent baserunner. He's played both outfield corners and while he doesn't fit the power profile for that, he doesn't have the speed and range to play center field every day. But he's a real gamer who comes to play every day, the type who'll be sure to maximize the tools he does have to overachieve.

PERSON starred at ORGANIZATION State PERSON for three years before going to the A's with ORGANIZATION. 25 overall pick in the 2014 Draft and signing for $1.75 million. A knee injury delayed the start of his first full season until May, and he missed most of the final two months while on the disabled list with an ailing wrist. That didn't keep PERSON from a breakout campaign, though, as he paced the A's system with 23 home runs despite playing only 80 games at ORGANIZATION A Advanced Stockton. PERSON has continued to showcase his huge power this season in the ORGANIZATION, and it would be a surprise if he didn't blow past his 2015 total in that department. PERSON's loud physical tools highlight his high-end combination of strength and athleticism. The right-handed hitter has some swing-and-miss to his game and will need to do a better job controlling the strike zone as he moves up the ladder, but he makes a lot of hard contact with a line-drive oriented swing, and he impressed with his feel for using the whole field last year during his time in the GPE. The power plays to all fields, too, thanks to his quick bat and his significant extension through point of contact, the combination of which could make him a 20-homer threat annually once fully developed.PERSON is a plus defender at third base with excellent hands and smooth actions as well as plus-plus arm strength that ranks among the best in the Minors at the position. Though his ultimate impact will depend on the development of his hit tool, PERSON's defense, along with his power potential, could still help him achieve an everyday role in the big leagues.

GPE underwent PERSON surgery during his sophomore year at GPE and didn't return to the mound until '14. The ORGANIZATION made him their fourth-round pick that June, and then limited his workload in his pro debut. GPE was dealt to the PERSON in a deal for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline the following year, and then impressed his new organization with a strong showing in the ORGANIZATION State League in 2016. A minor shoulder injury stemming from his time in the ORGANIZATION delayed the start of his 2017 campaign, but GPE's stuff has looked better than ever since beginning his season in June.GPE's arm strength is among the best in GPE's system, as he'll operate at 95-98 mph with late arm-side run that makes him difficult to square up. The right-hander complements his heater with a sharp, low-80s slider that flashes above average, and he also exhibits some feel for throwing a changeup.The PERSON will continue to develop GPE as a starter, but given his injury history, as well as his fastball-slider pairing and below-average control, the right-hander may ultimately assume a late-inning bullpen role.

Yet another prospect unearthed at an GPE junior college by the ORGANIZATION, PERSON batted .439/.545/.849 with more homers (20) than strikeouts (18) at ORGANIZATION in 2016. PERSON inside and outside of the organization believe he's one of the better all-around hitters in the ORGANIZATION system. He set career highs in most categories last season and continued to open eyes by ranking third in the ORGANIZATION in on-base percentage (.463), slugging (.561) and ORGANIZATION (1.023). A switch-hitter, PERSON has a better stroke and more power from the left side. Following a homerless pro debut, he started using his legs better in his swing and homered 31 times in his first two full seasons. He's a better hitter than his .248 career average might indicate, making repeated hard contact and drawing a healthy amount of walks.PERSON has a plus arm and reliable hands at third base, though he lacks quickness and has fringy range. He caught some at ORGANIZATION and in his first full season, but his bat was much more advanced than his receiving so the ORGANIZATION decided to focus on the former. He also played second base during the low Class A ORGANIZATION playoffs in 2017.

A star quarterback in high school, PERSON excelled as a reliever at GPE, compiling a 1.88 ERA in three seasons and ranking fourth in ORGANIZATION Division I with 16 saves in 2016. He gave the Ducks a reliever taken in the top 10 round for the fourth straight year -- following PERSON (D-backs), PERSON (Twins) and PERSON (GPE) -- and signed for a slightly below-slot $250,000 as a sixth-rounder. He had earned a mid-season promotion during his first full year when he was sent to the ORGANIZATION right before the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION deal.PERSON has more pitches than a typical reliever, using two versions of a fastball and both a slider and a cutter. He can sink a two-seam fastball in the low 90s and has more success with a four-seamer that reaches 96 mph and has an excessive spin rate that allows it to dodge bats up in the strike zone. Both his mid-80s slider and upper-80s cutter can be plus pitches at times, and he also can mix in a changeup with some fade.PERSON's control of his pitches fluctuates at times, but he generally throws enough strikes to keep himself out of trouble. The ORGANIZATION didn't hesitate to promote him, and if he continues to miss bats, he could continue to move quickly in the ORGANIZATION' system.

PERSON PERSON in GPE has had its fair share of talent come through its ranks, from 2004 first-rounder PERSON to 2011 sixth-rounder PERSON. Now it's PERSON's turn.PERSON has the chance to have three Major League average or better offerings from a strong and athletic pitcher's frame. His fastball will sit in the 91-92 mph range, with good movement, and he can reach back for a little extra. His sharp slider has the chance to be a strikeout pitch in the future, and he keeps his changeup down in the zone with good arm speed and deception.PERSON has good mound presence and has a good idea of what he's doing on the mound. That's not a huge surprise considering that if he doesn't go pro, he's headed to the ORGANIZATION of GPE to play for his father, PERSON.

PERSON didn't enter the spring of 2013 with much fanfare, and his teammate PERSON was considered to be PERSON's best Draft-eligible pitcher. That quickly changed as PERSON's fastball was regularly clocked up to 100 mph and he jumped into the conversation for the top overall pick before settling at ORGANIZATION. 3 overall with the Rockies.PERSON has excellent size for a right-hander, and he uses it to generate easy velocity. He throws his fastball in the mid- to upper 90s. His slider is his best offspeed pitch and he also throws a solid changeup. PERSON displayed impressive command in his professional debut and pitches well off his fastball.It didn't take long for PERSON to reach PERSON after signing, then went right to Double-A for his full-season debut. He has the stuff to become a front-line starter.

The FACILITY saw enough of GPE after he threw sparingly as a reliever in four years at ORGANIZATION to sign him for $50,000 in the 16th round of the 2011 Draft, and they converted him to a starter in the middle of his first full pro season and watched him lead the system with 138 strikeouts in 2013. He didn't start his 2014 season until mid-July because of a broken hand suffered in an off-field incident. He did come back to make his Major League debut, making six appearances -- five of them starts -- late in the year, before finishing things off with a strong stint as a reliever in the ORGANIZATION. The A's got him as part of the package they received in return for PERSON in December.GPE has streamlined and sped up his delivery since turning pro, allowing him to get more leverage out of his 6-foot-5 frame. That helped him add velocity, and he now sits at 91-93 mph and touches 95 with his fastball. GPE's heater is his lone plus pitch, so he has a ceiling of a back-of-the-rotation starter and may wind up back in the bullpen down the road. His fringy changeup is his best secondary offering, and he struggles at times to stay on top of his curveball and slider. There's some effort in GPE's delivery, costing him some command.

A two-way player as a ORGANIZATION freshman before becoming a full-time hitter, PERSON led the Flames to their first ORGANIZATION regional final in 2013 before signing for $100,000 as an 11th-rounder. He totaled 31 homers and 41 steals in his first two full pro seasons, though he batted just .217/.263/.335 after he reached Double-A last June. He fared better in his return to that level in 2016, only to be traded to the ORGANIZATION in early September as the ORGANIZATION in the deal that sent PERSON and PERSON to PERSON at the ORGANIZATION.  PERSON showed some of the best all-around tools in the ORGANIZATION' system and has a chance to be average or better across the board. He has the bat speed and strength to hit for power, and he showed the feel for hitting and sound approach to produce solid batting averages when he was in the lower Minors. PERSON didn't control his swing or the strike zone as well against more advanced pitchers in Double-A last year, though his ability to make adjustments when he returned there bodes well for his future. PERSON has plus speed that helps him steal bases and cover ground in the outfield. PERSON entered his senior year of high school as a talented two-sport project with a, having size and arm speed, but inconsistent command, offspeed stuff, and somewhat strange east/west elements to his delivery. While there's a wide array of potential outcomes for PERSON's fastball, his command, breaking ball quality, prototypical frame, and mechanical consistency have been stable. It sets up his best pitch, his changeup, and he also mixes in cutters and curveballs.PERSON is a quality athlete for his size and has a fluid delivery, which allows him to fill the strike zone with ease. His ceiling is limited to a No. 4 or 5 starter, but he's a good bet to reach it.

After pitching sparingly in three college seasons at LOCATION, PERSON signed as a seventh-round pick in 2016 and quickly established himself as the best left-handed pitching prospect in the FACILITY system. Then his stuff regressed in his first full pro season, which ended three weeks early after he strained an oblique. Working with diminished velocity helped him become a better pitcher, however, and he has consistently registered quality starts throughout '18.PERSON' fastball velocity fluctuated from 88-97 mph with the Trojans, parked at 92-97 during his pro debut, but sat around 90 mph in 2017. He's working at 90-94 mph this year, giving him more separation from a quality changeup that can be a well above-average pitch at its best. He has tightened his curveball in '18 and also will mix in a slider/cutter.PERSON' control was as inconsistent as his fastball in college, but he has pounded the strike zone throughout his pro career. Though he doesn't have a plus pitch and doesn't miss a lot of bats -- both of which limit his ceiling -- he has a reasonably high floor as a back-of-the-rotation starter.

GPE is an above-average runner, defender and thrower, but scouts aren't completely sold on him offensively, projecting him as a gap-to-gap hitter with modest power. PERSON had the trump card to sign him earlier this year and wouldn't top the rumored $2 million price he was offered to wait for July 2nd, 2019.

In the final Draft before bonus pools came into play, PERSON turned pro for $675,000 as a 29th-round pick in 2011 out of an Illinois high school. He signed late that summer and spent two years in different Rookie leagues, so he didn't reach full-season ball until 2014. He has improved consistently in the last three seasons and has one of the best combinations of stuff and strike-throwing ability among GPE mound prospects. As he has gotten stronger during the last couple of years, PERSON has added velocity and now works at 92-94 mph and tops out at 96 with his sinking fastball. He has gotten more consistent with his hard curveball and demonstrates good feel for his changeup, which features some fade and sink.PERSON averaged 19 points per game in basketball as a prep senior and had intriguing power potential as a third baseman that could have made him a two-way player had PERSON not signed him away from a GPE PERSON commitment. That athleticism and his sound delivery have allowed him to fill the strike zone since he turned pro. He's generating better plane on his pitches this year, and he has the durability and makeup to perhaps become a No. 3 or 4 starter.

The ORGANIZATION have had some success in developing young pitchers taken out of high school â see GPE, PERSON and PERSON, PERSON â and PERSON might be the next in line. He's big, strong and athletic, albeit raw. His fastball is easily plus, though he's still learning to command it. While he throws two breaking balls, and both can be effective at times, his slider is the better offering, one that eventually could become a plus pitch. His changeup has improved, though it's behind his other offerings. All the pieces are there for him to be a frontline starter. All he needs is time and experience to tighten his command and improve his offspeed stuff and he'll be ready.

A candidate for the first pick in the 2015 Draft, PERSON saw that dream end when he had PERSON surgery that April. Though he dropped to the third round, the ORGANIZATION paid him $2 million, the equivalent of first-round money. They hoped to have him work 100 innings in his first pro season, but his elbow began bothering him after his initial three-inning outing and they shut him down again.When he was healthy at ORGANIZATION, PERSON looked like a No. 1 starter. He sat at 93-97 mph with running life on his fastball and had a pair of swing-and-miss breaking balls in his curveball and slider. He also showed feel for a changeup and found the strike zone with ease.PERSON's 6-foot-6 frame creates angle and plane on his pitches that makes them more difficult to hit. He has No. 1 starter upside but has a long way to go to prove he can hold up physically after working just 145 2/3 innings (including summer ball) in three years of college. In addition to his elbow reconstruction, he also has spondylolysis, a manageable defect of the vertebrae in the lower back.

The ace of a 2013 PERSON pitching staff that included PERSON second-round choice PERSON, PERSON finished among the ORGANIZATION Division I leaders in wins (12), ORGANIZATION (1.57), strikeouts (122), K-BB ratio (6.8) and ORGANIZATION (0.80). He helped the ORGANIZATION end a three-year absence from the ORGANIZATION World Series and finished his sophomore season without allowing an earned run in his final 26 2/3 innings. He extended that streak to 54 innings this spring, when he has been better than ever.PERSON isn't physical or overpowering, but he has exquisite command of his three-pitch arsenal. He effortlessly works at 91-93 mph with his fastball, which plays up because his low three-quarters arm slot produces sink and he can locate the pitch wherever he wants. His changeup is his best secondary pitch, grading as plus at times, and he can throw his three-quarters breaking ball for strikes. Among the 2014 pitching crop, PERSON is the best bet to reach his ceiling and likely will be the first starter to appear in the big leagues. His older brother PERSON, who teamed with PERSON at ORGANIZATION in 2012, is a slick-fielding shortstop in the ORGANIZATION system.

PERSON was a famous name in this class as a sophomore in high school when his loose, quick arm was running his fastball into the mid-90's. Since then, PERSON has filled out considerably at roughly 6'5/250, taking after his father PERSON, a former ORGANIZATION defensive tackle who is the defensive line coach for GPE. PERSON topped out at 99 mph over the summer and has been considered a first round pick for years, but had his worst outing of the spring in his last outing, losing a playoff matchip to PERSON. At his best this spring, PERSON would sit 93-96, hitting 98 mph with a hellacious two-plane slider that was a 65 or 70 pitch for most scouts. His changeup wasn't needed much but flashed average at times and his command was average with control a hair better than that, though some scouts don't love his mechanics.

The questions on PERSON were 1) maintaining his current physique 2) maintaining his athleticism to repeat his delivery and stay a starter and 3) having enough feel to pitch and deception to flourish when he doesn't have his premium stuff. PERSON was often pitching on a week or more of rest this spring, so scouts didn't see diminished stuff until the ORGANIZATION outing, when PERSON was sitting mostly 90-93 mph, dipping into the high 80's in the 4th inning with a breaking ball that was a 50 or 55. His command wasn't as good that day and PERSON was hit around some, visibly frustrated. Granted that was one outing, but it could be considered a concern about a prep pitcher with no physical projection that will likely lose a tick or two of velocity as he matures.

Sits 92-94, will touch 97, has a an explosive but violent arm action, plus slider and started missing some bats with his changeup this year. But PERSON has had fluctuations in weight (he was in good shape this season, but not last) and served multiple team-imposed suspensions, finally culminating in his dismissal from the club a month before the draft.

Extremely projectable and athletic, PERSON could prove to be a steal as a ninth-rounder from the 2012 Draft. The ORGANIZATION thought enough of him to send him to low Class A as an 18-year-old to open '13, and while he struggled at first, he fared better once he returned there in mid-August after a demotion.PERSON generates easy velocity on his fastball, working from 90 to 95 mph and showing the ability to cut and sink the pitch. All three of his secondary pitches have the potential to become average or better down the road, with his curveball currently rating ahead of his slider and changeup.PERSON will need to do a better job of trusting his stuff as he advances. He's also working on smoothing out his delivery so he can throw more strikes. PERSON is still just 19, so he has plenty of time.

It's easy to see why some consider PERSON the top ORGANIZATION prospect in an impressive class of players from the country this year. The 6-foot-2, 175-pound PERSON does everything well and has the potential to be a five-tool player. Scouts have been impressed with the teenager's overall strength and his athletic build. They also like that PERSON can cover ground in the outfield and make all of the plays. Projected as a right fielder, he has been compared to a young PERSON because of his arm and raw power. Other scouts view PERSON as a better fit in left field. Evaluators talk about PERSON's presence on the field. He's a competitor and he is confident. PERSON also shown good work habits and leadership qualities.PERSON is based in GPE la Cruz, GPE, and is trained by PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are considered the favorite to ink the outfielder to a deal.

A college shortstop and closer, PERSON was viewed by the amateur arm of the scouting body as a third base prospect with big power. He was GPE's 2016 second rounder, then was traded the following summer as part of the Luzardo/Doolittle/Madson deal. He wrapped his 2017 season with short, statistically insignificant stints in Hi-A, Double-A, and the ORGANIZATION, but he performed at each stop, so combined there was confidence that PERSON's early-season showing was for real despite his relatively advanced age. 
He was sent right to Triple-A to start 2018 and flopped, hitting just .263/.304/.357 and striking out a concerning 32% of the time. PERSON has also thickened a bit, so while he's still an arm-reliant fit at third, he's trending more toward 3B/1B, and maybe right, than the SS/3B looks GPE gave him early in his career. The combination of the 2018 struggles and somewhat shaky standing on the defensive spectrum makes it imperative that PERSON have a bounce back 2019 performance. He's a baseball rat and younger than similarly-skilled players we've written up so far (like ORGANIZATION third baseman J.D. PERSON), so we're a little more bullish on a rebound here than we are elsewhere. If he struggles again it's perhaps worth considering two-way duty. PERSON was up to 96 in our looks at him in college.

The ORGANIZATION made PERSON their first-round pick (ORGANIZATION. 14 overall) in 2010, and he was set to sign until a post-Draft physical revealed that he had diabetes. He ultimately decided to stay close to home and attend the ORGANIZATION of GPE, where he produced mixed results before going to the A's in the fourth round of the 2013 Draft. After missing much of 2016 with injuries, most notably a strained oblique, he performed well in the ORGANIZATION and got picked by the FACILITY in the ORGANIZATION phase of the Rule 5 Draft.PERSON can run his fastball up to 95 mph but typically sits between 89-93 mph with heavy sink. His best pitch often is his changeup, which features splitter action. He also throws a curveball and slider, both of which have their moments but usually grade as average offerings.Because PERSON lacks a plus pitch, he must keep the ball down in the strike zone to succeed. He doesn't have huge upside as a starter, but he could be an innings eater toward the back of a rotation. Rule 5 mandates that GPE keep him on its active big league roster throughout the 2017 season, or else put him on waivers and offer him back to GPE for half of his $100,000 Draft price.
PERSON stood out for PERSON with a plus heater, above average breaker and solid command, though likely only in relief.

The ORGANIZATION have acquired PERSON twice, first when they drafted him in 2010 and then again in March 2013 in the ORGANIZATION deal. In between, PERSON was part of the package they sent to the A's for PERSON. After a disappointing year with the A's, PERSON broke out in his return to the ORGANIZATION, reaching Double-A Harrisburg and pitching in the 2013 ORGANIZATION.  PERSON relies on his fastball, which sits in the mid-90s and reaches 98 mph. He commands the pitch well and isn't afraid to come after hitters with it. Though both his changeup and curveball aren't as advanced as his fastball, both have the potential to be Major League-average offerings.  If PERSON can hone his offspeed pitches, he has the potential to be the latest homegrown member of the ORGANIZATION rotation.

Jenkins is a quick-twich athlete that made strides last summer turning his tools into skills and continued that this spring. He's a plus plus runner with some bat speed and bat control, but needs to work on consistency.

An outstanding athlete who played football in high school, ORGANIZATION gave up the gridiron to focus on the diamond and take a baseball scholarship to GPE. The Indians were able to sign him away from honoring that commitment. ORGANIZATION has some tools, particularly with a bat in his hands. He has excellent bat speed and should grow into plenty of power as he matures. He has above-average speed, but whether he stays in center field remains to be seen â he saw some time in left field as well during his pro debut --  but he could have enough bat to profile just fine at an outfield corner spot.

PERSON was the ace starter for one of the most prospect-laden prep teams in the country in 2015, PERSON, which was led by 11th overall pick catcher PERSON (Reds) and center fielder PERSON (ORGANIZATION), who got a $500,000 bonus in the 24th round. PERSON could've received a low-to-mid six figure bonus out of high school, but instead went to PERSON, where he mostly relieved, a role that agrees with his aggressive approach and standout fastball/curveball combination. PERSON's command backed up a bit in 2018, which is why he lasted until the fifth round despite being the sort of up-in-the-zone four-seam fastball and power curveball reliever that clubs now favor due to ORGANIZATION data. If he can dial in his delivery and command, there's quick-moving setup man potential for the 22-year-old.

So conservative was PERSON' swing when he first arrived in the states that ORGANIZATION coaches were trying to make adjustments to his lower-half use in the middle of games in the hopes that it would unlock power that was clearly dormant in his hands. He has good control of the strike zone and feel to hit for a teenager but despite playing some second and third, he may ultimately wind up at first base. If that's the case, a change that enables the power is necessary.

It's a good year for hard-throwing pitchers in the GPE junior college ranks, with a few who have the chance to go in the top three rounds. PERSON put up video-game type numbers at ORGANIZATION this spring, raising his Draft profile in the process, then created a huge amount of buzz by hitting triple digits consistently in a bullpen session in late May. There is no question about the quality of PERSON's fastball coming from his 6-foot-6 frame. He was consistently up to 97 mph all spring and has shown an ability to throw strikes with it as well. His secondary stuff, however, has been inconsistent. He throws both a slider and a curve, though the latter is his fourth pitch, and on some days he has two distinct, effective breaking balls. At other times, they run together, and it might serve him well to focus on just one at the next level. His changeup has improved, but it also comes and goes. There is an injury history with PERSON -- he had a screw put in his right elbow in high school -- but he's been nothing but healthy and durable in junior college. There's some debate over whether his future lies in the rotation or out of the bullpen, where his stuff would play up, but there's bound to be a team that believes he can start that will take him in the early rounds.

PERSON didn't sign as a 2nd rounder last year for unclear reasons and has had an up-and-down senior year, but his stuff was a little better down the stretch, likely allowing PERSON to go in the 2nd round again but now with less leverage and at nearly 23 years old.

Slowly and steadly, PERSON is turning himself into a very intriguing second base prospect. A shortstop in high school, he's worked diligently to become a better defender and while some thought a move to the outfield would be in his future, few doubt his ability to stay on the right side of the infield. PERSON has excellent speed and is a top-notch baserunner who should continue to steal bases as he moves up the ladder. He definitely has some ability with the bat and if he can tone down his approach a bit he has the chance to hit for a high average and tap into his average power. He played in just 67 games during his full-season debut in 2012, with an elbow injury ending his year in June. A healthy season in 2013 could help him take off.

GPE of a stellar GPE collegiate national team outfield with PERSON's PERSON and GPE's PERSON last summer, PERSON can't quite match their tools, but he did establish himself as the best pure hitter on the squad. He led PERSON in hitting (.386) and on-base percentage (.491) and projected as a mid-first-round pick. He hasn't been the same since having a cyst removed from his lower back last fall, however, with multiple scouts noting that he has looked stiff and his tools have regressed this spring. At his best, PERSON employs a sleek left-handed swing and delivers line drives from gap to gap. He has above-average raw pop and started to become more aggressive and drive the ball more often in 2015. He hasn't looked as fluid or powerful during a disappointing regular season this year but did help his cause by winning the LOCATION tournament ORGANIZATION award in late May in front of a bevy of scouts.While PERSON showed solid speed and arm strength with PERSON, both tools have elicited fringe-average grades in 2016. He profiled well as a right fielder in the past, but now scouts don't know what to make of him. A club that gives him the benefit of the doubt for past performance could take him in the first three rounds.

The pitches PERSON threw on the final day of GPE's 2018 fall instructional league were his first in more than two years due to an unfortunately-timed PERSON and subsequent rehabilitation. He topped out at 92. In high school, PERSON had No. 4 starter stuff. At his best, he'd sit 90-94 with pinpoint glove-side command of an above-average slider. He was in the 2016 draft's crowded late-first and early-second round prep pitching picture, a group that hasn't yet seen anyone emerge as several have required ORGANIZATION reconstruction. PERSON probably moves into the 40+ FV tier if his velocity and breaking ball are back in the spring, but he's clearly behind the developmental curve for a 21-year-old.

A basketball standout who averaged 19.6 points and 7.8 rebounds per game as a junior, PERSON tore the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee in the second game of his senior season in December. He returned to the mound this April, sooner than expected, and showed enough to merit an early-round selection in the GPE. But he was going to be a tough sign because of his strong commitment to GPE, and then word came out that he needed PERSON surgery in late May.Like his cousin, PERSON, PERSON is a tall right-hander who could blossom into a first-round pick after three years of college. He's very athletic, has a loose arm and has plenty of room to add strength and velocity in the future. PERSON's fastball presently is more notable for its heavy sink and downhill plane than its power. He usually operates at 86-90 mph and top outs at 92. He commands his fastball and mid-70s curveball well, though he'll have to develop his changeup and use it more often at the next level.

A multisport star in high school, PERSON's success on the gridiron at FACILITY (GPE) High led to a scholarship offer to play quarterback at ORGANIZATION. He also excelled on the track, where he won a gold medal in long jump and two relays in his school's division at the 2014 GPE state championships. But PERSON ultimately chose to pursue a career in baseball, signing with the ORGANIZATION for $1,316,000 in 2014 as a second-round pick.PERSON is an exceptional athlete with promising tools, but he's struggled to translate that into production to begin his career. There's a fair amount of swing-and-miss in his game now, and with just 12 walks through 161 pro games across his first two pro seasons, he'll need to tighten his approach considerably in the coming years. PERSON is physically strong and generates good bat speed, and scouts believe he'll eventually tap into his above-average raw power.PERSON's double-plus speed is his greatest asset on the dirt, though he's very much a work in progress defensively. The ORGANIZATION were pleased with his growth at the position in 2015, and particularly with the improved consistency of his throwing. But after receiving considerable work at second base during instructional league in the fall, PERSON has manned the keystone exclusively in 2016.

PERSON was sandwiched between PERSON and PERSON in the 2010 Draft. PERSON and GPE are both already All-Stars. PERSON was on the verge of joining them in the ORGANIZATION before it was discovered that he needed PERSON surgery in April 2014.PERSON is a classic power right-hander, mixing good size with a mid-90s fastball and a hard curveball. His changeup has also made strides, giving him a chance for three above-average pitches. PERSON's fastball has good sinking action, but it tends to flatten out and become easier to hit if he leaves it up in the zone.PERSON commands his pitches well and earns praise for his poise and confidence on the mound. The ORGANIZATION hope he will be able to join PERSON at the front of their big league rotation once he recovers from surgery.
GPE beast from cold weather locale. Has feel for spin and changeup, velo was trending up in the fall, coming out 90-94 in a highly-scouted appearance.

PERSON was worked hard at ORGANIZATION, sometimes throwing about 120 pitches several starts in a row, and his velocity was down after last year's draft. He's a big-framed guy with average stuff that plays up due to extension and his fastball has life that competes in the strike zone. Realistically he's a fifth or sixth starter but let's see how the fastball plays and what happens to the velocity when PERSON is handled in a way that prioritizes development rather than winning Big 12 games.

ORGANIZATION GPE has had one first-round pick in its history: PERSON, back in 2009. While PERSON won't beat PERSON's record of being taken No. 32 overall, the first baseman put together a strong junior season that helped his ORGANIZATION stock considerably.PERSON' calling card is his power. Big and strong, he's shown the ability to hit the ball out, finishing among the ORGANIZATION leaders in home runs last summer. There can be a little length to his swing, and he tends to be a pull hitter, sometimes to a fault. PERSON isn't a runner and has played first base at ORGANIZATION GPE the past two years, though he played an outfield corner as a freshman and on the Cape.Regardless of where he plays defensively, the team that takes him in the first five rounds will be buying his bat and the power potential it brings with it.

After swinging a relatively inconsistent bat for much of his career at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, PERSON got hot late, lifting himself to the second round of the 2016 Draft. The adjustments he had made to show that improvement continued into the ORGANIZATION World Series and his pro debut, where he hit for average and power in the ORGANIZATION York-Penn League. A broken hand forced him out for six weeks of his full-season debut, but he was swinging the bat well again early in the second half of 2017.PERSON had shortened his swing and used the whole field more effectively during his junior season, and he carried that over last summer. There had been questions about his hit tool, but he didn't show that in GPE, striking out well below the leave average rate and making good adjustments. If he can continue sticking to his solid game plan, that will allow him to tap into his tremendous raw power -- some evaluators put a 70 on it -- with more consistency. While he's a well below-average runner, PERSON is a solid defender at first.The industry often doesn't like the right-right first base only profile, and PERSON will have to continue to prove he can hit to move past that stigma. If the start to his career is any indication, he has the chance to do just that and be a run-producing presence in the middle of a big league lineup.

One of the best hitters in the class, PERSON might also be the best infield prospect out of GPE this year. The teen has a projectable body and good control on both sides of the ball that reminds some scouts of PERSON at the same age.PERSON might not be the best runner on the field at any given moment, but he could be the most well-rounded. Scouts like his easy actions on defense and smooth swing at the plate. Evaluators have taken note of his emerging raw power and an arm that is strong enough to move to third base if he has to switch positions. His tools might lack the "wow factor" that some of the other top prospects possess, but he is considered one of the most consistent, and therefore, one of the most coveted prospects on the market.PERSON, who starred at ORGANIZATION's ORGANIZATION in February, is from GPE, GPE, and trains with PERSON. The Indians are considered the favorite to land the teenager.

The projectable right-hander has had trouble turning his raw potential into performance thus far In his brief career. The ORGANIZATION sent PERSON to full-season ball in 2011 and he struggled, walking more batters than he struck out. He cut his walk rate in 2012, but he was down a level in the short-season LOCATION and didn't have much other success. His ceiling, athleticism and arm strength still make him worth watching. He still has the potential to have a plus fastball, though his secondary pitches and, obviously, his command need a lot of work.

All Boyd did during his career at ORGANIZATION State was hit and that's continued as he embarked on his first full season of pro ball, quickly earning a promotion up a level. The right-handed hitting first baseman should hit for plenty of average as he moves up the ladder, but it remains to be seen just how much power there is in his bat. A former third baseman, he plays a very solid defensive first base, though it's his bat that will have to carry him up the organizational ladder. How much power he ends up displaying will help determine if he can be an everyday player at first.

PERSON was the first true shortstop taken in the 2013 Draft, and the fifth high school position player selected. PERSON, taken from the junior college ranks one pick after PERSON, beat him to the big leagues, but PERSON, even despite lackluster numbers, still has every chance to be an elite-level impact talent at the premium position.While reaching the highest level of the Minors at a very young age, PERSON has managed to keep his advanced approach at the plate, continuing to draw a ton of walks and keep his strikeout rate low. While he makes a ton of contact, his power hasn't really shown up yet, though there is still hope he will grow into 10-15 home run performer as he matures. PERSON also continues to display outstanding defensive skills at short. Even though he has just average speed, he has tremendous range, footwork and hands to go along with a plus arm.PERSON's numbers should be digested with the knowledge that he is still just 22 years old, but the lack of production does start to be concerning. There's still plenty of time for him to develop into the All-Star caliber shortstop at the big league level everyone thought he'd be.

He's not especially toolsy or projectable, but PERSON is so polished in all facets (especially his reads in center field) that it was he who the ORGANIZATION called up when early-season injury dominos necessitated that the they push a low-level outfielder to Hi-A. When PERSON was sent back to developmentally appropriate Low-A PERSON, he excelled. Tough to beat with only velocity because of how short his swing is, PERSON hit .322 for PERSON and would have won the ORGANIZATION batting title had he taken enough at-bats to qualify, but his hand was struck by a pitch in early July, ending his season. The general consensus is that PERSON may ultimately have limited value due to a lack of power, and end up either as a fourth outfielder or a regular on par with what PERSON or PERSON have been to this point, and we agree that range of outcomes is most likely. But PERSON entered 2018 with a more open, upright stance that seemed to benefit his timing and enabled him to pull the ball more, so perhaps last year's power output isn't a complete mirage and there are some right-tail paths to everyday production.

PERSON had some late helium ahead of the 2017 Draft after he hit 102 mph during a heavily scouted bullpen session in late May. The ORGANIZATION ended up selecting the ORGANIZATION of ORGANIZATION product with the second of their two first-round picks the following month, signed him for slightly above slot value at $2,452,900 and then watched him light up radar guns during a dominant pro debut. PERSON's first full season lasted just 1 2/3 innings as he suffered a fractured right forearm after being struck by a line drive in early May, but he returned to the mound and impressed in the ORGANIZATION, finishing with a series of strong outings after a rusty start.PERSON features front-of-the-rotation stuff when he's healthy, including the best fastball and slider in GPE's system. His fastball sits in the upper 90s and routinely touches triple digits, and he showed he could run his heater up to 103-104 during an all-out first inning in the ORGANIZATION. His slider is a similarly powerful offering, thrown in the upper 80s with late, glove-side bite that leads to both whiffs and weak contact, especially against righties. He showed feel for landing a top-to-bottom curveball in the zone during the ORGANIZATION, giving him a solid change-of-pace breaking ball, and his changeup should be at least average once developed.PERSON uses his height to his advantage, creating a downhill angle to the plate so as to pound his fastball and slider down in the zone, and he's athletic enough to believe that both his control and command will improve as he gains experience. Few pitching prospects in the Minors can match PERSON's high ceiling, and he can move closer to reaching it with a healthy campaign in 2019.

Originally a fourth-round Draft pick of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON was sent to GPE for PERSON in December 2011. PERSON had been a reliever in 2010 and 2011 in the Oriolesâ system, and thatâs how he started the 2012 season, his first with the ORGANIZATION. He was dominating the Class A Advanced PERSON, posting a 0.98 ERA, a .208 ORGANIZATION and seven saves out of the bullpen. The ORGANIZATION tried him out in the rotation, and that experiment started out well, until he hit a wall in July and August, finishing with 4.53 ERA and .304 ORGANIZATION in 11 starts. Any team considering him in the Rule 5 will surely be looking at him back in a bullpen role.

There's an epidemic of baseball personnel calling one another 'coach' that is believed to be derived from the lexicon of PERSON' signing area scout. That scout finds players, coach, as PERSON is another in a long line of ORGANIZATION late-round steals at smaller colleges in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON traded him to GPE in the ORGANIZATION Gausman deal last summer, during PERSON' breakout season. Before 2018, PERSON would sit in the mid-90s, reach 97, and mix in a solid average slider, but the off-speed consistency and command weren't strong. Both of those things ticked up in 2018 at Triple-A, but regressed during PERSON' 11.2 inning ORGANIZATION debut. Like PERSON, PERSON will look to put his late summer struggles with the new club behind him and reach his upside as a middle reliever in 2019.

Ever since signing out of GPE in 2014 at age 16 in 2014, PERSON has shown a feel for pitching that belies his age and experience. While that hasn't translated to consistent statistical success as of yet, the organization thought highly enough to send him to the ORGANIZATION for PERSON's playoff run in 2016, giving up two runs in 10 innings over two starts. He made his full-season debut in 2017 at the age of 19.Based on a radar gun, PERSON's fastball is fringy, in the 89-91 mph range, but it plays up because of its life and his ability to command it well. There might be more in the tank velocity-wise as he physically matures and he's already shown a penchant for groundball outs. His best secondary pitch is his changeup, which could be a plus pitch when all is said and done. He throws a big, looping curve ball which will need refinement as he moves up the ladder, but he did start missing more bats in 2016.While PERSON throws a ton of strikes, improvement of his command within the zone will help him continue to miss bats and generate weak contact, as he's been a bit too hittable in the early stages of his career. With time and physical maturity, he could develop into a solid back half of the rotation starter.

The ORGANIZATION went above pick value in the 10th round of the 2013 Draft, giving PERSON $200,000 to sign out of ORGANIZATION in GPE, because they saw a potential up-the-middle player with special defensive skills. PERSON' thick lower half and average arm portend a move to second base, where his footwork and quick actions could make him an above average defender. GPE has started convincing more people in baseball that he's a capable defensive shortstop, drawing PERSON defensive comparisions because of his size. He's hitting and already performing at Double-A at age 20. He projects as an above-average everyday player right now, but his stock is rising.

ORGANIZATION's Friday night starter in 2014, PERSON's solid pro debut in the ORGANIZATION had the ORGANIZATION excited about seeing what he can do in his first full year of pro ball, and he largely hasn't disappointed.PERSON has the makings of the kind of three-pitch mix that can sit in a big league rotation one day, with both his fastball and curve grading out as at least above-average. GPE viewed as a high-risk, high-reward prospect for his massive raw power and penchant for striking out, PERSON began to shed that label in 2017. Scouting grades: Hit: 45 | Power: 60 | Run: 20 | Arm: 60 | Field: 40 | Overall: 50PERSON is the most intriguing two-way player available in the 2015 Draft. He may not have the highest ceiling in the world, but he's the kind of player who finds his way onto winning ballclubs.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 4, 2017 - PERSON, Calif.Favorite ORGANIZATION Team: GPE ORGANIZATION ORGANIZATION Player: PERSON, a 6-foot-4 outfielder from GPE, has committed to play for ORGANIZATION. GPE spent 2018 in the ORGANIZATION and should come stateside in 2019. PERSON was shelved with a back injury during the summer of 2016 but was healthy and turned loose on the ORGANIZATION in 2017. PERSON agreed to a $6.5 million bonus with the ORGANIZATION as the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall GPE pick in 2014 only to have the club cut the offer to $5 million after a post-GPE physical raised concerns about his left elbow. Signed by the ORGANIZATION out of the ORGANIZATION for $75,000 in 2009, PERSON began reaching triple digits with his fastball when he made his GPE debut in 2012. The ORGANIZATION liked PERSON's bat so much, they gave him seven figures to sign in 2012 and then let him make his pro debut stateside, in the ORGANIZATION in 2013. PERSON's crafty application of pretty average stuff enabled him to strike out a batter per inning at ORGANIZATION Beach last season, albeit as a prospect of relativley advanced age. PERSON didn't start pitching full time until he hit the junior college ranks, then he spent two seasons as PERSON's closer. Low-90s lefty with a good slider. PERSON frame.

The ORGANIZATION of GPE ace makes you take notice with a quick, loose arm and a plus fastball -- one that has touched 98 mph. But he's more than just fastball velocity. PERSON ORGANIZATION and PERSON represented the ORGANIZATION high school ranks in the first round of the Draft in 2011. In 2012, it was PERSON's turn. The stringy PERSON has arguably the most copious physical projection in the class and some scouts think his frame has room to add about 30 pounds while still retaining the range and flexibility for shortstop. PERSON GPE and PERSON were the marquee names among GPE high school pitchers entering the year, but PERSON joined them on the ORGANIZATION USA pitching staff that won a gold medal at the 18-and-under World Cup last September and has surpassed them both this spring. PERSON's first full season of pro ball after being taken from the high school ranks in GPE in 2013 was truncated considerably when the outfielder struck out and punched a wall, breaking his hand. PERSON began his incredible run in 2013 by winning the ORGANIZATION at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, and he ended it by winning the ORGANIZATION in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON was a Spring Training sensation for the ORGANIZATION in 2011 and appeared on the verge of reaching ORGANIZATION. Woods-Richardson broke out on the showcase circuit last summer, running his fastball up to 95 mph at the ORGANIZATION Games and showing three-pitch potential at multiple events. PERSON is going to strike out but he has above-average pull power that he's learning to tap into in games, runs well, and should be fine at third. Some scouts believe that only PERSON has more raw power than PERSON in this year's class. PERSON performed in Double-A and Triple-A in 2018 and was added to the 40-man this winter. PERSON's stock rose all spring as he helped PERSON (Fla.) to a Class 3A state championship. Another bargain international signing for the GPE, PERSON turned pro for $45,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in 2011. An everyday player at multiple infield positions for Michigan the last three years, GPE set a school record with 12 saves as a sophomore in 2014 and has shuttled between the bullpen and rotation this spring. The ORGANIZATION were a fun team to check out in 2015 because of the presence of PERSON and PERSON on the staff. PERSON led the Big East Conference in strikeouts as a Xavier sophomore and then continued to raise his profile in the ORGANIZATION, which he led in strikeouts (54), whiffs per nine innings (13.6) and K/BB ratio (13.5). The ORGANIZATION spent a Draft-record $17,865,000 on bonuses in 2015, including $900,000 for PERSON in the 11th round. He doesn't have a true out pitch, so he'll need to be finer with his control and command as he progresses through the Minors.

Built like a muscle car, PERSON has electric bat speed and exciting pull-side power for a player his age. PERSON very muscular and strong, he needs to develop on defense (some scouts wanted to see him catch rather than see if he could become a viable infielder, and his hands aren't great) and probably needs a swing overhaul (both the bat path and lower half usage were pretty rough in high school), but there's a chance he's a power-hitting up-the-middle player of some kind.

The ORGANIZATION have accumulated several pitching prospects with advanced command and control in recent years, and the star of that class was PERSON, who led all Minor Leaguers with an 8.1 K/BB ratio in 2013. PERSON also throws a curveball and a cutter, both of which can be solid at times. PERSON may not have a true plus pitch, but his command helps his stuff play up. He doesn't have a ton of physical projection remaining, so his ceiling likely tops out as a No. 4 starter.

If everything clicks for this young GPE lefty, PERSON has the chance to be something special, even if PERSON seems a long way off.PERSON has everything you want from a southpaw. He has a fastball that reaches up to 93-94 mph, and he has a good curveball to go along with it. PERSON also throws a slider, which isn't as good as his other breaking ball, and he shows a really good feel for a changeup. PERSON PERSON built on his momentum from the ORGANIZATION, where he displayed one of the best left-handed swings while hitting .329 last summer, he might have gone in the top three rounds of the 2015. It hasn't quite worked out that way because he failed to drive the ball consistently while dealing with oblique and knee injuries.With his compact stroke and plate discipline, PERSON should continue to hit for average. But through the end of the regular season, he had homered just seven times in three college seasons. He has the bat speed and strength for 15-18 homer power in pro ball, though he's going to have to get more aggressive and turn on and lift more pitches to get there.PERSON opened this year as PERSON's shortstop before his injuries pushed him to third base, which would be a better fit as a pro. He lacks the quickness for shortstop and may not be more than an adequate defender at third base, though he does have a very strong arm. If he doesn't produce more pop he may be relegated to a utility role, though some scouts are intrigued by the possibility of turning him into a catcher.

His days as a third baseman officially over, PERSON now hopes he can get to the big leagues as a corner outfielder.
