Offensively, PERSON has made some strides, cutting down on his strikeouts while continuing to show good plate discipline and draw walks. He's shown a penchant for hitting well late in games, a sign he likes to be up there in big situations. PERSON has enough bat to be an everyday corner outfielder at the big league level. Now all he has to do is go out and play like it.

Drafted in the 20th round in 2012 by the ORGANIZATION as a catcher, PERSON was a full-time hitter as an GPE freshman before becoming a two-way player as a sophomore and solely a pitcher as a junior. He excited scouts by running his fastball up to 96 mph and showing a hard slider at the 2014 Big Ten Conference tournament and in the ORGANIZATION, but he hasn't been as sharp this spring.PERSON has a big league body at 6-foot-5 and 220 pounds and shows flashes of becoming a power pitcher. He's still reaching the mid-90s with his fastball, but he's not maintaining his velocity deep into games. He's dipping as low as 87 mph and usually pitching around 90-93 with minimal life.PERSON's breaking ball hasn't been as sharp in 2015 and now resembles more of a curveball. He does show some feel for a sinking changeup but has a lot of work to do with his command. While he's understandably raw as a pitcher, he also has left scouts wishing he had made more progress this year.

PERSON turned in one of the better under-the-radar performances among college hurlers in 2017 as a GPE junior by posting a 2.86 ERA over a 100 2/3 innings, with 138 strikeouts and a strikeouts-per-nine rate of 12.34 that placed him in the top 10 nationally in both categories. However, PERSON's profile as an undersized righty with below-average velocity hurt his GPE stock, ultimately leading to his selection by GPE in the eighth round. Spending his entire pro debut with PERSON, PERSON piled up 58 strikeouts (14.9 K/9) and allowed just four earned runs over 35 innings en route to a 1.03 ERA, the third-best mark in the circuit for hurlers with at least 35 IP. PERSON makes a living by pairing his well-commanded fastball with a well-above-average changeup that scouts viewed as one of the best in his GPE class. Though his heater usually hovers around 90 mph, at times touching a few ticks higher, PERSON has enough velocity to effectively set up hitters for his fading changeup, which he throws with fastball-like arm action, and a slider that shows average potential. Nothing he throws is overpowering, but he has distinct feel for locating his entire arsenal. As an undersized right-hander with a pitchability-over-stuff profile, PERSON faces an uphill path toward becoming a big league starter.

Being the son of the greatest closer in the history of the game can be tough for a pitcher trying to find his way. After two pedestrian seasons at ORGANIZATION, there may not have been thoughts of following in dad's footsteps. But a breakout junior campaign has put PERSON Jr. firmly on the radar.PERSON has seen a big jump in his velocity, cranking his fastball up to 97 mph this spring. He sat in the 92-95 mph range more often than not. His slider shows glimpses of being at least above-average and could sharpen with more time and experience. He's shown a splitter in the bullpens, but a lack of feel for the offspeed pitch has kept him from using it in games. He's generally around the strike zone, though his overall command suffers as games go on.PERSON's size and slight build lead to the inevitable concerns about durability. His power stuff, not to mention his pedigree, point to a future as a reliever in the pro ranks.

As the son of former ORGANIZATION, it only makes sense that PERSON was one of the top overall prospects available during the 2015 international signing period. The ORGANIZATION traded a pair of prospects in exchange for international bonus pool money, and it ultimately allowed the club to give PERSON a $3.9 million bonus, the second highest in franchise history. Despite the lack of professional experience, it can be argued that PERSON's offensive ceiling is higher than any player in the system, and he's showcased some of the offensive potential this year during his pro debut for Rookie-level Bluefield. Much like his father, PERSON has an explosive right-handed swing and can put the barrel on almost any pitch he swings at. His combination of bat speed and physical strength produces effortless raw power, and his hand-eye coordination and barrel control should allow him to get to it in games consistently. PERSON is thicker and less athletic than his father at the same age. He was expected to play left field after signing, but the ORGANIZATION worked him out at third base during instructional league and he's passed most tests at the position thus far. However, he's also a well below-average runner who lacks the range and arm strength for the position, and some scouts believe he'll have to move to first base in the future. Regardless of his future defensive home, it will be PERSON's promising bat that carries him to the ORGANIZATION.

PERSON was the third GPE high school outfielder drafted in the first round in 2013. He doesn't profile as a five-tool player like fellow Peach State natives PERSON and PERSON. Instead, PERSON's speed and athleticism make him a potential top-of-the-order catalyst.PERSON's best tool is his plus speed, which makes him a threat to steal and allows him to cover ground well in center field. He also earns praise for his understanding of the game, helping his speed to play up on both sides of the ball.PERSON has an easy and smooth stroke, and he has a knack for putting the bat on the ball. His swing is geared to hitting line drives into the gaps, limiting his power potential.

When you're a big shortstop initially from the GPE PERSON, there are going to be the inevitable comparisons to the ORGANIZATION' PERSON, who was the ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick in 2012 out of the ORGANIZATION. PERSON, who moved to PERSON in GPE for his senior year, isn't on GPE's level, but does bring a lot to the table.PERSON performed well on the summer showcase circuit, at ORGANIZATION and the LOCATION Pro Showcase, capping things off by playing in GPE's All-American Classic. Over the summer, he displayed excellent bat speed and some offensive upside. He's been inconsistent this spring, starting off particularly slowly. PERSON physically mature, PERSON does have some power to tap into. That could be important because unlike GPE, most believe PERSON won't be able to stay at shortstop. A move to third base could be in order, where his defensive actions could make him an above-average defender at the hot corner.A team taking PERSON early could very well send him out as a shortstop to see what happens, but that team will also hope the bat they saw more consistently over the summer is the one that will allow him to profile well at an infield corner spot.

PERSON began his college career at the ORGANIZATION of GPE, but found himself stuck behind three infielders who could all go in the top five rounds in this year's Draft. So after his freshman season with the ORGANIZATION in 2018, he transferred to GPE Junior College in GPE. The move has paid off as the infielder has put up big numbers and moved himself into top-five-round consideration this June.The switch-hitter has shown the ability to hit for average and power in junior college and it's his bat that will carry him. He has easy power from the left side of the plate and has a good right-handed swing as well, with more gap power from that side. A shortstop in high school, PERSON moved to second base at GPE because they had a superior defender there and, to his credit, he was willing to do whatever was needed to make the team better. He has decent hands and a solid arm and he could get the chance to move back to shortstop after being drafted, though his somewhat limited range might make second the best spot for him long-term.A loaded GPE squad had five players taken in the top 10 rounds in the 2017 Draft. This year's roster isn't as loaded, but PERSON, with a floor of an offensive-minded utility player and a ceiling as a bat-first regular at second base, should join that crop in hearing his name called at some point on Day 2.

The ORGANIZATION lauded ORGANIZATION's glove after acquiring him, going so far as to say that they think he could handle shortstop if they needed him to. At least in our longest stretch of in-person evaluation of ORGANIZATION, he has looked just okay at third base, and saw time at first. 
The bat-to-ball skills are real. He's a career .286 hitter in the minors and has reached base at a .346 clip. A lack of game power probably means ORGANIZATION fits better in a multi-positional reserve role than as a regular at third or first base. He appears athletic enough to handle the corner outfield spots, and it makes sense to give him time there in the near future.

PERSON PERSON set an Illinois record with 14 saves in 2015, when the PERSON made him the ORGANIZATION. 6 overall choice in the GPE. This spring, GPE matched PERSON by the end of the regular season and also climbed to within two of his GPE career mark of 24 saves. He won't go as high in the GPE, but he should be one of the first college relievers selected and fit in the first four or five rounds.A pure reliever who has never started a game in three years of college or during summer ball, GPE attacks hitters with two pitches. He has sat at 92-96 mph with his fastball throughout the spring, even when working on consecutive days. His sharp 82-85 mph slider can be a plus pitch at times and is especially tough on right-handers.GPE has a lot of flying parts in his funky delivery, which provides deception but also hampers his command at times. How well he can locate his pitches ultimately will determine if he reaches his ceiling as a set-up man. His strong 6-foot-4 frame and resilient arm make him a durable bullpen option and he should be one of the first 2018 GPEees to reach the big leagues.

PERSON began his professional career with the Mariners in 2015, but was gone via a trade to the Padres that offseason before he even hit full-season ball. He reached Double-A with PERSON in 2017 and the ORGANIZATION acquired him in the ORGANIZATION trade that offseason. The right-hander was a consistent member of the Triple-A rotation, making his big league debut last July.PERSON has two pitches, his fastball and changeup, that are ready to get big league hitters out. He'll throw his fastball typically in the 92-95 mph range and will sit at 93-94 with comfort, showing the ability to reach back for a bit more at times. He'll miss bats and get groundball outs with it when he's at his best. His changeup is his best secondary pitch, one that flashes plus and has good fade to it. His breaking ball remains behind his other two offerings. On a good day, he'll show an average pitch, but it's often slurvy and some see it as more of a slider than a curveball.Just 23 for all of the 2019 season, PERSON has shown he has the durability to remain in a rotation and the ORGANIZATION aren't ready to give up on him as a starter just yet. His future might be depending on tightening up and consistently throwing his breaking ball, knowing that his fastball-changeup combination could play up in shorter stints out of the bullpen.

PERSON burst on the scene in 2011 when he hit .354 in two short-season stops. Despite missing time with a concussion that forced him out of the ORGANIZATION in 2012, he showed that his previous season was no mirage. He reached Double-A, even homering in the playoffs, while topping the organization in batting average and slugging percentage while finishing second in on-base percentage and third in GPE. A former infielder, PERSON made a smooth transition to right field and should profile well there, though perhaps without the plus power some like to see from the position. Still, he has a very good approach at the plate and a quick swing that should allow him to continue to hit for average. Heâs a good baserunner with average speed, and has the arm and range to be a good defensive outfielder. Itâs not often 13th-round picks turn into big league regulars, but this one has a chance to do just that.

GSP's conditioning and future position had some concerned about the GPE prepster as he entered his senior year of high school. But GSP shed weight, improved his overall conditioning and had a fantastic season to move into the top half of the first round. Then he went out and had as good, if not the best, of any debut by a 2012 draftee, finishing his summer in the full-season ORGANIZATION. GSP displayed outstanding bat speed and he should have above-average power in the future. He should become an even better all-around hitter as he learns to adjust to offspeed stuff. He's an average runner, maybe a tick above, but he's aggressive on the basepaths and should continue to steal some bases. It was initially assumed that GSP would have to move to third as a pro, and his bat would profile just fine there, but he's convinced many he can stay at shortstop with good hands, a well above-average arm and solid range. With his stunning debut, GSP could move more quickly than many high school hitters.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

PERSON is a projectable GPE high school pitcher. He started pitching late in his high school career but quickly excelled on the mound. Listed at 6-foot-2, 165 pounds, scouts see plenty of room for PERSON to physically mature. That, combined with his athleticism and easy arm action, lead them to believe PERSON will be able to add velocity to his fastball. PERSON, PERSON's fastball sits in the upper 80s and regularly touches the low 90s. He also throws a tight curveball and has some feel for a changeup.

Perhaps the draft's most fascinating prospect, PERSON laid waste to the ORGANIZATION this year, hitting .400/.500/.840 this season. This after he was a 38th rounder last year. He has made adjustments and is getting to his plus raw power more consistently but R/R college first baseman have a poor draf track record and, while superlative, PERSON's track record of hitting at this level is short.

We've learned a lot about PERSON's stuff based on the data we have from his 2017 relief-only cup of coffee with PERSON and from his larger, eight-start September 2018 carafe with PERSON. The PERSON gave PERSON his curveball back after it appeared that PERSON had shelved it late last year, but there's now release point data supporting the anecdotal evidence that the right-hander raises his arm slot when he throws it. It's also clear that despite high-end velocity, PERSON's fastball isn't going to miss that many bats. He's created greater demarcation in the movement between his four and two-seamers, that latter of which pairs well with his improving changeup, which now projects to be PERSON's best secondary pitch. There's a strong chance he either ends up in relief due to issues with his fastball efficacy stemming from limited command and movement, but even if that's the case, he's a four-pitch reliever with two plus offerings, and that probably plays at the back of a bullpen.

PERSON pitched to a 1.37 ERA over 21 appearances out of GPE's bullpen as a true freshman and was off to a strong start in 2016 before undergoing PERSON surgery. After making a healthy return and turning another strong relief campaign as a redshirt sophomore, PERSON was moved into the ORGANIZATION' rotation in 2018 and excelled in the new role, going 7-3 with a 2.19 ERA in 16 starts en route to GPE Athletic Conference pitcher of the year honors. The ORGANIZATION took him in the 14th round that June and used him as a swingman in his pro debut before shifting PERSON back to a full-time bullpen role for his first full season. It proved a wise decision, as he quickly climbed three levels, reaching the Double-A ORGANIZATION in mid-July before he was sent to the ORGANIZATION in return for PERSON at the ORGANIZATION Deadline.PERSON is capable of bumping 94-95 mph with his fastball but usually sits more in the low-90s, with the pitch playing on account of some funk in his delivery and because he hides the ball well on the backside. His slider is his lone above-average secondary pitch and makes him lethal on same-sided hitters, but he also has a good changeup that he uses to neutralize righties. He can throw strikes and miss bats with all three pitches, and hitters generally have trouble squaring him up. PERSON has been particularly effective against left-handed hitters early in his career thanks to his combination of stuff and deception, but he also shown that he can get outs on both sides of the plate while consistently inducing weak contact. Those traits suggest that he could be more than simply a situational left-hander out of the 'pen, although a ORGANIZATION role likely represents his clearest path to the ORGANIZATION.

GPE drew wide-ranging takes from scouts in the year leading up to signing with the ORGANIZATION as an 11th rounder from an Ohio high school. He played on the ORGANIZATION, the top travel team in the country, and was scouted often, with a decent but not great glove at third base, above average to plus power, and some feel for hitting and game power, but seemed a mid-round prospect. In the spring and into pro ball, GPE slimmed up a bit and now projects as at least average at third base, with similar raw power, but some pro scouts questioned his feel to hit. All the elements have been there at some point over the past year and some amateur scouts were really in on GPE -- one said he saw a lot of PERSON in him -- but didn't realize his price would end up being as low as it was once he started sliding in the draft.

When the ORGANIZATION signed PERSON out of GPE in 2011, scouts liked the 16-year-old's size and power potential. But he went homerless in his first three professional seasons, while his natural hitting ability proved to be better than advertised. He'll try to unlock his power with a new organization, as the D-backs acquired him in April in exchange for a competitive balance PERSON pick. PERSON has a good understanding of the strike zone and solid on-base skills, and he makes a lot of contact. His projectable frame and good bat speed give scouts optimism that he will add more power as he physically matures. Speed isn't a big part of his game, but he's savvy enough to run when he gets the chance.After primarily playing left field in his first two professional seasons, PERSON moved to right field in 2014. His defense remains a work in progress, but if he makes the strength gains he's expected to, he could develop into a prototypical corner outfielder in time.

With 10 of its pitchers appearing in the Majors since the turn of the century, PERSON is known for producing mound talent. Yet the ORGANIZATION' two best big leaguers have been position players PERSON and PERSON, and they should have their first ever selected in the first round in 2017. PERSON went undrafted out of high school but has blossomed into a college star, finishing second in ORGANIZATION Division I with 21 home runs in 2016 and winning PERSON player of the year honors this spring, when he led the league in all three triple crown categories (.341-22-63) entering ORGANIZATION tournament play.Though he went homerless with the GPE college national team during the summer, scouts still recognize PERSON as one of the top power sources available in a Draft class short on college hitters. He generates his pop more with strength than bat speed, and there are some worries about an arm bar in his right-handed swing. He controls the strike zone well and makes reliable contact for a slugger, so he should hit for some average as well.While PERSON isn't the most graceful player, one scout compared him to PERSON for his ability to get the job done in less than pretty fashion. Despite his large frame, he has average speed out of the batter's box and decent range at third base. With his solid arm, reliable hands and admirable work ethic, he should be able to stay at the hot corner.

PERSON jumped into the first round of the 2011 Draft because of his arm strength and projectability. In the early stages of his pro career â he didn't make his debut until 2012 â he's shown a solid feel for pitching to go along with his electric pure stuff. The LOCATION prep product has a plus fastball with a ton of sink that leads to a lot of ground-ball outs. His hard downer curve should be at least above-average and he continues to improve with his changeup, a pitch he didn't need or throw in high school. He has a clean delivery and the prototypical pitcher's body, which bodes well for a continuation of good control and command of his pitches.

Somewhat surprisingly, our pitch classifications indicate PERSON threw his low-spin breaking ball more often than his obviously nasty changeup in a sizable big league sample last year. PERSON's weirdo breaking ball, which can be hard to distinguish visually from his changeup, is also effective and may give him a pitch mix sufficient to enable him to close. His stuff exploded after the ORGANIZATION moved him to the bullpen in 2016; they eventually traded him in the 2018 PERSON deal. He'll likely be a significant part of the ORGANIZATION' bullpen this season and may have too tight a grip on late-inning duties to relinquish them to PERSON once the latter returns from PERSON.

Before the spring season began, the hope was PERSON could follow in the first-round footsteps of shortstops from GPE like PERSON and PERSON. Even if he wasn't quite at that level, some felt he had the raw tools to at least be in the conversation, but inconsistent performance has left his status a bit up in the air.While his uneven season has allowed PERSON to pass him by as the top PERSON player on GPE boards, PERSON's ability to stay up the middle should still be of interest. Defensively, he shows flashes of a plus arm when he gets his feet under him. He has good hands and his speed gives him range, though some feel second will be better for him in the future. His bat is behind his other tools, but he does have some power potential and could hit for average as well as he refines his approach.There is no longer talk about PERSON going in the first round, but he might have shown enough, especially later on in the summer showcase circuit, for a team to take a chance on the ORGANIZATION commit in the top five or six rounds.

There have been some interesting pitching prospects in recent Drafts who came late to full-time pitching, including first-rounders PERSON in 2013 and PERSON in 2012. While GPE isn't quite that high-profile, he has the chance to do well now that he's focused only on the mound.An outfielder for his first two years at ORGANIZATION, GPE split time between playing that position and pitching as a sophomore then turned to pitching full-time in 2014. He's athletic, if a bit undersized, with the makings of two plus pitches in his fastball and spike curveball, which looks like a hard slider at times. He's working on developing his changeup.The jury is still out on whether GPE can start long-term -- sometimes a bias against undersized right-handers -- or he'll end up in the bullpen. Either way, his arm looks like it has a shot to pitch at the highest level.

PERSON began his college career at ORGANIZATION, but he played sparingly as a freshman in 2011, before transferring to PERSON in GPE and then PERSON. There, PERSON grabbed attention in February '13, when he struck out PERSON, the eventual No. 2 overall pick, three times.PERSON mixes his low-to-mid-90s fastball effectively with a slider and a changeup. His delivery has some effort to it, though he is athletic enough to largely compensate for it.Some scouts think PERSON' delivery and short stature will ultimately push him to the bullpen. PERSON has used him as a reliever some this season, the club believes PERSON has the stuff to be a starter, and it will continue to develop him as one.

GPE, a GPE commit, is a high risk, high reward type high school bat from the GPE area, one who could pay big dividends if it all clicks for him at the plate.There is a lot of projection with the bat, particularly in terms of his left-handed power. He can be very streaky at the plate, but he has good bat speed with lift and when he's on time with his mechanics and gets his foot down, he can hit the ball as hard as anyone. A center fielder in high school, he'll likely move to a corner spot at the next level, with left field a probable destination.GPE's tools are real, if a bit raw. If it clicks, he could develop into an everyday corner outfielder with some serious pop at the highest level.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Feb. 5, 2017 - ORGANIZATION MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION MLB Player: PERSON ORGANIZATION comes from a baseball family as his dad, PERSON, is the senior advisor to PERSON' ORGANIZATION A.J. Preller. The younger PERSON has committed to play at ORGANIZATION next season after finishing up his high school career at ORGANIZATION (Ariz.)PERSON plays multiple positions, and the versatility has served him well. PERSON has a savvy look on the diamond and possesses adequate skills at both catcher and first base.In the batter's box, he has a straightaway stance with a high back elbow.

PERSON led ORGANIZATION III with 15 homers and a .918 slugging percentage in 2012, when the ORGANIZATION made him the highest-drafted D-III player in nine years by taking him 62nd overall. PERSON's production hasn't been as gaudy as a pro, in large part because he has devoted so much energy to refining his catching skills.While PERSON hasn't tapped into his plus raw power, his sound approach hasn't wavered. PERSON works counts and he focuses on driving the ball from gap to gap. The A's think he'll step up his offense, as his defense becomes more second nature to him.Oakland credits former big league catcher PERSON for helping PERSON improve behind the plate. At 6-foot-2 and 235 pounds, he's not the most agile backstop, but he has made strides with his receiving. PERSON has raw arm strength, but he needs to smooth out his throwing mechanics to better combat the running game.

PERSON was a bit of a late riser in the LOCATION ranks, partially because his strong commitment to PERSON had scared scouts off, but mostly because a very strong spring had teams giving him a longer look despite that commitment. The 6-foot-4 right-hander reminds many scouts in the region of GPE, who would be a sure-fire first-round pick this year out of PERSON if he were healthy, when he was a high schooler in the area. PERSON's fastball is typically in the 88-92 mph range, with some room for added velocity from his loose and projectable frame, though he'll likely be more command than premium velocity in the future. He throws a slider and a curve, with the latter a much better offering, buckling knees with sharp bite coming from a high three-quarters slot. He does a nice job of sprinkling in his changeup. He can throw strikes with all four offerings.PERSON's name was moving up ORGANIZATION boards as his strong string of performances continued and some of his contemporaries stagnated or went backwards. Whether or not he's signable away from following in GPE's footsteps remains to be seen.Prospect Development PERSON - PERSON, GPE.

The ORGANIZATION don't have a shortage on young power arms with electric stuff. PERSON definitely fits into that group and if the step forward he made in 2015 -- earning a promotion to full-season LOCATION and pitching meaningful ORGANIZATION playoff innings -- is any indication, he could rise to the top of it.PERSON lives off of a very good fastball-slider combination, and both are power pitches. He'll throw the fastball in the upper-90s with regularity and his slider continues to improve and could be a consistent swing-and-miss pitch in the future. Since he made his pro debut in the ORGANIZATION in 2013, he's been working to improve his command and he threw more strikes after getting bumped up to the ORGANIZATION, a good sign. Everything PERSON throws is hard, so the ORGANIZATION are trying to get him work on his changeup, just to give hitters a different look.If the progress the 20-year-old showed while pitching "under the lights" for the first time continues, he could be coming to a bullpen near you in the future.

The earliest-drafted pitcher ever from GPE, PERSON had a huge 2014 season that saw him start the PERSON in GPE, pitch well in Double-A and even made a start in Triple-A, all at age 20. He followed that up with another strong season in 2015, including a second straight PERSON start. PERSON pitches with the kind of confidence you like to see in a young starter. He has a live, quick arm that fires fastballs that touch 95-96 mph regularly and easily sits in the low-90s. His changeup is his best secondary offering, a sinking offspeed pitch which is very effective against left-handed hitters. His breaking ball is a hard slurve, thrown with good deception, and he'll vary the velocity and size of it to throw hitters off. PERSON is very athletic, repeating his delivery well and staying in and around the strike zone consistently. There isn't much more for PERSON to prove at the ORGANIZATION level. Because he just turned 21 during the 2015 season, there isn't any reason to rush him.

PERSON reached the upper 90s with a fastball as an amateur, but he was hard to scout because he missed his high school senior season with a knee injury and worked a total of just 74 innings in three years of college at three different school. A fifth-round pick out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE in 2010, he first reached the Majors with the ORGANIZATION in 2013 but has yet to establish himself in the big leagues. He came to the ORGANIZATION along with PERSON in a July 2014 trade for PERSON Peavy.In order to improve his control, PERSON has dialed down his fastball. He usually works at 92-95 mph with some sink, though he was vulnerable to home runs in his time with GPE last season.PERSON operates mainly with his fastball and his slider/cutter, which can climb into the upper 80s. Once considered PERSON's possible closer of the future, he now projects as more of a middle reliever because he lacks a wipeout pitch and fine control.

PERSON backed up his breakout 2017 campaign with a .313/.368/.430 2018 season line, mostly at Double-A. His swing is compact and rhythmic, and he's very difficult to beat with velocity because he can time just about everything. This, combined with an ability to guide the barrel around the zone, drives a promising, contact-first offensive package that would be quite valuable at catcher. PERSON moved from shortstop (in high school) to third base (as a college freshman) to catcher (as a sophomore) and has been behind the plate for four seasons now. He remains below-average in most aspects of catching, but isn't so bad that he'll surely have to move. He's not nearly as skilled a defender as PERSON, but PERSON has a much better chance to make an offensive impact. Yadier GPE is signed through 2020, which creates the illusion of a catching logjam, but he's somewhat fragile and PERSON and PERSON's experience at corner infield spots (PERSON has played some first base as a pro, but did not in 2018) could enable the Cardinals to carry all three of them at some point. If tasked with everyday duty, we think PERSON would produce like an average everyday player.

A 13th-round pick in the 2015 Draft out of the ORGANIZATION of GPE, ORGANIZATION's advanced feel for pitching allowed him to dominate two levels of A-ball during his first full season. It's unclear how his stuff will play when he moves up, but he has the ORGANIZATION interested in finding out.ORGANIZATION operates largely with fringy stuff. His fastball will be in the 86-90 mph range and he'll occasionally flash an average curve and slider. His changeup is the one pitch that grades out as a tick above-average. He has been an extreme strike-thrower in his brief pro career, commanding all four pitches and keeping hitters guessing and off-balance consistently. Because none of his pitches truly stand out, there is little margin for error for ORGANIZATION. A big test will come when he gets the chance to move up to Double-A. He has the ceiling of a back-end starter, but he's had good success against left-handed hitters, so if the rotation doesn't work out, a future as a specialist out of the bullpen isn't out of the question.

PERSON underwent PERSON surgery in July 2009, costing him his senior season of high school. He proved he was fully recovered at ORGANIZATION Community College and was drafted in the fifth round in 2012. PERSON's fastball, which he pairs with an above-average curveball, sits in the low-90s. He also throws a changeup, which is improving. PERSON has good command and had a productive debut at ORGANIZATION in 2012, posting a 2.95 ERA and striking out 44 batters in 42 2/3 innings. He struggled initially in 2013 after being double-jumped to the ORGANIZATION State League, but did show signs of improvement late in the year.

GPE seems to produce an enticing, projectable high school arm in just about every Draft, and GPE fit that profile when he signed with the ORGANIZATION for $897,500 as a third-rounder in 2014. PERSON didn't bring him to full-season ball until his fourth pro season, giving him time to add strength and improve his pitches. His stuff ticked up at the end of 2018, when he posted a 1.95 ERA in nine Double-A starts, and the ORGANIZATION landed him in December as the headline prospect in a three-team deal that shipped PERSON to the A's and lefty prospect PERSON to PERSON has boosted his fastball velocity and his ability to maintain it since turning pro, now working at 90-94 mph and topping out at 96 with some running action. He has some power and late bite with his slider, which has developed into a solid second offering. He also has some feel for throwing a fading changeup, which he continues to refine in order to combat right-handers.GPE had scattershot control coming out of high school but is doing a much better job of throwing strikes now. He still needs to refine his location in order to reach his ceiling as a mid-rotation starter. He has deception in his delivery that makes it difficult for hitters to square his pitches up.

Since signing for a $1.3 million bonus -- a record for a GPE player -- in January 2010, PERSON advanced rapidly to Double-A. He has the best combination of raw power and pure arm strength among PERSON catchers, though he's still polishing those tools and the other aspects of his game. Unfortunately for him, his 2015 season was put on hold when he underwent surgery on his left ankle in June. That didn't keep the Phillies from wanting him, making sure he was included in the package they received in return for PERSON has the strength and bat speed to drive balls out of any part of any ballpark without selling out for power, yet he's still overly aggressive at the plate. He swings and misses frequently, and he needs to do a better job of taking pitches and recognizing breaking balls. If he figures it out, he could be an average hitter with 20-plus homers per season in the big leagues. Similarly, he has a cannon arm and good athleticism for a catcher but needs a lot of refinement behind the plate. He threw out just 28 percent of basestealers and committed 23 passed balls in 90 games in 2014. Though he has played first base and tried the outfield in instructional league play, it's too soon to give up on the idea that he can become an All-Star catcher.

Though the ORGANIZATION drafted PERSON out of high school as a pitcher, it became evident his future was as a hitter when he led ORGANIZATION Division I in batting (.465) and homers (28) as a sophomore at GPE Tennessee State in 2009. A supplemental first-rounder a year later, he advanced steadily through the Minors before getting slowed by leg, knee and hamstring injuries the last two seasons.A healthy PERSON does have the tools to make it as a right fielder in the Majors. He has well above-average power and is an effective hitter when he focuses on going gap to gap rather than trying to crush the ball. He gets out of control at the plate, uppercutting and pulling pitches, and he'll probably always rack up large numbers of strikeouts.PERSON's strong arm is a good fit for right field, and he covers a decent amount of ground there. He can lose focus on defense at times, however.

GPE is emerging as a market for international prospects, and PERSON has positioned himself as the top young player from the country in this year's class.The young infielder has a chance to be special and here are a few reasons why: PERSON is a big bodied athlete with a plus bat, plus power and plus arm potential. He's a decent shortstop now and projects to be an above-average defender at third base, the position many scouts believe he will play as he grows and his body matures. Overall, evaluators like his hands and defensive actions. There's still room for improvement in terms of body control and footwork, but that's not uncommon for infielders his age.At the plate, he has already shown good strength and has a chance to develop more power as he grows. The tools are there and he's expected to hone his overall game once he signs with a club and enters its academy.PERSON is from GPE, GPE, and trains with former big league infielder PERSON. The ORGANIZATION are the favorite to sign him.

A top closer who racked up 40 saves at GPE in 2012 and 2013, PERSON looked like he was going to be a quick-to-the-big-leagues college reliever when he reached Double-A in his first full season of pro ball in 2014 and capped it off with a very strong ORGANIZATION performance. He went backwards in 2015, however, struggling with command, though he righted the ship in 2016, pitching across three levels of the Minors.Only six-feet, 175 pounds, PERSON still has the kind of electric stuff teams like to have in the back end of a bullpen. His fastball will sit in the 96-97 mph range with big-time boring action. His slider gives him a second above-average pitch with quick and late bite. Both miss plenty of bats, and PERSON can also induce ground-ball outs. He'll even mix in a changeup to keep hitters honest.The biggest thing holding PERSON back had been his command. He walked more than four batters per nine innings in his career, a rate that improved considerably in 2016, showing he might have the stuff to close games at the next level. At worst, PERSON could serve as a very effective setup man in the near future.

At 6-foot-7 and 230 pounds, PERSON looks more like he should be playing football (most of his college scholarship offers were as a tight end) or basketball (he has a close physical resemblance to ORGANIZATION star PERSON). He also has drawn comparisons to Hall of ORGANIZATION, who played in eight straight All-Star Games for the ORGANIZATION, and PERSON Stanton.The 32nd overall pick in the 2013 Draft and recipient of a $1.8 million bonus, PERSON has huge power potential. He uses his leverage and strength to crush balls, and he has a two-homer game against GPE. 1 overall pick PERSON and the ORGANIZATION title on his resume. With his long arms, his swing can get very long as well, which results in strikeouts and reduces his ability to hit for average.PERSON moves very well for a big man, with his solid speed and strong arm making him a nice fit in right field. He has yet to make his debut because he arrived in pro ball with a quad injury, yet PERSON could move quickly if he makes consistent contact.

After two nondescript years at ORGANIZATION, PERSON jumped on the radar with a strong junior season, building off an All-Star campaign in the ORGANIZATION League the previous summer. The top college prospect in GPE in the 2017 Draft class, he was taken by the ORGANIZATION in the fourth round and given a slightly above-pick value bonus to sign. Pitching in relief in the short-season ORGANIZATION York-Penn League during his debut, PERSON struck out 12.8 per nine innings, then followed it up with a solid first full year in the LOCATION, once again striking out better than 10 per nine.With a quick arm and a strong frame, PERSON can run his fastball up to 96 mph and sit at 93-94 and while his velocity had dipped after heavy use in his last college season, he proved durable and effective over his first full season, finishing with 131 innings pitched. He's fiddled with different versions of a breaking ball in the past, but now features a hard slider/cutter that has good, late life. PERSON can spin a curveball with good depth and has aptitude for throwing a changeup. His fastball, slider and changeup all can be plus pitches at their best, so he has the ingredients to start. In order to succeed in that role as he moves up the ORGANIZATION' ladder, he will have to continue to refine his overall control and command (3.7 BB/9 through 2018).

In a system deep in power bullpen arms, PERSON has flown under the radar, partially because of injury issues. Coming back healthy in 2015 has him set up to make more noise in 2016 and beyond.Signed out of GPE in September 2010, PERSON first made the move to the bullpen in winter ball in his home country in 2013. He's been a reliever since, though he missed considerable time in 2014 and the start of 2015 with a shoulder impingement. The right-hander did avoid surgery, and the ORGANIZATION mostly wanted 2015 to be about PERSON staying healthy. He did just that and put up good numbers as a bonus. PERSON misses plenty of bats with a fastball that sits in the 93-96 mph range. His best secondary offering is his changeup, while his curveball is inconsistent but has improved of late. The ORGANIZATION were encouraged with how PERSON threw at the end of the ORGANIZATION season in 2105, including eight scoreless innings in the playoffs, and feel PERSON has the chance to be a big league setup man in the future.

One of the more talented prospects cut loose by the ORGANIZATION during their international scandal, PERSON's fastball creeps into the mid-90s, and he has a good curveball and a sturdy build that is admittedly less projectable than is typical for a 19-year-old. His strike-throwing took a step forward in 2018, but his profile includes fairly significant relief risk. He spent all of 2018 at Low-A Lexington but has dealt with a biceps issue this spring, and isn't currently at an affiliate. He's in that No. 4 or 5 starter/potential late-inning reliever area as far as stuff goes, and is probably several years away from the majors.

The 2013 Draft already is shaping up as one of the ORGANIZATION' best in years. First-rounders PERSON, PERSON and PERSON are three of the system's top prospects; fourth-rounder PERSON's stock continues to climb; and seventh-rounder PERSON already has debuted in GPE. Another member of that bumper crop to watch is PERSON, an 18th-rounder who signed for $278,000.PERSON has some of the best all-around tools among ORGANIZATION farmhands. His two most obvious attributes are his speed and center-field defense, both of which grade as plus. He has solid arm strength and can play all three outfield positions.PERSON also has some intriguing offensive upside. He has hit for average in the lower levels of the ORGANIZATION, though he'll have to tighten his strike-zone discipline to do so against more advanced pitching. He has enough raw power to hit 15 or more homers per season, and he should be a basestealing threat as well.

PERSON put together a solid career at ORGANIZATION and was considered one of the best college hitters in the 2013 Draft class. He got off to a slow start as a professional before finishing the 2014 season strong with high Class A Stockton, and has built on that momentum this year in Double-A.PERSON has a short, quick swing with loft, giving him the potential to hit for both average and power. He does a good job of making contact and using the entire field to hit.The A's have used PERSON at both first and third base, but playing with PERSON and PERSON in 2014 meant that he played more DH than anything else. PERSON profiles best at first base, but no matter where he settles defensively, it'll be up to his bat to get him to the ORGANIZATION.

A two-time member of the Pac-12 All-Defensive Team during his time at GPE, PERSON's abilities in center field have never been questioned. His hitting ability, on the other hand, drew mixed reviews from scouts leading up to the 2015 GPE. The ORGANIZATION, believing in his bat, took him in the third round of the GPE, and he rewarded them in his pro debut by finishing second in the Class A Short PERSON with a .320 average. He made his full-season debut in '16, splitting the year between the GPE and GPE, and then returned to the latter stop in 2017 to earn All-Star honors before moving up to Double-A in July.A well-above-average runner and defender, PERSON makes it look easy in center field with his great jumps and exceptional range. That speed also makes him a threat on the basepaths, though he does have gains to make with both his technique and feel for reading pitchers. Offensively, PERSON has good bat speed from the right side of the plate, and he's shorter to the ball now after working with the ORGANIZATION to clean up his swing last summer. He should add some strength as he matures, which should lead to more gap power, but he's never going to be a home-run threat.Whether PERSON can reach his ceiling as a top-of-the-order center fielder will depend on how much his bat develops moving forward. Even if it doesn't, he still has a chance to be a big leaguer based on the merits of his speed-defense combo,

PERSON began the 2012 season in a prospect-laden PERSON rotation along with 2011 first-rounders PERSON and PERSON, but it was PERSON alone who pitched himself up to Double-A Huntsville. The big, strong right-hander features a heavy fastball that elicits ground balls and sits in the low 90s. His slider has the chance to be above average and he was much better at commanding it than he had been in the past. His changeup is still below average, though he threw it more effectively in 2012. His overall command isn't great, but his deception and sink give him the chance to start. If the command doesn't come, his stuff could play up in a bullpen role if needed.

PERSON had one of the best college catchers in the 2016 Draft in GPE, who signed with the ORGANIZATION as a second-rounder. The ORGANIZATION again have one of top college backstops this spring in GPE, who spent his freshman season at ORGANIZATION (Calif.) JC and started on the infield corners for PERSON in 2016. Despite an injury to his left hand at the beginning of 2017 and a jammed right shoulder in May that clouded his Draft status, he had as many homers (14) and a higher slugging percentage (.592) entering the ORGANIZATION playoffs than teammate and 2018 early-first-round candidate PERSON Beer.GPE' best tool is his plus right-handed raw power, though there are some mixed reviews on his bat. He can crush fastballs but some scouts worry about his ability to handle quality breaking pitches at the next level. He gets overly pull-conscious and doesn't show much patience at the plate, limiting his ability to hit for average.GPE still has work to do behind the plate. He has an average arm albeit with a long release that leads to concerns as to how he'll fare against pro basestealers, and his receiving needs more polish. If he doesn't make it as a catcher, he has enough power potential and athletic ability that he might be able to profile at first base or left field.

Any time there's a left-handed pitcher who can touch 97 mph and hit 95 mph with regularity, people are going to notice. PERSON has one of the more electric left arms in the Minors, one that has shown the ability to dominate at each level he's pitched. He did fade in the second half of 2012, but his .201 batting average against did lead the organization. His power breaking ball can be unhittable when his mechanics are right, but it's inconsistent and it can get slurvy. He sometimes will show feel for a changeup, but that too needs some work. The 2012 Futures Gamer also needs to refine his command in order to make his stuff more effective. That's what will determine if he can start long-term or eventually will have to move to the bullpen.

If you're a big, strong lefty with good command in the ORGANIZATION system, you're bound to be compared, however unfairly, to PERSON. But PERSON welcomes it and even got the chance to apprentice under PERSON when the veteran came to GPE en route to his 2012 comeback. With a great pitching frame, he has the chance to have four Major League average or better pitches. His fastball is up to 92 mph at times and he can command it to both sides of the plate. His curve has some nasty bite to it at times. When he's executing it well, it freezes hitters. His changeup also has the chance to be very effective and it dives at times. He competes well, gets ahead and finds a way to keep his team in games even without his best stuff.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

PERSON drew little attention from scouts as an PERSON high schooler in 2012, when he was a slight southpaw who topped out at 90 mph. His fastball and profile have taken off since he went to college, and he helped the Fighting Illini win 27 straight games this spring after starring with the GPE collegiate national team last summer. Now he's a lock to become the second first-round pick ever produced by PERSON, following PERSON in 1988, and he's the consensus best left-hander in the 2015 Draft.He is still not very physical at 6-foot-1 and 175 pounds, but PERSON now works at 93-95 mph and peaks at 98 mph with his fastball, even when he works on consecutive days. He generates that heat with athleticism and a quick arm rather than an excessive amount of effort in his delivery.PERSON has a deeper repertoire than most relievers. His plus slider is his second-best pitch, and he also has a curveball with power and depth and shows signs of interesting changeup. He has enough pitches and control to lead a pro team to consider trying him as a starter, though he lacks size and could speed to the Majors if he remains a reliever.

It might be difficult to find a better athlete in the 2012 Draft class and there certainly isn't anyone faster. While he's sure to be a major basestealing threat, he's much more than a one-tool guy. PERSON has the chance to hit, with good bat speed and even a bit of power to grow into. There's some refining to his approach that will need to happen, but he has an understanding of what his game will need to be hitting at the top of the lineup. He's able to outrun any mistakes in the outfield, but projects to be an above-average defender in the future. He's been compared to PERSON, not a bad aspiration, but he might have the chance to have a little more pop and a little less swing-and-miss if things click for him.

PERSON signed for the fifth highest bonus in the 2017 July 2nd class, among a few already-elite prospects like ORGANIZATION of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON shortstop PERSON, PERSON outfielder PERSON and ORGANIZATION shortstop PERSON. PERSON could be next in line to jump into the 50 FV tier during the 2019 season, building on a solid pro debut in 2018, where he improved his already-impressive tool profile. To clarify any confusion, it's worth noting that there is another, very similar middle infield prospect with the ORGANIZATION the same name who was also born in the same year. The ORGANIZATION' PERSON has an above average hit tool to go with above average speed, defense, and arm strength at shortstop, so it won't be a long journey to turn into a regular if he can maintain those current tools. He's played just 43 official minor league games and has an unsustainably-high .418 ORGANIZATION, but the performance also supports the standout skillset. Some scouts argue there isn't a plus tool here other than arm strength, so you can't stuff PERSON too high until he's done a little more in official games, but he's already among the top 200 prospects or so in baseball. Some see sneaky potential average raw power down the road, which PERSON could mostly get to in games if he ends up being the plus hitter that some are projecting, though some scouts see 45 hit and 40 power, given the limited pro looks they've had. It's also worth noting that PERSON has become close friends with PERSON; the pair could team up to form half of the infield of the future in GSP. PERSON will definitely be one to watch closely in 2019 as there's some in-season ceiling to his potential ranking, particularly if he can perform the way the ORGANIZATION' PERSON did this past year; that PERSON reached High-A at age 18.

After PERSON helped ORGANIZATION win the 2014 College World Series and starred with the GPE collegiate national team and in the ORGANIZATION during the summer, he entered last year as the top-rated prospect on the ORGANIZATION -- ahead of eventually ORGANIZATION. 1 overall pick PERSON and ORGANIZATION. 8 choice PERSON. PERSON missed his first two starts with elbow soreness and never really looked 100 percent, concluding his junior season by getting knocked out early in the final game of the ORGANIZATION. He dropped to the ORGANIZATION with the 24th overall pick and signed for a below-slot $1,777,500 at the deadline amid reports that he needed PERSON surgery, which he had in early August.When fully healthy as a sophomore, PERSON displayed four pitches that graded as solid or better and threw them all for strikes. He consistently worked at 90-96 mph with his fastball, with its command more notable than its life. He throws two distinct breaking balls and can miss bats with both his curveball and slider, as well as with his changeup.Even before he got hurt, there were some concerns as to whether PERSON's slight build could hold up to the demands of being a pro starter. He had no physical issues before his elbow gave out, however, and his athleticism and ability to repeat his sound delivery enabled him to maintain quality stuff deep into games.

Typically, international prospects are signed as teenagers and when they come to the GPE, there's as much emotional and cultural growth that needs to take place as there is physical. PERSON, on the other hand, signed just days before he turned 22 and thus came to the Pirates with plenty of maturity. That's allowed him to move fast -- three levels of the Minors followed by being absolutely dominant in the ORGANIZATION in 2016 -- all of which led to his first big league callup in 2017.PERSON dials up his fastball to 96-97 mph on most nights and can touch a tick higher on occasion. He has good depth and life on his heater, getting a ton of ground-ball outs. The consistency, shape and spin of his slider has improved and when he keeps his front side in, it's a true out pitch. He fills the strike zone with both offerings.Perhaps because PERSON didn't play a lot of baseball early on, he has a fresh arm and still has upside. He doesn't quite have the mentality to close just yet, but he could eventually get there.

For the second straight year, a big left-hander named PERSON has had scouts flocking to the ORGANIZATION. In 2013, a LOCATION CC southpaw by that name signed for $1.2 million as a second-round pick of the ORGANIZATION. This year, an ORGANIZATION high school lefty with the same name could go in the same area of the Draft.Reed has created plenty of buzz by boosting his fastball velocity from 88-90 mph in the past to 92-95 as a senior. When he stays on top of his breaking ball, he can snap off a sharp slider with depth, though at times it devolves into a slower slurve. He shows some fade with his changeup and the willingness to use it.Reed's weight ballooned to 260 pounds this spring, and while scouts think he needs to get in better shape, they also wonder what might happen to his velocity when he does. The ORGANIZATION recruit works in the strike zone but will have to locate his pitches better against more advanced competition.

The ORGANIZATION were initially attracted to PERSON because of his abilities at the plate, and they believed he would develop into a good defender. He has done just that, with his defense progressing even faster than expected.PERSON threw out 42 percent of would-be basestealers in 2013, leading the ORGANIZATION. He has improved his game management, and he uses his athleticism well behind the plate. A switch-hitter, PERSON makes consistent hard contact from both sides of the plate. His swing is more geared for line drives now, but he projects to have average power. PERSON has toned down his aggressive approach somewhat, though he wouldn't be confused with a patient hitter. He is faster than most catchers, and he isn't a baseclogger.PERSON is still a work in progress, but he has the potential to be an impact player in the ORGANIZATION.

One of the more exciting high school arms in the 2014 GPE class, PERSON was the third prep pitcher taken that June, going No. 16 overall to the ORGANIZATION. A year later, on PERSON's 19th birthday, the right-hander was dealt to the ORGANIZATION, basically in return for taking on PERSON's salary.PERSON struggled post-trade. PERSON of one of the best curveballs in his GPE class, he was limited in his use of it initially because the D-backs wanted him to improve his other pitches and not rely on the curve too much. As a result, he was inconsistent with it for much of the season. When he got to instructs, it all started to click again. PERSON had struggled with fastball command due to some mechanical issues and the coaches started to iron them out. He has the chance to have two plus pitches with his fastball and curve and while the changeup is behind the other two, it could be at least average.PERSON tried to do too much to justify the trade, but when he got to instructs, he hit the reset button and went to work. Now relaxing, he can use his combination of stuff and althleticsm to propel him up the ladder.

PERSON was dominant for a month and a half at ORGANIZATION but his strikeout rate was sawed in half after he was promoted to Hi-A Frederick. A vertical arm slot creates a tough angle on PERSON's fastball and vertical action on his breaking stuff. It also makes it hard for him to have east/west command, and a large portion of the industry has PERSON projected to the bullpen because of this. Dissenters believe his repertoire depth (four average pitches) fits at the back of a rotation.

The ORGANIZATION accomplished three objectives in a November 2017 trade with the Marlins: clearing spots on their 40-man roster by dealing PERSON and PERSON, acquiring international bonus pool money and grabbing King. GPE had drafted him in the 12th round in 2016, when he earned PERSON's lone victory in the only ORGANIZATION super-regional appearance in the program's history. He had a spectacular season after changing organizations, ranking second in the Minors in GPE (1.79) and third in GPE (0.91) while rising from PERSON to Triple-A, but has yet to pitch in 2019 after getting diagnosed with a stress reaction in his elbow in GPE, but missed the first three months of the 2019 season after getting diagnosed with a stress reaction in his elbow in GPE.King's success centers on precision command of a two-seam fastball that sits at 92-95 mph. He can run or sink his heater to either corner of the plate, and he's an extreme ground-ball pitcher with a career groundout/airout ratio of 1.7 through his first three pro seasons. The ORGANIZATION also helped him improve his secondary pitches, leading to a jump in his strikeout rate from 6.3 per nine innings in two years in GPE's system to 8.5 in his first in GPE York's.Both King's slider and changeup can be solid pitches when they're working, and evaluators generally prefer his slider by a slight margin. He has the best control and command among ORGANIZATION pitching prospects and one of the highest floors as well. Regarded as a finesse right-hander who might fit at the back of a rotation at the time of his trade, he now he appears to be more than that.
Natural defender with below average footspeed, arm may limit to second base, some projection with limited now strength but solid contact-oriented switch hitter.

PERSON was noticed early in his career at ORGANIZATION for showing early round tools as a defender who can stay in the middle infield with above average raw power and some feel to hit. The feel to hit came into question in his draft year, as his swing got a little too pull/power oriented, helping him slip to the fourth round. The Jays rave about PERSON's makeup and preparation, and how he spearheaded the adjustments to his swing to have a shorter path to the ball and increase his contact ability. He now has a flatter-planed swing, and one scout compared his offense to PERSON, while another thinks PERSON is a 50 hitter with 50 game power. Most scouts think he's fringy at shortstop despite a plus arm, and would shift him to second base long-term for the best fit, where he's got a chance to be above average. An 85 to 100 wRC+ with solid average defense at second base is worth 2-something WAR, so while it isn't sexy, there's some performance here, real changes to explain it, and a pretty good chance to be a 50 or 55 FV big leaguer.

The PERSON went above pick value to sign the GPE high school infielder, and they did so largely for his bat. With strong hands and a quick bat, PERSON shows the ability to hit line drives to the gap, and he should develop average power as he physically matures. A shortstop in high school, the PERSON tried PERSON at second and third base after he signed. They eventually settled on developing him as a second baseman. As he gets more comfortable there, he projects to develop into a good offensive-minded second baseman.

The way PERSON has pitched in 2013, it's somewhat curious why he wasn't the school's Friday starter from the start of the season. Regardless, he's pitched like one, showing a three-pitch mix and the ability to throw strikes with all three.PERSON's fastball will touch 93-94 mph and it has some late sink to it, giving him the ability to generate ground-ball outs. When he stays on top of his breaking ball, it's a solid curve with good tilt to it. He doesn't throw his changeup much, and it needs some work, but it has the chance to be a third average offering.Tall and strong, PERSON may not be among the elite-level college arms in this class, but he may not be too far behind.

The first half of PERSON's 2015 campaign at ORGANIZATION A Advanced ORGANIZATION mirrored his performance from his first full season, when he showed plus power but struggled to make consistent contact and get on base. But he began to find his stride at the plate in July while playing for PERSON in the ORGANIZATION Am Games, and then hit 16 homers over his final 151 at-bats back at ORGANIZATION. He finished the year with 32 home runs, tying for the second-highest total in the ORGANIZATION. PERSON's explosive bat speed generates effortless plus power, and he's strong enough to drive the ball out of the park even when he doesn't catch it flush on the barrel. While he understands the strike zone, he can get over anxious and chase breaking balls off the plate, while also get too pull-happy at times. Once he can find the balance between his hitting ability and power, he has the chance to hit for average in addition to the light-tower power. A former high school catcher, PERSON has slightly above-average arm strength and good athleticism, though he's a fringy defender at both corner outfield spots.Many scouts expected PERSON to struggle with the move to Double-A in 2016, but that has been anything but the case. The youngster has received raves for his capacity to make adjustments, while advancements in his approach and plate discipline have led to a drastically reduced strikeout rate. PERSON looks more and more like a future middle-of-the-order run producer, though the Mariners have no plans to rush him to the big leagues.

PERSON mostly played shortstop in high school, but when he moved behind the plate in his senior year, he gave many teams, including the ORGANIZATION, an idea. PERSON let PERSON played the infield during his pro debut after signing an above-pick value bonus, then moved him behind the plate for the 2014 season. Heading back to the ORGANIZATION, where he made his pro debut, has helped. PERSON has a quick left-handed swing with a solid approach at the plate. As he adds strength, he should add some power down the line. He's runs OK for a catcher and is not a base-clogger. He's solid across the board defensively, though he has a ways to go to become a complete catcher. The ORGANIZATION rave about PERSON's makeup and the natural leadership skills teams love to see in their regular backstops.

The son of former big league player and manager and current GPE bench coach PERSON, PERSON has the advanced instincts expected from someone who grew up around the game. He also has an intriguing toolset as well and could be a top-three-rounds pick if he's considered signable away from his commitment to Rice.A switch-hitter, PERSON shows a quick bat and good approach from both sides of the plate. He shows power potential from both sides as well -- perhaps more as a lefty despite being a natural righty -- and should begin to realize it once he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame.An average runner with a solid, accurate arm and defensive savvy, PERSON may be able to stay at shortstop. Even if he can't, he has enough quickness to profile at second base and the bat to handle the offensive demands at third base.

The Mariners have never been shy about being aggressive in the international market, and they weren't when they gave PERSON seven figures to sign out of Venezuela.Unlike some of the hard throwers in the system, PERSON relies more on command and control. His fastball sits in the low 90s, at best, and he couples it with solid yet unspectacular secondary stuff in his curve and his changeup. PERSON is a serious strike-thrower, though, keeping the ball down in the zone consistently, which allows his stuff to play up. At 6-foot-0 and 255 pounds, there's no projection here.Still only a teenager, PERSON's pitchabilty could allow him to move quickly, even if his ceiling maxes out as a No. 4-type starter.

After pitching with an upper-80s fastball on the showcase circuit last summer, PERSON dedicated himself to getting stronger in the offseason. His work paid off when he came out touching 93 mph early this spring and held his improved velocity throughout his senior season. He could go as early as the third round and figures to get picked high enough to sign him away from an Ohio State commitment.PERSON now operates in the low 90s early in games and should throw a bit harder as he continues to develop physically. He can flash a good curveball at times but it's below average at others and he can't always land it in the strike zone. He shows some feel for his changeup, which has fade and should become an effective third pitch.PERSON is athletic and has a clean delivery, so he should be able to iron out the inconsistencies with his control and command. Though he's not especially tall, he uses a high-three-quarters arm slot to create downhill plane on his pitches.

In the final year of LOCATION CC's baseball program, ORGANIZATION set school records for hitting (.419) and home runs (16) in 2016 before signing with the ORGANIZATION as a fourth-rounder. He has continued to mash in pro ball, leading the Rookie-level PERSON in runs (63), total bases (161) and ORGANIZATION (1.052) during his pro debut. In his first full season, he won GPE League MVP honors and topped the high Class A circuit in extra-base hits (61) and slugging (.514).Built along the lines of PERSON, ORGANIZATION has similar huge raw right-handed power and a strong arm. His strength and the leverage in his 6-foot-6 frame allow him to crush balls out of any part of any ballpark, though his size also leads to a naturally long swing. His 189 strikeouts also led the ORGANIZATION and he'll have to reduce his 32 percent strikeout rate, though he also demonstrated some selectivity by finishing second with 64 walks.Surprisingly athletic for a big man, ORGANIZATION shows average speed out of the batter's box and is faster than that once he gets going. Though he spent the majority of his first two pro seasons in center field, he doesn't have the speed and instincts to remain there. He's destined for right field and has the power and arm to fit the profile there.
PERSON popped up this spring and is sitting in the mid-90's with a chance to start, slotting just behind PERSON, J.J. Goss and PERSON in the Houston-area pitcher rankings.

Drafted by his hometown team, GPE took a step forward in 2013, pitching in the ORGANIZATION. He took a step back in 2014 while repeating the Double-A LOCATION, but he landed on the temporary inactive list in late June due to his struggles.When he's on top of his game, GPE has drawn comparisons to PERSON, both for his size and his stuff. He can throw his fastball in the low-90s from a three-quarters arm slot. GPE throws a changeup and a big sweeping curveball, which is his best offspeed pitch. All three of his pitches have a chance to be at least Major League-average offerings.GPE has struggled with his control throughout his professional career, and finding a way to improve it will be critical to his success as a starter in the ORGANIZATION. If he can lower his walk rate, GPE profiles as a middle-of-the-rotation starter.

PERSON might have gone in the top five rounds of the 2013 Draft based on talent, but signability dropped him to the ORGANIZATION in the 40th round. After a late-season surge left him leading the LOCATION with 14 homers entering ORGANIZATION tournament play, he should go around the third this time around. He doesn't have a true plus tool but he's at least average across the board and can play up the middle, claims few college players in this Draft class can match.PERSON hit .284 with a total of nine homers in his first two seasons at ORGANIZATION, and he struck out in 37 percent of his plate appearances and slugged just .344 with wood bats in the ORGANIZATION last summer. He's doing a much better job of recognizing offspeed pitches and making contact this spring. He employed more of a line-drive approach in the past but is driving the ball more consistently now and has the bat speed and strength for at least average power.His solid speed and instincts should allow PERSON to remain in center field, where his arm is stronger than most at the position. His quickness should enable him to steal a few bases but he needs to refine his technique.

Acquired in the April 2018 trade that sent ORGANIZATION Hernandez to the ORGANIZATION' organization, PERSON is a questionable hitter but has 80 raw power that seems poised to go off the charts at times with booming home runs that would leave any stadium in the GPE. He hit 35 home runs in 104 games for PERSON after the trade and his 36 total homers tied him for the ORGANIZATION lead.While there is no question about PERSON's ability to hit the ball out of the park, there are many worries about him making enough contact to use that power in games as he moves up the ladder. In 2018, PERSON also struck out 152 times or 36 percent of his at-bats. He has below average running ability and is below average as a defender. He does have an average arm and could be occasionally utilized in right field, where he played eight games for PERSON.PERSON could be a more athletic version of PERSON if he can refine his overall approach at the plate and harness his raw power. Otherwise, he's a likely one-trick pony who will hit the tape-measure homers and do little else, which would make it harder for him to reach the big leagues.

A 40th-round pick of the ORGANIZATION in 2014, PERSON passed on launching his pro career in favor of attending PERSON.
