PERSON's breakout campaign in college baseball's best league stood out in a thin crop of college hitters, and the ORGANIZATION were thrilled to find him still on the board in the third round. PERSON has a nice left-handed swing, shows good feel for the barrel and drives the ball across the entire field. After totaling six homers across his first two collegiate seasons, PERSON added some loft to his stroke and finally tapped into his raw power in 2017 to finish with 41 extra-base hits, including a team-high 15 home runs. An above-average runner, he moves well once underway but doesn't figure to be a stolen-base threat. Defensively, PERSON has looked comfortable at second base after previously struggling as a shortstop. He profiles as a passable defender there, one who can also play the outfield corners as well as first base. However, any future moves down the defensive spectrum will come with increased offensive demands.

Showing no ill effects from 2012 PERSON surgery, PERSON joined fellow lefty PERSON to form two-thirds of GPE State's very effective weekend rotation in 2014.PERSON uses deception and pitchability to allow his average stuff to play up. His fastball will top out in the low 90s, but it has a good amount of sink and tail to it. He'll add and subtract from his curveball to give hitters different looks, and his changeup often features good sink. He attacks hitters well, though he can get into trouble when he doesn't keep his stuff down in the zone.PERSON may not wow scouts with plus stuff, but guys who perform well, especially in a conference like the PAC-12, tend to do well on GPE day.

The third player taken from GPE in the 2011 Draft, the D-backs are very excited about what PERSON might become one day. Much of it is projection at this point, though he finished among the league leaders in a host of offensive categories in the ORGANIZATION in 2012. Thereâs definite power in his left-handed swing and heâll tap into it even more as he becomes a better all-around hitter. His solid arm allowed him to throw out 52 percent of would-be basestealers in 2012, though the rest of his receiving skills have a ways to go. If that comes together, he has the chance to be an exciting all-around backstop.

Signed out of the ORGANIZATION as a shortstop for $170,000 in 2013, PERSON moved to the mound after hitting .198/.312/.256 in his pro debut. He has made rapid progress since posting a 6.42 ERA in his GPE debut in 2015, passing several more hyped Dodgers pitching prospects to make his big league debut last June. After beating the ORGANIZATION while getting knocked around in relief, he went on the disabled list with a strained rotator cuff and missed the rest of 2018.PERSON has plenty of velocity on his fastball, working at 93-95 mph and reaching 98, though it's even more notable for nasty sink that keeps it off barrels and creates a lot of groundouts. His hard slider can be a wipeout pitch at times and keeps right-handers at bay, though it's not as consistent as his fastball and sometimes looks more like a curveball. He has made progress with developing his changeup and had more success against left-handers last year than in the past.PERSON sometimes struggles to command his pitches because he has so much life on his fastball and utilizes a crossfire delivery. He does throw enough strikes for GPE and most scouts to project him as a starter, with one organization rating him as the system's best prospect at the outset of 2019. If he winds up in the bullpen, he has the stuff to serve as a setup man or perhaps even a closer.

PERSON led GPE's top league with a 2.06 ERA as an 18-year-old during the 2014-15 season before defecting in May 2015. The ORGANIZATION originally signed him for a $5.15 million bonus in September 2016, voided the deal when a physical led to concerns about his elbow, then re-signed him for $2 million (plus a matching amount in penalty tax) that December. He expressed frustration with the process afterward and has stayed healthy since while making it to PERSON ahead of schedule this July.His fastball parked around 90 mph in GPE, but PERSON now sits at 93-95 mph and peaks at 98 with sink that generates ground balls. His slider has gotten harder and tighter, working in the low 80s, and his changeup has improved as well. He has three pitches that grade as at least solid as well as a slow curveball that isn't as reliable.PERSON has lived up to his reputation for advanced pitchability. He's not physical but has a quick arm and little effort in his delivery, which he repeats well. While he began his big league career in the bullpen and the elbow issue and his diminutive build raise questions about his durability as a starter, his efficiency helps his cause.

PERSON grew up in GPE Jersey but wasn't drawing much exposure as a high school infielder/pitcher, so he decided to move to the ORGANIZATION before what would have been his senior season. His arm strength took off once he returned to his parents' homeland, making him a coveted international free agent who landed a $950,000 bonus in December 2012.PERSON since has emerged as the preeminent power arm in the ORGANIZATION system. He has two legitimate swing-and-miss pitches in a 93-95 mph fastball that can reach triple digits and an upper-70s curveball that combines power and depth. He has an easy delivery that bodes well for his long-term health.Still somewhat raw on the mound, PERSON has yet to show much consistency with his changeup, control and command. He has a sturdy frame that carries more than his listed 185 pounds, and he'll have to watch his conditioning.

The first of two consecutive high school arms the ORGANIZATION took in the first round, PERSON has followed a developmental path most teams hope a prep pitcher will follow. The GPE native went to full-season ball in his first full professional year and pitched well there under a fairly tight pitch count and innings limit. In year two, the gloves came off and the right-hander earned a midseason promotion to Double-A while also pitching well in the ORGANIZATION Game.Much of PERSON' success has come as a result of his plus fastball. It will sit in the low 90s and will consistently touch the mid-90s with the pitch, thrown with good life down in the zone and improved overall command, allowing him to miss bats. His secondary stuff still needs refinement, and he struggled at times with it after moving up to Double-A, but he can spin a very good curve, has added a slider and has continued to work on developing his changeup.Continued work on his offspeed stuff will help PERSON continue to climb the ORGANIZATION' ladder, but everything is pointing in the right direction. He looks like a future big league starter, and if his non-fastball offerings improve greatly at age 21 in 2018, he could develop into more of a frontline guy.

ORGANIZATION Premier Event: Jan. 28, 2017 - PERSON, Fla.Favorite MLB Team: PERSON ORGANIZATION is a Miami commit who has earned a 2015 ORGANIZATION and a 2016 ORGANIZATION honor. He was invited to the 2016 ORGANIZATION where he had a successful showing that earned him a top 500 national rank. PERSON has a large, strong build. At the plate, he starts the bat with a medium draw and has an open stance, but he boasts fair power. He has a three-quarter arm slot and a compact arm on the mound. His fastball sits in the mid-to-high 80s and he has a 73-mph curveball that needs to be tightened.

The PERSON brothers pitched PERSON (Tallahassee) to the GPE state 3-A championship in 2014, with PERSON spinning a shutout in the semifinals and PERSON pitching four scoreless innings to win the finale. PERSON signed for $1.1 million as a fourth-round pick that June, while PERSON would have gone in about the same area of the 2015 PERSON had he not been strongly committed to PERSON's stuff has backed up a bit, but he's still a projectable left-hander with the potential for three average pitches. His fastball ranged from 90-95 mph when he was in high school but now sits more at 88-91, though he throws it for strikes with armside run. He also has a downer curveball and a fading changeup, and any of his three offerings can be his best on a given night.Like most young pitchers, PERSON needs to add strength and gain more consistency with his secondary pitches and command. If he can do that, he can become a mid-rotation starter.

Former-2020 prospect reclassfied into the 2019 class in mid-March after trasnferring to a GPE, ORGANIZATION high school. Big bat speed, raw power and foot speed, with scouts hanging 60 on four tools regularly. That said, scouts haven't been able to get many looks this spring, it was against poor competition and he wasn't focused on in his summer events. The tools are comparable to Rays ORGANIZATION, a former 1st rounder.

GPE (GPE) features the best hitting prospect/pitching prospect duo in high school baseball. PERSON may have hit his way into the first round, while PERSON could go that early as well. He kicked off the summer showcase circuit last June with a strong two-inning outing as the first pitcher to take the mound at the ORGANIZATION, and he hasn't let up since.PERSON can work in the low 90s with heavy sink on his two-seam fastball and hit 96 mph with his four-seamer. He has advanced feel for a breaking ball, showing the ability to morph his sharp slider into a bigger-breaking curveball or a harder cutter. He also has a deceptive changeup with tumble that lacks consistency but also can be his best pitch at times.At 6-foot-5 and 220 pounds, PERSON has a frame built for durability and also the room to add some more strength. He's athletic and repeats his delivery well, allowing him to throw strikes. He's a tough competitor who can get overly animated on the mound, but the only real knock against him is that he may difficult to sign away from GPE.
PERSON stood out last year while playing second base for PERSON but has really taken to shortstop this year as expected, with a scorching hot second half of the year, offensively and defensively.

GPE and shoulder injuries limited PERSON to 16 at-bats in his first year at ORGANIZATION, but he returned with a vengeance in 2014. He took home Most Outstanding Player honors at the ORGANIZATION World Series as the ORGANIZATION won their first-ever championship, then became the top position prospect in the college class after a strong summer with the GPE collegiate national team. He's maintained that status this spring by proving he can handle shortstop after moving from second base to replace ORGANIZATION ninth-round pick PERSON. Most scouts believe he has the quickness and arm strength to stay at the position long-term, even though he hadn't played there since he was a GPE high schooler in 2012, when the ORGANIZATION drafted him in the 38th round. PERSON is a technically sound hitter who fits at the top of his lineup with his on-base ability and speed. While he's not a big home run threat, he can drive the ball into the gaps. His makeup is off the charts and universally praised by coaches and scouts.

Signed for $350,000 as an 11th-rounder out of GPE (GPE) JC in 2011, PERSON led the low Class A GPE ORGANIZATION with a 2.25 ERA when he made his full-season debut two years later. He blew out his elbow and missed 2014 following PERSON surgery, then returned last year to claim a spot on the 40-man roster with his live arm.PERSON throws harder than any pitcher in the ORGANIZATION' system, with his lively fastball sitting at 97-99 mph and repeatedly climbing into triple digits when he worked as a reliever in the ORGANIZATION during the offseason. His mid-80s slider also can be a weapon with bite when he stays on top of it. PERSON's changeup isn't nearly as effective because he throws it too hard and doesn't command it well.PERSON has had trouble repeating his mechanics, as his release point wanders and he doesn't always take a direct line to the plate. He had little track record of throwing strikes, but he's doing a better job in 2016 and enhancing his chances of remaining a starter. If PERSON shifts to the bullpen, he could ascend to GPE in a hurry.

Pitching in GPE and the LOCATION Conference isn't an easy task, but PERSON has been doing it as a starter for three years. The tall right-hander was a first-team all-WAC performer as a sophomore, then used a strong performance in the ORGANIZATION to springboard to an even better junior year to put him firmly on the GPE radar.There's a lot to like with this GPE native's size and stuff. The 6-foot-4 righty has a fastball-curve combination that's attractive to many teams. He'll sit 92-94 mph with his fastball, and can touch 96 mph at times. He has a big 12-to-6 curve, thrown in the 76-80 mph range, that he uses effectively as his out pitch, and he mixes in a changeup. A big x-factor for ORGANIZATION might be his cutter-like slider, thrown in the upper-80s, that could develop into a much better pitch in the future. All of it comes from a catapult-like delivery with a lot of moving pieces. The positive of that is deception; the negative is spotty command, which gets away from him when he tries to go up and down in the zone or gets off to the side in his delivery.There's a split camp among scouts about PERSON's future role. With the potential for a four-pitch mix, a team taking him in the top three rounds is bound to let him head out as a starter, but knowing that his fastball-curve combination could tick up in shorter relief stints provides a nice backup plan.

For much of his amateur career, PERSON intrigued with his plus arm strength, but had trouble always finding the strike zone. He made great strides in that regard during his junior year at ORGANIZATION, pitching himself into the first round and that continued for the most part during his first full season. He took his power repertoire to the ORGANIZATION organization when the ORGANIZATION sent him to ORGANIZATION for PERSON during the offseason. With his tall, slender frame, PERSON will run into delivery issues, and while that can lead to command problems, he threw strikes more often than not while pitching at two levels. His fastball has a ton of sink and generates groundballs aplenty and he complements it with a big slider that gets swings and misses. His sinking changeup has the chance to be more than usable. All that, if he can maintain his delivery and stay in the strike zone, adds up to the kind of frontline starter the ORGANIZATION haven't developed in quite some time.Bernie PERSON's scouting report Â»

The ORGANIZATION used two of their first three selections in the 2014 Draft on college players who had a chance to catch and bats that still would make them valuable if they can't: first-rounder PERSON and third-rounder PERSON. PERSON attracted most of the headlines and has a higher offensive ceiling. PERSON had a greater likelihood of staying behind the plate but wasn't fully committed to doing so, so he became a full-time outfielder in his first full year as a pro.PERSON already has the best plate discipline in the system, rarely gives away at-bats and walked as much as he struck out in his debut. He strokes line drives from gap to gap and should record high batting averages and on-base percentages while providing 10-15 homers per season. He has solid speed to go with basestealing aptitude.PERSON has the quickness, agility and enough pure arm strength to make it work as a backstop, but was raw as a receiver and had little success throwing out basestealers. He has the athleticism to play on the outfield corners, though moving there places more demands on his bat and could leave him buried at a position where GPE looks loaded.

GPE is often a virtue, and that's certainly been the case with PERSON and the ORGANIZATION. The GPE Island-based high schooler was taken in the second round of the 2009 Draft but didn't throw a competitive pitch until 2012 following PERSON surgery and several subsequent issues. He brokeout in 2014 and kept it going in 2015, making his big league debut before a lat tear shut him down for a spell.PERSON is lean, lanky and loose, firing mid-90s fastballs with ease and having the ability to reach back for more when he needs it. He throws it with sink, not only missing bats, but also generating groundball outs. His changeup is his best secondary offering, which he turns over and sinks very well. His curveball has gotten better, a big breaking ball he can keep down in the zone and is now a Major League average pitch. He doesn't hurt himself with walks, and his overall command has improved over time. PERSON is looking more and more like a frontline starter, one who's ready to be a full-time part of the ORGANIZATION stable of young starters.

PERSON spent 2018 at ORGANIZATION before he was effectively showcased in the ORGANIZATION. He has bat-missing, big league stuff, sitting 92-95 and touching 96 in multi-inning ORGANIZATION appearances, and sitting comfortably in the 95-96 range when he was asked to air it out for a single inning. PERSON also has elite breaking ball spin rates. His 12-6 curveball spins in excess of 3,000 rpm and his firm, upper-80s slider/cutter often approaches that mark, which is rare for a breaking ball that hard. He also has a unique delivery that disorients hitters, during which his arm wraps behind his lower back. His arm action is ugly but, short of a 7-day DL stint this year after he was hit with a comebacker, PERSON hasnât been hurt as a pro. 
His usage has been atypical, however. His starts were often spaced out by seven or eight days in 2018, and itâs unrealistic to expect him to have that kind of recovery time between turns on a big league pitching staff. If asked to throw every fifth day, his stuff may not be as nasty as it was this year. He projects as a No. 4 or 5 starter but may also be deployed in a multi-inning relief role.

Acquired from PERSON as part of the return for PERSON, PERSON has advanced command of a four-pitch mix that enabled him to reach Double-A at age 19. He'll likely have a plus fastball and changeup at peak while his breaking balls are still works in progress. So too is PERSON's ability to handle a full-season workload. He's had some knee trouble and PERSON spaced out his starts pretty liberally late last year as a way to limit his inning. His 86 innings last year were a career high, so while PERSON is advanced from a stuff and pitchability standpoint, he likely won't reach PERSON and stay there until he's capable of handling more innings. He projects as an above-average big league starter with a bit more developmental distance to travel than you might think given his level.

PERSON (along with PERSON) came back from GPE in the 2015 PERSON trade. He's always been on the starter/reliever bubble, in large part because his fastball doesn't play quite as well as its pure velocity would seem to indicate and because the lack of a truly average changeup forces PERSON to use his fastball very heavily. His stuff backed up just a tad last year. He should still be a no. 5 starter or middle reliever if it doesn't any more.

Another in the long line of ORGANIZATION of GPE hitters with micro strikeout rates, PERSON'd just seven times during his entire junior season. He's carried that contact ability into pro ball, where he struck out just 8.5% of the time at Low-A in his first full season before moving on to Hi- and Double-A late in the year. 
We're skeptical of his ability to play shortstop due to below-average hands and actions, and think he probably fits best in center field due to his speed, but PERSON played him exclusively at short last year. The lack of power likely means he maxes out as a utility man, so it makes sense to hand Clement a ton of reps at shortstop to see if he can improve, since ideally he'd be able to play there on occasion. He spent a lot of time with the big league club during 2019 spring training and made characteristically high rates of contact. The bat and his speed should carry him to some kind of lesser major league role, with his defensive development determining if it's a super utility one or a limited runner/bench bat gig.
A potential plus defender at short, PERSON had strong numbers in a hitter-friendly college environment at ORGANIZATION. He's very patient, almost excessively so.
PERSON had injury issues and moved back and forth from the rotation to the bullpen in college. In the 'pen, sits upper-90s with life and angle. Breaking stuff has nasty, vertical action.

Signed in July 2012 out of the ORGANIZATION, PERSON spent his first three pro seasons in GPE ball before finally advancing to a full-season level for the first time in 2016. He scuffled a bit the following year, receiving a mid-season demotion from the Class A Advanced California League back to Class A PERSON, but rebounded with a breakout 2018 campaign in which he established career highs in most offensive categories. PERSON continued to perform well in the ORGANIZATION, and the A's added him to the 40-man roster after the season.PERSON makes a lot of contact from the left side of the plate, where he employs an open setup with a flat swing that enables him to spray the ball across the whole field. While it does limit his power potential, PERSON has a knack for finding the gaps and uses his plus speed to take extra bases when possible. That speed also makes PERSON a capable center fielder, and he has the requisite arm strength needed to play right field.With his left-handed bat, speed and defensive versatility, PERSON has the makings of becoming a future bench outfielder at the highest level. If he can make further strides as a hitter, and possibly add some power to his game, he could take on a greater role.

GPE of the ORGANIZATION (GPE, Ala.) program that produced a pair of big leaguers in the ORGANIZATION brothers, PERSON turned down the ORGANIZATION as a 39th-round pick in 2013 to attend PERSON. He improved dramatically from season to season in college, and he snuck into PERSON A as the D-backs saw an up-the-middle player with a track record of performance in a Draft that was light on that demographic.PERSON ranked among the LOCATION batting leaders in his junior season, but some worry his hitting ability won't translate as well against pro pitching. His right-handed swing can get long, giving him trouble against quality fastballs in on his hands and against breaking pitches. He does have good bat speed and drove the ball more consistently this past college season, showing double-digit home run potential for the next level after going deep just once in each of his first two years at PERSON.PERSON's best tool is his plus speed, which he uses well in center field and is learning to incorporate on the bases. He showed a much better feel for stealing bags this spring, and while he has fringy arm strength, he makes accurate throws.

Though he first became eligible to sign at age 16, PERSON didn't land a pro contract until he was nearly 21, turning pro for $50,000 out of the ORGANIZATION in February 2015. Raw on the mound despite his advanced age, he has yet to work 100 innings in a season and spent 2018 in high Class A as a 24-year-old. He impressed as a reliever in the ORGANIZATION after the season, so the ORGANIZATION decided to expedite him in that role.PERSON has an electric fastball with running life that parks at 95-98 mph and has reached 102 mph in shorter stints. In the ORGANIZATION, he worked on a two-seamer that sat in the mid-90s with some sink. His upper-80s slider is more notable for its velocity than its sharpness, while his changeup is often too firm to be effective.San PERSON had deployed PERSON as a starter because he needed innings to transition from thrower to pitcher, but scouts long have projected him to wind up in the bullpen. He looks more comfortable as a reliever with a simplified approach, doing a better job of keeping his delivery in sync and finding the strike zone. He could develop into a set-up man and perhaps even more if he can add significant polish.

ORGANIZATION, a ORGANIZATION commit, played well on the showcase circuit last summer and was the winning pitcher in the championship game of the ORGANIZATION World Championship in October. But it was his performance this spring in the ORGANIZATION high school ranks that sent him shooting up ORGANIZATION boards.ORGANIZATION has a powerful right arm and has touched 98 mph with his fastball this spring. He more typically works in the low to mid 90s but has room for additional strength gains in his lean frame. He has a pair of quality breaking balls, and his changeup has made strides to round out his full arsenal.Despite there being some effort in his delivery, ORGANIZATION generally works around the strike zone with all his pitches. He has a loose arm and good athleticism, which should help him clean up his delivery and pitch with better command as he gets more experience.

PERSON lost most of 2015 and 2016 at ORGANIZATION after a line drive to the head left him with severe concussion symptoms, then bounced back to become the second pitcher in school history with a 100-strikeout season as a redshirt senior in 2018. The ORGANIZATION offered him a $5,000 bonus as a 32nd-round pick and he has made the most of that opportunity. He began this year in extended spring training but earned a promotion from low Class A reliever to high Class A starter in GPE, and he didn't permit an earned run in his first four starts afterward.PERSON's success hinges on a sinker that rivals PERSON's as the best in the system. He has sat at 92-93 mph and touched 95 with his two-seamer as a starter, and Class A hitters have struggled to lift it in the air. He throws his curveball and slider in the low 80s, and they're reliably average offerings when they don't blend together.He has some feel for a changeup as well, enhancing PERSON's chances of remaining a starter and becoming a back-of-the-rotation option. To do so, he'll have to upgrade his control and command. He lacks a wipeout offering but his sinker gives him a chance to join PERSON as the only ORGANIZATION products to reach the Majors.

PERSON might have gone in the first two rounds of the 2017 ORGANIZATION had he been signable away from a ORGANIZATION commitment, and he should go in the same area this June as the best sophomore-eligible prospect at a four-year college. He's the fastest premium prospect in the college ranks and has the tools and upside to become the first Seahawk ever selected in the first round. He creates havoc when he gets on base and is doing a better job of doing so in 2019, making more consistent contact while posting one of the higher walk rates in ORGANIZATION Division I. A switch-hitter with some bat speed and strength, he shows average raw power from both sides of the plate during batting practice but has yet to translate it into home run production.Though PERSON has solid arm strength to go with his blazing speed, there's skepticism about his ability to remain at shortstop. He doesn't react as quickly as expected at short and doesn't throw well from different angles. Many scouts project him to wind up in center field, where his tools would fit well.

Viewed as a low-ceiling pitchability arm in college, PERSON reached Double-A just one calendar year after he was drafted by PERSON, which traded him to GPE in the ORGANIZATION deal the following winter. Last year he experienced an uptick in velocity and his four-seamer now sits in the low-90s and touches 94. It helped PERSON miss more bats, and he struck out a batter per inning at ORGANIZATION. Realistically, PERSON will pitch at the back of a rotation as a No. 4 or 5 starter because nothing he throws is plus and it's hard to envision him striking out many major league hitters. But if the velo bump last year was just the start of a trend that continues into the future, there might be a bit more here.

There are some red flags here, chief among them PERSON's reckless and epicurean approach at the plate. But he's remarkably talented, posessing elite bat control and an ability to lift the ball in the air with great regularity. PERSON is also a plus runner with a chance to be a plus defensive center fielder with a plus arm, so his bat has some room for regression after a breakout 2017. His scouting report reads much like PERSON' has for the last several years with a tick better tools across the board.

The ORGANIZATION got the power lefty from the ORGANIZATION at the 2012 trade deadline for PERSON and they should be able to reap the benefits soon. PERSON has struck out close to 12 per nine innings over the course of his ORGANIZATION career, using a power two-pitch combination to go right after hitters and miss a lot of bats. His fastball can be plus, up to 95 mph with late life and sink. His hard slider gives him a second plus offering, a breaking ball with late bite that heâs not afraid to throw at any point. As his 56 saves attest, PERSON has been used to close games and assuming he can maintain his average command, thereâs no reason to think he canât serve the same role in the big leagues.

PERSON has one of this class' most impressive physiques and some of its best present raw power. He projects to a corner outfield spot. Scouts have questions about PERSON' bat, citing swing length and feel for contact.
Massive 6'8 righty has huge sink in the low-90's and a sharp breaker, posted insane groundball numbers during his junior spring.

The ORGANIZATION teenager had a very successful GPE debut in 2012, pitching well in the rookie-level ORGANIZATION and earning a late promotion to finish the year in the ORGANIZATION. Heâs not the biggest guy in the world, but he has the makings of a good three-pitch mix that allowed him to strike out a batter per inning during his stateside debut. Since the ORGANIZATION took PERSON with the ORGANIZATION. 31 overall pick in the 2014 Draft, he's lived up to the "have left arm, will travel" axiom. PERSON improved his ORGANIZATION stock in 2016 as an GPE junior by hitting .360/.465/.646 with a career-best 10 home runs before the ORGANIZATION made him their second-round pick. After he continued to swing the bat well early in his first full season, the A's landed PERSON, left-hander PERSON and reliever PERSON in the July deal that sent PERSON and PERSON to ORGANIZATION posted a .380 average in 40 games while reaching Double-A after joining the A's system, and then he continued to elevate his stock in the ORGANIZATION, where he finished in the top three in the circuit in GPE, doubles, extra-base hits, runs scored, total bases, slugging and home runs. PERSON's right-handed swing is short and simple, but he also keeps his barrel in the hitting zone for an extended period of time and drives the ball across the whole field. He has above-average raw power and already knows how to get to it in games, a notion supported by his 16 home runs and 26 doubles across three levels in 2017. Some scouts still question how it will translate at higher levels because his game does have some swing-and-miss tendencies, albeit with sound overall plate discipline.PERSON is a fringe-average runner who shows good instincts on the bases and in the field. A shortstop in college, PERSON saw time there as well as third base prior to being dealt, but he handled the hot corner exclusively after joining the A's. He profiles as an average defender there, with soft hands, good range and a plus arm that produced 94 mph off the mound in college. Regardless of his position, PERSON has the hitting ability to profile as a big league regular.

Signed for just south of $700,000 out of GPE, PERSON was a polished amateur arm who has been as advertised in two years of pro ball. He has good command of mostly average stuff as a 19-year-old, so there's a chance he either grows into better stuff through physical maturation, or develops such special command that he doesn't have to. After signing for $1.3 million as a fourth-round pick in 2012, PERSON developed more slowly than expected. He didn't reach full-season ball until 2014 and struggled when he got there, posting a 6.85 ERA in 11 starts in low Class A. This year he has looked more like the pitcher the ORGANIZATION thought they were signing, earning a promotion to high Class A after a month.PERSON has reclaimed the fastball velocity he displayed in high school, working at 92-93 mph and topping out at 96 repeatedly this year. His heater can be very tough to hit when he uses his 6-foot-6 frame to drive it down in the strike zone. His hard knuckle-curve can generate swings-and-misses as well.Though PERSON still has work to do with his changeup, it shows signs of becoming a usable third option. He's doing a better job of throwing strikes this year, which bodes well for his chances of remaining a starter at higher levels.
